Units and Dimensions.front: What is a physical quantity?
Units and Dimensions.back: A physical quantity is a property of a physical system that can be measured and expressed as a number and a unit (e.g., length, mass, time).

Units and Dimensions.front: Name the seven SI base quantities and their SI units (symbol).
Units and Dimensions.back:
Length — metre (m) 
Mass — kilogram (kg) 
Time — second (s) 
Electric current — ampere (A) 
Thermodynamic temperature — kelvin (K) 
Amount of substance — mole (mol) 
Luminous intensity — candela (cd)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is a derived unit? Give examples.
Units and Dimensions.back:
A derived unit is formed from base units by multiplication/division. Examples:
Newton (N) = kg·m·s⁻² (force)
Joule (J) = kg·m²·s⁻² (energy)
Pascal (Pa) = kg·m⁻¹·s⁻² (pressure)
Watt (W) = kg·m²·s⁻³ (power)

Units and Dimensions.front: How do we denote the dimension of a physical quantity?
Units and Dimensions.back: Dimension of a quantity X is written as [X]. Example: [velocity] = L·T⁻¹.

Units and Dimensions.front: Base dimension symbols commonly used in dimensional formulae.
Units and Dimensions.back:
Length = L
Mass = M
Time = T
Electric current = I
Thermodynamic temperature = Θ
Amount of substance = N
Luminous intensity = J

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of area?
Units and Dimensions.back: Area = length × length → [Area] = L²

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of volume?
Units and Dimensions.back: Volume = length³ → [Volume] = L³

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of velocity and speed?
Units and Dimensions.back: Velocity (v) = displacement / time → [v] = L·T⁻¹

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of acceleration?
Units and Dimensions.back: Acceleration (a) = velocity / time → [a] = L·T⁻²

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of force (Newton's second law)?
Units and Dimensions.back: Force (F) = mass × acceleration → [F] = M·L·T⁻² (unit: N = kg·m·s⁻²)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of momentum?
Units and Dimensions.back: Momentum (p) = mass × velocity → [p] = M·L·T⁻¹

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of work and energy?
Units and Dimensions.back: Work / Energy (W) = force × distance → [W] = M·L²·T⁻² (unit: J = kg·m²·s⁻²)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of power?
Units and Dimensions.back: Power (P) = energy / time → [P] = M·L²·T⁻³ (unit: W = kg·m²·s⁻³)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of pressure?
Units and Dimensions.back: Pressure (P) = force / area → [P] = M·L⁻¹·T⁻² (unit: Pa = N·m⁻² = kg·m⁻¹·s⁻²)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of density?
Units and Dimensions.back: Density (ρ) = mass / volume → [ρ] = M·L⁻³ (unit: kg·m⁻³)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of surface tension?
Units and Dimensions.back: Surface tension (σ) = force / length → [σ] = M·T⁻² (unit: N·m⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of dynamic viscosity (η)?
Units and Dimensions.back: Dynamic viscosity η = force·time / area → [η] = M·L⁻¹·T⁻¹ (unit: Pa·s)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of kinematic viscosity (ν)?
Units and Dimensions.back: Kinematic viscosity ν = dynamic viscosity / density → [ν] = L²·T⁻¹ (unit: m²·s⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of moment of inertia?
Units and Dimensions.back: Moment of inertia (I) ≈ mass × (length)² → [I] = M·L²

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of torque?
Units and Dimensions.back: Torque (τ) = force × distance → [τ] = M·L²·T⁻² (same dimensions as energy)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of angular momentum?
Units and Dimensions.back: Angular momentum (L) = moment of momentum → [L] = M·L²·T⁻¹

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of frequency and angular frequency?
Units and Dimensions.back:
Frequency (f) = 1 / time → [f] = T⁻¹
Angular frequency (ω) → [ω] = T⁻¹

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of electric charge (Q).
Units and Dimensions.back: Charge Q = current × time → [Q] = I·T (unit: C = A·s)

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of electric potential (V).
Units and Dimensions.back: Potential V = energy / charge → [V] = M·L²·T⁻³·I⁻¹ (unit: V = J·C⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of electric field (E) (force per unit charge).
Units and Dimensions.back: E = force / charge → [E] = M·L·T⁻³·I⁻¹

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of the spring constant (k).
Units and Dimensions.back: Hooke's law: F = k·x → k = F / x → [k] = M·T⁻² (unit: N·m⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of gravitational constant (G).
Units and Dimensions.back: From Newton's law: F = G·m1·m2 / r² → [G] = M⁻¹·L³·T⁻²

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of Planck's constant (h).
Units and Dimensions.back: h (action) has dimensions of energy × time → [h] = M·L²·T⁻¹ (unit: J·s)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the principle of homogeneity of dimensions?
Units and Dimensions.back: All terms in a physically meaningful equation must have the same dimensions. You can only add/subtract quantities with identical dimensions.

Units and Dimensions.front: How is dimensional analysis used to check a formula?
Units and Dimensions.back: Replace each quantity by its dimensional symbol and verify both sides have identical dimension expressions. If not identical, the formula is wrong.

Units and Dimensions.front: Derive the form of the period T of a simple pendulum by dimensional reasoning (T depends on length l and g).
Units and Dimensions.back: Assume T ∝ lᵃ·gᵇ. Dimensions: [T] = (L)ᵃ·(L·T⁻²)ᵇ = L^{a+b}·T^{-2b}. Equate powers: for T: 1 = −2b → b = −1/2. For L: 0 = a + b → a = 1/2. So T ∝ √(l/g). Full formula: T = 2π·√(l/g).

Units and Dimensions.front: What are dimensionless (pure) quantities? Give examples.
Units and Dimensions.back: Quantities with no dimension (all base exponents zero). Examples: refractive index, strain (ΔL/L), coefficients (friction, drag), angles (radians), Reynolds number, Mach number, π and e.

Units and Dimensions.front: Give common SI prefixes and their factors (kilo, centi, milli, micro, nano).
Units and Dimensions.back:
kilo (k) = 10³
centi (c) = 10⁻²
milli (m) = 10⁻³
micro (μ) = 10⁻⁶
nano (n) = 10⁻⁹

Units and Dimensions.front: Convert: 1 N in base SI units and 1 J in base SI units.
Units and Dimensions.back:
1 N (Newton) = 1 kg·m·s⁻²
1 J (Joule) = 1 N·m = 1 kg·m²·s⁻²

Units and Dimensions.front: Limitations of dimensional analysis — what it cannot tell you?
Units and Dimensions.back: It cannot give dimensionless constants (e.g., numeric factors like 2π), it cannot distinguish between quantities with same dimensions but different physics (e.g., torque and energy), and it cannot give exact functional dependence when more than one dimensionless variable exists.

Units and Dimensions.front: How to check if two expressions are dimensionally the same? (Example test)
Units and Dimensions.back: Find dimensional formula for each expression and compare exponents of base symbols. Example: Is [g² / l] same as [ω]? [g² / l] → (L·T⁻²)² / L = L·T⁻⁴. [ω] → T⁻¹. Not same (dimensions differ).

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of Reynolds number Re (general idea).
Units and Dimensions.back: Re = (ρ·v·L) / η → Reynolds number is dimensionless because ρ (M·L⁻³), v (L·T⁻¹), L (L), η (M·L⁻¹·T⁻¹) ⇒ overall dimension cancels to 1.

Units and Dimensions.front: Why mathematical constants like π and e are dimensionless?
Units and Dimensions.back: They are pure numbers arising from geometry/analysis; adding them does not change dimensions. Any argument of transcendental functions (sin, exp, ln) must be dimensionless.

Units and Dimensions.front: Example: Show that velocity of waves on a string v = √(T/μ) is dimensionally consistent (T is tension, μ is linear mass density).
Units and Dimensions.back: Tension T dimension = force = M·L·T⁻². μ (linear mass density) = M·L⁻¹. So T/μ → (M·L·T⁻²) / (M·L⁻¹) = L²·T⁻² ⇒ √(T/μ) has dimension L·T⁻¹ = velocity.

Units and Dimensions.front: Give dimensional formula of specific heat capacity (c).
Units and Dimensions.back: Specific heat c = energy / (mass·temperature) → [c] = (M·L²·T⁻²) / (M·Θ) = L²·T⁻²·Θ⁻¹

Units and Dimensions.front: What is meant by coherent units (SI coherent units)?
Units and Dimensions.back: Coherent units are derived units formed from base units without additional numerical factors. Example: N = kg·m·s⁻² is coherent in SI.

Units and Dimensions.front: How to express 1 Pascal (Pa) in base SI units and physical meaning?
Units and Dimensions.back: 1 Pa = 1 N·m⁻² = 1 kg·m⁻¹·s⁻². It represents pressure equal to one newton of force applied uniformly over an area of one square metre.

Units and Dimensions.front: Dimensional formula of diffusion coefficient D (from Fick's law).
Units and Dimensions.back: Diffusion coefficient D has dimensions of area / time → [D] = L²·T⁻¹ (unit: m²·s⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: How does dimensional analysis help in experiments and modelling?
Units and Dimensions.back: It reduces variables using dimensionless groups (similarity parameters), helps design experiments (scale models), checks formulas for correctness and guides form of empirical relations.

Units and Dimensions.front: Example: Show dimensional formula of heat flux (energy per unit area per unit time).
Units and Dimensions.back: Heat flux q = power / area → [q] = (M·L²·T⁻³) / L² = M·T⁻³ (unit: W·m⁻²; base dims → kg·s⁻³)

Units and Dimensions.front: What is the dimensional formula of impedance (electrical) approximately? (General idea)
Units and Dimensions.back: Electrical impedance Z has same dimension as resistance: voltage / current → [Z] = (M·L²·T⁻³·I⁻¹) / I = M·L²·T⁻³·I⁻² (unit: Ω = V·A⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: Quick unit conversion examples commonly asked in exams.
What is the dimensional formula of thermal conductivity (k) in Fourier's law (q = −k·∇T)?
Units and Dimensions.back: Heat flux q (M·T⁻³) = k · (temperature gradient Θ·L⁻¹) → [k] = (M·T⁻³) / (Θ·L⁻¹) = M·L·T⁻³·Θ⁻¹ (unit: W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹)

Units and Dimensions.front: How to handle constants with dimensions in equations (example: gravitational constant)?
Units and Dimensions.back: If a constant carries dimensions (e.g., G), include its dimensional formula in analysis. Dimensional analysis cannot determine numeric value of such constants, only how other variables combine with G to give required dimensions.

Units and Dimensions.front: Checklist: steps to perform dimensional analysis on an equation.
Units and Dimensions.back:
1) Replace each quantity with its dimensional symbol (powers of M, L, T, I, Θ, N, J).
2) Simplify both sides.
3) Compare exponents of each base symbol. If all match, equation is dimensionally consistent.

Units and Dimensions.front: Sample exam-style check: Are the expressions "energy = mass × velocity" and "energy = mass × (velocity)²" dimensionally correct?
Units and Dimensions.back: Energy dims = M·L²·T⁻². mass × velocity dims = M·(L·T⁻¹) = M·L·T⁻¹ → Not correct. mass × velocity² dims = M·(L²·T⁻²) = M·L²·T⁻² → Correct.

Units and Dimensions.front: Why is dimensional homogeneity necessary but not sufficient for physical correctness?
Units and Dimensions.back: Dimensional homogeneity is necessary (all terms must share dimensions) but not sufficient because different physics laws can share the same dimensions and numeric/functional factors matter.

Units and Dimensions.front: Provide a compact list of frequently used dimensional formulas (cheat-sheet).
Units and Dimensions.back:
Area = L²
Volume = L³
Velocity = L·T⁻¹
Acceleration = L·T⁻²
Force = M·L·T⁻²
Energy = M·L²·T⁻²
Power = M·L²·T⁻³
Pressure = M·L⁻¹·T⁻²
Density = M·L⁻³
Viscosity = M·L⁻¹·T⁻¹
Surface tension = M·T⁻²
Angular momentum = M·L²·T⁻¹
Gravitational constant G = M⁻¹·L³·T⁻²

Motion.front: What is motion?
Motion.back: Motion is the change in position of an object with respect to time as observed from a chosen reference frame.

Motion.front: Define distance and displacement.
Motion.back:
Distance: scalar; total path length traveled (always ≥ 0).
Displacement: vector; shortest straight-line from initial to final position (may be negative or zero).

Motion.front: Define speed and velocity.
Motion.back:
Speed: scalar; rate of change of distance with time (avg speed = total distance / total time).
Velocity: vector; rate of change of displacement with time (avg velocity = Δx / Δt).

Motion.front: What is instantaneous velocity and instantaneous speed?
Motion.back:
Instantaneous velocity = limit of average velocity as Δt → 0; equal to slope of x–t curve.
Instantaneous speed = magnitude of instantaneous velocity.

Motion.front: Define acceleration.
Motion.back:
Acceleration (a) = rate of change of velocity with time.
Instantaneous a = dv/dt.
Units: m·s⁻².

Motion.front: Scalar vs Vector — what should you watch for in problems?
Motion.back: Scalars have magnitude only (e.g., speed, distance); vectors have magnitude + direction (e.g., velocity, displacement). Add vectors by tip-to-tail or components.

Motion.front: List the three basic kinematic equations for constant acceleration (symbols: s, u, v, a, t).
Motion.back:
1) v = u + a·t
2) s = u·t + 1/2·a·t²
3) v² = u² + 2·a·s
(Also: average velocity v_avg = (u + v)/2 for constant a.)

Motion.front: When can you use s = ut + 1/2·a·t²? What does each symbol mean?
Motion.back:
Use when acceleration a is constant.
u = initial velocity, v = final velocity, s = displacement (in direction of motion), t = time, a = acceleration.

Motion.front: How to find displacement using velocity-time graph?
Motion.back: Displacement = area under the v-t graph (signed area: area above time axis positive, below negative).

Motion.front: How to find acceleration using velocity-time graph?
Motion.back: Acceleration = slope of v-t graph (Δv/Δt).

Motion.front: How to find velocity using position-time graph?
Motion.back: Velocity = slope of x-t (position-time) graph (instantaneous slope gives instantaneous velocity).

Motion.front: Meaning of area under acceleration-time graph?
Motion.back: Area under a-t graph = change in velocity (Δv) — because ∫a dt = Δv.

Motion.front: What is uniform (constant) velocity motion?
Motion.back: Velocity constant in magnitude and direction → acceleration = 0 → displacement s = u·t (linear relation).

Motion.front: What is uniformly accelerated motion?
Motion.back: Acceleration is constant (a constant value). Kinematic equations for constant a apply (SUVAT).

Motion.front: Explain free fall and acceleration due to gravity.
Motion.back: Free fall: motion under gravity alone (neglect air resistance). Acceleration g ≈ 9.8 m·s⁻² downward (use 9.8 or 10 as exam convention if stated).

Motion.front: Velocity-time relation for free fall (starting from rest).
Motion.back: If u = 0, then v = g·t (downward). Displacement s = 1/2·g·t² (downwards).

Motion.front: What is terminal velocity (qualitative)?
Motion.back: Terminal velocity occurs when drag force equals weight → net force = 0 → acceleration = 0. Object falls at constant speed thereafter.

Motion.front: Define relative velocity (one-dimensional).
Motion.back: Velocity of A relative to B: v_A/B = v_A − v_B (vector subtraction). For motion along same line: subtract magnitudes with sign conventions.

Motion.front: How to add velocities in two dimensions (vector addition)?
Motion.back: Resolve each velocity into components (x,y), add corresponding components, recombine: v_total = √(v_x² + v_y²), direction θ = arctan(v_y/v_x).

Motion.front: What is projectile motion? Key assumptions.
Motion.back: Motion of an object thrown with initial speed u at angle θ to horizontal. Key assumptions: neglect air resistance; horizontal and vertical motions are independent; acceleration horizontally = 0, vertically = −g.

Motion.front: Projectile motion: initial velocity components.
Motion.back: u_x = u·cosθ, u_y = u·sinθ (θ measured from horizontal).

Motion.front: Projectile: time of flight (total) for launch from and landing on same level.
Motion.back: T = 2·u·sinθ / g

Motion.front: Projectile: maximum height H.
Motion.back: H = u²·sin²θ / (2·g)

Motion.front: Projectile: horizontal range R (same level).
Motion.back: R = u²·sin(2θ) / g. Maximum range when θ = 45° (sin2θ = 1).

Motion.front: Projectile: horizontal motion equation and vertical motion equation.
Motion.back:
Horizontal: x = u·cosθ · t (no horizontal acceleration).
Vertical: y = u·sinθ · t − 1/2·g·t² (vertical acceleration −g).

Motion.front: Projectile: velocity at any instant (components & magnitude).
Motion.back:
v_x = u·cosθ (constant).
v_y = u·sinθ − g·t.
Speed v = √(v_x² + v_y²).

Motion.front: Range on an inclined plane (formula idea).
Motion.back: Range on inclined plane depends on slope angle; use component method and solve quadratic in t for intersection with plane. (Standard exam questions give formula or require derivation.)

Motion.front: What is uniform circular motion? Acceleration direction and magnitude?
Motion.back:
Speed constant, direction continuously changing → centripetal acceleration toward centre.
a_c = v² / r = ω²·r (where ω = angular speed).

Motion.front: Relate linear speed v and angular speed ω.
Motion.back: v = ω·r (r = radius). Units: ω in rad·s⁻¹.

Motion.front: Centripetal force required for circular motion.
Motion.back: F_c = m·a_c = m·v² / r = m·ω²·r (directed toward centre).

Motion.front: What is angular displacement, velocity and acceleration (basic relations)?
Motion.back:
Angular displacement θ (radians).
Angular velocity ω = dθ/dt.
Angular acceleration α = dω/dt.
Relation with linear: s = r·θ, v = r·ω, a_tangential = r·α.

Motion.front: Kinematics in rotational form (constant angular acceleration).
Motion.back: Analogous to linear equations: ω = ω₀ + α·t; θ = ω₀·t + 1/2·α·t²; ω² = ω₀² + 2·α·Δθ.

Motion.front: What is motion in two dimensions (vector projectile) — independence of motions?
Motion.back: Horizontal and vertical motions are independent (except through time). Solve using components and same time t for both directions.

Motion.front: How to solve 2D motion problems with constant acceleration — steps?
Motion.back: 1) Choose axes. 2) Resolve initial velocity into components. 3) Write separate kinematic eqns for x and y. 4) Eliminate t where needed. 5) Use boundary/initial conditions to solve.

Motion.front: Give common exam trick: maximum horizontal range occurs at which angle?
Motion.back: For level ground (no air resistance), maximum range occurs at θ = 45° when launch & landing heights equal.

Motion.front: What is instantaneous centre of rotation (qualitative)?
Motion.back: Instantaneous centre of rotation: point with zero instantaneous velocity in a rigid body undergoing planar motion. Useful for analysing velocities.

Motion.front: Describe motion under variable acceleration (general approach).
Motion.back: When a = a(t) or a = a(x), integrate: v(t) = ∫a(t) dt + C; x(t) = ∫v(t) dt + C. If a depends on x: v dv/dx = a(x) → integrate to get v² relation.

Motion.front: Example: use v dv/dx = a to derive v² relation.
Motion.back: Since a = dv/dt and v = dx/dt, a = dv/dt = (dv/dx)·(dx/dt) = v·dv/dx. So v·dv/dx = a(x) → integrate both sides: ∫v dv = ∫a(x) dx → 1/2·v² = ∫a(x) dx + C.

Motion.front: What is the slope of x–t graph and what does a curved x–t graph indicate?
Motion.back: Slope of x–t = velocity. Curved x–t graph indicates non-constant velocity (acceleration present).

Motion.front: Common unit conversions useful in motion problems.
Motion.back:
1 km·h⁻¹ = (5/18) m·s⁻¹; 1 m·s⁻¹ = 3.6 km·h⁻¹.
Use g = 9.8 m·s⁻² (or 10 m·s⁻² if exam uses g = 10).

Motion.front: What is average velocity vs average speed?
Motion.back:
Average velocity = total displacement / total time (vector).
Average speed = total distance / total time (scalar). They are equal only if motion in one direction or no backtracking.

Motion.front: How to find peak height/time to reach peak for projectile?
Motion.back:
Time to reach max height t_peak = u·sinθ / g (when vertical component v_y becomes 0).
Max height H = u_y² / (2·g) = u²·sin²θ / (2·g).

Motion.front: Collision of vertical component symmetry in projectile motion.
Motion.back: For symmetric projectile (same launch & landing height): speed at two points equidistant in time from peak have equal magnitude but opposite vertical components.

Motion.front: Quick check: v² = u² + 2as holds when?
Motion.back: Holds for constant acceleration; valid for any direction if using signed displacement s along line of motion.

Motion.front: Exam tip: sign conventions and choosing positive direction.
Motion.back: Pick a positive direction (often right/up positive). Be consistent. If acceleration is downward, use a = −g when up is positive.

Motion.front: Sample short question style (what to recall): 'A car accelerates from rest at 2 m·s⁻² for 5 s. Find v and s.'
Common pitfall: confusion between displacement s and path length.
Motion.back: Displacement is straight-line change of position; path length is total distance traveled. For round trips displacement may be zero while distance is nonzero.

Motion.front: Short formula list (cheatsheet) — motion in 1D with constant a.
Motion.back:
v = u + a·t
s = u·t + 1/2·a·t²
v² = u² + 2·a·s
avg = (u + v)/2 (if a constant)
Keep units consistent: m, s, m·s⁻¹, m·s⁻².

Motion.front: How to approach multi-part motion questions (e.g., braking then constant speed)?
Motion.back: Break into segments where acceleration is constant or known. Solve sequentially for each segment; match boundary conditions (position/time/velocity continuity).

Motion.front: Why are radians preferred in rotational motion?
Motion.back: Radians give direct relation s = r·θ (no conversion constant). Angular acceleration in rad·s⁻² combined with r gives correct linear acceleration.

Motion.front: What is uniform acceleration with initial velocity negative — sign example.
Motion.back: If u negative and acceleration positive, object may slow down then reverse direction. Use signed equations; v² = u² + 2as still valid.

Motion.front: Final exam tip: check dimensions and limiting cases.
Motion.back: Always do dimensional check and test limiting cases (e.g., set a → 0, t → 0, θ → 0 or 90°) to catch algebra errors quickly.

Work Power Energy.front: What is work (physics definition)?
Work Power Energy.back: Work is the scalar product of force and displacement in the direction of the force. Mathematically: W = F·s·cosθ, where θ is angle between force and displacement.

Work Power Energy.front: What are SI unit and dimensional formula of work?
Work Power Energy.back:
SI unit: joule (J).
1 J = 1 N·m = 1 kg·m²·s⁻².
Dimensional formula: [W] = M·L²·T⁻².

Work Power Energy.front: How is work by a constant force calculated?
Work Power Energy.back:
For constant force F acting through displacement s at angle θ: W = F·s·cosθ.
If force parallel to displacement: W = F·s; if perpendicular: W = 0.

Work Power Energy.front: Sign convention for work (positive/negative/zero)?
Work Power Energy.back:
Work positive when force has component along displacement (adds energy).
Work negative when force opposes displacement (removes energy).
Work zero when force ⟂ displacement (no work).

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by a variable force (general formula).
Work Power Energy.back: W = ∫_{x₁}^{x₂} F(x)·dx (area under F–x curve). Use integral when F depends on position.

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by gravitational force near Earth's surface.
Work Power Energy.back: For vertical displacement Δy: W_gravity = −m·g·Δy if you take upward displacement positive and work done BY gravity is −mgΔy (work done ON mass by gravity = mg·(−Δy) depending on sign conv.). Common simple formula: work by weight when object moves down Δy: W = m·g·Δy (positive if down is positive).

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by a spring force (Hooke's law).
Work Power Energy.back:
Spring force F = −k·x.
Work to move from x₁ to x₂: W = ∫_{x₁}^{x₂} (−k·x) dx = −(1/2)·k·(x₂² − x₁²).
Work done BY spring during expansion (from compressed to relaxed) is positive.

Work Power Energy.front: What is kinetic energy (KE)?
Work Power Energy.back: Kinetic energy of a particle: K = 1/2·m·v² where m is mass and v is speed. It is scalar and always ≥ 0.

Work Power Energy.front: What is potential energy (PE)?
Work Power Energy.back: Potential energy is energy associated with configuration or position in a force field. For conservative forces a potential energy function U can be defined so that F = −∇U.

Work Power Energy.front: Gravitational potential energy near Earth's surface.
Work Power Energy.back: U = m·g·h (take reference level where U = 0). For change in height Δh: ΔU = m·g·Δh.

Work Power Energy.front: Elastic (spring) potential energy.
Work Power Energy.back: For a spring with constant k stretched/compressed by x from equilibrium: U_spring = 1/2·k·x².

Work Power Energy.front: General (universal) gravitational potential energy between two masses.
Work Power Energy.back: U(r) = −G·m₁·m₂ / r (zero reference at r → ∞). Here G is gravitational constant.

Work Power Energy.front: Work–energy theorem (translation).
Work Power Energy.back: Net work done on a particle = change in its kinetic energy: W_net = ΔK = 1/2·m·(v_f² − v_i²).

Work Power Energy.front: Conservative vs non-conservative forces — definition.
Work Power Energy.back:
Conservative force: work done between two points is path independent and total work around a closed loop is zero (e.g., gravity, spring).
Non-conservative force: work depends on path; closed-loop work ≠ 0 (e.g., friction).

Work Power Energy.front: Conservation of mechanical energy (when applicable).
Work Power Energy.back: If only conservative forces do work (no non-conservative work), mechanical energy E = K + U is conserved: K_i + U_i = K_f + U_f.

Work Power Energy.front: How does friction affect mechanical energy?
Work Power Energy.back: Friction is non-conservative: it does negative work and converts mechanical energy into thermal energy. Mechanical energy is not conserved; W_fric = ΔE_mech (negative).

Work Power Energy.front: Power — definition and SI unit.
Work Power Energy.back:
Power P is rate at which work is done or energy is transferred: P = dW/dt.
SI unit: watt (W) where 1 W = 1 J·s⁻¹.

Work Power Energy.front: Instantaneous power for a force acting on an object.
Work Power Energy.back: Instantaneous P = F·v·cosθ = F·v_∥ where v_∥ is component of velocity along force direction. In vector form P = F·v (dot product).

Work Power Energy.front: Average power versus instantaneous power.
Work Power Energy.back: Average power over time interval Δt: P_avg = ΔW / Δt. Instantaneous power P(t) = dW/dt.

Work Power Energy.front: Power in rotational motion.
Work Power Energy.back: Rotational analogue: P = τ·ω where τ is torque and ω is angular speed. (Same form: power = moment × angular velocity.)

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by a torque (rotation).
Work Power Energy.back: Work W when an object rotates through angle Δθ under torque τ: W = ∫ τ·dθ. For constant torque W = τ·Δθ.

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by pressure (thermodynamics context).
Work Power Energy.back: Work done by/on a gas during volume change: W = ∫ P dV. Convention: W_by_gas positive for expansion (V increases).

Work Power Energy.front: Example: Work to stretch a spring from 0 to x.
Work Power Energy.back: W = ∫_{0}^{x} k·x' dx' = 1/2·k·x² (work done ON spring). If done BY spring during release, sign reverses.

Work Power Energy.front: Example: stopping distance with friction (use work–energy theorem).
Work Power Energy.back: Initial KE 1/2·m·v² is removed by work of friction W = −μ_k·m·g·s. Solve s = v² / (2·μ_k·g) assuming horizontal plane and constant μ_k.

Work Power Energy.front: How to compute work from force–displacement graph?
Work Power Energy.back: Work = area under the force vs displacement (F–x) curve between x₁ and x₂.

Work Power Energy.front: Potential energy curve and stable/unstable equilibrium (qualitative).
Work Power Energy.back: At equilibrium dU/dx = 0. If U''(x) > 0 → stable (local minimum). If U''(x) < 0 → unstable (local maximum). Small oscillations near stable equilibrium approximate simple harmonic motion.

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by normal force and tension (common exam points).
Work Power Energy.back: Normal force may do zero work if displacement is along the surface (normal ⟂ displacement). Tension does work equal to integral of its component along displacement; often nonzero.

Work Power Energy.front: Example: Work done by gravity for vertical displacement h.
Work Power Energy.back: W_gravity = −m·g·Δy (if upward is positive and we compute work done BY gravity: negative when object goes up). Many exam problems use W = m·g·h with sign chosen per convention—be consistent.

Work Power Energy.front: Relation between work and energy in a system with non-conservative forces.
Work Power Energy.back: ΔE_mech = W_nc where W_nc is total work done by non-conservative forces (like friction). Equivalently: K_i + U_i + W_nc = K_f + U_f.

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by friction on a block sliding a distance s.
Work Power Energy.back: W_fric = −f_k·s = −μ_k·N·s (negative sign since friction opposes motion). For horizontal N = m·g.

Work Power Energy.front: What is elastic limit and plastic deformation (brief)?
Work Power Energy.back: Elastic limit: maximum stretch where object returns to original shape; beyond it plastic deformation occurs and some energy is irreversibly dissipated (not fully stored as U_spring).

Work Power Energy.front: Work required to lift an object slowly (quasi-static).
Work Power Energy.back: Minimum work to raise mass m by height h against gravity = m·g·h (done slowly so kinetic energy change ≈ 0).

Work Power Energy.front: How to treat sign for work in multi-step processes (example: up then down)?
Work Power Energy.back: Compute work for each segment with consistent sign convention and sum. For conservative forces total work over closed path = 0.

Work Power Energy.front: What is mechanical efficiency (η)?
Work Power Energy.back: η = (useful output energy or power / input energy or power) × 100%. For machines: η = (P_out / P_in) × 100% or η = (work_out / work_in) × 100%.

Work Power Energy.front: Energy forms and simple conversions relevant to problems.
Work Power Energy.back: Common forms: kinetic, gravitational potential, elastic potential, rotational kinetic (K_rot = 1/2·I·ω²), thermal (from friction). Problems often convert between K and U.

Work Power Energy.front: Rotational kinetic energy expression.
Work Power Energy.back: K_rot = 1/2·I·ω² where I is moment of inertia and ω is angular speed. Analogous to translational K = 1/2·m·v².

Work Power Energy.front: Work and energy for a rolling object (without slipping).
Work Power Energy.back: Total kinetic energy K_total = K_trans + K_rot = 1/2·m·v² + 1/2·I·ω². For rolling without slipping v = ω·R.

Work Power Energy.front: Power and force relation useful in problems (linear).
Work Power Energy.back: If object moves with speed v under force F in same direction, P = F·v. Useful to find force given power and speed: F = P / v.

Work Power Energy.front: Work done by centripetal force in uniform circular motion?
Work Power Energy.back: Centripetal force is always perpendicular to instantaneous displacement (toward centre), so work done by centripetal force = 0 for uniform circular motion.

Work Power Energy.front: Energy required to escape Earth's gravity (escape energy per unit mass).
Work Power Energy.back: Escape speed v_e from radius R: 1/2·m·v_e² = G·M_e·m / R → v_e = √(2·G·M_e / R). Work per unit mass required = G·M_e / R.

Work Power Energy.front: Example problem: minimum work to lift chain/rope partially off table (idea).
Work Power Energy.back: When mass distribution changes, integrate: dW = g·x·(dm) etc. Use W = ∫ g·y dm converting dm to λ·dx where λ is linear mass density.

Work Power Energy.front: What is escape velocity — quick explanation?
Work Power Energy.back: Minimum speed from surface to reach infinity (ignoring atmosphere) such that kinetic energy converts to gravitational potential: v_e = √(2·G·M / R).

Work Power Energy.front: Dimension check and limiting-case check (exam strategy).
Work Power Energy.back: Always verify units of formula and check limiting cases (e.g., k → 0, g → 0, small angles) to detect algebra/sign mistakes.

Work Power Energy.front: Short useful formula list (cheat-sheet).
Work Power Energy.back:
Work: W = F·s·cosθ or W = ∫ F dx
Kinetic energy: K = 1/2·m·v²
Potential (gravity): U = m·g·h
Spring U: U = 1/2·k·x²
Work–energy: W_net = ΔK
Power: P = dW/dt = F·v
Rotational power: P = τ·ω
Work by gas: W = ∫ P dV

Work Power Energy.front: Common pitfalls in exams (list).
Work Power Energy.back:
1) Sign confusion for work by gravity or work by external agent.
2) Using W = F·d without cosθ when force not along displacement.
3) Forgetting to integrate for variable forces.
4) Mixing up work done ON system vs BY system (thermo problems).

Work Power Energy.front: Quick numerical example: block pulled with constant F at angle θ on frictionless surface — work after displacement s?
Work Power Energy.back: W = F·s·cosθ (only horizontal component does work in horizontal displacement). If friction present, net work = F·s·cosθ − f_k·s.

Work Power Energy.front: How to compute work done by varying pressure in a cylinder (graphically)?
Work Power Energy.back: Plot P–V diagram. Work by gas during expansion from V₁ to V₂ is area under P–V curve: W = ∫_{V₁}^{V₂} P dV.

Work Power Energy.front: Why is work a scalar though it involves vectors?
Work Power Energy.back: Work uses dot product F·s which yields scalar. Result represents energy transferred, not direction.

Work Power Energy.front: What to remember about units when combining rotational and translational energies?
Work Power Energy.back: Both translational and rotational energies are in joules (J). Ensure ω in rad·s⁻¹, I in kg·m² so 1/2·I·ω² has units kg·m²·s⁻² = J.

Work Power Energy.front: Final exam tip: solve by energy when forces/paths are complicated.
Work Power Energy.back: Energy methods often simplify problems where forces vary or there are constraints (use conservation of energy + work by non-conservative forces) instead of solving equations of motion directly.

Gravitation.front: State Newton's law of universal gravitation.
Gravitation.back: Every two point masses m₁ and m₂ separated by distance r attract each other with force of magnitude: F = G·m₁·m₂ / r². Here G is universal gravitational constant.

Gravitation.front: What is the value and SI unit of the gravitational constant G?
Gravitation.back: G ≈ 6.674×10⁻¹¹ N·m²·kg⁻² (often rounded 6.67×10⁻¹¹ N·m²·kg⁻²). Unit: N·m²·kg⁻².

Gravitation.front: Direction and nature of gravitational force between two masses.
Gravitation.back: Gravitational force is always attractive and acts along the line joining the two masses (central force).

Gravitation.front: What is gravitational field (acceleration due to gravity) g⃗ at a point?
Gravitation.back: Gravitational field g⃗ at a point is force per unit mass: g⃗ = F⃗/m (test mass). For point mass M at distance r: g = G·M / r² directed toward M.

Gravitation.front: Relation between gravitational force and gravitational field.
Gravitation.back: F⃗ = m·g⃗ where g⃗ is gravitational field due to other mass(es) at location of mass m.

Gravitation.front: What is gravitational potential φ (at a point) due to a point mass?
Gravitation.back: Gravitational potential φ (scalar) due to mass M at distance r: φ(r) = −G·M / r. It is negative (zero at infinity) for attractive gravity.

Gravitation.front: Relation between gravitational field and potential.
Gravitation.back: g⃗ = −∇φ. In radial symmetry g = −dφ/dr = G·M / r² directed inward (sign convention consistent with φ negative).

Gravitation.front: What is gravitational potential energy U of two point masses m₁ and m₂ separated by r?
Gravitation.back: U = −G·m₁·m₂ / r (zero reference at r → ∞). Negative value indicates bound system.

Gravitation.front: Explain the concept of escape velocity from a planet of mass M and radius R.
Gravitation.back: Escape speed v_e is minimum speed at surface to reach infinity with zero kinetic energy: 1/2·m·v_e² = G·M·m / R → v_e = √(2·G·M / R). Independent of test mass m.

Gravitation.front: What is orbital velocity for a circular orbit at radius r around mass M?
Gravitation.back: For circular orbit, centripetal force = gravitational force: m·v² / r = G·M·m / r² → v_orb = √(G·M / r).

Gravitation.front: What is the period T of a small-mass satellite in circular orbit radius r?
Gravitation.back: T = 2·π·r / v = 2·π·√(r³ / (G·M)). This follows from v = √(G·M / r).

Gravitation.front: State Kepler's three laws of planetary motion (brief).
Gravitation.back:
1) Orbits are ellipses with Sun at one focus.
2) Line joining planet and Sun sweeps equal areas in equal times.
3) Square of orbital period T ∝ cube of semi-major axis a: T² ∝ a³ (for same central mass).

Gravitation.front: How is Kepler's third law expressed quantitatively for a small mass m orbiting mass M?
Gravitation.back: T² = (4·π² / (G·M))·a³ for elliptical orbit with semi-major axis a (for circular orbit a = r).

Gravitation.front: What is geostationary orbit (definition and condition)?
Gravitation.back: A geostationary satellite orbits Earth above equator with orbital period equal to Earth's rotation period (sidereal day ≈ 23 h 56 min). It appears fixed over one longitude. Condition: T = Earth's rotation period and orbit is circular above equator.

Gravitation.front: Estimate of geostationary orbit radius (idea/formula).
Gravitation.back: From T² = (4·π² / GM)·r³, solve r_geo = [GM·T² / (4·π²)]^(1/3). For Earth T = 86164 s; r_geo ≈ 4.216×10⁷ m from Earth's centre (approx 42,164 km).

Gravitation.front: What is apparent weight and how is it affected in an accelerating elevator?
Gravitation.back: Apparent weight = normal reaction N. In elevator accelerating up with a: N = m·(g + a). Accelerating down: N = m·(g − a). In free fall (a = g down) N = 0 (weightlessness).

Gravitation.front: Why astronaut feels weightless in orbit though gravity exists?
Gravitation.back: In orbit, both astronaut and spacecraft are in free fall around Earth; both accelerate equally under gravity, so normal force is zero — sensation of weightlessness (apparent weight = 0).

Gravitation.front: What is the Roche limit (qualitative)?
Gravitation.back: Approximate distance from a planet within which a self-gravitating satellite held by its own gravity will be tidally disrupted by the planet's differential gravity. Depends on densities of planet and satellite and satellite rigidity.

Gravitation.front: Tidal force — what causes tides on Earth?
Gravitation.back: Tides arise due to spatial variation (gradient) of Moon's and Sun's gravitational field across Earth's diameter; differential attraction stretches ocean toward and away from Moon producing two tidal bulges.

Gravitation.front: What is tidal locking (synchronous rotation)?
Gravitation.back: Tidal locking occurs when rotation period of a satellite becomes equal to its orbital period about its primary (e.g., Moon always shows same face to Earth).

Gravitation.front: Shell theorem (Newton) — statement.
Gravitation.back:
1) A spherically symmetric shell of mass exerts zero net gravitational force on a particle located anywhere inside the shell.
2) For points outside a spherically symmetric mass distribution, the gravitational force is as if all mass were concentrated at centre.

Gravitation.front: What is gravitational potential inside and outside a uniform spherical shell?
Gravitation.back:
Outside (r ≥ R): φ = −G·M / r.
Inside (r ≤ R): φ = −G·M / R = constant (for thin shell). For solid sphere, inside potential varies as φ = −G·M·(3R² − r²) / (2R³) (for uniform density).

Gravitation.front: Gravitational acceleration g on Earth's surface in terms of Earth's mass and radius.
Gravitation.back: g = G·M_e / R_e². Using M_e ≈ 5.97×10²⁴ kg and R_e ≈ 6.371×10⁶ m gives g ≈ 9.8 m·s⁻².

Gravitation.front: How does g vary with altitude h above Earth's surface (approximate)?
Gravitation.back: g(h) = G·M_e / (R_e + h)² ≈ g · (1 + h/R_e)⁻² ≈ g·(1 − 2·h / R_e) for h ≪ R_e (first-order approximation).

Gravitation.front: How does g vary with depth d below Earth's surface (assuming uniform density)?
Gravitation.back: For depth d (r = R_e − d), inside uniform sphere: g(d) = G·M_enclosed / r² = G·[M_e·(r³ / R_e³)] / r² = g·(r / R_e) = g·(1 − d / R_e). So g decreases linearly with depth (uniform density assumption).

Gravitation.front: What is gravitational binding energy of a uniform sphere (order-of-magnitude formula)?
Gravitation.back: Total gravitational potential energy (binding) U ≈ −(3/5)·G·M² / R for a uniform solid sphere of mass M and radius R. This is energy required to disperse the sphere to infinity.

Gravitation.front: Explain reduced mass μ for two-body gravitational problems.
Gravitation.back: For two masses m₁ and m₂ interacting gravitationally, reduce to one-body problem with reduced mass μ = m₁·m₂ / (m₁ + m₂) moving under central force around common centre of mass. Useful for orbital energy and motion analysis.

Gravitation.front: Total mechanical energy E of a circular orbit (per unit mass).
Gravitation.back: Specific energy ε = E / m = kinetic + potential per unit mass = 1/2·v² − G·M / r. For circular orbit v² = G·M / r → ε = −G·M / (2·r) (negative for bound orbit).

Gravitation.front: For elliptical orbit what is total specific energy in terms of semi-major axis a?
Gravitation.back: ε = −G·M / (2·a). Independent of eccentricity; determines size of ellipse.

Gravitation.front: Escape speed relation and connection to orbital speed.
Gravitation.back: v_e = √(2)·v_orb where v_orb = √(G·M / r) is circular orbital speed. Escape speed is √2 times circular orbital speed at same radius.

Gravitation.front: What is perigee and apogee (for Earth satellites)?
Gravitation.back: Perigee: point of orbit closest to Earth. Apogee: farthest point. For general central body terms: periapsis / apoapsis (e.g., perihelion/aphelion for Sun).

Gravitation.front: What is specific angular momentum and its conservation in central force motion?
Gravitation.back: Specific angular momentum h⃗ = r⃗ × v⃗ (per unit mass). In central force (gravity) torque about centre is zero, so angular momentum is conserved — leads to area law (Kepler's 2nd law).

Gravitation.front: Why orbital motion is planar?
Gravitation.back: For central forces (force along r⃗), angular momentum vector is constant. Motion stays in plane perpendicular to constant angular momentum vector — hence planar orbit.

Gravitation.front: What is vis-viva equation (relates speed, position and semi-major axis)?
Gravitation.back: v² = G·M·(2 / r − 1 / a) where r is current distance and a is orbit semi-major axis. Valid for any conic orbit (ellipse, parabola, hyperbola).

Gravitation.front: What speed corresponds to parabolic (escape) trajectory according to vis-viva?
Gravitation.back: For parabolic trajectory the specific energy ε = 0 so v² = 2·G·M / r — this is exactly escape speed squared; parabolic orbit separates bound (ε < 0) and unbound (ε > 0) motions.

Gravitation.front: What is the effect of Earth's rotation on apparent g (centrifugal effect)?
Gravitation.back: Apparent g = true gravitational acceleration − centrifugal acceleration ω_e²·r_e·cosφ (directed outward), where φ is latitude and ω_e is Earth's angular speed. This slightly reduces g, more at equator.

Gravitation.front: Why gravity is weaker at equator than at poles (two reasons)?
Gravitation.back:
1) Centrifugal effect due to Earth's rotation reduces apparent weight at equator.
2) Earth's equatorial radius > polar radius (oblate spheroid) so surface at equator is farther from mass centre → smaller g by inverse-square law.

Gravitation.front: What is gravitational lensing (qualitative)?
Gravitation.back: In general relativity, mass curves spacetime and light follows geodesics; massive objects bend light from background sources producing lensing effects. (Note: Newtonian gravity does not predict null-ray bending correctly.)

Gravitation.front: How to compute work done by gravity when moving mass between two points r₁ and r₂?
Gravitation.back: Work done by gravity W = ∫_{r₁}^{r₂} F·dr = ∫_{r₁}^{r₂} (−G·M·m / r²) dr = −G·M·m·(1 / r₂ − 1 / r₁) = U(r₁) − U(r₂).

Gravitation.front: What is specific orbital energy sign convention and what it indicates?
Gravitation.back: Specific energy ε = 1/2·v² − G·M / r. ε < 0 → bound (elliptic), ε = 0 → parabolic (escape), ε > 0 → hyperbolic (unbound).

Gravitation.front: Qualitative difference between Newtonian gravity and Einstein's GR (brief).
Gravitation.back: Newtonian gravity: instantaneous action-at-a-distance inverse-square force. General Relativity: gravity is manifestation of curved spacetime; predicts corrections (perihelion precession, light bending, gravitational time dilation). For most exam problems Newtonian treatment suffices.

Gravitation.front: What is the perihelion precession of Mercury (conceptual mention)?
Gravitation.back: Observed extra advance of Mercury's perihelion not accounted by Newtonian interactions; explained by General Relativity (famous test). Numerical detail not required for basic gravitation chapter but often mentioned conceptually in higher-level questions.

Gravitation.front: Common exam trick: if mass distribution is spherically symmetric you can treat it as point mass for external points — application.
Gravitation.back: Use shell theorem: gravitational force outside sphere = G·M_enclosed / r² as if mass at centre. Useful for Earth gravity, planets, hollow spheres, layered planets (use mass enclosed up to r).

Gravitation.front: How to find gravitational acceleration inside a hollow spherical shell?
Gravitation.back: Inside a thin spherical shell gravitational field is zero everywhere inside (shell theorem).

Gravitation.front: Quick formula list (cheat-sheet).
Gravitation.back:
Newton's law: F = G·m₁·m₂ / r²
Gravitational field: g = G·M / r²
Potential: φ = −G·M / r
Potential energy: U = −G·m₁·m₂ / r
Orbital speed (circular): v = √(G·M / r)
Orbital period: T = 2·π·√(r³ / (G·M))
Escape speed: v_e = √(2·G·M / r)
Vis-viva: v² = G·M·(2 / r − 1 / a)

Gravitation.front: Sample short problem (recall): Compute period of low Earth circular orbit at altitude h (idea).
Gravitation.back: Use r = R_e + h; T = 2·π·√(r³ / (G·M_e)). Plug numeric values for R_e, M_e, G to get T (typically ~90–100 minutes for h ≈ few hundred km).

Gravitation.front: Common pitfall: confusing gravitational potential φ (per unit mass) and potential energy U.
Gravitation.back: φ is potential per unit mass: φ = U / m. U is energy for mass m: U = m·φ = −G·M·m / r. Keep distinction clear in problems.

Gravitation.front: How to combine gravitational forces from multiple masses (vector sum)?
Gravitation.back: Gravitational forces add vectorially. Compute individual force vectors F⃗_i = G·m·M_i·(r̂_i) / r_i² (directed toward each M_i) and sum: F⃗_total = Σ F⃗_i.

Gravitation.front: Practical exam tip: units and dimensional checks in gravitation problems.
Gravitation.back: Check dimensions: G has units N·m²·kg⁻² = m³·kg⁻¹·s⁻². Ensure distances in metres, mass in kg, time in seconds for SI results. Verify via dimensional analysis if unsure.

Gravitation.front: Final exam strategy: when to use energy methods vs force methods in orbital problems?
Gravitation.back: Use energy/vis-viva for speed and energy-related questions (escape speed, specific energy). Use force/centripetal relations for instantaneous circular speed and period. Both combined often simplify multi-step problems.

Pressure.front: What is pressure (basic definition)?
Pressure.back: Pressure p is the force F acting normally per unit area A: p = F / A. It is a scalar (magnitude) but acts normal to surfaces.

Pressure.front: What is the SI unit of pressure and its base-unit form?
Pressure.back:
SI unit: pascal (Pa).
1 Pa = 1 N·m⁻² = 1 kg·m⁻¹·s⁻² (dimensional formula: M·L⁻¹·T⁻²).

Pressure.front: Give common pressure units and conversions (useful values).
Pressure.back:
1 atm = 1.013×10⁵ Pa = 760 mm Hg.
1 bar = 10⁵ Pa.
1 Torr (mm Hg) ≈ 133.322 Pa.
1 psi ≈ 6.895×10³ Pa.

Pressure.front: What is hydrostatic pressure in a fluid at depth h?
Pressure.back: Hydrostatic pressure due to a fluid column of density ρ at depth h (below free surface): p = p₀ + ρ·g·h, where p₀ is pressure at surface, g is acceleration due to gravity.

Pressure.front: Why hydrostatic pressure depends only on vertical depth, not on shape of container?
Pressure.back: Because p = p₀ + ρ·g·h depends only on vertical height h of fluid column; Pascal's law and equilibrium of fluid elements make pressure at a given depth same regardless of container shape.

Pressure.front: What is gauge pressure and absolute pressure?
Pressure.back:
Absolute pressure = pressure measured relative to vacuum.
Gauge pressure = pressure measured relative to atmospheric pressure: p_gauge = p_absolute − p_atm.

Pressure.front: What is atmospheric pressure (approximate) at sea level?
Pressure.back: Standard atmospheric pressure p_atm ≈ 1.013×10⁵ Pa (≈ 760 mm Hg).

Pressure.front: State Pascal's law.
Pressure.back: A change in pressure applied to an enclosed incompressible fluid is transmitted undiminished to every portion of the fluid and to the walls of the container.

Pressure.front: How does Pascal's law lead to the hydraulic press formula?
Pressure.back: If p applied on small piston A₁ produces force F₂ on piston A₂, then p = F₁ / A₁ = F₂ / A₂ → F₂ = F₁·(A₂ / A₁). Small input force can produce larger output force.

Pressure.front: What is the principle of communicating vessels?
Pressure.back: In connected vessels containing the same fluid, the free surfaces settle at the same vertical height when in equilibrium (neglecting surface tension and density differences).

Pressure.front: Define density and specific weight (relation to pressure).
Pressure.back:
Density ρ = mass / volume (kg·m⁻³).
Specific weight γ = ρ·g (N·m⁻³). Hydrostatic pressure increment dp = γ·dh = ρ·g·dh.

Pressure.front: What is the hydrostatic paradox?
Pressure.back: Hydrostatic paradox: The force on a container base depends only on fluid height, not on total fluid volume. A tall thin column and a short wide container with same height exert same base pressure.

Pressure.front: How to compute force on a plane surface submerged in a fluid?
Pressure.back: Total hydrostatic force = pressure at centroid × area = p_centroid · A where p_centroid = p₀ + ρ·g·h_centroid (use center-of-pressure for moment calculations).

Pressure.front: What is center of pressure?
Pressure.back: Center of pressure is the point on a submerged surface where resultant hydrostatic force acts. It generally lies below the centroid for a plane vertical surface.

Pressure.front: What is Archimedes' principle (buoyancy)?
Pressure.back: A body immersed in a fluid experiences an upward buoyant force equal in magnitude to the weight of the fluid displaced: F_b = ρ_fluid · V_displaced · g.

Pressure.front: When does an object float, sink or remain neutrally buoyant?
Pressure.back:
Float: weight (m·g) < buoyant force → object rises until equilibrium.
Sink: weight > buoyant force → object sinks.
Neutrally buoyant: weight = buoyant force → stays at that depth.

Pressure.front: Define relative density (specific gravity).
Pressure.back: Relative density (RD) = density of substance / density of water (ρ_sub / ρ_water). Dimensionless. RD < 1 → floats on water.

Pressure.front: How to find fraction of volume submerged for a floating object?
Pressure.back: For floatation: weight = buoyant force → ρ_object · V_total · g = ρ_fluid · V_submerged · g → V_submerged / V_total = ρ_object / ρ_fluid.

Pressure.front: What is a barometer and how does a mercury barometer work (basic idea)?
Pressure.back: A mercury barometer measures atmospheric pressure using a column of mercury: p_atm = ρ_Hg · g · h, where h is height of mercury column (≈ 760 mm at 1 atm).

Pressure.front: What is a manometer and types (brief)?
Pressure.back: A manometer measures pressure difference using liquid columns. Types: U-tube manometer (single fluid), differential manometer (two fluids), inclined manometer (increased sensitivity).

Pressure.front: U-tube manometer relation for pressure difference (simple case, same fluid).
Pressure.back: For two pressures p₁ and p₂ connected by same fluid of density ρ: p₁ − p₂ = ρ·g·(h₂ − h₁) where h differences measured vertically.

Pressure.front: Explain differential manometer with different fluid densities (idea).
Pressure.back: When manometer contains liquid of different density ρ_m, pressure difference relates to column heights of each fluid segment accounting for density and vertical distances; solve by equating pressures along connected streamline.

Pressure.front: What is vapour pressure and its effect on pressure measurements?
Pressure.back: Vapour pressure is pressure exerted by vapor in equilibrium with its liquid. In mercury barometer/manometer, vapour pressure (if non-negligible) reduces effective mercury column; must be accounted for in high-precision work.

Pressure.front: What is capillarity's effect on pressure readings in narrow tubes?
Pressure.back: Surface tension causes capillary rise/drop in narrow tubes, altering local fluid heights. For manometers or barometers with narrow tubes, capillary effects can change apparent height; use wide tube or correct for meniscus.

Pressure.front: Explain pressure at a point in a fluid is same in all directions (isotropy).
Pressure.back: In a static fluid, net shear is zero and pressure at a point exerts equal normal force per unit area on all oriented surfaces passing through that point → pressure is isotropic (same in all directions).

Pressure.front: What is pressure in a rotating fluid (free surface shape)?
Pressure.back: For fluid rotating with angular speed ω about vertical axis, free-surface shape is parabolic: z(r) = z(0) + (ω²·r²)/(2·g). Pressure inside fluid follows p = p_atm + ρ·g·z_effective.

Pressure.front: How does pressure vary in a fluid with varying density (compressible)?
Pressure.back: For compressible fluids (gases), dp/dz = −ρ(z)·g and ρ depends on p and T; integrating with equation of state (e.g., ideal gas) gives barometric formula p(z) = p₀·exp(−M·g·z / (R·T)) for isothermal atmosphere.

Pressure.front: What is absolute zero-pressure point and vacuum levels (qualitative)?
Pressure.back: Absolute zero pressure is perfect vacuum (p = 0). Practical vacuums are expressed as low absolute pressures; gauge pressure can be negative relative to atmosphere (partial vacuum).

Pressure.front: What is hydrostatic thrust on a plane surface and how to compute its line of action?
Pressure.back: Thrust (resultant force) = ∫ p·dA = p_centroid·A. Line of action (center of pressure) found by equating moment of pressure distribution: y_cp = y_centroid + I_centroid / (y_centroid·A), where I_centroid is second moment about axis.

Pressure.front: How to compute force on a horizontal inclined plane submerged (simple idea)?
Pressure.back: For horizontal plane at depth h: force = p(h)·A. For inclined plane integrate pressure over depth; resultant acts at centroid depth for area element with appropriate geometry.

Pressure.front: What is the role of surface tension in pressure across a curved interface (Young–Laplace)?
Pressure.back: Pressure jump across a curved liquid interface: Δp = p_inside − p_outside = γ·(1/R₁ + 1/R₂), where γ is surface tension and R₁, R₂ are principal radii of curvature.

Pressure.front: What is the pressure at the bottom of a container with layered immiscible fluids?
Pressure.back: Total pressure at depth = p_surface + Σ (ρ_i · g · h_i) summing contributions of each layer with density ρ_i and thickness h_i above the point.

Pressure.front: Practical example: how to find pressure at depth h in freshwater vs seawater?
Pressure.back: Use p = p_atm + ρ·g·h. For freshwater ρ ≈ 1000 kg·m⁻³; seawater ρ ≈ 1025 kg·m⁻³. Difference influences pressure by ~2.5%.

Pressure.front: Explain why pressure increases with depth even if fluid is at rest (intuitive).
Pressure.back: A deeper fluid element supports weight of fluid above it; to balance that weight, net upward normal force must be greater → pressure increases with depth to supply larger normal forces.

Pressure.front: What is a vacuum pump's action in terms of pressure?
Pressure.back: A vacuum pump reduces absolute pressure inside a chamber by removing gas molecules, lowering p_absolute below atmospheric; the pressure difference can do work (e.g., suction).

Pressure.front: What is cavitation (brief connection to pressure)?
Pressure.back: Cavitation occurs when local fluid pressure drops below vapor pressure, forming vapor bubbles that collapse violently when entering higher pressure regions, potentially damaging surfaces (e.g., propellers).

Pressure.front: How to measure pressure in gases using manometers and Bourdon gauges (basic idea)?
Pressure.back:
Manometer: liquid column balances pressure difference (direct hydrostatic relation).
Bourdon gauge: curved tube straightens as internal pressure increases; mechanical linkage converts deformation to dial reading (gauge reads relative to atmosphere).

Pressure.front: What is the barometric formula for an isothermal atmosphere (basic form)?
Pressure.back: For constant temperature T and molecular mass M: p(z) = p₀ · exp(−M·g·z / (R·T)), where R is universal gas constant. (Used to estimate pressure variation with altitude.)

Pressure.front: What is the relationship between pressure and boiling point (qualitative)?
Pressure.back: Boiling occurs when vapor pressure equals ambient pressure. Lower ambient pressure (e.g., at high altitude) reduces boiling point; higher pressure increases boiling point (pressure cookers).

Pressure.front: Common exam trick: difference between pressure and force (short).
Pressure.back: Force is vector quantity with magnitude and direction (N). Pressure is scalar defined as force per unit area (N·m⁻²). A small force over small area can give high pressure.

Pressure.front: Compute pressure exerted by a column: Example — a 2 m column of water (ρ = 1000 kg·m⁻³).
Pressure.back: Δp = ρ·g·h = 1000·9.8·2 = 1.96×10⁴ Pa ≈ 0.196 bar ≈ 147 mm Hg equivalent (approx).

Pressure.front: What is 'absolute zero of pressure' and can gauge pressure be negative?
Pressure.back: Absolute zero pressure is perfect vacuum p = 0 Pa. Gauge pressure can be negative if absolute pressure < atmospheric (i.e., partial vacuum), e.g., p_gauge = −10 kPa means absolute p = p_atm − 10 kPa.

Pressure.front: Why is pressure important in biological/medical contexts (brief reminders)?
Pressure.back: Blood pressure (hemodynamics), lung alveolar pressure, intracranial pressure all depend on fluid pressure principles. Understanding gauge vs absolute and pressure differences is key in physiology and medical devices.

Pressure.front: What is hydrostatic equilibrium (in astrophysics/planetary context)?
Pressure.back: Hydrostatic equilibrium: internal pressure gradient balances gravitational force in a star/planet: dp/dr = −ρ(r)·g(r). Determines internal pressure/density profiles.

Pressure.front: Exam strategy: steps to solve typical pressure problems (checklist).
Pressure.back:
1) Choose reference level and sign conventions.
2) Identify densities and heights of layers.
3) Use p = p_surface + Σ ρ·g·h for vertical columns.
4) For manometers equate pressures along same fluid line.
5) Convert units carefully.

Pressure.front: Short cheat-sheet (key formulas).
Pressure.back:
p = F / A
p = p₀ + ρ·g·h
Δp = ρ·g·Δh (manometer)
p₁ − p₂ = ρ·g·(h₂ − h₁) (U-tube)
Pascal: Δp transmitted undiminished
Buoyant force: F_b = ρ_fluid·V_disp·g
Surface tension pressure jump: Δp = γ(1/R₁ + 1/R₂)

Pressure.front: Common pitfalls to avoid in pressure questions.
Pressure.back:
1) Using vertical heights not slant lengths.
2) Ignoring atmospheric pressure when absolute pressure needed.
3) Confusing gauge vs absolute pressure.
4) Forgetting to use same fluid density in manometer segments or account for multiple fluids correctly.

Floatation.front: What is floatation (basic idea)?
Floatation.back: Floatation is the condition in which a body placed in a fluid is supported by an upward buoyant force so that it either floats partially submerged or remains suspended.

Floatation.front: State Archimedes' principle.
Floatation.back: A body wholly or partially immersed in a fluid experiences an upward buoyant force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the body: F_b = ρ_fluid·V_displaced·g.

Floatation.front: Define buoyant force (upthrust).
Floatation.back: Buoyant force (upthrust) is the net upward force that a fluid exerts on an immersed object due to pressure difference: magnitude = weight of displaced fluid = ρ·V_displaced·g.

Floatation.front: What are SI units and dimension of buoyant force?
Floatation.back: SI unit: newton (N). Dimensional formula: [F_b] = M·L·T⁻² (same as force).

Floatation.front: Condition for floating vs sinking (weight vs buoyant force).
Floatation.back:
Float: weight ≤ buoyant force (m·g ≤ ρ_fluid·V_displaced·g).
Sink: weight > buoyant force (m·g > ρ_fluid·V_total·g).
Neutral equilibrium (suspended): weight = buoyant force and net vertical force = 0.

Floatation.front: Fraction of volume submerged for a floating body (formula).
Floatation.back: For a body of total volume V and density ρ_body floating in fluid density ρ_fluid: V_sub / V = ρ_body / ρ_fluid (provided it floats without trapping air).

Floatation.front: When does a body sink even if its material is less dense than fluid (practical note)?
Floatation.back: If the rigid body is filled with heavy material or has openings causing flooding, or if its average density (including trapped air or cavities filled with fluid) exceeds ρ_fluid, it will sink. Shape alone doesn't guarantee floatation—average density matters.

Floatation.front: Apparent weight of a body submerged in a fluid (definition & formula).
Floatation.back:
Apparent weight = actual weight − buoyant force.
W_app = m·g − ρ_fluid·V_displaced·g.

Floatation.front: How to measure density using buoyancy (simple method).
Floatation.back: Weigh object in air (W_air = m·g) and apparent weight in fluid (W_fluid). Then buoyant force = W_air − W_fluid = ρ_fluid·V·g → density ρ_object = m / V = (W_air / g) / ( (W_air − W_fluid) / (ρ_fluid·g) ) → simpler: ρ_object = ρ_fluid · W_air / (W_air − W_fluid).

Floatation.front: Define center of gravity (G) for a body.
Floatation.back: Center of gravity G is the point through which resultant weight acts; location depends on mass distribution of the body.

Floatation.front: Define center of buoyancy (B).
Floatation.back: Center of buoyancy B is the centroid of the displaced fluid volume; it is the point through which the resultant buoyant force (upthrust) acts.

Floatation.front: What happens to B when a floating body is tilted slightly?
Floatation.back: When the body is tilted, the submerged shape changes and B shifts to a new position (B′) corresponding to centroid of new displaced volume; this shift can produce a restoring or overturning moment depending on relative positions of G and metacentre M.

Floatation.front: Define metacentre (M) (qualitative).
Floatation.back: Metacentre M is the point where the line of action of buoyant force for a slightly tilted position intersects the vertical through the original center of buoyancy. It is used to assess initial stability of floating bodies.

Floatation.front: Metacentric height (GM) and its significance.
Floatation.back: Metacentric height GM = distance from center of gravity G to metacentre M. If GM > 0 (G below M) → initial stable equilibrium; if GM < 0 (G above M) → unstable; if GM = 0 → neutral stability.

Floatation.front: Formula for BM (distance from B to M) for small angles.
Floatation.back: BM = I_wp / V_disp where I_wp is second moment of area (moment of inertia) of the water-plane area about the tilt axis and V_disp is displaced volume. Thus GM = BM − BG.

Floatation.front: What is I_wp (water-plane area moment of inertia)?
Floatation.back: I_wp is the second moment of area of the plane of flotation (water-plane) about the axis of tilt. For standard shapes (rectangular, circular), formulae exist (e.g., for rectangle of width b about centroidal axis: I = b³·l /12 etc.).

Floatation.front: Explain BG (distance between center of buoyancy and center of gravity).
Floatation.back: BG is the vertical distance from B (center of buoyancy) to G (center of gravity). BM − BG = GM. BG depends on geometry and mass distribution; lowering G increases GM (more stable).

Floatation.front: Stability criteria for a floating body (initial stability).
Floatation.back: Initial stability: if G is below M (GM > 0) the body righting moment when tilted tends to restore it to equilibrium. If G above M (GM < 0) tilt produces overturning moment → unstable.

Floatation.front: Righting moment (restoring moment) for small angle φ (formula idea).
Floatation.back: Righting moment ≈ Δ·GM·sinφ where Δ = weight (displaced fluid weight) = ρ_fluid·V_disp·g and φ is small angle of heel. For small φ, sinφ ≈ φ (radians).

Floatation.front: What is angle of loll (brief)?
Floatation.back: If a vessel is unstable in upright position (GM negative), it may assume a new equilibrium at some heel angle where G and M align — that angle is called angle of loll. It indicates marginal stability after trimming.

Floatation.front: Why lowering center of gravity increases stability (practical measures)?
Floatation.back: Lowering G increases GM (since BG fixed or changes less), making GM positive or larger; larger GM gives greater restoring moment for a given heel angle → more stable vessel. Ballast is used to lower G.

Floatation.front: What is reserve buoyancy (definition)?
Floatation.back: Reserve buoyancy is volume of enclosed space above waterline that can become submerged before ship sinks; greater reserve buoyancy gives more margin to stay afloat when damaged or taking water.

Floatation.front: Effect of free surface (sloshing) in tanks on stability.
Floatation.back: Liquid with free surface inside vessel reduces effective metacentric height (creates free-surface moment); moving liquid shifts B and reduces stability. Designers use baffles to reduce free-surface effect.

Floatation.front: Floatation of composite bodies (multiple materials/air cavities) — approach.
Floatation.back: Compute total mass m_total and total volume V_total. For floatation, weight m_total·g = ρ_fluid·V_submerged·g. V_submerged found by equating weight to displaced fluid. Treat cavities and solid parts in volume and mass balance.

Floatation.front: How does density of fluid affect floatation (example: fresh water vs salt water)?
Floatation.back: Since V_sub / V = ρ_body / ρ_fluid, object floats higher (less submerged) in denser fluid. Ships float slightly higher in seawater (ρ ≈ 1025 kg·m⁻³) than in fresh water (ρ ≈ 1000 kg·m⁻³).

Floatation.front: Floating in layered fluids (two immiscible fluids of different densities) — idea.
Floatation.back: An object may float at interface or partly in each fluid. Equate weight to sum of buoyancies from each layer: m·g = ρ₁·V₁·g + ρ₂·V₂·g. Solve for submerged volumes V₁, V₂ using geometry and densities.

Floatation.front: Example: fraction submerged of wooden block in water (numerical method idea).
Floatation.back: If block density ρ_block = 600 kg·m⁻³ in water ρ_water = 1000 kg·m⁻³ → fraction submerged = ρ_block / ρ_water = 0.6. So 60% volume submerged in equilibrium.

Floatation.front: Floating of a boat with cargo — how does loading affect floatation & stability?
Floatation.back: Loading increases weight → greater V_disp (sinks deeper). Loading alters G (shifts toward cargo). If G rises above M or raises BG relative to BM, stability may reduce; proper stowage keeps G low and within safe GM.

Floatation.front: Concept of angle of heel and equilibrium when heel occurs.
Floatation.back: Angle of heel is tilt angle from upright. Equilibrium occurs when line of action of weight through G and buoyant force through B′ intersect (or when G, B′, M align appropriately). Stability judged by sign of righting moment.

Floatation.front: How to compute center of buoyancy for simple submerged shapes (approach).
Floatation.back: Compute centroid of displaced fluid volume — for uniform bodies submerged fully, B is centroid of submerged geometry. For simple shapes use geometry formulae for centroid (e.g., cube: center at geometric center; part-submerged: use composite area/volume integrals).

Floatation.front: Why surface tension can allow small objects to float (qualitative)?
Floatation.back: For small objects (e.g., a steel needle) surface tension creates an upward vertical component along contact line that can balance weight; occurs when object does not break through liquid surface and contact angle & meniscus support it.

Floatation.front: Capillary effect vs buoyant force — which dominates for tiny objects?
Floatation.back: Surface tension (capillary) effects dominate at small length scales (millimetres or less); buoyant force dominates for larger objects where displaced fluid weight becomes significant.

Floatation.front: What is the role of contact angle in floating due to surface tension?
Floatation.back: Contact angle determines direction of surface tension force at the contact line and whether meniscus provides upward component. Hydrophobic surfaces tend to create upward curvature aiding floatation of small objects.

Floatation.front: Floating equilibrium for objects with concave shapes (e.g., boats) — intuitive note.
Floatation.back: Concave hulls trap air and enlarge displaced volume for given draft → more buoyancy. Hull shape affects water-plane area I_wp and thus BM, influencing initial stability (metacentric height).

Floatation.front: How to compute metacentric height GM for simple rectangular barge (formula idea).
Floatation.back: Approximate BM = I_wp / V_disp. For rectangular water-plane of breadth b and length l about transverse axis: I_trans = l·b³ / 12. Then BM = I_trans / V_disp. Compute BG from B and G positions and GM = BM − BG.

Floatation.front: What is the significance of large GM vs small GM in vessel motion comfort and safety?
Floatation.back: Large GM → strong initial stability but quick/harsh rolling (uncomfortable). Small positive GM → gentle roll but could be slow to right. Designers balance GM for safety and comfort.

Floatation.front: How does damage (flooding) reduce stability and floatation?
Floatation.back: Flooding increases mass (and often raises G) while reducing effective enclosed volume → larger draft and reduced reserve buoyancy. Free-surface effect of flooded compartments further reduces GM, risking capsize.

Floatation.front: What is trim and list (definitions)?
Floatation.back:
Trim: difference in draft between bow and stern (longitudinal inclination).
List: steady lateral inclination (heel) usually due to off-centre weight.

Floatation.front: How to restore stability if ship lists due to shifted cargo (practical fixes)?
Floatation.back: Shift weight to counter-list, pump out water from flooded side, add ballast to low side, or move cargo to lower/compensating position to lower G and restore GM positive.

Floatation.front: Why is density of ice less than water important for floatation (conceptual)?
Floatation.back: Ice has density ≈ 917 kg·m⁻³ < 1000 kg·m⁻³ → ice floats and about 9/10 of iceberg's mass is submerged; fraction submerged = ρ_ice / ρ_water ≈ 0.917.

Floatation.front: Floating of hollow sphere vs solid sphere of same material — which floats higher?
Floatation.back: Hollow sphere has lower average density (if air inside) and thus smaller fraction submerged; solid sphere of same material (no cavity) likely sinks if material density > fluid. So hollow may float while solid sinks.

Floatation.front: Compute work done to submerge an object further by Δh (conceptual).
Floatation.back: Work required = ∫ (weight − buoyant force)·dz over displacement if doing quasi-static; for small increase when object nearly floating, approximate incremental work ≈ (effective stiffness)·(Δh²/2) depending on geometry and fluid.

Floatation.front: What is heeling moment due to wind or current and its effect on stability?
Floatation.back: Heeling moment is external torque tending to tilt vessel. Righting moment due to buoyancy must exceed heeling moment for equilibrium. Designers ensure sufficient GM and righting arm curve (GZ vs φ) to resist expected heeling moments.

Floatation.front: Righting arm GZ (definition).
Floatation.back: GZ is horizontal distance between line of action of weight through G and buoyancy line through B′ at angle φ; righting moment = Δ·GZ where Δ = displacement (weight). GZ varies with heel angle and hull geometry.

Floatation.front: GZ curve and its importance.
Floatation.back: GZ (or righting lever) plotted vs heel angle φ gives stability characteristics: positive area indicates capacity to resist capsize; key values: range of positive GZ, maximum GZ, angle of vanishing stability (where GZ = 0).

Floatation.front: Practical exam question style: Given densities and dimensions find submerged depth — approach.
Floatation.back: Compute mass m = ρ_body·V_total. For floatation set m·g = ρ_fluid·V_sub·g → V_sub = (ρ_body / ρ_fluid)·V_total. For prismatic shapes convert to submerged depth via V_sub = base_area · h_sub.

Floatation.front: Why small insects can walk on water — short explanation.
Floatation.back: Their weight is tiny and the surface tension of water provides upward force along contact perimeter; legs distribute load and prevent breaking surface. Capillary effect and hydrophobic legs contribute.

Floatation.front: Common pitfalls in floatation problems (exam tips).
Floatation.back:
1) Mix up ρ_body and average density.
2) Forget to include trapped air/cavities.
3) Use vertical heights not slanted distances for hydrostatic pressures.
4) Confuse center of gravity and center of buoyancy.
5) Ignore free-surface effects in partially filled tanks.

Floatation.front: Cheat-sheet: key formulas for floatation.
Floatation.back:
Archimedes: F_b = ρ_fluid·V_disp·g
Floating fraction: V_sub/V = ρ_body / ρ_fluid
BM = I_wp / V_disp
GM = BM − BG (stability criterion)
Righting moment ≈ Δ·GM·sinφ (small φ)
Apparent weight = m·g − F_b

Floatation.front: Short numerical example: A block of wood (density 600 kg·m⁻³) floats in water. Fraction submerged?
Floatation.back: Fraction submerged = ρ_block / ρ_water = 600 / 1000 = 0.6 → 60% of volume is submerged.

Floatation.front: Final exam strategy notes for floatation problems.
Floatation.back: Always: 1) draw diagram with G, B and waterline; 2) identify volumes and centroids; 3) use weight = buoyancy for vertical equilibrium; 4) check stability via GM (= I_wp / V − BG); 5) mind units (m, kg, s).

Surface Tension.front: What is surface tension (basic definition)?
Surface Tension.back: Surface tension γ (or σ) is the force per unit length acting along the surface of a liquid, tending to minimize the surface area. Unit: N·m⁻¹. It can also be seen as energy per unit area (J·m⁻²).

Surface Tension.front: Dimensions and SI unit of surface tension.
Surface Tension.back: SI unit: newton per metre (N·m⁻¹) which equals joule per square metre (J·m⁻²). Dimensional formula: [γ] = M·T⁻².

Surface Tension.front: Molecular origin of surface tension (qualitative).
Surface Tension.back: Molecules at the surface experience unbalanced intermolecular forces (net inward attraction). This makes creating extra surface energetically costly, producing a contractile effect called surface tension.

Surface Tension.front: Surface energy vs surface tension — relation.
Surface Tension.back: Surface energy (energy required to create unit area) = surface tension for a liquid under constant temperature: γ = (dW/dA). So work dW to create area dA is dW = γ·dA.

Surface Tension.front: Force interpretation of surface tension (string model).
Surface Tension.back: Surface tension acts like a line tension: along a length ℓ of the contact line the total force = γ·ℓ. Example: force on a frame edge = γ × (perimeter in contact).

Surface Tension.front: Why droplets tend to be spherical (role of surface tension).
Surface Tension.back: A sphere has minimum surface area for a given volume; surface tension tends to minimize surface area, so free liquid droplets form spherical shapes (neglecting gravity).

Surface Tension.front: Young–Laplace equation (pressure difference across a curved interface).
Surface Tension.back: Δp = p_inside − p_outside = γ·(1/R₁ + 1/R₂). For a spherical liquid drop (R₁ = R₂ = r): Δp = 2·γ / r.

Surface Tension.front: Pressure difference for a soap bubble vs liquid drop.
Surface Tension.back:
Liquid drop (single interface): Δp = 2·γ / r.
Thin soap bubble (two interfaces): Δp = 4·γ / r (because two surfaces contribute).

Surface Tension.front: What is contact angle (θ) and angle of contact definition?
Surface Tension.back: Contact angle θ is the angle between tangent to liquid surface and solid surface measured inside the liquid at the contact line. It characterises wetting: small θ → good wetting; large θ → poor wetting.

Surface Tension.front: Young's equation relating contact angle and surface tensions.
Surface Tension.back: γ_SG − γ_SL = γ_LG·cosθ where γ_SG = solid–gas surface tension, γ_SL = solid–liquid, γ_LG (or γ) = liquid–gas. This gives cosθ and hence wetting behaviour.

Surface Tension.front: Wetting and non-wetting (θ ranges).
Surface Tension.back: Complete wetting: θ ≈ 0°. Partial wetting: 0° < θ < 90° (hydrophilic). Non-wetting: θ > 90° (hydrophobic).

Surface Tension.front: Capillary action — qualitative description.
Surface Tension.back: Capillary action (rise or depression) occurs when surface tension and contact angle cause liquid to climb or fall in narrow tubes or porous media. Result of balance between surface forces and weight of liquid column.

Surface Tension.front: Jurin's law (capillary rise formula).
Surface Tension.back: Capillary rise h in a tube of radius r: h = (2·γ·cosθ) / (ρ·g·r). If cosθ positive → rise; cosθ negative → depression.

Surface Tension.front: Derive the direction of meniscus (concave vs convex).
Surface Tension.back: If liquid wets the wall (θ < 90°) the meniscus is concave (liquid climbs up wall). If liquid does not wet (θ > 90°) meniscus is convex (liquid depressed).

Surface Tension.front: Capillary pressure inside a cylindrical meniscus (approx.).
Surface Tension.back: Pressure jump across curved meniscus Δp ≈ 2·γ / R_eff where R_eff is effective radius of curvature of meniscus determined by tube radius and contact angle.

Surface Tension.front: Effect of radius on capillary rise (qualitative).
Surface Tension.back: Smaller tube radius r → larger capillary rise h (inversely proportional). Very narrow pores lead to significant capillarity (important in plants/soils).

Surface Tension.front: Role of gravity in limiting capillary rise.
Surface Tension.back: Capillary rise stops when upward surface-tension force equals weight of raised liquid column: γ·(2πr)·cosθ = ρ·g·(πr²)·h → Jurin's law arises.

Surface Tension.front: Surface tension variation with temperature.
