Surface Tension.back: Surface tension typically decreases with increasing temperature and goes to zero at critical temperature. Approximate linear relation near room temperature: γ(T) ≈ γ₀ − k·T (k positive).

Surface Tension.front: Effect of impurities and surfactants on surface tension.
Surface Tension.back: Surfactants (detergents) reduce γ dramatically by accumulating at the interface. Ionic impurities can also change γ. Reducing γ changes capillary behaviour and wetting.

Surface Tension.front: Marangoni effect (surface-tension-driven flow).
Surface Tension.back: Gradient of surface tension (due to temperature or concentration differences) creates tangential stress that drives fluid flow from low-γ to high-γ regions — Marangoni flow (e.g., tears of wine).

Surface Tension.front: Work needed to create a new surface area (expression).
Surface Tension.back: Work ΔW required to create new area ΔA (two-sided film counts appropriately) is ΔW = γ·ΔA. For soap films with two surfaces multiply by 2: ΔW = 2·γ·ΔA.

Surface Tension.front: Surface tension as force per unit length — example with a frame and film.
Surface Tension.back: If a movable wire length ℓ is attached to a soap film, the force needed to pull it = 2·γ·ℓ (two surfaces). If single interface, force = γ·ℓ.

Surface Tension.front: Measurement methods — capillary rise method (idea).
Surface Tension.back: Measure equilibrium capillary rise h in tube of known radius r and contact angle θ (or assume θ). Use h = 2·γ·cosθ / (ρ·g·r) to compute γ.

Surface Tension.front: Measurement methods — du Noüy (ring) method (basic principle).
Surface Tension.back: A platinum ring pulled from liquid surface measures maximum force F_max required to detach ring. Surface tension estimated from force and ring circumference with correction factors: γ ≈ F_max / (2·π·R_eff) · calibration factor.

Surface Tension.front: Measurement methods — stalagmometer (drop weight/volume method).
Surface Tension.back: Count number of drops of known liquid falling from a capillary; relation between drop mass and γ allows relative measurement of surface tension vs a reference liquid.

Surface Tension.front: Pendant/drop method (idea).
Surface Tension.back: Shape of a pendant drop (or maximum drop size before detachment) depends on γ. Analysis of drop profile or weight at detachment yields γ using known formulas or fitting.

Surface Tension.front: Surface tension and bubbles — energy and stability notes.
Surface Tension.back: Soap bubbles have lower γ due to surfactant and have two surfaces. Surface tension resists expansion; to inflate bubble work must be done against surface tension and internal pressure Δp = 4·γ / r.

Surface Tension.front: Why detergents help wet surfaces (practical).
Surface Tension.back: Detergents lower γ of water and reduce contact angle on many solids → improved wetting and spreading of water over surfaces, aiding cleaning.

Surface Tension.front: Contact-angle hysteresis (advancing vs receding).
Surface Tension.back: Real surfaces show different advancing and receding contact angles due to surface heterogeneity and pinning. Hysteresis affects droplet motion and adhesion.

Surface Tension.front: Meniscus shape near wall (qualitative).
Surface Tension.back: Near a vertical wall, the meniscus height decays over a capillary length ℓ_c = √(γ / (ρ·g)). If system size ≫ ℓ_c gravity dominates; if ≪ ℓ_c surface tension dominates.

Surface Tension.front: Capillary length ℓ_c — definition and significance.
Surface Tension.back: ℓ_c = √(γ / (ρ·g)). It is the length scale where gravity and surface tension balance; determines drop shapes and wetting profiles.

Surface Tension.front: Application — rise of sap in plants (role of surface tension).
Surface Tension.back: Capillary action in xylem conduits, along with transpiration pull and cohesion of water, helps transport water upward. Surface tension is a key contributor at micro-scale conduits.

Surface Tension.front: Application — detergents, emulsions and foams (role of surface tension).
Surface Tension.back: Surfactants stabilize emulsions/foams by lowering γ and forming monolayers that reduce coalescence; they change interfacial rheology and Marangoni effects contribute to stability.

Surface Tension.front: Derive force balance for a liquid rise between two parallel plates (brief result).
Surface Tension.back: For two plates separated by distance b (b ≪ capillary length), rise h ≈ (2·γ·cosθ) / (ρ·g·b) (similar to tube with effective radius ≈ b/2).

Surface Tension.front: Effect of temperature on capillary rise.
Surface Tension.back: Since γ decreases with T, capillary rise h (∝ γ) decreases with increasing temperature (assuming ρ, θ roughly constant).

Surface Tension.front: Small-drop approximation and Young–Laplace: curvature dominates for tiny drops.
Surface Tension.back: For very small drops (r ≪ capillary length) surface-tension pressure 2γ/r dominates over hydrostatic pressure ρ·g·r and gravity can be neglected in shape calculations.

Surface Tension.front: How surface tension causes coalescence or breakup of droplets.
Surface Tension.back: Surface tension drives minimization of surface area; two droplets coalesce to reduce total surface area. Competing inertial/viscous forces determine breakup/fragmentation under flow (Rayleigh–Plateau instability).

Surface Tension.front: Rayleigh–Plateau instability (short idea).
Surface Tension.back: A cylindrical liquid column is unstable to sinusoidal perturbations with wavelength > circumference; surface tension causes breakup into drops to reduce surface energy.

Surface Tension.front: Energy argument: why two small droplets sometimes merge into one larger droplet.
Surface Tension.back: Total surface area of two equal small spheres > surface area of single sphere with combined volume. Merging reduces total area → lowers surface energy by ΔE = γ·(ΔA).

Surface Tension.front: Surface tension and viscosity interplay in dynamic wetting.
Surface Tension.back: Dynamic contact-line motion involves balance of viscous dissipation and capillary driving force (γ·cosθ). Contact-line friction and viscous bending affect spreading rates.

Surface Tension.front: Common exam formulas (cheat-sheet).
Surface Tension.back:
Δp (Laplace) = γ·(1/R₁ + 1/R₂)
Drop: Δp = 2·γ / r; Bubble: Δp = 4·γ / r
Capillary rise: h = 2·γ·cosθ / (ρ·g·r)
Work to create area: ΔW = γ·ΔA (or 2·γ·ΔA for film)
Capillary length: ℓ_c = √(γ / (ρ·g))

Surface Tension.front: Typical numerical values of surface tension (examples).
Surface Tension.back: Water at 20 °C: γ ≈ 0.0728 N·m⁻¹. Mercury at 20 °C: γ ≈ 0.485 N·m⁻¹. Alcohols much lower (e.g., ethanol ≈ 0.022 N·m⁻¹). Values vary with T and impurities.

Surface Tension.front: Example problem (capillary rise): Tube radius 0.5 mm, water γ = 0.0728 N·m⁻¹, θ ≈ 0°, ρ = 1000 kg·m⁻³. Find h (use g = 9.8 m·s⁻²).
Example problem (pressure inside small droplet): water drop radius 1 mm, γ = 0.073 N·m⁻¹. Find Δp.
Why small insects (e.g., water strider) can walk on water.
Surface Tension.back: Their weight is supported by surface tension via menisci around their hydrophobic legs; legs distribute load and surface tension provides upward vertical component without breaking surface.

Surface Tension.front: Common pitfalls in exam questions on surface tension.
Surface Tension.back:
1) Forgetting factor 2 for soap films (two surfaces).
2) Using diameter instead of radius in Jurin's law.
3) Neglecting contact angle when needed.
4) Confusing surface tension units (N·m⁻¹ vs N·m⁻²).

Surface Tension.front: Practical tips for measurements and experiments.
Surface Tension.back: Keep surfaces clean (impurities change γ). Use wide tubes to avoid significant meniscus curvature when measuring bulk properties. Account for temperature and surfactant effects.

Surface Tension.front: Relation between surface tension and boiling/evaporation phenomena (brief).
Surface Tension.back: Lower γ usually correlates with easier spreading/evaporation; surfactants can change evaporation rates by modifying surface composition and Marangoni flows that redistribute heat/solute.

Surface Tension.front: Advanced note: dynamic surface tension vs equilibrium surface tension.
Surface Tension.back: Dynamic γ(t) depends on time after creating new interface (surfactant adsorption kinetics). Equilibrium γ reached after sufficient time when adsorption/desorption balance is established.

Surface Tension.front: Final quick revision checklist for surface tension topics.
Surface Tension.back: Know definitions (force/energy view), units/dimensions, Young–Laplace formula, Jurin's law, contact angle (Young's equation), bubble vs drop Δp, measurement methods, Marangoni effect, common applications and pitfalls.

Viscosity.front: What is viscosity (basic definition)?
Viscosity.back: Viscosity is a measure of a fluid's internal resistance to flow or shear. It quantifies the friction between adjacent layers of fluid moving at different velocities.

Viscosity.front: Different types of viscosity — dynamic and kinematic (definitions & symbols).
Viscosity.back:
Dynamic (absolute) viscosity η: measure of shear stress per unit velocity gradient (units Pa·s).
Kinematic viscosity ν: ν = η / ρ (viscosity per unit density), with units m²·s⁻¹. ρ is fluid density.

Viscosity.front: Dimensional formulas and SI units of η and ν.
Viscosity.back:
Dynamic viscosity η: SI unit Pa·s = N·s·m⁻² = kg·m⁻¹·s⁻¹. Dimensional formula: [η] = M·L⁻¹·T⁻¹.
Kinematic viscosity ν: SI unit m²·s⁻¹. Dimensional formula: [ν] = L²·T⁻¹.

Viscosity.front: Shear stress and velocity gradient relation (Newton's law of viscosity).
Viscosity.back: For a Newtonian fluid: shear stress τ = η · (du/dy), where du/dy is velocity gradient perpendicular to flow. τ is force per unit area (N·m⁻²).

Viscosity.front: What is a Newtonian fluid? Give examples.
Viscosity.back: Newtonian fluids have linear relation τ ∝ (du/dy) with constant η independent of shear rate. Examples: water, air, many simple oils.

Viscosity.front: What are non-Newtonian fluids? Common types and examples.
Viscosity.back: Non-Newtonian fluids have shear-dependent viscosity or time-dependent response. Types: shear-thinning/pseudoplastic (e.g., ketchup, blood), shear-thickening/dilatant (e.g., cornstarch slurry), Bingham plastic (yield stress, e.g., toothpaste), viscoelastic fluids (polymer melts).

Viscosity.front: Physical origin of viscosity (qualitative).
Viscosity.back: Viscosity arises from momentum transfer between fluid layers (molecular collisions for gases; intermolecular forces and structure for liquids). It represents internal friction converting macroscopic kinetic energy into heat.

Viscosity.front: Temperature dependence: how viscosity varies with temperature for liquids and gases.
Viscosity.back:
Liquids: viscosity decreases strongly with increasing temperature (molecules overcome cohesive forces).
Gases: viscosity increases with temperature (higher molecular speeds increase momentum transfer).

Viscosity.front: Typical values (order of magnitude) — water and air at ~20 °C.
Unit conversion: Poise and centipoise to SI.
Viscosity.back:
1 poise (P) = 0.1 Pa·s.
1 centipoise (cP) = 10⁻³ Pa·s. (Water ≈ 1 cP at 20 °C.)

Viscosity.front: Stokes' law for a small sphere moving in viscous fluid (drag force).
Viscosity.back: For Re ≪ 1 (creeping flow), drag F_d = 6·π·η·r·v where r is sphere radius and v is relative speed. Valid for small spheres and low Reynolds number.

Viscosity.front: Terminal velocity of a small sphere in viscous fluid (Stokes regime).
Viscosity.back: For a sphere of density ρ_s in fluid ρ_f: v_t = (2/9)·(ρ_s − ρ_f)·g·r² / η (assuming Re ≪ 1 and neglecting added mass effects).

Viscosity.front: Hagen–Poiseuille law (volumetric flow in a circular pipe, laminar).
Viscosity.back: For steady laminar flow in a pipe of radius R and length L under pressure drop ΔP: Q = (π·R⁴·ΔP) / (8·η·L). Valid for Newtonian fluid and Re below critical.

Viscosity.front: Velocity profile in laminar pipe flow (parabolic).
Viscosity.back: For pipe radius R and pressure gradient ΔP/L: v(r) = (ΔP / (4·η·L))·(R² − r²). Maximum at centre v_max = (ΔP·R²) / (4·η·L). Average v_avg = Q / (π·R²) = v_max / 2.

Viscosity.front: Shear stress at pipe wall and relation to pressure gradient.
Viscosity.back: Wall shear stress τ_w = (R·ΔP) / (2·L). Also τ(r) = (ΔP / (2·L))·r for cylindrical coordinates (linear in r).

Viscosity.front: When is flow laminar vs turbulent? Role of Reynolds number.
Viscosity.back: Reynolds number Re = ρ·v·D / η (or Re = v·D / ν). For pipe flow, laminar typically for Re < 2000, transitional ~2000–4000, turbulent for Re > ~4000. Exact thresholds vary.

Viscosity.front: Definition of Reynolds number and physical meaning.
Viscosity.back: Re = (inertial forces) / (viscous forces) = ρ·v·L / η (L characteristic length). High Re → inertial-dominated (turbulence possible). Low Re → viscous-dominated (creeping flow).

Viscosity.front: Viscous dissipation and energy loss in pipe flow (power loss).
Viscosity.back: Rate of work done by pressure = ΔP·Q. This power is dissipated into heat by viscous stresses. Hydraulic power lost per unit length relates to shear stress and flow rate.

Viscosity.front: Darcy–Weisbach relation and friction factor for laminar flow.
Viscosity.back: Head loss h_f = f·(L/D)·(v² / (2·g)). For laminar flow in circular pipe, Darcy friction factor f = 64 / Re (use Re based on average v).

Viscosity.front: Boundary layer concept and role of viscosity.
Viscosity.back: Viscosity creates a thin boundary layer near solid surfaces where velocity transitions from zero (no-slip) to free-stream value. Boundary-layer thickness δ grows with downstream distance and depends on ν and flow conditions.

Viscosity.front: No-slip condition (statement and implication).
Viscosity.back: At a solid boundary, the fluid velocity equals the boundary velocity (usually zero). This arises from viscous interactions and is essential for boundary-layer theory and shear stress calculations.

Viscosity.front: Shear stress at a wall (general form).
Viscosity.back: τ_w = η·(du/dy)|_w (gradient of tangential velocity at wall). Determines frictional force per unit area.

Viscosity.front: Flow between parallel plates (Couette and Poiseuille components).
Viscosity.back:
Couette flow: one plate moves with speed U and other fixed → linear velocity profile, shear-driven.
Poiseuille flow: pressure-driven between stationary plates → parabolic profile. General solution superposes both drivers.

Viscosity.front: Viscosity measurement methods (brief descriptions).
Viscosity.back:
Capillary (Ostwald) viscometer: measure time for fluid to flow through capillary.
Falling-ball viscometer: use terminal velocity of ball.
Rotational viscometer/rheometer: measure torque vs angular speed.
Stokes method: small sphere descent in liquid.

Viscosity.front: Viscometry units often used in industry (centipoise, Saybolt second, Redwood).
Viscosity.back:
centipoise (cP) common for liquids: 1 cP = 10⁻³ Pa·s.
Saybolt and Redwood seconds are empirical time-based viscosity measures used in petroleum industry (convert via calibration).

Viscosity.front: Viscosity and lubrication (why viscosity important in bearings).
Viscosity.back: Lubrication relies on viscous film to separate surfaces, preventing metal–metal contact. Viscosity must be high enough to sustain film at operating load/speed but low enough to avoid excessive viscous drag (viscosity selection critical).

Viscosity.front: Reynolds number based on pipe diameter and interpretation for flow regimes.
Viscosity.back: Re = ρ·v_avg·D / η (D pipe diameter). Re small → laminar profile, Re large → turbulent with flatter velocity profile and higher friction factor.

Viscosity.front: Stokes flow (creeping flow) characteristics.
Viscosity.back: Re ≪ 1 → inertial terms negligible in Navier–Stokes; flow governed by linear Stokes equations. Flow reversible in time (Purcell's scallop theorem context) and dominated by viscosity.

Viscosity.front: Example: compute terminal velocity in Stokes regime — formula recap.
Viscosity.back: v_t = (2/9)·(ρ_s − ρ_f)·g·r² / η. Use when particle small and Re ≪ 1; otherwise correction (Oseen, empirical) required.

Viscosity.front: Effect of dissolved substances and impurities on viscosity.
Viscosity.back: Solutes can increase or decrease viscosity depending on interactions (e.g., salts often increase water's viscosity slightly; polymers can dramatically increase viscosity). Temperature and concentration matter.

Viscosity.front: Viscosity of mixtures — general approach.
Viscosity.back: Mixture viscosity not simple average; use empirical mixing rules (e.g., logarithmic mixing, Kendall–Monroe) or measure experimentally. For dilute suspensions, Einstein relation: η_eff = η_0(1 + 2.5ϕ) for small volume fraction ϕ of rigid spheres.

Viscosity.front: Einstein viscosity relation for dilute suspensions (first-order).
Viscosity.back: η_eff = η_0 · (1 + 2.5·ϕ) where ϕ is volume fraction of rigid spherical particles (valid for ϕ ≪ 1).

Viscosity.front: Viscous heating (qualitative).
Viscosity.back: Viscous dissipation converts mechanical energy into heat within the fluid; important in high-shear processes and can increase local temperature, altering viscosity (coupled effect).

Viscosity.front: Flow in pipes with rough walls — effect on viscous flow.
Viscosity.back: Roughness increases frictional losses, especially in turbulent regime. In laminar flow roughness negligible; in turbulent flow friction factor depends on both Re and relative roughness.

Viscosity.front: Dimensionless groups related to viscosity (besides Re).
Viscosity.back: Peclet number Pe = v·L / α (ratio advective transport to diffusive thermal transport) where α thermal diffusivity; Stokes number Stk for particle dynamics; Bingham number for yield-stress fluids, etc.

Viscosity.front: Bingham plastic model (yield stress fluids).
Viscosity.back: τ = τ_y + η_p·(du/dy) for τ > τ_y; τ_y is yield stress, η_p plastic viscosity. Fluid behaves rigid until τ exceeds τ_y (e.g., toothpaste).

Viscosity.front: Shear-thinning and shear-thickening behaviour (mathematical modelling).
Viscosity.back: Power-law fluid model: τ = K·(du/dy)^n where n < 1 → shear-thinning (apparent viscosity decreases with shear), n > 1 → shear-thickening. K is consistency index.

Viscosity.front: Practical example: why motor oil viscosity grade matters (SAE ratings).
Viscosity.back: Oil viscosity affects film thickness and engine drag. Multigrade oils have additives (VI improvers) to keep viscosity in acceptable range across temperatures (cold start vs running). Viscosity index (VI) quantifies sensitivity to temperature.

Viscosity.front: Viscosity index (VI) — concept (brief).
Viscosity.back: VI is an empirical number indicating how much a lubricant's viscosity changes with temperature. High VI → viscosity changes less with temperature (desirable).

Viscosity.front: Flow past a flat plate — shear at the wall and boundary-layer growth (idea).
Viscosity.back: Laminar boundary-layer thickness δ(x) ∼ x / √Re_x (Blasius solution) and wall shear stress τ_w ∼ μ·(du/dy)_w. Viscosity controls momentum diffusion into flow near the plate.

Viscosity.front: When does Stokes' law fail? (limitations).
Viscosity.back: Stokes' law fails when Re is not ≪ 1 (inertia significant), when particle near wall (wall corrections), for non-spherical particles, or when slip at boundary occurs for rarefied gas.

Viscosity.front: Slip vs no-slip boundary conditions (when slip occurs).
Viscosity.back: No-slip generally valid for liquids at macroscopic scales. Slip may occur for rarefied gases (Knudsen number high) or engineered hydrophobic surfaces (apparent slip).

Viscosity.front: Application: sedimentation and centrifugation (role of viscosity).
Viscosity.back: Settling speed of particles depends on η (viscous drag). In centrifuges effective gravity increases v_t ∝ g_eff; viscosity still limits terminal acceleration — design considers η for separation rates.

Viscosity.front: Application: inkjet printing and coating (importance of viscosity).
Viscosity.back: Viscosity controls droplet formation, breakup, and spreading on substrates. Proper viscosity range essential for print-head function and uniform coatings.

Viscosity.front: Application: blood rheology (non-Newtonian behaviour).
Viscosity.back: Blood is shear-thinning (effective viscosity decreases with shear rate) and contains cells/particles; models often use power-law or Casson models for clinical/engineering calculations.

Viscosity.front: Analogy: viscosity as 'momentum diffusivity' and connection to kinematic viscosity.
Viscosity.back: Kinematic viscosity ν = η / ρ acts like diffusion coefficient for momentum in Navier–Stokes; it sets scale for how quickly velocity perturbations diffuse across fluid layers.

Viscosity.front: How to estimate whether flow is viscous-dominated in microfluidics.
Viscosity.back: Microfluidic devices have small L so Re = v·L / ν often ≪ 1 → flows laminar and viscous-dominated. Mixing relies on diffusion rather than turbulence.

Viscosity.front: Power required to overcome viscous drag on an object moving at speed v (order-of-magnitude).
Viscosity.back: For small Stokes drag F ≈ 6π η r v, power P = F·v ≈ 6π η r v². For turbulent/high-Re, drag ~ 1/2·C_d·ρ·A·v² giving P ∝ v³.

Viscosity.front: Viscosity and sound attenuation in fluids (qualitative).
Viscosity.back: Viscous effects dissipate acoustic energy; attenuation increases with frequency and viscosity. Viscous dissipation contributes to acoustic damping.

Viscosity.front: Quick cheat-sheet: important formulas (viscosity chapter).
Viscosity.back:
Newton's law: τ = η·(du/dy)
Kinematic viscosity: ν = η / ρ
Stokes drag: F = 6·π·η·r·v (Re ≪ 1)
Terminal speed (Stokes): v_t = (2/9)·(ρ_s − ρ_f)·g·r² / η
Poiseuille (pipe): Q = (π·R⁴·ΔP) / (8·η·L)
Velocity profile (pipe): v(r) = (ΔP/(4·η·L))(R² − r²)
Reynolds number: Re = ρ·v·D / η = v·D / ν
Laminar pipe f = 64 / Re

Viscosity.front: Common exam pitfalls in viscosity problems (short list).
Viscosity.back:
1) Confusing η and ν (units differ).
2) Using Poiseuille's law outside laminar regime.
3) Forgetting factor 8 in Q formula or using diameter vs radius.
4) Applying Stokes law at high Re.
5) Ignoring temperature dependence of η when needed.

Viscosity.front: Sample short question style: 'Calculate flow rate Q for water (η = 1.0×10⁻³ Pa·s) through pipe R = 1 cm, L = 2 m, ΔP = 1000 Pa.' (approach).
Viscosity.back: Use Hagen–Poiseuille: Q = π·R⁴·ΔP / (8·η·L). Convert R = 0.01 m → R⁴ = 1e-8 m⁴. Then Q = π·1e-8·1000 / (8·1e-3·2) = π·1e-5 / (0.016) ≈ (3.1416e-5) / 0.016 ≈ 1.96×10⁻³ m³·s⁻¹ (approx).

Viscosity.front: Final exam strategy tips for viscosity topics.
Viscosity.back: 1) Identify flow regime (compute Re). 2) Use appropriate relation (Stokes, Poiseuille, or turbulent correlations). 3) Keep units consistent (SI). 4) Check limiting cases (η → 0 or large r). 5) Remember geometric factors (radius vs diameter).

Elasticity.front: What is elasticity (basic idea)?
Elasticity.back: Elasticity is the property of a material to regain its original shape and size after removal of deforming forces (within elastic limit).

Elasticity.front: Define stress (basic types) and its SI unit.
Elasticity.back: Stress σ = force / area. Types: tensile/compressive stress, shear stress τ. SI unit: pascal (Pa) = N·m⁻². Dimensional formula: M·L⁻¹·T⁻².

Elasticity.front: Define strain (basic types) and its nature.
Elasticity.back: Strain is measure of deformation (dimensionless). Types: linear (engineering) strain ε = ΔL / L, shear strain γ = displacement / transverse distance, volumetric strain ΔV / V.

Elasticity.front: Hooke's law (linear elasticity) — statement.
Elasticity.back: Within proportional limit, stress ∝ strain. For uniaxial tension: σ = E·ε where E is Young's modulus (elastic modulus).

Elasticity.front: What is Young's modulus E? Units and dimension.
Elasticity.back: Young's modulus E (tensile modulus) measures stiffness under uniaxial load: E = σ / ε. Unit: Pa (N·m⁻²). Dimensional formula: M·L⁻¹·T⁻².

Elasticity.front: Formula for elongation of a rod under axial load (ΔL).
Elasticity.back: For rod of length L, cross-section A, under axial force F: ε = ΔL / L = F / (A·E) → ΔL = F·L / (A·E).

Elasticity.front: Spring constant of an elastic rod (relation to E).
Elasticity.back: For a rod acting as spring: k = F / ΔL = A·E / L. Strain energy stored U = 1/2·k·(ΔL)² = 1/2·F·ΔL.

Elasticity.front: Define shear modulus (modulus of rigidity) G and relation to shear stress.
Elasticity.back: Shear modulus G: τ = G·γ where τ is shear stress and γ is shear strain. Unit: Pa. Relation with E and ν: E = 2·G·(1 + ν).

Elasticity.front: Define bulk modulus K (volume modulus) and relation to volumetric strain.
Elasticity.back: Bulk modulus K: relates pressure change to volumetric strain: Δp = −K·(ΔV / V) or volumetric strain = −Δp / K. Unit: Pa. Relation with E and ν: E = 3·K·(1 − 2·ν).

Elasticity.front: What is Poisson's ratio ν and typical range for isotropic materials?
Elasticity.back: Poisson's ratio ν = −(lateral strain / longitudinal strain) (for tensile). For isotropic stable materials −1 < ν < 0.5. Most metals: ~0.25–0.35. For incompressible material ν ≈ 0.5.

Elasticity.front: Relations between elastic moduli (E, G, K, ν).
What is tensile/compressive strength, yield strength and elastic limit?
Elasticity.back: Elastic limit: max stress for reversible deformation. Yield strength: stress at which plastic (permanent) deformation begins. Ultimate tensile strength: maximum stress material sustains before necking/failure.

Elasticity.front: Stress–strain curve for ductile vs brittle materials — key features to note.
Elasticity.back: Ductile: distinct proportional limit, elastic limit, yield point, large plastic region, necking, fracture. Brittle: little/no plastic region, fracture soon after elastic limit. Area under curve = energy per unit volume (toughness).

Elasticity.front: Proportional limit, elastic limit, yield point, ultimate stress — short definitions.
Elasticity.back: Proportional limit: end of linear σ∝ε. Elastic limit: max reversible stress. Yield point: stress where significant plastic strain at nearly constant stress. Ultimate stress: peak stress before failure.

Elasticity.front: Work done (strain energy) in stretching a rod — formula.
Elasticity.back: Work done (elastic strain energy) for axial stretch: U = 1/2·F·ΔL = 1/2·σ·ε·(volume) = 1/2·E·ε²·(V). Strain energy per unit volume = 1/2·σ·ε = 1/2·E·ε².

Elasticity.front: Define modulus of resilience and modulus of toughness.
Elasticity.back:
Modulus of resilience = energy per unit volume absorbed up to yield = (1/2)·σ_y² / E.
Toughness = total energy per unit volume absorbed up to fracture = area under entire stress–strain curve.

Elasticity.front: Shear stress in torsion of a solid circular shaft (formula).
Elasticity.back: For shaft radius r and polar moment J, shear stress τ(r) = T·r / J. Max shear at outer surface τ_max = T·c / J where c is outer radius. J (solid circular) = π·d⁴ / 32 (d = diameter).

Elasticity.front: Angle of twist and torsional stiffness (relation).
Elasticity.back: Angle of twist θ (radians) for shaft length L: θ = T·L / (J·G). T is torque, J polar moment, G shear modulus.

Elasticity.front: Polar moment of inertia J for solid and hollow circular shafts.
Elasticity.back:
Solid circular: J = π·d⁴ / 32.
Hollow circular: J = (π / 32)·(d_o⁴ − d_i⁴) where d_o outer diameter, d_i inner diameter.

Elasticity.front: Bending stress (flexure formula) for beams.
Elasticity.back: For bending moment M, bending stress at distance y from neutral axis: σ = M·y / I where I is second moment of area about neutral axis. Maximum at extreme fibre y = c (distance to outermost fiber).

Elasticity.front: Second moment of area (area moment of inertia) — common formulas.
Elasticity.back:
Rectangle about centroidal neutral axis (base b, height h): I = b·h³ / 12.
Circle (diameter d): I = π·d⁴ / 64.
Parallel axis theorem: I = I_centroid + A·d².

Elasticity.front: Neutral axis — definition and significance in bending.
Elasticity.back: Neutral axis is line in cross-section where longitudinal fibers experience zero strain during bending; above it fibers in compression, below in tension (or vice versa depending on sign).

Elasticity.front: Deflection of beams — cantilever with end load formula.
Elasticity.back: Cantilever length L with end load F: maximum deflection at free end δ = F·L³ / (3·E·I).

Elasticity.front: Deflection of simply supported beam with central load P formula.
Elasticity.back: Simply supported span L with central load P: maximum deflection at midspan δ_max = P·L³ / (48·E·I).

Elasticity.front: Shear force V and bending moment M relations (beam).
Elasticity.back: Differential relations: dV/dx = −w(x) (w = distributed load), dM/dx = V(x). Use sign conventions consistently.

Elasticity.front: Elastic bending energy (strain energy) in a beam (basic idea).
Elasticity.back: Strain energy in bending U = ∫ (M² / (2·E·I)) dx over beam length. This relates bending moment distribution to stored elastic energy.

Elasticity.front: Relation between speed of longitudinal waves in rod and E.
Elasticity.back: Speed of longitudinal (elastic) waves in a thin rod: v = √(E / ρ) where ρ is material density. (Use for rod wave problems — valid for long slender rods.)

Elasticity.front: Bulk modulus and speed of sound in fluids/solids (brief).
Elasticity.back: Speed of sound in fluid v = √(K / ρ) where K is bulk modulus. (In solids more complex due to shear effects; longitudinal v = √(E (1−ν) / (ρ(1+ν)(1−2ν))) for isotropic solids.)

Elasticity.front: What is Poisson effect — qualitative and formula?
Elasticity.back: Poisson effect: lateral contraction when material stretched longitudinally. Relation: lateral strain ε_lat = −ν·ε_long where ν is Poisson's ratio.

Elasticity.front: Composite bars in series and parallel — effective stiffness formulas.
Elasticity.back:
Series (different L_i, same force): total ΔL = Σ (F·L_i / (A_i·E_i)).
Parallel (same ΔL, different area/material): total F = Σ (E_i·A_i / L)·ΔL → effective k = Σ (E_i·A_i / L).

Elasticity.front: Temperature effects — thermal stress in constrained members.
Elasticity.back: If member free: thermal expansion ΔL_th = α·L·ΔT. If constrained (no expansion), thermal stress σ_th = E·α·ΔT (approx, if within elastic limit). α is coefficient of linear expansion.

Elasticity.front: Elastic stability — buckling of columns (Euler load for ideal column).
Elasticity.back: Euler critical load for slender column: P_cr = (π²·E·I) / (K·L)² where K is column effective length factor (depends on end conditions), L actual length. Buckling occurs when axial compressive load exceeds P_cr.

Elasticity.front: End condition factors K for common column supports.
Elasticity.back: Both ends pinned: K·L = L (K = 1). Both ends fixed: effective length = L / √2 (K = 0.5?). (Common exam values: pinned–pinned: K = 1; fixed–fixed: K = 0.5; fixed–free (cantilever): K = 2; fixed–pinned: K ≈ 0.7). Use standard table.

Elasticity.front: Stress concentration and notch sensitivity (qualitative).
Elasticity.back: Sharp corners, holes, notches cause local stress concentration (factor k_t > 1) increasing local stress relative to nominal. Design uses fillets or increase section to reduce concentration.

Elasticity.front: Elastic vs plastic deformation — definitions and energy implications.
Elasticity.back: Elastic deformation reversible; energy stored as recoverable strain energy. Plastic deformation irreversible; energy dissipated (heat, microstructural changes). Hysteresis seen in load–unload curves for plastic materials.

Elasticity.front: Young's modulus experimental methods (brief list).
Elasticity.back: Common methods: tensile test (stress–strain curve), bending (beam deflection), longitudinal wave speed in rod, Searle's or dynamic methods, resonance methods.

Elasticity.front: Relation of spring (coil) constant with material E (qualitative).
Elasticity.back: Helical spring stiffness k_s depends on shear modulus G, wire diameter d, mean coil diameter D, and number of active coils n: k_s ≈ (G·d⁴) / (8·D³·n) for round wire spring (approx).

Elasticity.front: Torsion vs bending energy comparison (qualitative).
Elasticity.back: Both store elastic energy; bending energy ∝ ∫ M²/(2 E I) dx; torsional energy ∝ ∫ T²/(2 G J) dx. Choice depends on dominant deformation mode.

Elasticity.front: Practical definitions: ductility, brittleness, malleability, hardness in elastic/plastic context.
Elasticity.back:
Ductility: ability to undergo plastic deformation before fracture (high strain at failure).
Brittleness: little plastic deformation.
Malleability: compressive forming ability.
Hardness: resistance to surface indentation (not directly elastic property).

Elasticity.front: Elastic limit vs proportional limit — difference.
Elasticity.back: Proportional limit: end of linear σ–ε behaviour. Elastic limit: maximum stress for which deformation is fully reversible. Elastic limit can be slightly higher than proportional limit for some materials.

Elasticity.front: Stress transformation and principal stresses (2D plane stress basics).
Elasticity.back: Principal stresses σ₁, σ₂ obtained by solving stress transformation equations: σ_avg = (σ_x + σ_y)/2; radius R = √[((σ_x − σ_y)/2)² + τ_xy²]; σ₁,₂ = σ_avg ± R. Mohr's circle used for visualization.

Elasticity.front: Tresca and von Mises yield criteria (brief concept).
Elasticity.back: Yielding under multiaxial stress predicted by criteria: Tresca uses maximum shear stress; von Mises uses distortion energy (common in ductile material design). Formulas often given in advanced courses (conceptual note).

Elasticity.front: Fatigue and endurance limit (brief introduction).
Elasticity.back: Repeated cyclic stresses can cause failure at stress levels below static yield (fatigue). Endurance limit is stress amplitude below which infinite life expected for some materials (e.g., steels).

Elasticity.front: Viscoelasticity (qualitative) — time dependent elasticity.
Elasticity.back: Viscoelastic materials show both elastic (recoverable) and viscous (time-dependent) behaviour: creep (increasing strain under constant stress) and stress relaxation (decreasing stress under constant strain).

Elasticity.front: Creep and relaxation — short definitions.
Elasticity.back:
Creep: gradual increase in strain under constant stress over time.
Stress relaxation: decrease in stress over time under constant strain (important at high temperatures).

Elasticity.front: Example quick calculation: elongation of steel rod — approach.
Elasticity.back: Given F, L, A, E: ΔL = F·L / (A·E). Use consistent SI units, compute stress and ensure within elastic limit (σ < σ_y).

Elasticity.front: How to compute energy stored in a stretched bar per unit volume.
Elasticity.back: Strain energy density u = (1/2)·σ·ε = (1/2)·E·ε² = σ² / (2·E). Multiply by volume for total energy.

Elasticity.front: Design concept: factor of safety (FoS) in elastic design.
Elasticity.back: FoS = allowable stress / working stress (or ultimate strength / working stress) chosen to ensure safe operation under uncertainties. Elastic design ensures working stress usually below proportional/elastic limit.

Elasticity.front: Common pitfalls in elasticity problems (exam tips).
Elasticity.back:
1) Confusing engineering strain vs true strain.
2) Mixing units (mm vs m).
3) Using wrong moment of inertia formula.
4) Using E where G/K required.
5) Forgetting sign conventions for bending and torsion.

Elasticity.front: Quick formula cheat-sheet (important formulas).
Elasticity.back: σ = F / A; ε = ΔL / L; σ = E·ε; ΔL = F·L / (A·E); k = A·E / L; τ = G·γ; E = 2·G·(1 + ν); E = 3·K·(1 − 2·ν); bending σ = M·y / I; I_rect = b·h³ / 12; I_circle = π·d⁴ / 64; J_solid = π·d⁴ / 32; θ = T·L / (J·G); δ_cantilever = F·L³ / (3·E·I).

Elasticity.front: Final exam strategy for elasticity chapter.
Elasticity.back:
1) Draw clear free-body and deformation diagrams.
2) Identify whether axial, bending, torsion or combined.
3) Choose correct formula (use E, G or K appropriately).
4) Check units and limits (σ < σ_y for elastic formulas).
5) Use energy methods (U = 1/2·F·Δ) when convenient.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: What is Simple Harmonic Motion (SHM)?
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: SHM is periodic motion in which acceleration is directly proportional to displacement from equilibrium and directed towards it: a = −ω²·x. Motion is sinusoidal in time.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Standard equation of motion for SHM (linear).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: d²x/dt² + ω²·x = 0, where ω is angular frequency (rad·s⁻¹). General solution: x(t) = A·cos(ω·t + φ).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Meaning of parameters A, ω and φ.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: A = amplitude (maximum |x|). ω = angular frequency (rad·s⁻¹). φ = phase constant (initial phase) determined by initial conditions.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Relation between angular frequency ω, frequency f and period T.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: ω = 2·π·f and T = 1 / f. Thus T = 2·π / ω and f = ω / (2·π).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Velocity and acceleration in SHM (expressions).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back:
x(t) = A·cos(ω·t + φ).
v(t) = dx/dt = −A·ω·sin(ω·t + φ).
a(t) = d²x/dt² = −A·ω²·cos(ω·t + φ) = −ω²·x(t).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Maximum speed and maximum acceleration.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back:
v_max = A·ω.
a_max = A·ω².

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Phase relationship between x, v and a.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Velocity v leads displacement x by phase π/2 (v is 90° ahead if x is cos). Acceleration a is exactly opposite phase to x (a = −ω²·x).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Expression for total energy in SHM (mass–spring).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: For mass m and spring constant k (ω² = k/m): E_total = K + U = 1/2·m·v² + 1/2·k·x² = 1/2·k·A² (constant).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Energy interchange during SHM (qualitative).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: At maximum displacement x = ±A: K = 0, U = 1/2·k·A². At equilibrium x = 0: U = 0, K = 1/2·k·A². Energy oscillates between kinetic and potential.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Derive ω for mass–spring system.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Equation: m·d²x/dt² = −k·x → d²x/dt² + (k/m)·x = 0. Hence ω = √(k / m).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Period of oscillation for mass–spring system.
SHM as projection of uniform circular motion (concept).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Projection of uniform circular motion of radius A on a diameter gives x(t) = A·cos(ω·t + φ) — provides geometric understanding of phase and sinusoidal form.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Simple pendulum small-angle approximation and equation.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: For small θ (in radians) sinθ ≈ θ. Equation: d²θ/dt² + (g / l)·θ = 0. So ω = √(g / l) and period T = 2·π·√(l / g).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Physical pendulum — expression for ω and T.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: For rigid body about pivot: I·d²θ/dt² = −m·g·d·θ (small angles), where d = distance from pivot to center of mass, I = moment of inertia. ω = √(m·g·d / I). T = 2·π·√(I / (m·g·d)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Relation between SHM and circular frequency for pendulum and spring.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Both give form d²x/dt² + ω²·x = 0. ω is √(k/m) for spring and √(g/l) for small-angle simple pendulum.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Define angular amplitude and phase constant from initial conditions.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Given x(0) = x₀ and v(0) = v₀, amplitude A = √(x₀² + (v₀/ω)²), phase φ = arctan(−v₀/(ω·x₀)) adjusted to correct quadrant.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Alternative form using sine/cosine only (two-constant form).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: x(t) = C·cos(ω·t) + D·sin(ω·t), where C and D determined by initial conditions. Equivalent to A·cos(ω·t + φ) with A = √(C² + D²).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Damped harmonic oscillator equation (general).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: m·d²x/dt² + b·dx/dt + k·x = 0, where b is damping coefficient (N·s·m⁻¹). Define γ = b / (2·m).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Damping regimes and discriminant.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back:
Characteristic: r = −γ ± √(γ² − ω₀²) where ω₀ = √(k/m).
Underdamped: γ < ω₀ → oscillatory with exponentially decaying amplitude.
Critically damped: γ = ω₀ → fastest return without oscillation.
Overdamped: γ > ω₀ → non-oscillatory slow return.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Solution for underdamped oscillator.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: x(t) = A·e^{−γ·t}·cos(ω_d·t + φ), where ω_d = √(ω₀² − γ²) is damped angular frequency.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Energy decay in lightly damped oscillator.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Total energy decays as E(t) ∝ e^{−2·γ·t} for underdamped SHM (since amplitude decays ∝ e^{−γ·t}).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Logarithmic decrement δ (definition & formula).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Logarithmic decrement δ = ln(x_n / x_{n+1}) for successive peak amplitudes. For underdamped: δ = 2·π·γ / ω_d ≈ 2·π·γ / ω₀ for small damping.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Quality factor Q (definition) and relation to damping.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Q = ω₀ / (2·γ). High Q → low damping, narrow resonance. Energy lost per cycle ≈ 2·π / Q fraction of total energy.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Forced (driven) harmonic oscillator equation.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: m·d²x/dt² + b·dx/dt + k·x = F_0·cos(ω·t) (external drive of frequency ω). Seek steady-state solution of form x_p(t) = X·cos(ω·t − δ).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Amplitude of steady-state driven oscillator (formula).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: X(ω) = F_0 / √[ (k − m·ω²)² + (b·ω)² ]. Using ω₀² = k / m rewrite: X = (F_0 / m) / √[ (ω₀² − ω²)² + (2·γ·ω)² ].

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Phase lag δ between drive and response (formula).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: tanδ = (b·ω) / (k − m·ω²) = (2·γ·ω) / (ω₀² − ω²). δ → π/2 at resonance for lightly damped case.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Resonance frequency for driven damped oscillator.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Resonant peak occurs near ω_r = √(ω₀² − 2·γ²). For weak damping (γ ≪ ω₀), ω_r ≈ ω₀. Undamped ideal (b = 0) gives singularity at ω = ω₀.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Power absorbed by driven oscillator (average).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Average power P_avg = (1/2)·F_0·X·cosδ = (1/2)·(F_0² / m) · (γ·ω²) / [ (ω₀² − ω²)² + (2·γ·ω)² ]. Max power near resonance.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Beats phenomenon — cause and beat frequency.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Beats occur when two close frequencies superpose: x = A·cos(ω₁t) + A·cos(ω₂t) ≈ 2A·cos(Δω·t/2)·cos(ω_avg·t). Beat frequency = |ω₁ − ω₂| / (2·π) in cycles·s⁻¹ or Δf = |f₁ − f₂|.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Superposition principle for linear oscillators (idea).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Because equations are linear, general solution is sum of homogeneous (transient) and particular (steady-state) solutions. Transients decay for damped systems leaving steady-state.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Initial transient vs steady-state in driven oscillator.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Transient solution uses homogeneous equation and decays like e^{−γ·t} (if damped). Steady-state persists with drive frequency ω and amplitude X(ω).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Small oscillations and potential near stable equilibrium.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Near stable equilibrium, potential U(x) ≈ U_0 + 1/2·k_eff·x². Small oscillations about equilibrium are SHM with ω = √(k_eff / m). Useful to linearize nonlinear systems.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Example: small oscillations of a bead on a smooth wire — approach.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Find equilibrium point, expand potential/force to second order in displacement, identify k_eff from second derivative of potential, then ω = √(k_eff / m).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Torsional (rotational) SHM — equation and ω.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: I·d²θ/dt² + C·θ = 0 where C is torsional constant. ω = √(C / I). Analogous to linear mass–spring with I ↔ m and C ↔ k.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Small oscillation of simple pendulum vs physical pendulum — when to use which.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Use simple pendulum formula T = 2·π·√(l/g) for point mass on massless string. For rigid body (extended mass) use physical pendulum T = 2·π·√(I / (m·g·d)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Phase-space plot for SHM (x vs v) — shape and meaning.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Phase trajectory is an ellipse: (x/A)² + (v/(A·ω))² = 1. Shows constant total energy; orientation gives phase relation between x and v.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Relation between amplitude and energy (mass–spring).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: E = 1/2·k·A². So amplitude A = √(2·E / k).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Dimension check for SHM equation terms.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: In d²x/dt² + ω²·x = 0, ω² has dimension T⁻² so ω has dimension T⁻¹ (rad·s⁻¹); ensures dimensional consistency.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Common small-angle pitfalls for pendulum problems.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Small-angle approx sinθ ≈ θ valid only when θ in radians and θ ≪ 1 (say < ~0.1 rad ≈ 5.7° for good accuracy). For larger amplitudes period increases slightly (nonlinear correction).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Amplitude dependence of period for simple pendulum (nonlinear effect).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: For finite amplitude, period increases with amplitude. Leading correction: T ≈ 2·π·√(l/g)·[1 + (1/16)·θ_0² + ...] where θ_0 is maximum angular amplitude in radians.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Use of energy method to get period (example mass–spring).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Set E = 1/2·k·A² = 1/2·m·v² + 1/2·k·x² → dx/dt = ±ω·√(A² − x²). Integrate dt = dx / v to obtain period T = 4·∫_0^{A} dx / (ω·√(A² − x²)) = 2·π / ω.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Free oscillation frequency vs driven response frequency (key point).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Free (natural) frequency = ω₀ = √(k/m). Driven steady-state response has amplitude peak near ω₀ but actual resonance ω_r depends on damping (ω_r = √(ω₀² − 2·γ²)).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Practical resonance examples and dangers.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Resonance occurs in bridges, buildings, machines — large amplitudes can cause failure. Engineers avoid driving frequencies near natural frequencies or add damping to reduce Q.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Analogy: LC circuit as SHM (electrical analogue).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: LC circuit differential: d²q/dt² + (1/LC)·q = 0. Charge q analogous to displacement x, inductance L analogous to mass m, capacitance C analogous to 1/k. ω = 1/√(L·C).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Beats in mechanical and electrical oscillators (analogy).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Two oscillators with close frequencies superpose to give amplitude modulation (beats) with beat frequency equal to frequency difference; same appears in acoustics and electronics.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Experimental determination of ω and damping γ from data.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Fit x(t) peaks to A·e^{−γ·t} to find γ from slope of ln(amplitude) vs t (logarithmic decrement). Extract ω_d from period of decaying oscillation; ω₀ = √(ω_d² + γ²).

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Quality factor Q from resonance width (frequency domain).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Q ≈ ω_r / Δω where Δω is full width at half maximum (FWHM) of amplitude squared (power) vs ω curve; for lightly damped Q large and Δω small.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Practical exam tips for SHM problems (checklist).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: 1) Identify if linearization (small-angle) is valid. 2) Write equation in standard form d²x/dt² + 2·γ·dx/dt + ω₀²·x = F(t)/m. 3) Solve homogeneous + particular. 4) Use energy methods when easier. 5) Keep track of units.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Common mistakes students make in SHM questions.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: Confusing ω and f, mixing degrees/radians for angles, forgetting sign conventions, using small-angle for large θ, ignoring damping when asked about steady-state resonance amplitude.

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Short formula cheat-sheet for SHM (quick reference).
Simple Harmonic Motion.back:
Equation: d²x/dt² + ω₀²·x = 0
Solution: x = A·cos(ω₀·t + φ)
ω₀ = √(k/m) (spring)
T = 2·π/ω₀, f = ω₀/(2·π)
v_max = A·ω₀, a_max = A·ω₀²
Damped: γ = b/(2m), ω_d = √(ω₀² − γ²)
Forced amplitude: X = (F_0/m)/√[(ω₀² − ω²)² + (2γω)²]

Simple Harmonic Motion.front: Short example: find amplitude given initial x₀ and v₀.
Simple Harmonic Motion.back: A = √(x₀² + (v₀/ω₀)²). Phase φ = arctan(−v₀/(ω₀·x₀)) (choose correct quadrant).

Waves.front: What is a wave (basic definition)?
Waves.back: A wave is a disturbance that transfers energy and momentum through a medium or space without bulk transport of matter. Examples: water waves, sound waves, electromagnetic waves.

Waves.front: Types of waves (classification).
Waves.back:
By medium: mechanical (require medium) vs electromagnetic (need no medium).
By displacement: transverse (particle displacement ⟂ propagation) vs longitudinal (displacement ∥ propagation).
By dimensionality: 1D, 2D, 3D waves.
By form: progressive (travelling) vs standing (stationary).

Waves.front: Wave function for a travelling harmonic wave (standard form).
Waves.back:
y(x,t) = A·sin(k·x − ω·t + φ) or y(x,t) = A·cos(k·x − ω·t + φ).
A = amplitude, k = wave number, ω = angular frequency, φ = phase constant.

Waves.front: Definitions of k and ω and their relations to λ and f.
Waves.back:
Wave number k = 2·π / λ (rad·m⁻¹).
Angular frequency ω = 2·π·f (rad·s⁻¹).
λ = wavelength, f = frequency, T = period = 1 / f.

Waves.front: Basic dispersion relation and phase velocity.
Waves.back:
For harmonic wave ω(k) is dispersion relation.
Phase velocity v_p = ω / k (m·s⁻¹) — speed of phase fronts.

Waves.front: Relation between wave speed, frequency and wavelength.
Waves.back: v = f·λ = ω / k. (Use consistent units: m·s⁻¹, Hz, m.)

Waves.front: Progressive vs standing waves — key differences.
Waves.back:
Progressive wave: energy transports along medium; waveform moves.
Standing wave: formed by superposition of two counter-propagating waves of same frequency and amplitude; no net energy transport (nodes and antinodes appear).

Waves.front: Formation of standing waves on a string — condition.
Waves.back: Standing waves form when incident and reflected waves interfere: y = 2A·sin(kx)·cos(ωt) (example). Allowed wavelengths on string length L with fixed ends: λ_n = 2L / n where n = 1,2,3,...

Waves.front: Nodes and antinodes in standing waves — definitions & spacing.
Waves.back:
Nodes: points with zero displacement at all times (fixed).
Antinodes: points with maximum amplitude.
Distance between adjacent nodes (or adjacent antinodes) = λ/2. Distance node→antinode = λ/4.

Waves.front: Natural frequencies (harmonics) of a string fixed at both ends.
Waves.back: f_n = n·v / (2·L) where n = 1,2,3,... and v = wave speed on string. Fundamental (n=1) has λ = 2L.

Waves.front: Wave speed on a stretched string (formula).
Waves.back: v = √(T / μ) where T is tension (N) and μ is linear mass density (kg·m⁻¹).

Waves.front: Energy in a travelling wave on a string (average power).
Waves.back: Average power transmitted P_avg = (1/2)·μ·ω²·A²·v. Energy density ∝ A². (μ = linear density, A = amplitude, v = wave speed.)

Waves.front: Superposition principle and linearity.
Waves.back: For linear wave equations, net displacement = algebraic sum of individual wave displacements. Leads to interference, beats, standing waves.

Waves.front: Interference — constructive and destructive conditions (phase difference).
Waves.back:
Constructive interference: phase difference Δφ = 2·m·π → path difference Δ = m·λ.
Destructive interference: Δφ = (2·m + 1)·π → path difference Δ = (m + 1/2)·λ. m integer.

Waves.front: Path difference and phase difference relation.
Waves.back: Phase difference Δφ = (2·π / λ)·(path difference Δ) = k·Δ. Use when comparing waves from two sources to a point.

Waves.front: Young's double slit (fringe positions on screen).
Waves.back: For slit separation d and screen distance D (D ≫ d), fringe maxima at y_m = (m·λ·D) / d, minima at y = ((m + 1/2)·λ·D) / d. Fringe spacing Δy = λ·D / d.

Waves.front: Diffraction by single slit — first minima condition.
Waves.back: Single-slit minima at a·sinθ = m·λ where a = slit width and m = ±1, ±2,... (m ≠ 0). Central maximum width ≈ 2·λ / a (small-angle approx).

Waves.front: Diffraction grating condition for maxima.
Waves.back: For grating spacing d (distance between adjacent slits) maxima: d·sinθ = n·λ where n = 0, ±1, ±2,... Order n.

Waves.front: Huygens' principle (qualitative).
Waves.back: Every point on a wavefront can be considered a source of secondary wavelets; sum of these wavelets forms the new wavefront. Useful for explaining reflection, refraction, diffraction.

Waves.front: Reflection of wave — fixed vs free end (string).
Waves.back: Fixed end: reflected wave is inverted (phase change π). Free end: reflected wave not inverted (no phase change). This affects node/antinode positions.

Waves.front: Transmission and partial reflection at boundary (qualitative).
Waves.back: When a wave encounters boundary between media with different impedances, part is transmitted and part reflected. Reflection sign depends on relative impedances (phase inversion possible).

Waves.front: Acoustic impedance (mechanical) concept (Z).
Waves.back: Acoustic impedance Z = ρ·v for medium (ρ density, v wave speed). Ratio of pressures to particle velocity; governs reflection/transmission at interfaces.

Waves.front: Doppler effect (moving source and/or observer) — formula (one-dimensional).
Waves.back:
Observed frequency f' = f · (v ± v_o) / (v ∓ v_s).
v = wave speed in medium, v_o = observer speed (+ toward source), v_s = source speed (+ toward observer). Upper signs apply when observer moves toward source / source moves toward observer as appropriate — careful with sign convention.

Waves.front: Doppler effect special cases.
Waves.back:
Stationary observer, moving source: f' = f·(v / (v ∓ v_s)).
Moving observer, stationary source: f' = f·(1 ± v_o / v).
For sound in air, treat v as speed of sound in air (≈ 343 m·s⁻¹ at 20 °C).

Waves.front: Shock waves and Mach number (qualitative).
Waves.back: Mach number M = v_object / v_sound. If M > 1 object is supersonic and produces shock waves (cone, sonic boom).

Waves.front: Beats — cause and beat frequency formula.
Waves.back: Beats occur when two waves of nearly equal frequency f₁ and f₂ superpose: amplitude modulation at beat frequency f_beat = |f₁ − f₂|. Audible as pulsation.

Waves.front: Phase and group velocity (definition & relation).
Waves.back:
Phase velocity v_p = ω / k (speed of a monochromatic phase).
Group velocity v_g = dω / dk (speed of envelope or energy/pulse). In dispersive media v_g ≠ v_p.

Waves.front: Dispersion — dispersive vs non-dispersive media.
Waves.back: Dispersive: wave speed depends on frequency (ω/k varies) → wave packet spreads. Non-dispersive: v_p independent of frequency so wave packet travels without distortion (e.g., v = constant).

Waves.front: Wave equation in 1D (classical form).
Waves.back: ∂²y/∂x² = (1 / v²)·∂²y/∂t² for transverse waves on a string or pressure waves (suitably interpreted). Solutions are travelling wave functions y(x,t) = f(x − v·t) + g(x + v·t).

Waves.front: Boundary conditions for wave equation (examples).
Waves.back: Fixed end: y = 0 at that x for all t. Free end: ∂y/∂x = 0 at that x (slope zero). For pipes: open end pressure node, closed end pressure antinode.

Waves.front: Reflection and transmission coefficients (qualitative).
Waves.back: At interface between media A and B, amplitude reflection coefficient r and transmission coefficient t depend on impedances Z_A and Z_B: r = (Z_B − Z_A)/(Z_B + Z_A), t = 2·Z_B/(Z_B + Z_A) (definitions vary by convention). Energy reflection ∝ r².

Waves.front: Intensity of a wave — definition and relation to amplitude.
Waves.back: Intensity I = average power per unit area carried by wave. For mechanical waves I ∝ A². For sound, I = (p_rms²) / (ρ·v) (p_rms = root-mean-square pressure amplitude).

Waves.front: Sound intensity level in decibels (dB) — formula.
Waves.back: Sound level β (dB) = 10·log₁₀(I / I₀) where I₀ = 1.0×10⁻¹² W·m⁻² (reference). Every +10 dB ≈ perceived as twice as loud.

Waves.front: Inverse square law for point sources (intensity fall-off).
Waves.back: For isotropic point source radiating power P, intensity I = P / (4·π·r²) so I ∝ 1 / r² (neglecting absorption).

Waves.front: Speed of sound in air — approximate formulas.
Waves.back: Approximate: v ≈ 331 m·s⁻¹ + 0.6·T_C where T_C is temperature in °C. More generally v = √(γ·R·T / M) for ideal gas (γ ratio of specific heats, R universal gas constant, M molar mass).

Waves.front: Standing waves in pipes — open-open and open-closed conditions.
Waves.back:
Open–open pipe (both ends antinodes): f_n = n·v / (2·L), n = 1,2,3,...
Open–closed pipe (one end node, other antinode): f_n = n·v / (4·L), n = 1,3,5,... (only odd harmonics).

Waves.front: Relation between pressure nodes and displacement nodes in sound waves.
Waves.back: At displacement nodes (no particle motion), pressure has antinodes (max pressure variation). At displacement antinodes, pressure has nodes. Keep distinction clear for pipe problems.

Waves.front: Resonance — definition and examples.
Waves.back: Resonance occurs when a system is driven at a frequency close to its natural frequency, producing large amplitude response (limited by damping). Examples: organ pipe, tuning fork, bridge resonance.

Waves.front: Quality factor Q and bandwidth relation (brief).
Waves.back: Q = ω₀ / (2·γ) ≈ ω₀ / Δω where Δω is width of resonance (FWHM). High Q → sharp resonance, low damping.

Waves.front: Power delivered to a driven damped oscillator (frequency dependence).
Waves.back: Average power absorbed peaks near resonance and is proportional to (F_0²·γ·ω²) / [ (ω₀² − ω²)² + (2·γ·ω)² ]. Energy dissipation occurs via damping.

Waves.front: Group velocity example — wave packet on dispersive string (qualitative).
Waves.back: A wave packet composed of multiple Fourier components travels at group velocity v_g = dω/dk — energy/information speed. Phase of each component moves at v_p = ω/k.

Waves.front: Fourier decomposition idea for arbitrary waves (qualitative).
Waves.back: Any wave disturbance can be expressed as superposition (integral) of sinusoidal components (Fourier series/transform). Each component evolves by its dispersion relation.

Waves.front: Pulse broadening (dispersion) — consequence for signals.
Waves.back: In dispersive media different frequency components travel at different v_p or v_g → pulse spreads over time (important in optics and communications).

Waves.front: Reflection phase change for light at boundary (qualitative).
Waves.back: When a wave reflects from a medium of higher refractive index, phase changes by π (inversion). Reflection from lower index yields no phase inversion. Analogue exists for mechanical waves with impedance mismatch.

Waves.front: Refractive index and wave speed in medium (electromagnetic waves).
Waves.back: Refractive index n = c / v where c speed of light in vacuum and v speed in medium. Dispersion gives n(λ) dependence (chromatic dispersion).

Waves.front: Critical angle and total internal reflection (brief).
Waves.back: At interface n₁ > n₂, critical angle θ_c = arcsin(n₂ / n₁). For incidence θ > θ_c light undergoes total internal reflection; used in optical fibres.

Waves.front: Phase difference due to path around obstacle (diffraction interference qualitative).
Waves.back: Diffraction arises because wavelets from different parts of aperture have different path lengths and phases; interference of these produces observed intensity patterns.

Waves.front: Rayleigh criterion for resolving power (basic notion).
Waves.back: Two point sources are just resolved when principal maximum of one diffraction pattern falls on first minimum of the other. Angular resolution θ_min ≈ 1.22·λ / D for circular aperture (D diameter).

Waves.front: Standing wave on a stretched string — harmonic nodes positions (formula).
Waves.back: For nth harmonic (n = 1,2,...): nodes at x = m·(λ_n / 2) where m integer. λ_n = 2L / n and f_n = n·v / (2L).

Waves.front: Derive relation v = √(T/μ) for string waves (sketch).
Waves.back: Balance transverse forces on string element and linearize small-angle approximations to get wave equation ∂²y/∂x² = (1/v²)·∂²y/∂t² with v² = T/μ.

Waves.front: Practical units & conversions useful in wave problems.
Waves.back: Frequency: Hz = s⁻¹. Angular frequency ω in rad·s⁻¹. Wavelength in m. Intensity in W·m⁻². dB levels: 10·log₁₀(I/I₀) with I₀ = 10⁻¹² W·m⁻².

Waves.front: Common exam pitfalls in waves problems (short list).
Waves.back:
1) Confusing phase velocity and group velocity.
2) Using degrees instead of radians in trig/phase formulas.
3) Wrong sign convention in Doppler formula.
4) Mixing up node/antinode (displacement vs pressure for sound).
5) Forgetting boundary conditions (fixed/free/open/closed).

Waves.front: Quick formula cheat-sheet (important wave formulas).
Waves.back:
Wave eqn: ∂²y/∂x² = (1/v²)·∂²y/∂t²
Travelling wave: y = A·sin(kx − ωt + φ)
k = 2π/λ, ω = 2πf, v = f·λ
String speed: v = √(T/μ)
Pipe open–open: f_n = n·v/(2L)
Pipe open–closed: f_n = n·v/(4L), n odd
Double-slit: d·sinθ = m·λ
Single-slit minima: a·sinθ = m·λ
Doppler (1D): f' = f·(v ± v_o)/(v ∓ v_s)
Beats: f_beat = |f₁ − f₂|
Intensity level: β = 10·log₁₀(I/I₀)

Waves.front: Sample short problem: A string of length 1.2 m fixed at both ends supports 3rd harmonic with frequency 150 Hz. Find wave speed and wavelength.
Sample short problem: Doppler (simple): Source approaches stationary observer at 20 m·s⁻¹, source frequency 440 Hz, speed of sound 340 m·s⁻¹. Find observed f'.
Exam strategy: solving wave problems checklist.
Waves.back:
1) Identify wave type and boundary conditions.
2) Write correct form of wave function and sign convention.
3) Use k = 2π/λ, ω = 2πf.
4) Apply superposition, matching phases for interference.
5) Check units, use radians for trig and phases.
6) For sound, pay attention to pressure vs displacement nodes.

Waves.front: Final practical tips for students revising waves.
Waves.back: Memorise key formulas and meanings of symbols (k, ω, λ, f, v). Draw diagrams for interference/diffraction. Practice sign conventions for Doppler and reflection. Always check limiting cases (e.g., v→0, λ→∞) to catch mistakes.

Sound Waves.front: What is sound (basic definition)?
Sound Waves.back: Sound is a mechanical longitudinal wave of pressure and particle displacement that propagates through a material medium (solid, liquid or gas) by successive compressions and rarefactions.

Sound Waves.front: Types of sound waves (by frequency).
Sound Waves.back:
Infrasound: f < 20 Hz (below human hearing).
Audible sound: 20 Hz – 20 kHz (approximate human hearing range).
Ultrasound: f > 20 kHz (used in imaging, cleaning, echolocation).

Sound Waves.front: Longitudinal vs transverse in context of sound.
Sound Waves.back: Sound in fluids is longitudinal: particle displacement ∥ wave propagation. In solids both longitudinal and transverse elastic waves can propagate.

Sound Waves.front: Wave equation and harmonic plane wave (basic form).
Sound Waves.back: Plane harmonic wave: p(x,t) = p_m·sin(k·x − ω·t + φ) where p is pressure variation, p_m amplitude, k = 2·π/λ, ω = 2·π·f, λ wavelength, f frequency.

Sound Waves.front: Relation between speed, frequency and wavelength for sound.
Sound Waves.back: v = f·λ = ω / k. Use v for speed of sound in the medium (m·s⁻¹).

Sound Waves.front: Speed of sound in a medium — general formula (bulk modulus).
Sound Waves.back: v = √(B / ρ) where B is bulk modulus (N·m⁻²) of the medium and ρ its density (kg·m⁻³).

Sound Waves.front: Speed of sound in an ideal gas (useful forms).
Sound Waves.back: v = √(γ·R·T / M) (R = universal gas constant, M = molar mass) or v = √(γ·p / ρ). For dry air at 20 °C, v ≈ 343 m·s⁻¹.

Sound Waves.front: Typical value: speed of sound in air at 20 °C.
Sound Waves.back: Approximately v ≈ 343 m·s⁻¹ (use 340 m·s⁻¹ or 331 m·s⁻¹ depending on exam convention).

Sound Waves.front: Pressure variation and particle velocity relation (acoustic impedance).
Sound Waves.back: For a plane progressive wave p = Z·u where u is particle velocity and Z = ρ·v is acoustic impedance of the medium. Z has units Pa·s·m⁻¹ or kg·m⁻²·s⁻¹.

Sound Waves.front: Sound intensity — definition and unit.
Sound Waves.back: Intensity I is average power transmitted per unit area normal to propagation: I = P_avg / A. SI unit: W·m⁻². For plane wave I = p_{rms}² / (ρ·v).

Sound Waves.front: Sound intensity level (decibel scale).
Sound Waves.back: Sound level β (dB) = 10·log₁₀(I / I₀) where I₀ = 1.0×10⁻¹² W·m⁻² (threshold of hearing). Increase of 10 dB ≈ perceived ×2 loudness.

Sound Waves.front: Relation between pressure amplitude and intensity (plane wave).
Sound Waves.back: I = (p_{rms}²) / (ρ·v). For sinusoidal wave p_{rms} = p_m / √2 so I = p_m² / (2·ρ·v).

Sound Waves.front: Thresholds: hearing and pain (typical values).
Sound Waves.back:
Threshold of hearing: ~0 dB (I = 10⁻¹² W·m⁻²).
Comfortable speech: ~40 dB.
Loud traffic: ~80–90 dB.
Threshold of pain: ~120–130 dB (risk of hearing damage).

Sound Waves.front: Inverse-square law for sound intensity (point source).
Sound Waves.back: For an isotropic point source radiating power P, intensity I(r) = P / (4·π·r²) (neglecting absorption). So I ∝ 1 / r².

Sound Waves.front: Reflection of sound — echoes and conditions.
Sound Waves.back: Sound reflects from surfaces; an echo is heard when reflected sound arrives sufficiently after direct sound (rule of thumb: time delay ≥ 0.1 s → distinct echo). Distance for echo from wall ~ v·Δt/2.

Sound Waves.front: Absorption, transmission and reflection coefficients (qualitative).
Sound Waves.back: At boundary some sound is reflected, transmitted and absorbed. Reflection depends on impedance mismatch Z₁ vs Z₂. Absorption coefficient α (0–1) measures fraction energy absorbed by material.

Sound Waves.front: Reverberation and reverberation time (Sabine formula).
Sound Waves.back: Reverberation time T_{60} (s) ≈ 0.161·V / A where V is room volume (m³) and A = Σ(α_i·S_i) is total absorption (m² equivalent). T_{60} is time for sound level to drop 60 dB.

Sound Waves.front: Standing waves in pipes — open and closed ends (frequencies).
Sound Waves.back:
Open–open pipe: f_n = n·v / (2·L), n = 1,2,3,... (all harmonics).
Open–closed pipe: f_n = n·v / (4·L), n = 1,3,5,... (only odd harmonics).

Sound Waves.front: Nodes and antinodes for sound in pipes (pressure vs displacement).
Sound Waves.back: At an open end: displacement antinode and pressure node. At a closed end: displacement node and pressure antinode. Keep distinction between pressure and displacement patterns.

Sound Waves.front: Resonance and natural frequencies (qualitative).
Sound Waves.back: Resonance occurs when a system is driven at one of its natural frequencies resulting in large amplitude. In acoustics, resonant cavities or strings amplify particular frequencies (standing waves).

Sound Waves.front: Helmholtz resonator (basic idea).
Sound Waves.back: Helmholtz resonator: cavity + neck behaves like mass-spring acoustic system with resonant frequency f = (v / 2·π)·√(A / (V·L_{eff})) where A neck area, V cavity volume, L_{eff} effective neck length.

Sound Waves.front: Beat phenomenon — cause and beat frequency.
Sound Waves.back: Beats arise from superposition of two sound waves with close frequencies f₁ and f₂; amplitude modulates at beat frequency f_beat = |f₁ − f₂| producing audible beats.

Sound Waves.front: Interference of sound (constructive & destructive).
Sound Waves.back: Constructive interference when path difference Δ = m·λ. Destructive interference when Δ = (m + 1/2)·λ. Observed in double-source setups and noise-cancelling principles.

Sound Waves.front: Doppler effect for sound (moving source/observer) — general formula.
Sound Waves.back: Observed frequency f' = f·(v + v_o) / (v − v_s) where v speed of sound, v_o observer velocity (+ toward source), v_s source velocity (+ toward observer). Use careful sign convention.

Sound Waves.front: Doppler special cases — stationary observer or source.
Sound Waves.back:
Moving observer, stationary source: f' = f·(v ± v_o) / v.
Moving source, stationary observer: f' = f·v / (v ∓ v_s). (Top sign when motion toward other party.)

Sound Waves.front: Mach number and sonic boom (qualitative).
Sound Waves.back: Mach number M = v_object / v_sound. If M > 1 (supersonic), shock waves form; sonic boom heard on ground is due to abrupt pressure change from shock cone.

Sound Waves.front: Quality of sound: pitch, loudness, timbre (definitions).
Sound Waves.back:
Pitch: perceptual correlate of frequency.
Loudness: perceptual correlate of intensity (depends on frequency too).
Timbre (quality): character that distinguishes sounds of same pitch & loudness — depends on harmonic content and envelope.

Sound Waves.front: Harmonics and overtones in musical sounds.
Sound Waves.back: Fundamental frequency f₁ and harmonics at n·f₁ (n integer). Overtones are frequencies above fundamental; harmonic series shapes timbre of instrument.

Sound Waves.front: Fourier analysis — any periodic sound decomposed into harmonics.
Sound Waves.back: A periodic waveform can be represented as sum of sinusoidal components (Fourier series). Harmonic content and amplitudes determine waveform shape and timbre.

Sound Waves.front: Loudness scaling: phons and sones (concept).
Sound Waves.back:
Phon: loudness level in dB at which a 1 kHz tone is perceived equally loud.
Sone: scale where 1 sone = loudness of 1 kHz tone at 40 phon; doubling sones ≈ perceived twice as loud.

Sound Waves.front: Absorption coefficient α and soundproofing basics.
Sound Waves.back: Absorption coefficient α (0–1) fraction of incident energy absorbed by surface. Materials with high α (foams, carpets) reduce reverberation; mass and damping aid soundproofing (blocking transmission).

Sound Waves.front: Acoustic impedance and reflection at interface.
Sound Waves.back: Reflection coefficient r = (Z₂ − Z₁) / (Z₂ + Z₁) (amplitude). If impedances equal, no reflection; large mismatch → strong reflection. Z = ρ·v.

Sound Waves.front: Standing waves in rooms — room modes (qualitative).
Sound Waves.back: Room resonances (modes) occur at frequencies determined by room dimensions; produce local peaks/nulls in sound level and affect acoustics. Mode frequencies depend on boundary conditions and dimensions.

Sound Waves.front: Sabine absorption unit — concept of sabin.
Sound Waves.back: One sabin = absorption by 1 m² of perfectly absorbing surface. Total absorption A = Σ(α_i·S_i) measured in sabins; used in Sabine formula for reverberation time.

Sound Waves.front: Intensity addition in decibels — rule of thumb.
Sound Waves.back: Equal sources: two identical independent sources each of level β produce β + 3 dB total. In general add intensities (not dB): I_total = Σ I_i then β_total = 10·log₁₀(I_total / I₀).

Sound Waves.front: Masking effect (psychoacoustics) — brief idea.
Sound Waves.back: A loud sound at one frequency can mask (make inaudible) a quieter sound nearby in frequency. Important in audio coding and hearing tests.

Sound Waves.front: A-weighting (dB(A)) in sound measurement — practical note.
Sound Waves.back: A-weighting filters account for human ear sensitivity vs frequency; dB(A) used in regulations to represent perceived loudness rather than raw sound power.

Sound Waves.front: Sound power vs sound pressure — difference.
Sound Waves.back: Sound power P (W) is acoustic energy emitted per unit time by a source (intrinsic). Sound pressure p (Pa) is local pressure variation dependent on distance and environment; intensity relates both.

Sound Waves.front: Transmission loss and insertion loss (concepts for barriers).
Sound Waves.back: Transmission loss (TL) quantifies how much sound power is reduced by barrier (dB). Insertion loss measures reduction when barrier added; both depend on frequency and mass/rigidity of barrier.

Sound Waves.front: Echoes, reverberation and clarity (C80) — short definitions.
Sound Waves.back:
Echo: discrete delayed reflection.
Reverberation: dense field of overlapping reflections causing decay.
Clarity metrics (C80) compare early to late energy and affect speech/music intelligibility.

Sound Waves.front: Ultrasound applications (brief list).
Sound Waves.back: Medical imaging (diagnostic ultrasonography), non-destructive testing, cleaning, sonar, distance measurement, ultrasonic welding.

Sound Waves.front: Infrasonic applications & sources (brief).
Sound Waves.back: Infrasound used for monitoring volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, explosions, some animal communications (elephants). Natural sources include ocean waves and earthquakes.

Sound Waves.front: Human ear anatomy in brief (relevant to sound).
Sound Waves.back: Outer ear (pinna + ear canal) collects sound, eardrum (tympanic membrane) vibrates; middle ear ossicles transmit and amplify to inner ear; cochlea transduces mechanical vibrations to neural signals.

Sound Waves.front: Hearing protection and exposure limits (practical).
Sound Waves.back: Prolonged exposure above ~85 dB raises risk of hearing loss. Use hearing protection (earplugs/earmuffs) in noisy environments. Regulations specify exposure-duration vs level limits.

Sound Waves.front: Shock wave vs sound wave distinction.
Sound Waves.back: Sound waves are small-amplitude linear pressure variations. Shock waves are nonlinear steep fronts with abrupt pressure jump satisfying Rankine–Hugoniot conditions and dissipative processes; occur at supersonic speeds.

Sound Waves.front: Formula: wavelength of sound in air for given frequency.
Sound Waves.back: λ = v / f. Example: for f = 440 Hz (A4) and v = 343 m·s⁻¹, λ ≈ 0.78 m.

Sound Waves.front: Practical calculation example: distance from echo (given delay Δt).
Sound Waves.back: Distance to reflecting surface d = v·Δt / 2 (sound travels to wall and back). Example: delay 0.5 s → d = 343·0.5 / 2 ≈ 85.75 m.

Sound Waves.front: Common exam pitfalls in sound problems (short list).
Sound Waves.back:
1) Mixing up pressure node vs displacement node in pipes.
2) Using degrees instead of radians in phase relations.
3) Adding dB values directly instead of adding intensities.
4) Confusing sound power and sound pressure.
5) Wrong sign convention in Doppler formula.

Sound Waves.front: Cheat-sheet: key formulas for sound waves.
Sound Waves.back:
v = f·λ
v = √(B / ρ) or v = √(γ·R·T / M)
I = p_{rms}² / (ρ·v)
β (dB) = 10·log₁₀(I / I₀)
Doppler: f' = f·(v + v_o)/(v − v_s) (use correct signs)
Open–open pipe: f_n = n·v/(2L)
Open–closed pipe: f_n = n·v/(4L) (odd n)
Sabine: T_{60} ≈ 0.161·V / A

Sound Waves.front: Final exam tip for sound chapter.
Sound Waves.back: Draw clear diagrams (pipes, waves, paths). Distinguish pressure vs displacement, use radians for phase, convert dB → intensity when adding sources, and always check units (m, s, Pa, W·m⁻²).

Heat.back: Heat is energy transferred between systems (or a system and surroundings) due to a temperature difference. Symbol: Q. Unit: joule (J).

Heat.front: What is temperature and its SI unit?
Heat.back: Temperature is a measure of the hotness/coldness of a body related to average kinetic energy of particles. SI unit: kelvin (K). Common scales: Celsius (°C) and Fahrenheit (°F).
If A in thermal equilibrium with B and B with C, then A is in equilibrium with C. Establishes temperature as transitive property and basis for thermometry.
Heat is energy in transfer (extent depends on process); temperature is an intensive property indicating thermal state (not an amount).
Specific heat c is heat required to raise temperature of unit mass by 1 K: c = Q / (m·ΔT). Unit: J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹.
Molar heat capacity C_m is heat required to raise temperature of one mole by 1 K. Units: J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹. C = m·c / n relates mass-based and molar quantities.
Heat capacity C_total = Q / ΔT for whole body (J·K⁻¹) — depends on mass; specific heat c = C_total / m (J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹) independent of mass.
Heat lost by hotter bodies = heat gained by cooler bodies (neglecting losses): Σ m_i·c_i·ΔT_i = 0. Use for mixing, finding specific heats and latent heats.

Heat.front: Latent heat (definition) and latent heat of fusion/vaporization.
Heat.back: Latent heat L is heat absorbed/released during phase change at constant T per unit mass. Fusion L_f (melting/freezing) and vaporization L_v (boiling/condensation). Units: J·kg⁻¹.
Q = m·L (m mass, L latent heat). No temperature change during ideal phase change at constant pressure.

Heat.front: Specific heat relation for temperature change (constant c).
Heat.back: Q = m·c·ΔT for processes where c approximately constant over ΔT. For variable c: Q = ∫ m·c(T)·dT.
ΔU = Q − W (sign convention: ΔU increase = heat Q added to system minus work W done by system). Alternative conventions exist — be consistent.

Heat.front: Work done by/on a gas during quasi-static expansion/compression (PV work).
Heat.back: Work by gas W = ∫_{V_i}^{V_f} p·dV. For isobaric W = p·ΔV. Sign: positive when system does work on surroundings.

Heat.front: Isothermal process for ideal gas (work and heat).
Heat.back: For isothermal (T constant) ideal gas: ΔU = 0 → Q = W. Work W = n·R·T·ln(V_f/V_i) = n·R·T·ln(p_i/p_f) (use consistent variables).

Heat.front: Adiabatic process (definition & relation for ideal gas).
Heat.back: Adiabatic: no heat exchange (Q = 0). For reversible adiabatic ideal gas: p·V^γ = constant, TV^{γ−1} = constant, where γ = C_p / C_v.

Heat.front: Adiabatic index γ and typical values.
Heat.back: γ = C_p / C_v (ratio of molar heat capacities). Monoatomic ideal gas: γ = 5/3 ≈ 1.667. Diatomic (room T): γ ≈ 7/5 = 1.4.

Heat.front: Isobaric and isochoric processes (definitions & heat expressions).
Heat.back: Isobaric: constant pressure. Heat Q = n·C_p·ΔT (molar). Isochoric: constant volume. Work W = 0; Q = ΔU = n·C_v·ΔT.

Heat.front: Relation C_p − C_v = R (ideal gas, per mole).
Heat.back: For ideal gas: C_p − C_v = R (universal gas constant). Useful to compute one from the other.

Heat.front: Internal energy U of an ideal gas (dependence).
Heat.back: For ideal gas, internal energy U depends only on temperature: U = n·C_v·T (for constant C_v) or ΔU = n·C_v·ΔT.

Heat.front: Kinetic theory relation: average translational kinetic energy per molecule.
Heat.back: For monoatomic ideal gas: ⟨ε_kin⟩ = 3/2·k_B·T per molecule (k_B Boltzmann constant = 1.380649×10⁻²³ J·K⁻¹). Per mole: 3/2·R·T.
Each quadratic degree of freedom contributes (1/2)·k_B·T to average energy per particle in thermal equilibrium. Use to find C_v for ideal gases (classical regime).
p·V = n·R·T (n moles). For mass m and molar mass M: p·V = (m/M)·R·T. Also p = ρ·(R_specific)·T with R_specific = R / M.

Heat.front: Thermal expansion — linear, area and volume coefficients.
Heat.back: Linear expansion ΔL = α·L·ΔT (α linear coeff). Area expansion ≈ 2α for isotropic solids. Volume expansion β ≈ 3α (β is volume coeff).

Heat.front: Thermal strain and thermal stress (constrained expansion).
Heat.back: Free expansion causes no stress. If constrained, thermal stress σ_th ≈ E·α·ΔT (for linear elastic material, small strains) where E is Young's modulus.
Two metals with different α bonded together bend upon temperature change because one expands more — used in thermostats and switches.
Rate of heat conduction Q̇ = −k·A·(dT/dx) where k is thermal conductivity (W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹), A area, gradient dT/dx. Negative sign: heat flows from high to low T.

Heat.front: Thermal resistance and analogy to electrical resistance.
