Heat.back: For conduction through slab of thickness L and area A: R_th = L / (k·A). Then Q̇ = ΔT / R_th. For series/parallel layers resistances add like electrical resistances.
Total R_th = Σ (L_i / (k_i·A)). Heat flow Q̇ = ΔT_total / R_th. Useful for multi-layer insulation calculations.

Heat.front: Thermal conductivity k — typical values and materials behaviour.
Heat.back: Metals: high k (good conductors). Insulators (air, wood): low k. Units: W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹. Examples: copper ~ 400 W·m⁻¹·K⁻¹, water ~ 0.6, air ~ 0.025.
α = k / (ρ·c) (m²·s⁻¹). Measures speed at which temperature disturbances diffuse through a material.

Heat.front: Newton's law of cooling (convective heat transfer).
Heat.back: Rate of heat loss Q̇ = h·A·(T_surface − T_∞) where h is convective heat-transfer coefficient (W·m⁻²·K⁻¹), A area, T_∞ ambient temperature. Empirical h depends on flow conditions.

Heat.front: Convective regimes — free (natural) vs forced convection.
Heat.back: Free (natural): motion caused by density differences due to temperature gradients (buoyancy). Forced: external agent (fan, pump) causes flow; different correlations for h.
If Biot number Bi = h·L_c / k ≪ 1 (L_c characteristic length), temperature inside body is approximately uniform and T(t) solves exponential cooling: (T−T_∞)/(T₀−T_∞) = e^{−(h·A/(ρ·V·c))·t}.
Bi = h·L_c / k where L_c = V / A (characteristic length). Bi ≪ 1 → negligible internal gradients; Bi ≫ 1 → internal conduction significant.
Power radiated by blackbody: P = σ·A·T⁴ where σ ≈ 5.670374419×10⁻⁸ W·m⁻²·K⁻⁴. For real surface with emissivity ε: P = ε·σ·A·T⁴.
Emissivity ε (0–1) is ratio of radiation emitted to blackbody. Kirchhoff: at thermal equilibrium absorptivity = emissivity for each wavelength (a(λ) = ε(λ)).

Heat.front: Net radiative exchange between two surfaces (simple form).
Heat.back: For two black surfaces exchanging: Q̇ = σ·A·(T_1⁴ − T_2⁴). For gray bodies and geometry factors more complex (view factors needed).
λ_max·T = b where b ≈ 2.898×10⁻³ m·K. Hotter bodies radiate peak at shorter wavelengths.
Gray body: emissivity roughly independent of wavelength. Kirchhoff's law: ε(λ) = α(λ) at thermal equilibrium for each λ.
dp/dT = L / (T·Δv) where L is latent heat per mole and Δv change in molar volume between phases. Useful to estimate vapor pressure variation with T.
Boiling occurs when vapor pressure equals ambient pressure. Lower ambient pressure (high altitude) → lower boiling point; higher pressure (pressure cooker) → higher boiling point.

Heat.front: Heat engines — basic cycle and efficiency definition.
Heat.back: Heat engine absorbs Q_h from hot reservoir, does work W, rejects Q_c to cold reservoir. Efficiency η = W / Q_h = 1 − Q_c / Q_h (≤ Carnot limit).
Reversible Carnot efficiency: η_max = 1 − T_c / T_h (temperatures in K). No engine between two reservoirs can exceed this efficiency.
For refrigerator moving heat Q_c from cold to hot using work W: COP_R = Q_c / W. For Carnot refrigerator COP_max = T_c / (T_h − T_c).

Heat.front: Second law of thermodynamics — Kelvin–Planck and Clausius statements.
Heat.back: Kelvin–Planck: impossible to construct engine that converts heat from single reservoir fully into work. Clausius: heat cannot spontaneously flow from cold to hot without work.

Heat.front: Entropy S — definition for reversible heat transfer.
Heat.back: dS = δQ_rev / T. Entropy is a state function; for reversible processes ΔS = ∫ δQ_rev / T. Unit: J·K⁻¹.

Heat.front: Entropy change for ideal gas during temperature change (constant V or p).
Heat.back: For ideal gas with constant C: ΔS = n·C_v·ln(T_f/T_i) (isochoric) or ΔS = n·C_p·ln(T_f/T_i) (isobaric). More generally ΔS = ∫ C(T)/T dT.
For any real (irreversible) process in isolated system, total entropy increases: ΔS_total > 0. For reversible process ΔS_total = 0.
Enthalpy H = U + pV. For constant-pressure processes, ΔH = Q_p (heat at constant p) for many practical cases.

Heat.front: Heat capacity at constant pressure vs constant volume (relation re-cap).
Heat.back: For ideal gas per mole: C_p − C_v = R. C_p = C_v + R. C_p relates to enthalpy change ΔH = n·C_p·ΔT.

Heat.front: Molar latent heat and relation to enthalpy change.
Heat.back: Latent heat per mole L_m corresponds to enthalpy change ΔH during phase change at constant p: ΔH = L_m (molar units J·mol⁻¹).
Account for heat absorbed by calorimeter itself: Q_lost = Q_gained by calorimeter + water etc. Use known calorimeter heat capacity C_cal in equations: C_cal·ΔT included.

Heat.front: Heat transfer in steady vs transient conduction (qualitative).
Heat.back: Steady conduction: ∂T/∂t = 0 (time-independent). Transient conduction: temperature varies with time; governed by heat equation ∂T/∂t = α∇²T.
∂T/∂t = α·∂²T/∂x² where α = k / (ρ·c) is thermal diffusivity. Describes transient conduction in homogeneous material.

Heat.front: Fourier number (Fo) — significance in transient conduction.
Heat.back: Fo = α·t / L² (dimensionless). Measures relative importance of conduction vs storage; larger Fo → system approaches steady state.
At interfaces imperfect contact or thin films increase resistance to conduction. Effective R_contact must be included in series R_th for accurate heat flow.

Heat.front: Heat transfer by phase change (boiling/condensation) — high heat flux.
Heat.back: Phase-change processes (boiling/condensation) can transfer large heat per unit mass via latent heat — often used in heat exchangers and cooling systems.

Evaporation: surface phenomenon at temperatures below boiling point; molecules escape liquid surface. Boiling: bulk phenomenon when vapor pressure equals ambient pressure throughout liquid at nucleation sites.
For any cyclic process ∮ δQ / T ≤ 0. Equality for reversible cycle, inequality for irreversible; leads to definition of entropy as state function.
Gives molecular speed distribution in ideal gas; mean kinetic energy connected to T. Useful for kinetic theory context of heat and temperature.

Heat.front: Practical constants: specific heat of water and latent heats (useful numbers).
Heat.back: Water: c ≈ 4186 J·kg⁻¹·K⁻¹. Latent heat of fusion (water) L_f ≈ 3.34×10⁵ J·kg⁻¹. Latent heat of vaporization L_v ≈ 2.26×10⁶ J·kg⁻¹ (approx values).

Heat.front: Example calorimetry problem approach (mixing hot metal in water).
Heat.back: Set m_metal·c_m·(T_m − T_f) = (m_w·c_w + C_cal)·(T_f − T_w_initial). Solve for unknown c_m or T_f. Keep sign conventions consistent.

Heat.front: Thermal stress in constrained heating (formula recapitulation).
Heat.back: If expansion constrained: thermal strain ε_th = α·ΔT, induced stress σ = E·ε_th (if elastic and small). For different constraints, compute compatibilities and reactions.

Heat.front: Heat exchanger basic types & mean temperature difference (qualitative).
Heat.back: Counterflow, parallel flow, crossflow heat exchangers. Use log-mean temperature difference (LMTD) for calculating heat transfer in steady-state exchangers.
LMTD = (ΔT_1 − ΔT_2) / ln(ΔT_1 / ΔT_2) where ΔT_1 and ΔT_2 are temperature differences at two ends. Useful to compute Q̇ = U·A·LMTD for overall heat transfer coefficient U.
1 / U = Σ R_i where R_i are convective and conductive resistances including fouling, surfaces, and conduction through walls. Q̇ = U·A·ΔT_lm.

Heat.front: Entropy change for phase change at T (reversible).
Heat.back: ΔS = Q_rev / T = m·L / T for phase change at temperature T (use absolute T in K).
For Carnot heat pump delivering Q_h with work W: COP_HP = Q_h / W = 1 / (1 − T_c / T_h) = T_h / (T_h − T_c). For ideal reversible devices use reservoir temperatures in K.

Common cycles: Carnot (reversible ideal), Otto (spark-ignition engine), Diesel (compression-ignition), Rankine (steam power), Brayton (gas turbine). Each has characteristic processes and efficiencies.

Heat.front: Practical exam tips for heat & thermodynamics problems.
Heat.back: 1) Use absolute temperature (K) for thermodynamic formulas. 2) Keep sign convention for Q and W consistent. 3) Check limits (adiabatic vs isothermal). 4) Convert units (kg, J, K). 5) Use energy conservation and entropy as checks.

Q = m·c·ΔT; Q = m·L; ΔU = Q − W; pV = nRT; Work (isothermal) W = nRT ln(V_f/V_i); pV^γ = const (adiabatic); Fourier: Q̇ = −kA dT/dx; Stefan–Boltzmann: P = εσAT⁴; Newton cooling: Q̇ = hA(T−T_∞); α = k/(ρc).

Light.back: Light is electromagnetic radiation that is visible to the human eye. More generally, 'light' refers to electromagnetic waves across a range of wavelengths; it carries energy and momentum and exhibits both wave-like and particle-like properties.

Light.front: Speed of light in vacuum and units.
Light.back: Speed of light in vacuum c = 299,792,458 m·s⁻¹ (exact by definition). In many exam problems use c ≈ 3.00×10⁸ m·s⁻¹.
Light shows wave behaviour (interference, diffraction) and particle behaviour (photoelectric effect — photons). Photon energy E = h·ν where h is Planck's constant and ν frequency.
Photon energy E = h·ν = h·c / λ. Photon momentum p = E / c = h / λ.
Range from radio → microwave → infrared → visible → ultraviolet → X-ray → γ-ray. Visible light ≈ 380 nm – 750 nm (violet→red).

Light.front: Definitions: wavelength λ, frequency ν, period T, angular frequency ω.
Light.back: λ = wavelength (m). ν = frequency (Hz). T = 1/ν (s). ω = 2·π·ν (rad·s⁻¹). Relation: c = λ·ν (in vacuum).

Light.front: What is intensity and irradiance for light?
Light.back: Irradiance (intensity) I is power per unit area carried by light (W·m⁻²). For a point source in free space I ∝ 1 / r² (inverse-square law) for isotropic radiation.
Angle of incidence = angle of reflection: θ_i = θ_r (angles measured from the normal). Incident ray, reflected ray and normal lie in same plane.
Specular: smooth surface; reflected rays remain ordered and form images (mirror). Diffuse: rough surface; reflected rays scatter in many directions; no clear image.
Plane mirror (virtual, upright image, same size). Curved mirrors: concave (converging) can form real or virtual images; convex (diverging) forms virtual, diminished, upright images only.
1 / v + 1 / u = 1 / f where u = object distance, v = image distance (both measured from pole), f = focal length. Sign conventions must be consistent.
Linear (transverse) magnification m = h_i / h_o = −v / u. Negative m indicates image inverted relative to object.

Light.front: Focal length relation for spherical mirror.
Light.back: For a spherical mirror of radius of curvature R: f = R / 2 (with sign depending on mirror type under chosen convention).
When light crosses interface between two media with refractive indices n₁ and n₂: n₁·sinθ₁ = n₂·sinθ₂ (θ measured from normal).

Light.front: Refractive index definition and relation to speed.
Light.back: n = c / v where v is speed of light in medium. For material medium n ≥ 1 (normally). Also n = √(ε_r·μ_r) for electromagnetic properties.

Light.front: Dispersion — wavelength dependence of refractive index.
Light.back: Refractive index n(λ) varies with wavelength → different colours refract by different amounts (prism dispersion), causing spectral separation. Generally n decreases with increasing λ in visible range (normal dispersion).

Light.front: Critical angle and total internal reflection (TIR).
Light.back: For n₁ > n₂ critical angle θ_c = arcsin(n₂ / n₁). For incidence θ > θ_c from medium n₁ → n₂, total internal reflection occurs and no transmitted refracted ray exists.
Optical fibres (light guided by TIR), prisms in binoculars, light pipes, some sensors.

Light.front: Refraction at a plane parallel slab (lateral displacement).
Light.back: Light entering slab (thickness t, refractive index n) is emergent parallel to incident ray but displaced laterally by Δ = t·sin(θ_i − θ_t) / cosθ_t (use geometry). Net deviation depends on θ_i and n.

Light.front: Lens types and thin lens approximation.
Light.back: Convex (converging) lens: positive focal length, can form real inverted images. Concave (diverging) lens: negative focal length, forms virtual upright diminished images. Thin-lens equation: 1 / v + 1 / u = 1 / f.

Light.front: Lens-maker's formula (for thin lens in air).
Light.back: 1 / f = (n − 1)·(1 / R₁ − 1 / R₂) where R₁, R₂ are radii of curvature (signs per convention) and n is lens refractive index. Use consistent sign rules.

Light.front: Power of a lens and unit.
Light.back: Optical power P = 1 / f (f in metres). Unit diopter (D) where 1 D = 1 m⁻¹. For combination of thin lenses in contact P_total = Σ P_i.
Transverse magnification m = h_i / h_o = −v / u (same sign convention as mirrors). Negative sign indicates inverted image.

Light.front: Combination of thin lenses separated by distance d (approx).
Light.back: Use matrix or iterative imaging: for two thin lenses with focal lengths f₁, f₂ and separation d, effective focal length f_eff satisfies 1 / f_eff = 1 / f₁ + 1 / f₂ − d / (f₁·f₂) (for paraxial approx).

Light.front: Formation of images by plane mirrors (location & nature).
Light.back: Plane mirror forms a virtual image at distance v = −u (image appears as far behind mirror as object in front), upright and same size. Lateral inversion occurs.

Light.front: Principal rays for thin lens ray diagrams (3 useful rays).
Light.back:
1) Ray parallel to axis → refracts through focal point on other side.
2) Ray through centre of lens → undeviated.
3) Ray through focal point → emerges parallel to axis. Use intersections to find image.

Spherical aberration: marginal rays focus at different points than paraxial rays → blurred image. Coma: off-axis point sources produce comet-like blur. These are lens aberrations; reduced by aperture stop or aspheric elements.
Different wavelengths focus at different axial positions due to dispersion (n(λ) variation) → coloured fringes. Corrected using achromatic doublets (combining glasses with opposite dispersion).

Light.front: Interference — coherent sources and path difference condition.
Light.back: Constructive interference: path difference Δ = m·λ. Destructive: Δ = (m + 1/2)·λ. Sources must be coherent (stable phase relation) for sustained interference pattern.

Light.front: Young's double slit experiment — fringe spacing formula.
Light.back: For slit separation d and screen distance D ≫ d, fringe separation Δy = λ·D / d. Position of m-th bright fringe y_m = m·λ·D / d.

Light.front: Thin-film interference — phase changes and effective path difference.
Light.back: Phase change of π (equivalent to λ/2 path) occurs upon reflection when wave reflects from medium of higher n. Net condition uses 2·n·t = (m + 1/2)·λ (for constructive or destructive depending on phase flips). Use careful sign and phase-change accounting.
Formed by air film between plano-convex lens and glass plate. Radii of dark fringes r_m satisfy r_m² = m·λ·R for small angle approx (R radius of curvature). Useful to measure λ or R.
Single-slit minima at a·sinθ = m·λ (m = ±1, ±2,...), where a is slit width. Central maximum width ≈ 2·λ / a (small-angle approx).

Light.front: Diffraction grating — grating equation and maxima.
Light.back: For grating spacing d: d·sinθ = n·λ where n = 0, ±1, ±2,... gives directions of principal maxima. Higher-order spectra occur for n ≠ 0.
R = λ / Δλ = m·N where m is diffraction order and N is total number of illuminated slits. Higher N and m give better resolution.

Light.front: Rayleigh criterion for resolving two point sources (circular aperture).
Light.back: Minimum angular separation θ_min ≈ 1.22·λ / D where D is aperture diameter (for circular aperture). Two Airy discs just resolved when principal max of one falls on first minimum of other.
Diffraction by circular aperture produces Airy pattern: central bright disk surrounded by rings. Diameter of central disk sets resolution limit for imaging systems.

Light.front: Polarization of light — types and definition.
Light.back: Polarization: orientation of electric field vector in transverse electromagnetic wave. Types: linear, circular, elliptical. Natural light is usually unpolarized (random orientations).

A linear polarizer transmits component of E along its axis. Malus's law: I = I₀·cos²θ where θ is angle between incident light polarization and polarizer axis; I₀ transmitted by polarizer when aligned.
At Brewster angle θ_B where reflected light is fully polarized (no parallel component), tanθ_B = n₂ / n₁ (for light from medium n₁ to n₂). Reflected and refracted rays are at 90° to each other.

Fresnel equations give amplitude reflection and transmission coefficients for s- and p-polarized light at an interface based on n₁, n₂ and angle of incidence. Use for calculating reflectivity vs angle.
Every point on a wavefront acts as a source of secondary wavelets; the envelope of these wavelets after time t gives new wavefront. Useful to derive refraction, reflection and diffraction.

Temporal coherence: measure of phase correlation over time (related to spectral linewidth). Spatial coherence: phase correlation across wavefront (related to source size). Coherent sources needed for stable interference.
Michelson interferometer splits beam into two arms; path difference produces interference fringes. Used to measure small lengths, refractive index changes, spectral lines (via fringe shifts).
OPL = ∫ n(s)·ds along ray path. Phase accumulated ∝ OPL. Two rays interfere based on difference in OPL (not just geometric length).

Light.front: Refractive index dispersion in prisms — minimum deviation.
Light.back: For prism apex angle A and minimum deviation δ_min: n = sin((A + δ_min)/2) / sin(A / 2). Minimum deviation occurs when ray is symmetric inside prism.

Light.front: Total internal reflection vs evanescent wave (brief).
Light.back: At TIR an evanescent (exponentially decaying) field exists in rarer medium near interface — can be exploited in frustrated TIR, near-field optics and optical tunnelling.

Light.front: Relativistic Doppler effect for light (brief formula).
Light.back: Relativistic formula for source moving at speed v along line of sight: f' = f·√((1 + β) / (1 − β)) where β = v / c (positive for approach). Redshift/blueshift described by z = (λ_obs − λ_emit)/λ_emit.
A simple magnifier (convex lens) produces an enlarged virtual image when object placed within focal length. Angular magnification M ≈ 25 cm / f (using near-point 25 cm conventional reference).

Light.front: Compound microscope — basic formula for total magnification.
Light.back: Total magnification M_total = M_objective · M_eyepiece. Objective creates a real enlarged image; eyepiece acts as magnifier for that image. Use focal lengths and tube length to compute M_objective ≈ L / f_obj etc.
Angular magnification M = f_objective / f_eyepiece (for two-lens Keplerian telescope in normal adjustment). Field of view and brightness depend on aperture and eyepiece design.

Light.front: Human eye optics — focal adjustment and near point.
Light.back: Eye focuses by changing lens curvature (accommodation). Relaxed eye focuses distant objects at retina; near point ~ 25 cm for normal young eye. Defects corrected by lenses.

Myopia (nearsighted): image focuses in front of retina; correct with diverging (concave) lenses (negative power). Hyperopia (farsighted): image focuses behind retina; correct with converging (convex) lenses (positive power).

Light.front: Pinhole camera — imaging principle and advantages.
Light.back: Pinhole camera forms inverted image by geometric projection without lens. Advantage: infinite depth of field; disadvantage: low brightness and diffraction-limited sharpness.
Etendue (optical extent) measures beam spread × area; cannot be decreased by passive optics — limits concentration and brightness enhancement by lossless optical systems.

Light.front: Photometry basics: luminous flux, candela, illuminance.
Light.back: Luminous flux Φ (lumens, lm) is perceived power weighted by human eye sensitivity. Luminous intensity (candela, cd) is flux per unit solid angle. Illuminance E (lux, lx) = lumens per m².
Blackbody emits spectral radiance given by Planck's law. Colour temperature describes apparent colour of light source approximated by blackbody temperature (e.g., 2700 K warm, 6500 K daylight).

Light.front: Photons and photoelectric effect — basic relation.
Light.back: Photoelectric effect: photons incident on metal eject electrons if h·ν ≥ φ (work function). K_max = h·ν − φ. Demonstrates particle aspect of light and quantization of energy.
Collective oscillations of electrons at metal–dielectric interface (surface plasmons) couple strongly to light at subwavelength scales — basis of some sensors and near-field phenomena.

Light.front: Common exam pitfalls in optics problems (short list).
Light.back:
1) Mixing sign conventions (stick to one and be consistent).
2) Using degrees instead of radians in small-angle approximations.
3) Confusing image distance sign for virtual vs real images.
4) Forgetting phase change of π on reflection from higher n.
5) Adding dB or intensities incorrectly for optical power (use correct units).

c = λ·ν; n = c / v; Snell: n₁ sinθ₁ = n₂ sinθ₂; Mirror/lens: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f; m = −v / u; Lens maker: 1/f = (n − 1)(1/R₁ − 1/R₂); Grating: d sinθ = m λ; Rayleigh criterion: θ_min ≈ 1.22 λ / D; Malus: I = I₀ cos²θ; Photon: E = h ν = h c / λ.

Light.front: Final exam tip for light chapter.
Light.back: Draw clear ray diagrams, state and use a consistent sign convention, check limiting cases (λ → 0, n → 1), remember phase-change on reflection rules, and keep units consistent (m, s, rad). Practice interference and diffraction problems carefully with path and phase bookkeeping.

Static Electricity.front: What is electrostatics (basic definition)?
Static Electricity.back: Electrostatics is the study of electric charges at rest, the electric fields they produce, the forces between them, and related potentials and energy.

Static Electricity.front: What is electric charge and its units?
Static Electricity.back: Electric charge q is a fundamental property of matter that causes electric forces. SI unit: coulomb (C). Charge of electron: −1.602176634×10⁻¹⁹ C (elementary charge e).

Static Electricity.front: Conservation of charge — statement.
Static Electricity.back: Total electric charge in an isolated system remains constant. Charge can be transferred between bodies but not created or destroyed (macroscopically).

Static Electricity.front: Types of charging methods (brief).
Static Electricity.back: By friction (triboelectric), by conduction/contact (transfer of charge on contact), by induction (redistribution due to nearby charge with grounding), and by polarization (in dielectrics).

Static Electricity.front: Coulomb's law (magnitude and vector form).
Static Electricity.back:
Magnitude: F = k·|q₁·q₂| / r² where k = 1/(4·π·ε₀) ≈ 8.988×10⁹ N·m²·C⁻².
Vector: F⃗₁₂ = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(q₁·q₂ / r²)·r̂ (directed along line joining charges).

Static Electricity.front: Permittivity of free space ε₀ — value and unit.
Static Electricity.back: ε₀ ≈ 8.854×10⁻¹² F·m⁻¹ (farads per metre). k = 1/(4·π·ε₀) ≈ 8.988×10⁹ N·m²·C⁻².

Static Electricity.front: Definition of electric field E⃗ (field of a point charge).
Static Electricity.back:
Electric field E⃗ at a point is force per unit positive test charge: E⃗ = F⃗ / q_test.
For point charge q: E⃗ = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(q / r²)·r̂.

Static Electricity.front: Superposition principle for electric fields.
Static Electricity.back: Electric field from multiple charges is vector sum of individual fields: E⃗_total = Σ E⃗_i. Use superposition to compute fields of charge distributions.

Static Electricity.front: Electric flux Φ_E (definition).
Static Electricity.back: Electric flux through area A: Φ_E = ∫ E⃗·dA⃗ (units: V·m = N·m²·C⁻¹·m?). For uniform E through flat area: Φ = E·A·cosθ.

Static Electricity.front: Gauss's law (integral form) — statement and formula.
Static Electricity.back: Total electric flux over closed surface = enclosed charge / ε₀: ∮ E⃗·dA⃗ = Q_enclosed / ε₀. Useful to find E for symmetric charge distributions.

Static Electricity.front: Common Gaussian-symmetry examples (results).
Static Electricity.back:
Infinite line charge (linear density λ): E = λ / (2·π·ε₀·r) radially.
Infinite plane sheet (surface density σ): E = σ / (2·ε₀) (both sides).
Spherical charge (point or shell): E = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(Q / r²) outside; inside shell E = 0.

Static Electricity.front: Charge densities — definitions and symbols.
Static Electricity.back: Volume density ρ (C·m⁻³), surface density σ (C·m⁻²), line density λ (C·m⁻¹). Use appropriate integrals to compute total charge.

Static Electricity.front: Electric potential V (definition and relation to E⃗).
Static Electricity.back: Electric potential V is potential energy per unit charge: V = U / q. Relation: E⃗ = −∇V (in one dimension E = −dV/dx). For point charge: V = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(q / r) (zero at ∞).

Static Electricity.front: Potential energy of two point charges.
Static Electricity.back: U = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(q₁·q₂ / r). Work done to bring charges from ∞ to separation r equals this potential energy.

Static Electricity.front: Work done by/on electric field (relation with potential).
Static Electricity.back: Work done by electric force moving q from A to B: W = q·(V_A − V_B). Work done by field = decrease in potential energy.

Static Electricity.front: Equipotential surfaces — definition and properties.
Static Electricity.back: Surfaces of constant potential. Electric field lines are everywhere perpendicular to equipotential surfaces. No work is done moving a charge along an equipotential.

Static Electricity.front: Poisson and Laplace equations (electrostatics).
Static Electricity.back: Poisson: ∇²V = −ρ / ε₀ (general). Laplace (in charge-free region): ∇²V = 0. Boundary-value problems solved using these PDEs.

Static Electricity.front: Electrostatic boundary conditions at surface charge σ.
Static Electricity.back:
Normal component discontinuity: E⃗_above·n̂ − E⃗_below·n̂ = σ/ε₀.
Tangential components continuous: E_tangent,above = E_tangent,below (ideal conductor: tangential E = 0).

Static Electricity.front: Electrostatic equilibrium in conductors — key properties.
Static Electricity.back:
1) Electric field inside conductor = 0.
2) Excess charge resides on outer surface.
3) Conductor is an equipotential (V constant throughout).
4) Electric field just outside surface = σ / ε₀ (normal outward).

Static Electricity.front: Surface charge distribution on irregular conductor (qualitative).
Static Electricity.back: Charge density σ is higher at sharp points/edges (smaller radius of curvature). This causes stronger local fields — basis of corona discharge and lightning rod effectiveness.

Static Electricity.front: Method of images — short idea and typical use-case.
Static Electricity.back: Replace conductors and boundary conditions by equivalent image charges that reproduce the same boundary potential in region of interest. Commonly used for point charge near infinite grounded plane.

Static Electricity.front: Electric dipole — definition and dipole moment p⃗.
Static Electricity.back: Two equal and opposite charges ±q separated by vector ℓ⃗. Dipole moment p⃗ = q·ℓ⃗ (direction from −q to +q).

Static Electricity.front: Electric field of a dipole on axis and on perpendicular bisector (approx far-field).
Static Electricity.back:
On axis (distance r ≫ ℓ): E_axis ≈ (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(2·p / r³) (along/against axis).
On equatorial plane: E_perp ≈ (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(−p / r³) (opposite direction).

Static Electricity.front: Torque and potential energy of a dipole in uniform field E⃗.
Static Electricity.back:
Torque τ⃗ = p⃗ × E⃗ (tends to align p with E).
Potential energy U = −p⃗·E⃗ (minimum when aligned).

Static Electricity.front: Force on a dipole in a non-uniform field (qualitative).
Static Electricity.back: Net force F⃗ ≈ (p⃗·∇)E⃗; dipole experiences force toward region of stronger field if aligned favorably. No net force in uniform field (only torque).

Static Electricity.front: Definition of capacitance (single conductor and capacitor).
Static Electricity.back: Capacitance C = Q / V, ratio of charge on conductor to its potential (with reference at infinity). For two-conductor capacitor C = Q / (V_+ − V_−). Unit: farad (F).

Static Electricity.front: Parallel-plate capacitor — capacitance formula (vacuum/dielectric).
Static Electricity.back: C = ε·A / d where ε = ε₀ for vacuum or ε = ε_r·ε₀ for dielectric-filled, A plate area, d separation (valid for d ≪ √A, fringe neglected).

Static Electricity.front: Capacitance of isolated sphere (radius R).
Static Electricity.back: C = 4·π·ε₀·R (capacitance of an isolated conducting sphere relative to infinity).

Static Electricity.front: Coaxial cable capacitance per unit length (formula).
Static Electricity.back: For inner radius a and outer radius b, capacitance per unit length C' = 2·π·ε / ln(b / a) (ε = permittivity of dielectric).

Static Electricity.front: Series and parallel combination of capacitors (formulas).
Static Electricity.back: Parallel: C_eq = Σ C_i (voltages same). Series: 1 / C_eq = Σ (1 / C_i) (charge same).

Static Electricity.front: Energy stored in a capacitor — formulas.
Static Electricity.back: U = 1/2·C·V² = Q² / (2·C) = 1/2·Q·V. Energy density in electric field: u = 1/2·ε·E² (J·m⁻³).

Static Electricity.front: Dielectric — polarization and relative permittivity κ (ε_r).
Static Electricity.back: Dielectric placed in field becomes polarized; bound charges reduce effective field. Relative permittivity κ = ε / ε₀; increases capacitance by factor κ for homogeneous dielectric between plates.

Static Electricity.front: Bound charge vs free charge (qualitative).
Static Electricity.back: Free charges are externally supplied (conduction). Bound charges arise inside dielectrics due to molecular polarization — manifest as surface polarization charge and volume charge (∇·P).

Static Electricity.front: Electric displacement field D⃗ — definition and Gauss form.
Static Electricity.back: D⃗ = ε₀·E⃗ + P⃗ (or D = ε·E in linear dielectrics). Gauss law for D: ∮ D⃗·dA⃗ = Q_free,enclosed (bound charges excluded). Useful in problems with dielectrics.

Static Electricity.front: Breakdown and dielectric strength (practical).
Static Electricity.back: Dielectric breakdown occurs when E exceeds material's dielectric strength (V·m⁻¹), causing ionization and conduction. Air breakdown ~ 3×10⁶ V·m⁻¹ (approx), depends on conditions.

Static Electricity.front: Charging by induction (process outline).
Static Electricity.back: Bring charged object near conductor, ground the conductor so charges of opposite sign are drawn, remove ground then object — conductor left charged opposite to object without direct contact.

Static Electricity.front: Electroscope — working principle (qualitative).
Static Electricity.back: Detects presence and sign of charge by electrostatic repulsion of leaves/foil. Charge brought to top causes leaves to diverge; divergence magnitude relates roughly to amount of charge and geometry.

Static Electricity.front: Field of infinite line charge and infinite plane — formulas recap.
Static Electricity.back:
Infinite line (linear density λ): E = λ / (2·π·ε₀·r) (radial).
Infinite plane (surface density σ): E = σ / (2·ε₀) on each side (for single infinite sheet).

Static Electricity.front: Electric field of uniformly charged sphere (solid) — inside & outside.
Static Electricity.back:
Outside (r ≥ R): E = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(Q / r²) radial.
Inside (r < R), for uniformly distributed charge: E = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·(Q·r / R³) (∝ r).

Static Electricity.front: Surface charge density σ and relation to E just outside conductor.
Static Electricity.back: E_outside_normal = σ / ε₀ (just outside conductor). Direction outward for positive σ.

Static Electricity.front: Grounding (earthing) — purpose and effect.
Static Electricity.back: Connecting conductor to Earth provides reservoir for charges; it can neutralize excess charge or supply charges. Grounded conductor has potential ≈ 0 by convention.

Static Electricity.front: Electrostatic shielding — Faraday cage idea.
Static Electricity.back: A hollow conducting enclosure shields interior from external static fields because charges redistribute on outer surface producing zero internal field. Sensitive equipment often enclosed in Faraday cages.

Static Electricity.front: Electric field energy density and total energy (integral form).
Static Electricity.back: Energy density u = 1/2·ε·E². Total energy stored in space U = ∫ (1/2·ε·E²) dV over region containing field.

Static Electricity.front: Image-charge example: point charge q at distance d above grounded infinite conducting plane — result summary.
Static Electricity.back: Field in region above plane same as that of q plus an image charge −q located symmetric point below plane. Induced surface charge distribution and force on q can be computed from image method.

Static Electricity.front: Forces between conductors and between charged bodies (brief).
Static Electricity.back: Coulomb's law applies to point charges; for extended conductors compute via fields/pressure: electrostatic pressure on conductor surface = σ² / (2·ε₀) (tends to push surface outward for like charges).

Static Electricity.front: Electrostatic pressure and mechanical effect.
Static Electricity.back: Electrostatic pressure p_e = ε₀·E² / 2 = σ² / (2·ε₀) (on conductor surface). Used in problems of membrane deflection or capacitor plate attraction.

Static Electricity.front: Capacitance measurement and practical notes.
Static Electricity.back: Measure C with LCR meter or by charge–voltage method (apply V, measure Q). Parasitic capacitances and leakage paths affect low-capacitance measurements; guard rings reduce errors.

Static Electricity.front: Leakage and dielectric loss (practical).
Static Electricity.back: Real dielectrics have finite resistivity causing leakage current and energy loss; characterized by loss tangent tanδ in AC; for static problems ensure good insulation to avoid charge decay.

Static Electricity.front: Common pitfalls in electrostatics exams (short list).
Static Electricity.back: 1) Sign errors (positive vs negative charge directions). 2) Confusing potential V and potential energy U. 3) Using incorrect reference (V=0 at ∞ vs other). 4) Forgetting vector nature of E. 5) Misapplying Gauss law without sufficient symmetry.

Static Electricity.front: Short formula cheat-sheet (static electricity).
Static Electricity.back:
Coulomb: F = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·q₁q₂ / r²
E (point): E = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·q / r²
Potential (point): V = (1/(4·π·ε₀))·q / r
Gauss: ∮ E·dA = Q_enclosed / ε₀
Parallel-plate: C = ε·A / d
Energy (cap): U = 1/2·C·V²
Energy density: u = 1/2·ε·E²
Dipole torque: τ = p × E, U = −p·E

Static Electricity.front: Practical exam tips for static electricity problems (checklist).
Static Electricity.back: 1) Draw field lines, equipotentials, and choose coordinate system. 2) Check symmetry before using Gauss law. 3) Keep units consistent (C, m, N, V). 4) Use superposition for multiple charges. 5) Be careful with signs and vector directions.

Current Electricity.back: Electric current I is rate of flow of electric charge through a cross-section: I = ΔQ / Δt. SI unit: ampere (A) where 1 A = 1 C·s⁻¹.
Conventional current direction is from positive to negative (by historical definition). Electron flow (actual charge carriers in metals) is opposite direction (from negative to positive).

Current Electricity.front: What is current density J and relation to I?
Current Electricity.back: Current density J is current per unit area vector: J⃗ = I / A · n̂ (for uniform flow). In general J⃗(r) = ρ_charge·v⃗_d where v⃗_d is drift velocity times charge sign. Units: A·m⁻².

Current Electricity.front: Drift velocity v_d — definition and formula.
Current Electricity.back: Drift velocity v_d is average velocity of charge carriers under electric field. Relation: I = n·A·e·v_d for electrons in metal (n = number density, A area, e elementary charge).
n is number of free charge carriers per unit volume (m⁻³). For metals n is typically ~10²⁸ m⁻³. Use in I = n·A·q·v_d.

Current Electricity.front: What is resistivity ρ and conductivity σ?
Current Electricity.back: Resistivity ρ is material property relating E and J: E = ρ·J. Conductivity σ = 1 / ρ relates J = σ·E. Units: ρ in Ω·m, σ in S·m⁻¹ (siemens per metre).
Macroscopic: V = I·R for ohmic conductors (V voltage across, I current, R resistance). Microsopic: J = σ·E (linear relation between current density and electric field).

Current Electricity.front: Definition of resistance R and its dependence on geometry/material.
Current Electricity.back: Resistance R = ρ·L / A where ρ resistivity, L length, A cross-sectional area. Units: ohm (Ω). Longer rod → higher R; larger area → lower R.
For metals ρ typically increases with temperature (approx ρ = ρ₀[1 + α·(T − T₀)] for small ΔT). For semiconductors ρ decreases with T. α is temperature coefficient (K⁻¹).
Ohmic: V ∝ I and R constant (linear V–I). Non-Ohmic: V–I relation not linear (diodes, thermistors, filament lamps).

Current Electricity.front: Electromotive force (EMF) ℰ — definition and units.
Current Electricity.back: EMF ℰ is energy supplied per unit charge by a source (battery) when moving charge from negative to positive terminal: ℰ = dW_source / dq. Unit: volt (V) = J·C⁻¹.

Current Electricity.front: Internal resistance r of a cell and terminal voltage.
Current Electricity.back: If cell has EMF ℰ and internal resistance r, terminal voltage V across terminals under load I: V = ℰ − I·r (when delivering current). When charging sign reverses: V = ℰ + I·r.
Open-circuit voltage = terminal voltage when I = 0 → V = ℰ. Short-circuit current I_sc ≈ ℰ / r (if external resistance → 0), not recommended due to heating and damage.

Current Electricity.front: Power delivered by a source and power dissipated internally.
Current Electricity.back: Electrical power delivered to external load P_out = V·I = (ℰ − I·r)·I. Power dissipated inside cell P_internal = I²·r. Total power from source P_total = ℰ·I.

Current Electricity.front: Series and parallel connection of resistors — equivalent formulas.
Current Electricity.back: Series: R_eq = Σ R_i. Current same through each, voltage divides. Parallel: 1 / R_eq = Σ (1 / R_i). Voltage same across each, currents add.
Sum of currents entering a node = sum leaving node (conservation of charge). Σ I_in = Σ I_out.
Sum of potential differences (voltage) around any closed loop = 0. Σ ΔV = 0. Apply signs consistently for rises/drops including EMF and IR drops.

Current Electricity.front: Wheatstone bridge — principle and balance condition.
Current Electricity.back: Bridge has four resistances R1, R2, R3, R4. Balanced (no current through galvanometer) when R1 / R2 = R3 / R4. Used for precise resistance measurement.
Uses uniform resistive wire with sliding jockey to implement bridge. Balance point x gives R_unknown = R_standard · x / (L − x) where L wire length (e.g., 100 cm).

Potentiometer compares EMFs by balancing against a known potential gradient along a long uniform wire with no current drawn from test cell at balance. Used to measure EMF, internal resistance and for calibration.
Find open-circuit balance length l₀ for ℰ. Connect load causing current I and find balance length l. Terminal voltage V = k·l where k potential gradient. Then r = (ℰ − V) / I.

Current Electricity.front: Ammeter and voltmeter internal resistance and ideal values.
Current Electricity.back: Ideal ammeter: zero internal resistance (R_A = 0) so it doesn't change circuit. Practical ammeter: small R. Ideal voltmeter: infinite internal resistance (R_V → ∞) to draw no current. Practical voltmeter: large R.

Current Electricity.front: How to connect ammeter and voltmeter in circuit.
Current Electricity.back: Ammeter in series with load to measure current. Voltmeter in parallel across element to measure potential difference.
Instantaneous power P = V·I. Using Ohm's law: P = I²·R = V² / R. For source: P_supplied = ℰ·I; for resistor: P_dissipated = I²·R.
Resistive heating occurs as charges lose energy colliding with lattice: heat rate P = I²·R = V·I. Energy dissipated in time t: E = I²·R·t.
Use I = n·A·e·v_d → v_d = I / (n·A·e). For typical metal current densities drift velocities are mm·s⁻¹ or less despite large electron speeds (thermal).

Current Electricity.front: Mobility μ of charge carriers and relation to drift velocity.
Current Electricity.back: Mobility μ = v_d / E. Also conductivity σ = n·q·μ. Units μ: m²·V⁻¹·s⁻¹.

Current Electricity.front: Hall effect — basic principle and Hall coefficient.
Current Electricity.back: When current flows in a conductor in magnetic field B, transverse voltage (Hall voltage) appears due to Lorentz force. Hall coefficient R_H = E_H / (J·B) = 1 / (n·q) (sign indicates carrier sign).
Measure carrier density n, determine sign of carriers (electrons vs holes), magnetic field sensors, speed sensors.

Current Electricity.front: Conductors vs semiconductors — carrier concentration effect.
Current Electricity.back: Metals: large n, high σ; semiconductors: much smaller n but mobility may be high, conductance varies strongly with temperature and doping (intrinsic vs extrinsic behaviour).

Current Electricity.front: RC circuit — charging of capacitor (series with resistor).
Current Electricity.back: Charging equation: q(t) = C·V₀·(1 − e^{−t/RC}). Current I(t) = (V₀ / R)·e^{−t/RC}. Time constant τ = R·C defines rate (t ≈ 5τ → near full charge).
Discharging: q(t) = q₀·e^{−t/RC}. Current I(t) = −(q₀ / R·C)·e^{−t/RC}. Voltage across capacitor V(t) = V₀·e^{−t/RC}.
τ = R·C is time for voltage/charge to change by ~63.2% of difference to final value during charging/discharging. Larger τ → slower response.
U = 1/2·C·V² = 1/2·Q² / C. During charging, energy supplied by source splits: stored in capacitor and dissipated as heat in resistor.
Ideal LC circuit oscillates exchange between capacitor energy (1/2·C·V²) and inductor magnetic energy (1/2·L·I²). Angular frequency ω = 1 / √(L·C).

Current Electricity.front: Inductance L — definition and energy stored.
Current Electricity.back: Inductance L relates flux linkage to current Φ = L·I (for linear device). Energy stored in inductor U = 1/2·L·I². Unit: henry (H).
Self-inductance L: emf induced in same coil when current changes. Mutual inductance M: emf induced in coil 2 due to rate of change of current in coil 1; M depends on geometry and coupling.

Current Electricity.front: Back emf in inductors and RL circuits.
Current Electricity.back: Inductor opposes change in current: emf ε_L = −L·(dI/dt). In RL series circuit step response: I(t) = (ℰ / R)·(1 − e^{−R·t / L}). Time constant τ = L / R.
Instantaneous power p = V·I. For ideal inductor average power over full cycle in AC = 0 (energy alternates between source and inductor). Similarly ideal capacitor averages zero reactive power.

Current Electricity.front: AC basics — RMS values and relation to amplitude.
Current Electricity.back: For sinusoid x(t) = X_m·sinωt, root-mean-square X_rms = X_m / √2. For voltage and current use V_rms and I_rms to compute average power: P = V_rms·I_rms·cosφ.
Impedance Z generalizes resistance to AC: Z = R + jX where X reactance (inductive X_L = ωL positive, capacitive X_C = −1/(ωC) negative). Use phasors to add voltages/currents.

Current Electricity.front: Power in AC circuits — real, reactive, apparent power.
Current Electricity.back: Real power P = V_rms·I_rms·cosφ (W), reactive power Q = V_rms·I_rms·sinφ (var), apparent power S = V_rms·I_rms (VA). Power factor = cosφ.

Current Electricity.front: Wheatstone bridge sensitivity & null method advantage.
Current Electricity.back: Null detection (zero galvanometer) is most accurate because measurement independent of source fluctuations; sensitivity depends on ratio arms and galvanometer sensitivity.

For linear circuits, response (voltage/current) due to multiple independent sources is sum of responses due to each source acting alone (other sources replaced by internal resistances: ideal volts → short, ideal currents → open).
Any linear circuit seen from two terminals can be reduced: Thevenin equivalent = ℰ_th in series with R_th. Norton equivalent = I_no in parallel with R_no where I_no = ℰ_th / R_th and R_no = R_th.

Maximum power delivered to a load R_L occurs when R_L = R_th (load equals Thevenin internal resistance). Maximum power P_max = (ℰ_th²) / (4·R_th). For AC use conjugate matching (R_L = R_th and X_L = −X_th).

Current Electricity.front: Measuring small resistances — Kelvin (four-terminal) method idea.
Current Electricity.back: Four-terminal (Kelvin) connection separates current and potential leads to eliminate lead/contact resistance errors when measuring low R by using sense leads to measure voltage drop precisely.
Thermistor: temperature-dependent resistor. NTC (negative temperature coefficient) decreases R with increasing T; PTC increases R with T. Used for temperature sensing and inrush current limiting.
Light-dependent resistor decreases resistance when illumination increases. Used in light sensors, automatic night lights, exposure meters.

Current Electricity.front: Common exam pitfalls in current electricity problems (short list).
Current Electricity.back: 1) Forget internal resistance of meters/cells. 2) Mixing up series/parallel current vs voltage rules. 3) Sign errors with EMFs. 4) Using average vs instantaneous values in AC. 5) Confusing peak and RMS values.
I = ΔQ / Δt; J = I / A; J = σ·E; R = ρ·L / A; V = IR; P = VI = I²R = V² / R; ℰ = V + Ir; τ_RC = R·C; τ_RL = L / R; LC ω = 1/√(LC); Hall coef R_H = 1/(nq); C_plate = εA/d; U_cap = 1/2 CV².

Current Electricity.front: Final exam tips for current electricity chapter.
Current Electricity.back: Always draw clear circuit diagram and mark polarities. Check meter connections and internal resistances. Use KCL/KVL carefully and keep sign conventions consistent. Convert between peak and RMS for AC. Verify limiting cases (R→0 or ∞) to check answers.

Magnetism.front: What is magnetism (basic definition)?
Magnetism.back: Magnetism is the phenomenon by which materials and moving charges produce forces on other moving charges and magnetic materials. It arises from electric currents and intrinsic magnetic moments of particles (e.g., electron spin).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic field B — definition and SI unit.
Magnetism.back: Magnetic induction (magnetic flux density) B⃗ is the vector field that exerts force on moving charges and currents. SI unit: tesla (T). 1 T = 1 N·s·m⁻¹ = 1 kg·s⁻²·A⁻¹.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic field intensity H — definition and relation to B.
Magnetism.back: Magnetic field H⃗ relates to B and magnetization M by B = μ0·(H + M) in SI. In linear media B = μ·H = μ0·μ_r·H where μ0 is vacuum permeability and μ_r relative permeability.

Magnetism.front: Vacuum permeability μ0 — value and unit.
Magnetism.back: μ0 = 4·π × 10⁻⁷ H·m⁻¹ (exact). Unit: henry per metre (H·m⁻¹) or N·A⁻².

Magnetism.front: No magnetic monopoles — Gauss's law for magnetism.
Magnetism.back: Magnetic flux through any closed surface is zero: ∮ B⃗·dA⃗ = 0 → ∇·B = 0. This expresses absence of isolated magnetic charges (monopoles) in classical electromagnetism.

Magnetism.front: Lorentz force on a moving charge (magnetic part).
Magnetism.back: A charge q moving with velocity v⃗ in electromagnetic fields experiences F⃗ = q·(E⃗ + v⃗ × B⃗). Magnetic force is F_mag = q·(v⃗ × B⃗) and acts perpendicular to v and B (does no work).

Magnetism.front: Force on a current-carrying wire in magnetic field.
Magnetism.back: A wire of length vector ℓ⃗ carrying current I in magnetic field B⃗ experiences force F⃗ = I·(ℓ⃗ × B⃗). For straight segment of length L perpendicular to B: F = I·L·B.

Magnetism.front: Force between two parallel currents (formula).
Magnetism.back: Two long parallel wires separated by distance r carrying currents I₁ and I₂ exert force per unit length: F/L = μ0·I₁·I₂ / (2·π·r). Currents in same direction attract; opposite directions repel.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic dipole moment μ of a current loop.
Magnetism.back: Magnetic moment μ⃗ of a planar current loop = I·A⃗ (I current, A⃗ area vector normal to loop given by right-hand rule). Unit: A·m² (or J·T⁻¹).

Magnetism.front: Torque on a magnetic dipole in uniform field (formula).
Magnetism.back: Torque τ⃗ = μ⃗ × B⃗. Magnitude τ = μ·B·sinθ, tends to align μ with B. Potential energy U = −μ⃗·B⃗ (minimum when aligned).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic field at centre of circular loop (on axis formula).
Magnetism.back: For a single circular loop radius R carrying current I, magnetic field at centre: B = μ0·I / (2·R). On axis at distance x: B(x) = (μ0·I·R²) / (2·(R² + x²)^{3/2}).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic field of long straight current (Biot–Savart/Ampere result).
Magnetism.back: Magnetic field at distance r from long straight wire carrying current I: B = μ0·I / (2·π·r) (circles around wire by right-hand rule).

Magnetism.front: Biot–Savart law (differential form).
Magnetism.back: Magnetic field contribution dB⃗ from current element I·dℓ⃗ at point r⃗: dB⃗ = (μ0 / (4·π))·(I·dℓ⃗ × r̂) / r² where r̂ points from current element to field point. Integrate over current path.

Magnetism.front: Ampère's circuital law (integral form).
Magnetism.back: ∮ B⃗·dℓ⃗ = μ0·I_enclosed (magnetostatics). Useful for finding B in high-symmetry situations (long wire, solenoid, toroid).

Magnetism.front: Differential form of Ampère's law (with Maxwell correction).
Magnetism.back: ∇×B⃗ = μ0·J⃗ + μ0·ε0·∂E⃗/∂t. For steady currents (magnetostatics) the displacement current term μ0·ε0·∂E/∂t = 0, so ∇×B = μ0·J.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic field inside an ideal infinitely long solenoid.
Magnetism.back: Inside an ideal solenoid with n turns per unit length carrying current I: B = μ0·n·I (approximately uniform along axis). Outside field ≈ 0 for ideal infinite solenoid.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic field inside a toroid.
Magnetism.back: For toroid radius r (inside ring) with N total turns and current I: B(r) = μ0·N·I / (2·π·r) (inside core). Outside toroid B ≈ 0 for ideal toroid.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic flux Φ_B — definition and unit.
Magnetism.back: Magnetic flux through surface S: Φ_B = ∫_S B⃗·dA⃗. SI unit: weber (Wb). 1 Wb = 1 T·m². Magnetic flux linkage for N turns: N·Φ_B.

Magnetism.front: Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction (integral form).
Magnetism.back: Induced emf ε in a closed loop = −d/dt ∫_S B⃗·dA⃗ = −dΦ_B/dt. Negative sign is Lenz's law — induced emf opposes change in flux.

Magnetism.front: Lenz's law (qualitative).
Magnetism.back: Direction of induced current is such that its magnetic field opposes the change in original magnetic flux that produced it (consequence of energy conservation).

Magnetism.front: Motional emf (conductor moving in B).
Magnetism.back: If a conductor of length ℓ moves with velocity v perpendicular to B, emf induced between ends: ε = B·ℓ·v (when ℓ ⟂ v and ℓ ⟂ B).

Magnetism.front: Self-inductance L — definition.
Magnetism.back: Self-inductance L of a coil: flux linkage N·Φ = L·I. Unit: henry (H). Induced emf by changing current: ε = −L·(dI/dt).

Magnetism.front: Energy stored in an inductor (formula).
Magnetism.back: Magnetic energy U = 1/2·L·I². Energy density in magnetic field in linear medium: u = B² / (2·μ).

Magnetism.front: Mutual inductance M between two coils.
Magnetism.back: Mutual flux linkage: Φ_21 = M·I₁ (flux in coil 2 due to current I₁). Induced emf in 2: ε₂ = −M·(dI₁/dt). Reciprocity: M_{12} = M_{21}.

Magnetism.front: Eddy currents — cause and effect.
Magnetism.back: Time-varying magnetic fields induce circulating currents in conductors (eddy currents). They produce heating and oppose change of flux; reduced by laminations or using non-conducting cores.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic circuits — magnetic analogue of Ohm's law.
Magnetism.back: Magnetomotive force F_m = N·I. Reluctance ℜ = l / (μ·A). Flux Φ = F_m / ℜ (analogous to V = I·R). Useful for designing transformers, cores.

Magnetism.front: Reluctance ℜ — definition and unit analogy.
Magnetism.back: Reluctance ℜ = l / (μ·A) where l length of magnetic path, A cross-sectional area, μ permeability. Unit: A·turns per weber (analogous to ohm).

Magnetism.front: Permeability μ, relative permeability μ_r and susceptibility χ_m.
Magnetism.back: μ = μ0·μ_r. Magnetic susceptibility χ_m relates M = χ_m·H. For linear media μ_r = 1 + χ_m.

Magnetism.front: Magnetization M⃗ — definition.
Magnetism.back: Magnetization M⃗ is magnetic dipole moment per unit volume (A·m⁻¹). It describes how material responds to applied H field (alignment of atomic moments).

Magnetism.front: Types of magnetic materials: diamagnetic, paramagnetic, ferromagnetic (short).
Magnetism.back: Diamagnetic: χ_m < 0, weakly repelled by B (all materials show weak diamagnetism). Paramagnetic: χ_m > 0 small, weak attraction. Ferromagnetic: large positive susceptibility, spontaneous magnetization, domain formation, strong attraction and hysteresis.

Magnetism.front: Curie temperature (T_C) and magnetic ordering.
Magnetism.back: Curie temperature T_C is temperature above which ferromagnetic material becomes paramagnetic (thermal agitation destroys long-range alignment). Each ferromagnet has characteristic T_C.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic domains (concept).
Magnetism.back: Ferromagnetic materials partition into domains where atomic moments are aligned. Domains reduce net external field; alignment of domains under applied H gives macroscopic magnetization.

Magnetism.front: Hysteresis loop — remanence and coercivity definitions.
Magnetism.back: Hysteresis loop plots B (or M) vs H when cycling applied field. Remanence (B_r) = residual induction at H = 0. Coercivity (H_c) = reverse H needed to reduce B (or M) to zero. Area of loop ∝ energy loss per cycle.

Magnetism.front: Soft vs hard magnetic materials — uses.
Magnetism.back: Soft magnetic materials: low coercivity, low hysteresis loss (used for transformer cores). Hard magnetic materials: high coercivity, retain magnetization (used for permanent magnets).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic circuits with air gaps — effect on reluctance.
Magnetism.back: Air gaps greatly increase reluctance (since μ_air ≈ μ0 ≪ μ_core). Gaps reduce saturation and control flux; flux concentrates in core while gap dominates total reluctance.

Magnetism.front: Demagnetizing field and shape effects.
Magnetism.back: Magnetized body produces internal demagnetizing fields depending on shape (demagnetizing factor). Long slender rod has small demagnetizing field; flat disc large demagnetizing field affecting net B and M.

Magnetism.front: Boundary conditions for B and H at interfaces.
Magnetism.back: Normal component of B continuous: B1_n = B2_n (since ∇·B = 0). Tangential component of H has jump equal to surface current K: n̂ × (H2 − H1) = K⃗_free.

Magnetism.front: Screening and shielding of magnetic fields (Faraday vs magnetic).
Magnetism.back: Static magnetic fields are not blocked by conductors as electric fields are; high-μ materials (mu-metal) provide magnetic shielding by providing low-reluctance path diverting flux. Superconductors expel magnetic fields (Meissner effect).

Magnetism.front: Meissner effect (superconductivity & magnetism).
Magnetism.back: Superconductors below critical temperature expel magnetic flux (perfect diamagnetism), causing magnetic field lines to be excluded from bulk (distinct from ideal conductor behavior).

Magnetism.front: Magnetostatic potentials and vector potential A⃗.
Magnetism.back: Since ∇·B = 0, magnetic field can be written as B⃗ = ∇×A⃗ where A⃗ is vector potential. Gauge choices (e.g., Coulomb gauge ∇·A = 0) used in solving problems.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic scalar potential (where applicable).
Magnetism.back: In current-free regions (∇×B = 0) one can define scalar potential ψ_m with H = −∇ψ_m. Not globally applicable where currents exist.

Magnetism.front: Force on magnetic dipole in non-uniform field.
Magnetism.back: Net force on dipole μ⃗ in field B⃗: F⃗ = ∇(μ⃗·B⃗) (for small dipole aligned). Dipole moves toward region of stronger field if oriented suitably.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic pressure (surface mechanical effect).
Magnetism.back: Magnetic pressure on surface related to energy density: p_mag ≈ B² / (2·μ). Surfaces with field lines tend to experience mechanical stresses.

Magnetism.front: Cyclotron motion — charged particle in uniform B.
Magnetism.back: Charged particle q with perpendicular velocity v⊥ in uniform B moves in circle with radius r = m·v⊥ / (|q|·B). Cyclotron frequency ω_c = |q|·B / m (independent of speed).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic mirror effect (qualitative).
Magnetism.back: Particles moving along converging field lines experience increasing perpendicular B, increasing magnetic moment causes reflection if parallel velocity becomes zero → particle trapped between mirror points (used in fusion devices and Earth's magnetosphere).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic reconnection (brief, qualitative).
Magnetism.back: Process where magnetic field lines rearrange topology in plasma, converting magnetic energy into kinetic/thermal energy — important in solar flares and space plasmas (advanced topic).

Magnetism.front: Eddy-current braking and magnetic damping (applications).
Magnetism.back: Moving conductor in non-uniform B induces eddy currents that oppose motion (Lenz). Used for contactless braking and damping (e.g., magnetic braking in trains, damping in galvanometers).

Magnetism.front: Hall probe — measuring B using Hall effect (principle).
Magnetism.back: Hall voltage V_H = (I·B) / (n·q·t) across a thin conductor carrying current I in magnetic field B. Hall probes provide direct local measurement of B and sign of carriers.

Magnetism.front: Magnetic susceptibility and Curie's law (paramagnets).
Magnetism.back: For paramagnets at high T, susceptibility χ_m ≈ C / T (Curie's law) where C is Curie constant. χ_m small and positive for paramagnets.

Magnetism.front: Magnetostriction — definition and effect.
Magnetism.back: Magnetostriction is change in dimensions of ferromagnetic material when magnetized (used in sensors, actuators; also causes noise in transformers).

Magnetism.front: Transformer cores and hysteresis/eddy loss considerations.
Magnetism.back: Transformer cores use soft magnetic materials with low hysteresis loss and laminated or ferrite cores to reduce eddy current losses. Core design balances permeability, saturation and loss.

Magnetism.front: Saturation magnetization — concept.
Magnetism.back: In ferromagnets, magnetization saturates at high H when most domains aligned; further increase in H yields little additional M and B approaches μ0·(H + M_s).

Magnetism.front: Magnetic circuit example: flux in solenoid core with gap (approach).
Magnetism.back: Compute MMF F_m = N·I. Compute reluctances of core and gap ℜ_core = l_core/(μ_core·A), ℜ_gap = l_gap/(μ0·A). Total ℜ = ℜ_core + ℜ_gap. Flux Φ = F_m / ℜ.

Magnetism.front: Remanent magnetization and use in permanent magnets.
Magnetism.back: Remanence (residual B when H returned to zero) determines strength of permanent magnets. High remanence and coercivity desirable for strong, stable permanent magnets.

Magnetism.front: Common magnetic materials and their applications (summary).
Magnetism.back: Soft iron/permalloy: transformer cores, electromagnets (high μ_r, low coercivity). Ferrites: high-frequency cores (low eddy losses). NdFeB, SmCo: strong permanent magnets. Mu-metal: magnetic shielding.

Magnetism.front: Practical exam tips for magnetism problems (checklist).
Magnetism.back: 1) Identify symmetry and choose Ampère loop carefully. 2) Use Biot–Savart for finite wires or loops. 3) Keep vector directions (right-hand rule) consistent. 4) Distinguish B and H and use material relations. 5) Apply Faraday + Lenz carefully for induced emf sign.

Magnetism.front: Short formula cheat-sheet (magnetism).
Magnetism.back:
Lorentz: F = q·(v × B)
Wire: F = I·(ℓ × B)
Long wire: B = μ0·I / (2·π·r)
Loop centre: B = μ0·I / (2·R)
Solenoid: B = μ0·n·I
Toroid: B = μ0·N·I/(2·π·r)
Flux: Φ = ∫ B·dA
Faraday: ε = −dΦ/dt
Self L: Φ = L·I, ε = −L·dI/dt
Energy: U = 1/2·L·I², u = B²/(2μ)
Force between wires: F/L = μ0·I₁·I₂/(2·π·r)
Ampère: ∮ B·dℓ = μ0·I_enclosed
∇·B = 0, ∇×B = μ0·J + μ0·ε0·∂E/∂t

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: What is an atom (basic definition)?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: An atom is the smallest unit of an element that retains chemical identity. It consists of a small positively charged nucleus (protons + neutrons) surrounded by electrons in bound states.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Constituents of nucleus — notation and meaning.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Proton (p): charge +e, mass ≈ 1.007276 u. Neutron (n): neutral, mass ≈ 1.008665 u. Atomic number Z = number of protons. Mass number A = Z + N (N = number of neutrons).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Isotopes, isobars and isotones — definitions.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Isotopes: same Z, different N (same element different mass). Isobars: same A, different Z (different elements, same mass number). Isotones: same N, different Z.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Atomic mass unit (u) and conversion.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: 1 unified atomic mass unit u = 1/12 mass of 12C ≈ 1.66053906660×10⁻²⁷ kg. Energy equivalent 1 u c² ≈ 931.494 MeV.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Mass defect and binding energy — what are they?
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Mass defect Δm = (Z·m_p + N·m_n − m_nucleus). Binding energy B = Δm·c² — energy required to separate nucleus into individual nucleons. Binding energy per nucleon = B / A indicates nuclear stability.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Semi-empirical mass formula (liquid-drop idea) — terms qualitatively.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: B(A,Z) ≈ a_v A − a_s A^{2/3} − a_c Z(Z−1)/A^{1/3} − a_a (A−2Z)²/A + δ(A,Z) (pairing term). Terms: volume, surface, Coulomb, asymmetry, pairing.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Nuclear binding energy curve and stability.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Binding energy per nucleon rises rapidly to peak near A ≈ 56 (Fe/Ni) then slowly decreases. Light nuclei can gain energy by fusion; heavy nuclei by fission.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Nuclear force characteristics (qualitative).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Strong nuclear force: attractive at ~1–2 fm, short-range (falls off beyond a few fm), charge-independent (acts between p–p, n–n, p–n with slight differences), much stronger than Coulomb at short distances.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Rutherford model of atom — key result from scattering.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Most α particles pass through thin foil; few scatter at large angles → nucleus is small, massive and positively charged. This replaced plum-pudding model.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Bohr model — quantization postulates (brief).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Electrons move in circular orbits where angular momentum m·v·r = n·ħ (n = 1,2,...). Radiation occurs only when electron jumps between stationary orbits; energy levels E_n = −(13.6 eV)·(Z² / n²) for hydrogen-like atoms.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Rydberg formula for hydrogen-like spectral lines.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: 1/λ = R·Z²·(1/n_f² − 1/n_i²) where R ≈ 1.097×10⁷ m⁻¹ is Rydberg constant, Z nuclear charge, n_i > n_f integers.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Quantum numbers for electron in atom (principal, azimuthal, magnetic, spin).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: n principal (1,2,...), ℓ azimuthal (0..n−1) (s,p,d,f correspond to 0,1,2,3), m_ℓ magnetic (−ℓ..+ℓ), m_s spin (±1/2). Pauli exclusion: no two electrons in atom have identical set of four quantum numbers.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Pauli exclusion principle — statement and consequence.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: No two identical fermions (e.g., electrons) can occupy same quantum state simultaneously. Determines electronic structure, periodic table and chemical properties.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Spin and magnetic moment of electron (brief).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Electron spin s = 1/2 with magnetic moment μ_s ≈ −g·(eħ)/(2m_e)·ŝ (g ≈ 2 for electron). Spin gives rise to fine structure and magnetic interactions.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Fine structure (qualitative) in atomic spectra.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Small splittings of energy levels due to relativistic corrections and spin–orbit coupling. Observed as closely spaced spectral lines.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Zeeman effect — splitting in magnetic field.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Presence of external magnetic field splits atomic energy levels according to m_j (magnetic quantum number), producing multiple spectral components. Normal Zeeman: triplet for spinless levels; anomalous Zeeman includes spin.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Stark effect — electric-field induced splitting.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: External electric field perturbs atomic energy levels causing splitting/shifting of spectral lines (linear or quadratic Stark effect depending on level symmetry).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: X-rays — origin and types (characteristic and continuous).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Continuous (bremsstrahlung): deceleration of electrons in target. Characteristic X-rays: inner-shell electron ejection and electron transitions to fill vacancy produce lines (K_α, K_β etc.).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Moseley's law for X-ray frequencies.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: √ν ∝ (Z − σ) (effective nuclear charge). More commonly frequency of K_α lines scales like (Z − 1)² approximately, enabling atomic number determination.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Photoelectric effect — Einstein equation.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: K_max = h·ν − φ where φ is work function. Demonstrates quantization (photons) and energy–frequency relation E = h·ν. Threshold frequency ν_0 = φ / h.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Compton scattering — photon wavelength shift formula.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Δλ = λ′ − λ = (h / (m_e·c))·(1 − cosθ) where θ is scattering angle. Compton wavelength of electron λ_c = h / (m_e·c) ≈ 2.426×10⁻¹² m.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Pair production — photon energy threshold and process.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Photon converts to electron–positron pair in presence of nucleus; threshold E_γ ≥ 2·m_e·c² ≈ 1.022 MeV. Excess energy shared as kinetic energy.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Atomic excitation vs ionization (definitions).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Excitation: electron promoted to higher bound state (discrete energy absorbed). Ionization: electron removed completely from atom (energy ≥ ionization potential).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Auger effect (brief description).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Non-radiative de-excitation: energy from filling inner-shell vacancy transfers to another electron which is ejected (Auger electron) instead of emitting X-ray photon.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Radioactivity — types of decay α, β⁻, β⁺, γ (basic descriptions).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: α decay: emission of ⁴He nucleus (α, charge +2) — reduces A by 4, Z by 2. β⁻ decay: neutron → proton + e⁻ + ν̄_e (emits electron). β⁺ decay (positron emission): proton → neutron + e⁺ + ν_e. γ decay: emission of high-energy photon from excited nucleus; no change in A or Z.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Conservation laws in nuclear decay (which quantities conserved).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Conserved: energy, linear momentum, angular momentum, electric charge, baryon number (nucleons), lepton number (when including neutrinos).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Decay law (exponential) and definitions.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Number of undecayed nuclei N(t) = N₀·e^{−λt} where λ is decay constant. Activity A(t) = −dN/dt = λ·N(t).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Half-life T_{1/2} and mean life τ — relations.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: T_{1/2} = ln2 / λ. Mean life τ = 1 / λ. T_{1/2} ≈ 0.693·τ. Activity halves every T_{1/2}.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Activity units — Bq and Ci.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Becquerel (Bq) = 1 decay·s⁻¹. Curie (Ci) ≈ 3.7×10¹⁰ Bq (historical).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Branching ratio (in decays).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: If nucleus has multiple decay modes, branching ratio for mode i = fraction of decays that proceed via mode i (sum of branching ratios = 1).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Q-value of nuclear reaction/decay.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Q = (mass_initial − mass_final)·c². Positive Q → exothermic (energy released), negative Q → endothermic (requires energy).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Beta decay spectrum and neutrino role.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: β decay produces continuous electron energy spectrum — explained by three-body decay including neutrino (ν or ν̄) carrying away variable fraction of energy; conservation of energy and momentum requires neutrino.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Electron capture (K-capture) — process and consequence.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Proton in nucleus captures orbital electron (often K-shell) converting to neutron and emitting neutrino: p + e⁻ → n + ν_e. Leaves inner-shell vacancy leading to X-rays/Auger electrons.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Internal conversion — alternative to γ emission.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Instead of emitting γ, nucleus transfers excitation energy directly to an atomic electron which is ejected (internal conversion electron). Competes with γ emission.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Alpha decay characteristics (penetration and ionization).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: α particles are heavy, +2 charge, highly ionizing but low penetration (stopped by few cm air or paper). Energies ~4–9 MeV. α decay follows quantum tunnelling through Coulomb barrier.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Quantum tunnelling explanation for α decay.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: α particle preformed in nucleus tunnels through Coulomb barrier even if its kinetic energy less than barrier height; tunnelling probability determines half-life (Gamow theory).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Fermi theory (β decay) basics (conceptual).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: β decay arises from weak interaction; Fermi's theory treats transition as point-like interaction producing electron and neutrino with selection rules; modern treatment via weak interaction and V−A theory.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Nuclear reaction notation and conservation.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: General form: A(a,b)B or a + A → b + B. Must conserve A (mass number), Z (charge), energy and momentum, and other quantum numbers (spin, parity) where applicable.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Cross-section σ — definition and unit (barn).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Reaction cross-section σ is effective target area for a given nuclear reaction (probability measure). Unit 1 barn = 10⁻²⁸ m². Reaction rate ∝ flux × σ × number of targets.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Neutron interactions: scattering vs absorption vs capture.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Neutrons may scatter elastically/inelastically (transfer energy), or be absorbed (capture) leading to reactions (n,γ) or (n,α) etc. Capture cross-section often large for thermal neutrons in some isotopes.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Thermal vs fast neutrons — definitions & relevance.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Thermal neutrons: kinetic energies ~0.025 eV (in equilibrium with room temperature). Fast neutrons: MeV energies. Many nuclei have much higher capture cross-sections for thermal neutrons — important in reactors.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Moderator and its role in reactors.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Moderator (e.g., graphite, heavy water, light water) slows down fast neutrons to thermal energies via elastic scattering, increasing probability of fission in certain fuels (e.g., ²³⁵U).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Fission — basics and energy release.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Heavy nucleus absorbs neutron and splits into two (or more) lighter fragments + multiple neutrons + energy (~200 MeV per fission). Energy from mass defect (binding energy differences).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Chain reaction and criticality (subcritical, critical, supercritical).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Effective multiplication factor k: if k < 1 → subcritical (reaction dies out), k = 1 → critical (steady), k > 1 → supercritical (increasing reaction). Critical mass is amount of fissile material needed for k ≥ 1 under given geometry and conditions.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Control rods — purpose and materials.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Control rods absorb neutrons to regulate fission rate and maintain criticality. Typical materials: cadmium, boron (B-10), hafnium due to large neutron capture cross-sections.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Types of reactors (basic categories).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Thermal reactors (use moderators to run on thermal neutrons), fast reactors (no moderator, rely on fast neutrons), pressurized water reactor (PWR), boiling water reactor (BWR), heavy-water reactor (CANDU), breeder reactors (produce more fissile material).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Breeder reactor concept (brief).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Breeder converts fertile isotopes (e.g., ²³⁸U, ²³⁹Pu production) into fissile fuel, potentially producing more fissile material than consumed, expanding fuel resources.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Nuclear fusion basics and energy conditions.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Fusion: light nuclei combine (e.g., D + T → ⁴He + n + 17.6 MeV) releasing energy. Requires overcoming Coulomb barrier — high temperature and/or quantum tunnelling, confinement (magnetic/inertial).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Q-value examples for fusion and fission.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Typical fission Q ≈ 200 MeV per event (heavy nuclei). D–T fusion Q ≈ 17.6 MeV per reaction. Energy per mass from fusion/fission far exceeds chemical reactions (e.g., combustion).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Radioactive decay chains and secular equilibrium.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Series of successive decays leading toward stable nuclide (e.g., ²³⁸U → ... → ²⁰⁶Pb). Secular equilibrium: parent half-life ≫ daughter half-life → activity of daughter ≈ activity of parent after transient.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Detection of radiation — common detectors and principles.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Geiger–Müller counter (ionization gas amplification, pulse counts), Scintillation detectors (light produced in scintillator → photomultiplier → pulse), Semiconductor detectors (e.g., Si, Ge p–n junctions measure energy), Ionization chambers (measure current proportional to dose).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Geiger–Müller characteristics and limitations.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Counts individual ionizing events; has dead time (cannot record immediately successive events), limited energy information (pulse height not proportional to energy), good for surveys and gross activity.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Dosimetry units — gray and sievert.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Gray (Gy) = 1 J·kg⁻¹ absorbed dose (physical). Sievert (Sv) = dose equivalent accounting biological weighting (Sv = Gy × Q × tissue factors); used for health effects. 1 Sv large; typical occupational limits in mSv.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Radiation shielding basics (materials and interactions).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Alpha stopped by paper or skin, beta by plastic/Al, gamma/ X-rays require dense/high-Z materials (lead, concrete) with exponential attenuation I = I₀·e^{−μx} where μ linear attenuation coefficient; neutrons require hydrogenous materials for slowing and high-capture materials for absorption.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Half-value layer (HVL) concept.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: HVL is thickness of material that reduces gamma/X-ray intensity by 50%: HVL = ln2 / μ. Useful for shielding design and attenuation estimates.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Photo-disintegration (γ,n) reactions — concept.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: High-energy photons can eject neutrons from nuclei (photonuclear reactions) if E_γ exceeds separation energy of neutron. Occurs at MeV-scale photon energies.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: K-shell binding energies and characteristic X-ray nomenclature (K, L, M).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Inner shell (K) has highest binding energy; K_α corresponds to transition L → K, K_β to M → K, etc. Energies scale roughly as (Z − σ)².

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Nuclear shell model — magic numbers and consequences.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Nucleons occupy discrete single-particle levels; closed shells at 'magic numbers' (2, 8, 20, 28, 50, 82, 126) confer extra stability (observed in binding energy jumps and abundance).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Pairing and odd–even effects in nuclear masses.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Nuclei with even Z and even N are generally more tightly bound (pairing energy); odd–odd are less stable; manifests in nuclear mass systematics and decay patterns.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Beta-delayed processes (brief).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: After β decay, daughter nucleus may be formed in excited state and subsequently emit γ or particle (β-delayed neutron emission important in reactor physics and nucleosynthesis).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Astrophysical nucleosynthesis basics (s- and r-process).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: s-process (slow neutron capture) occurs in stars producing heavy stable isotopes along valley of β stability. r-process (rapid neutron capture) occurs in explosive environments (supernovae, neutron-star mergers) producing very neutron-rich nuclei.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Applications of radioisotopes (brief list).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Medical diagnostics (PET, SPECT), radiotherapy (cancer treatment), industrial radiography, tracer studies, dating (C-14), sterilization, power (RTGs).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Radioactive dating (carbon-14) principle.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Living organisms maintain equilibrium C-14/C-12; after death intake stops and C-14 decays (T_{1/2} ≈ 5730 y). Measure remaining activity to estimate age up to ~50,000 y with calibration.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Beta decay selection rules (spin and parity notes).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Allowed and forbidden transitions depend on change in nuclear angular momentum and parity. Allowed (ΔJ = 0,±1 with no parity change) transitions have higher probability (shorter half-lives).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Conservation of angular momentum and parity in nuclear transitions.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Photon emission γ carries multipole radiation (Eλ or Mλ) with angular momentum λ; selection rules relate initial and final nuclear spins and parity (parity change depends on electric/magnetic multipole).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Isomeric states and nuclear isomers (metastable states).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Nuclei can have long-lived excited states (isomers) that decay via γ emission or internal conversion with significantly longer half-lives due to large spin change or inhibited transitions.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Muon capture and exotic decay modes (brief).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Muon can be captured by nucleus (negative muon substitution for orbital electron) leading to nuclear transmutation; exotic decays beyond standard α/β/γ exist but are rare and specialized.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Neutrinos in nuclear physics — roles and properties.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Neutrinos (ν_e, ν_μ, ν_τ) are neutral, very low-mass particles produced in weak interactions (β decay). They interact weakly, escape dense media, and are crucial for energy/momentum balance in weak decays.
