Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Inverse beta (inverse β) reactions (basic example).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: ν̄_e + p → n + e⁺ (inverse beta) used in reactor neutrino detection (e.g., via delayed coincidence between positron annihilation and neutron capture).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Conservation of lepton number in weak decays.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Lepton number is conserved (electron-type leptons separate from others) in standard β processes; neutrino emission preserves lepton number accounting.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Radiation safety principles: time, distance, shielding.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Minimize exposure time, maximize distance (inverse-square reduction), use appropriate shielding material for radiation type; monitor with dosimeters and follow ALARA (as low as reasonably achievable).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Activation of materials — induced radioactivity.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Materials exposed to neutrons can become radioactive via (n,γ) or other reactions producing radioisotopes (consider in reactor operation and handling irradiated components).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Criticality accidents — basic concept and prevention.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Accidental assembly of supercritical mass leading to uncontrolled chain reaction; prevention via geometry control, neutron absorbers, limiting moderator presence, and strict procedural controls.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Neutron moderation and scattering kinematics (energy loss per collision).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Energy loss per elastic collision depends on mass ratio; light nuclei (hydrogen) most effective moderators. Average fractional energy loss per collision α = ((A−1)/(A+1))² for target nucleus mass A (in nucleon units).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Cross-section resonance behaviour (qualitative).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Neutron capture cross-sections often show resonances at specific energies corresponding to nuclear excited states — large σ at resonances (important in reactor calculations and activation).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Saturation activity and build-up formula (when irradiating a sample).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Activity during irradiation A(t) = R (1 − e^{−λt}) where R production rate = φ·σ·N_target. Saturation activity A_sat = R when t ≫ 1/λ.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Nuclear databases and notation (how to read e.g., ²³⁵U).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Notation A^Z X or ^A X_Z: A mass number as superscript, Z atomic number as subscript, X chemical symbol. Example: ^235U means uranium with A = 235.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Common radioisotopes and uses (short list).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: C-14 dating, Co-60 radiotherapy and industrial radiography, Tc-99m medical imaging, I-131 thyroid therapy/diagnosis, Cs-137 calibration/source, Pu-238 RTGs (space).

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Practical exam tips for atomic & nuclear questions.
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: Keep track of units (eV, MeV), use mass-energy equivalence for Q-values, check conservation laws, know typical numeric constants (m_e c² ≈ 511 keV, 1 u ≈ 931.5 MeV), draw decay/reaction schemes, and practice half-life/activity calculations.

Atomic & Nuclear Physics.front: Quick constants & useful numbers (handy cheat-sheet).
Atomic & Nuclear Physics.back: m_e c² ≈ 511 keV. 1 u c² ≈ 931.494 MeV. α-particle energy ∼ few MeV. Electron charge e = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C. ħ ≈ 6.582×10⁻²² MeV·s (or 1.055×10⁻³⁴ J·s). Neutron mass ≈ 1.008665 u. Proton mass ≈ 1.007276 u.

Introduction to Chemistry.back: Chemistry is the science that studies the composition, structure, properties and changes of matter and the energy changes that accompany these processes.
Analytical, Physical, Organic, Inorganic, Biochemistry, Theoretical/Computational — each focuses on different types of substances or methods.
Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space (volume). It exists in three common states: solid, liquid and gas; plasma is another state at very high energy.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Difference between element, compound and mixture.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Element: pure substance of one kind of atom (e.g., O). Compound: chemically combined elements in fixed ratio (e.g., H₂O). Mixture: physical combination of substances with variable composition (homogeneous = solution, heterogeneous = suspension).
Pure substance has constant composition & distinct properties (element or compound). Mixture’s components retain individual properties and can vary in proportion.
Physical change: no change in chemical identity (e.g., melting, dissolving). Chemical change: new substances form with different composition (e.g., combustion, rusting).
In a closed system mass is neither created nor destroyed during a chemical reaction — total mass of reactants = total mass of products (Lavoisier).
A given compound always contains its component elements in fixed mass ratios (e.g., water is always ~88.81% O and ~11.19% H by mass).
If two elements form more than one compound, the masses of one element that combine with a fixed mass of the other are in small integer ratios (e.g., CO and CO₂).
Matter made of atoms; atoms of an element identical in mass & properties (modern: isotopes refine this); compounds formed by combinations of atoms in fixed ratios; chemical reactions rearrange atoms.
Atom consists of nucleus (protons p⁺ positive, neutrons n⁰ neutral) and electrons e⁻ (negative) in surrounding cloud. Atomic number Z = number of protons; mass number A = Z + N (neutrons).
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with same Z but different A (different neutrons). Example: ¹²C, ¹³C, ¹⁴C — same chemistry, different mass & some nuclear properties.
Format A/Z X where A = mass number (superscript), Z = atomic number (subscript), X = element symbol. Example: ¹⁴₆C has 6 protons and 8 neutrons.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: What is an ion? Cation vs anion.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Ion: charged atom or group of atoms. Cation: positively charged (lost e⁻). Anion: negatively charged (gained e⁻).
Relative atomic mass is average mass of atoms (weighted by isotopic abundance) relative to ¹²C. 1 u = 1.66053906660×10⁻²⁷ kg.
A mole is 6.02214076×10²³ entities (Avogadro's number). It links microscopic particle counts to macroscopic measurable amounts (mass, volume, concentration).
N_A = 6.02214076×10²³ mol⁻¹ (exact SI-defined).
Molar mass is mass per mole of substance (g·mol⁻¹). Numerically equal to relative molecular/atomic mass but with units g·mol⁻¹ (e.g., M(H₂O) ≈ 18.015 g·mol⁻¹).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: How to calculate moles from mass and vice versa.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: n (mol) = mass (g) / M (g·mol⁻¹). mass = n × M.
Empirical formula: simplest integer ratio of atoms in a compound (e.g., CH₂ for polymer monomer). Molecular formula: actual number of atoms (e.g., C₂H₄). Molecular = empirical × integer factor.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: How to determine empirical formula from percent composition (outline).
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Convert % to grams (assume 100 g), convert grams → moles for each element, divide by smallest mole, obtain simplest integer ratio (multiply to clear fractions).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Stoichiometry basics — balanced chemical equations importance.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Balanced equations conserve atoms/electrons; coefficients give mole ratios used for converting between reactants/products and solving limiting reagent & yield problems.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Limiting reagent concept & how to find it.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Limiting reagent is consumed first, limiting the amount of product. Compare mole ratio of available reactants to stoichiometric ratios; reagent giving least product is limiting.
Percent yield = (actual yield / theoretical yield) × 100%.
Combination (A + B → AB), decomposition (AB → A + B), displacement (single replacement), double displacement (metathesis), combustion (fuel + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O), redox (electron transfer).
Oxidation: loss of electrons (LEO = loss of electrons oxidation). Reduction: gain of electrons (GER = gain of electrons reduction). Assign oxidation numbers to track electron transfer.
Elemental form = 0. Monatomic ion = charge. O usually −2 (peroxide −1). H usually +1 (hydride −1). Sum of oxidation numbers = charge of species.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Acids and bases — Arrhenius, Brønsted–Lowry and Lewis definitions (short).
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Arrhenius: acid produces H⁺ in water; base produces OH⁻. Brønsted–Lowry: acid = H⁺ donor, base = H⁺ acceptor. Lewis: acid = electron-pair acceptor, base = electron-pair donor.
pH = −log₁₀[H⁺]. pOH = −log₁₀[OH⁻]. At 25 °C, pH + pOH = 14 because K_w = 1.0×10⁻¹⁴.
Strong acids/bases dissociate almost completely in aqueous solution (e.g., HCl, HNO₃, NaOH). Weak acids/bases partially dissociate (e.g., CH₃COOH, NH₃).

Salts form from neutralization (acid + base → salt + water). Solubility rules: nitrates and alkali salts soluble; halides mostly soluble except Ag⁺, Pb²⁺; sulfates mostly soluble except Ba²⁺, Pb²⁺, Ca²⁺ (partial). Carbonates/phosphates generally insoluble except alkali/NH₄⁺.
HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O. Neutralization is typically exothermic (releases heat).
Molarity M = moles solute / litres solution (mol·L⁻¹). Prepare solutions by dissolving required moles in final volume.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Other concentration units: molality, mass percent, ppm, mole fraction.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Molality m = mol solute / kg solvent. Mass% = mass solute / mass solution ×100. ppm ≈ mg·L⁻¹ for dilute aqueous solutions. Mole fraction xᵢ = nᵢ / Σ n_j.

Properties depending on number of solute particles, not identity: vapor-pressure lowering, boiling point elevation, freezing point depression, osmotic pressure. Use van 't Hoff factor i for electrolytes.
PV = nRT, where P = pressure, V = volume, n = moles, R = 8.314 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ (or 0.082057 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹), T = temperature (K).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Standard temperature and pressure (STP) common convention.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Many exam problems use STP = 273.15 K and 1 atm; molar volume at STP ≈ 22.414 L·mol⁻¹. Some use NTP = 298.15 K, 1 atm — check problem statement.
Total pressure of gas mixture = sum of partial pressures of components: P_total = Σ P_i. P_i = x_i · P_total (mole fraction relation).
Equal volumes of gases at same T and P contain equal numbers of molecules (V ∝ n at constant T,P).
Graham's law: rate of effusion/diffusion ∝ 1/√M (molar mass). Lighter gases diffuse/effuse faster than heavier ones.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Intermolecular forces (IMFs) — types & effect on properties.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: London dispersion (weak, all molecules), dipole–dipole (polar molecules), hydrogen bonding (H—F/O/N). Stronger IMFs → higher boiling/melting points and lower vapor pressure.

Molecular polarity depends on bond polarities and molecular geometry. If bond dipoles don't cancel → polar molecule (e.g., H₂O). Symmetric molecules with polar bonds may be nonpolar overall (e.g., CO₂).

Covalent: electron sharing between atoms (non-metals), directional bonds, molecules. Ionic: electron transfer creating ions (metal + non-metal), electrostatic attraction, high melting points and soluble in polar solvents.
Electronegativity increases across a period, decreases down a group. Large difference → ionic character; similar values → covalent. Use EN to predict bond polarity.

Lewis structure shows valence electrons and bonding. Most second-row elements follow octet (8 e⁻) in stable compounds; exceptions include electron-deficient (B), expanded octet (≥ P,S) and odd-electron species.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: VSEPR theory — predicting molecular shapes (very short).
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion: electron pairs around central atom repel, arranging to minimize repulsion → shapes like linear, trigonal planar, tetrahedral, trigonal bipyramidal, octahedral. Lone pairs alter ideal bond angles.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Basic periodic table layout & groups/periods meaning.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Periods are horizontal rows (increasing principal quantum number). Groups/families are vertical columns with similar valence electron configurations and chemical properties (e.g., Group 1 alkali metals).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Periodic trends: atomic radius, ionization energy, electron affinity.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Atomic radius decreases across a period, increases down a group. Ionization energy generally increases across, decreases down. Electron affinity generally becomes more negative across (varies).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Metals, non-metals & metalloids — general periodic positions.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Metals left and center (good conductors, malleable). Non-metals on right (poor conductors). Metalloids along boundary (B, Si, Ge, As) have intermediate properties.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: What is allotropy (brief) and common examples.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Allotropy: element exists in two or more forms with different structures & properties. Examples: carbon (diamond, graphite, graphene), phosphorus (white, red), oxygen (O₂, O₃).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Basic lab techniques: filtration, distillation, crystallization, chromatography — one-line uses.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Filtration: separate solid from liquid. Distillation: separate liquids by boiling point. Crystallization: purify solids. Chromatography: separate mixture components by affinity for stationary/mobile phases.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Titration basics — equivalence point vs end point and indicator choice.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Equivalence point = stoichiometric completion. End point = indicator colour change. Choose indicator whose transition range matches pH at equivalence (e.g., phenolphthalein for strong acid–strong base titrations gives clear colour change).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Safety essentials in a chemistry lab (short list).
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Wear PPE (goggles, gloves, lab coat). Know MSDS for chemicals. Work in fume hood for volatiles. Proper waste disposal, no eating/drinking, know emergency equipment (eyewash, fire extinguisher).
Report results to correct significant figures based on measurement precision. For multiplication/division use least significant figures; for addition/subtraction use least decimal places.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Units & conversions common in chemistry (quick examples).
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Mass: g ↔ kg (1000 g = 1 kg). Volume: mL ↔ L (1000 mL = 1 L). Pressure: atm ↔ Pa (1 atm = 101325 Pa). Energy: 1 cal = 4.184 J.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Basic thermochemistry terms: system, surroundings, exothermic vs endothermic.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: System: part under study; surroundings: rest of universe. Exothermic: releases heat (ΔH < 0). Endothermic: absorbs heat (ΔH > 0).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Enthalpy ΔH — what is measured and sign convention.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: ΔH is heat flow at constant pressure. ΔH < 0 exothermic (heat released); ΔH > 0 endothermic (heat absorbed).
Activation energy is energy barrier for reaction. Catalysts lower activation energy (increase rate) without being consumed, providing alternative pathway.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Chemical equilibrium — dynamic nature & equilibrium constant K.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: At equilibrium forward and reverse rates equal. Equilibrium constant K (for aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD): K = [C]^c [D]^d / ([A]^a [B]^b) (heterogeneous excl. solids/liquids from expression).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Le Châtelier’s principle — simple rule for shifts.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: If a system at equilibrium is disturbed (Δ[conc], ΔP, ΔT), it shifts to counteract the change and re-establish equilibrium.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Relationship between ΔG° and equilibrium constant K.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: ΔG° = −RT ln K. If K > 1 (ΔG° < 0) products favoured at equilibrium; if K < 1 (ΔG° > 0) reactants favoured.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Common exam tip: approach to stoichiometry problems (4 steps).
Introduction to Chemistry.back: 1) Write balanced equation. 2) Convert given quantities to moles. 3) Use mole ratios to find required moles. 4) Convert moles to requested units (g, L at STP, etc.).

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Practical example: number of molecules in 2.5 mol of CO₂.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Number = n × N_A = 2.5 × 6.022×10²³ ≈ 1.506×10²⁴ molecules CO₂.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: Practical example: calculate mass of 0.50 mol NaCl (M ≈ 58.44 g·mol⁻¹).
Common pitfalls students make in introductory chemistry.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Unit inconsistencies (g vs kg, L vs m³), forgetting to convert T to K in gas laws, ignoring stoichiometric coefficients, confusing molarity & molality, wrong significant figures.

Introduction to Chemistry.front: One-line strategy for tackling 'Introduction to Chemistry' MCQs.
Introduction to Chemistry.back: Identify the topic (stoichiometry, gases, acids–bases, thermochemistry), recall the key formula or law, convert units carefully, and apply stepwise with attention to sign conventions.

States of Matter.front: What are the three classical states of matter?
States of Matter.back: Solid, liquid and gas. (Plasma is a fourth state at very high energy where atoms are ionised.)

States of Matter.front: Kinetic Molecular Theory — main postulates (brief).
States of Matter.back: Particles are in constant random motion; gases consist of point particles with elastic collisions; average kinetic energy ∝ absolute temperature (T); no intermolecular forces in ideal gas.

States of Matter.front: Ideal gas law — formula and variables.
States of Matter.back: PV = nRT where P = pressure, V = volume, n = moles, R = 8.314 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ (or 0.082057 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹), T = temperature (K).

States of Matter.front: Boyle's law (isothermal) — statement & equation.
States of Matter.back: At constant T and n: P ∝ 1/V → P₁V₁ = P₂V₂.

States of Matter.front: Charles's law (isobaric) — statement & equation.
States of Matter.back: At constant P and n: V ∝ T → V₁/T₁ = V₂/T₂ (T in K).

States of Matter.front: Avogadro's law — statement.
States of Matter.back: At constant T and P, equal volumes of gases contain equal numbers of moles: V ∝ n.

States of Matter.front: Gay-Lussac's law (isovolumetric) — statement & equation.
States of Matter.back: At constant V and n: P ∝ T → P₁/T₁ = P₂/T₂.

States of Matter.front: Molar volume of an ideal gas at STP (273.15 K, 1 atm).
States of Matter.back: V_m ≈ 22.414 L·mol⁻¹ (often approximated as 22.4 L·mol⁻¹).

States of Matter.front: Relation between rms speed and temperature (formula).
States of Matter.back: u_rms = √(3RT / M) where M is molar mass in kg·mol⁻¹ and R = 8.314 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹.

States of Matter.front: Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution — what it shows.
States of Matter.back: Distribution of molecular speeds in a gas at given T: shows most probable, average and rms speeds; distribution broadens and shifts to higher speeds as T increases.

States of Matter.front: Graham's law of effusion — formula.
States of Matter.back: Rate_A / Rate_B = √(M_B / M_A). Lighter gas effuses/diffuses faster.

States of Matter.front: Mean free path (qualitative) — what is it?
States of Matter.back: Average distance a gas molecule travels between collisions. Increases as pressure decreases or molecular size decreases.

States of Matter.front: Van der Waals equation for real gases (form).
States of Matter.back: (P + a(n/V)²)(V − nb) = nRT where a corrects for intermolecular attractions and b for finite molecular volume.

States of Matter.front: What is compressibility factor Z?
States of Matter.back: Z = PV / (nRT). For ideal gas Z = 1. Deviations (Z ≠ 1) indicate non-ideality due to molecular size or interactions.

States of Matter.front: Critical temperature (T_c) and critical pressure (P_c) — definitions.
States of Matter.back: T_c = maximum temperature where gas can be liquefied by pressure alone. P_c = pressure required to liquefy at T_c. Above T_c no distinct liquid phase exists (supercritical fluid).

States of Matter.front: Supercritical fluid — properties & example use.
States of Matter.back: State above T_c and P_c with gas-like diffusivity and liquid-like density. Used as solvent in supercritical CO₂ extraction (decaffeination, extraction).

States of Matter.front: Vapour pressure — definition.
States of Matter.back: Equilibrium pressure of vapour above a liquid (or solid) at a given T. Increases with T; when vapour pressure = external pressure, liquid boils.

States of Matter.front: Boiling point & its dependence on pressure.
States of Matter.back: Temperature at which vapour pressure equals external pressure. Lower at high altitudes (lower P), higher under pressure (pressure cookers raise boiling point).

States of Matter.front: Clausius–Clapeyron equation (integrated form useful in exams).
States of Matter.back: ln(P₂/P₁) = −ΔH_vap / R · (1/T₂ − 1/T₁) where ΔH_vap is enthalpy of vaporisation, R gas constant, T in K.

States of Matter.front: Latent heat (fusion & vaporisation) — meaning.
States of Matter.back: Energy required per unit mass (or per mole) to change phase at constant T: latent heat of fusion (melting) and latent heat of vaporisation (boiling/evaporation).

States of Matter.front: Heat of vaporisation vs heat of fusion (typical relation).
States of Matter.back: ΔH_vap >> ΔH_fus typically (vapourising requires breaking more intermolecular interactions than melting).

States of Matter.front: Surface tension — definition & molecular origin.
States of Matter.back: Energy (or work) required to increase unit surface area of liquid. Caused by stronger cohesive forces between molecules in bulk than at surface; leads to phenomena like droplet shape and capillarity.

States of Matter.front: Capillary action — cause & formula factors.
States of Matter.back: Rise or fall of liquid in narrow tube due to surface tension and adhesion with tube walls. Height h ∝ 2γ cosθ / (ρ g r) where γ = surface tension, θ = contact angle, ρ = density, r = tube radius.

States of Matter.front: Viscosity — what it measures and trend with temperature.
States of Matter.back: Measure of a fluid's resistance to flow (internal friction). For liquids viscosity decreases with increasing T; for gases viscosity increases with T.

States of Matter.front: Diffusion in liquids vs gases — qualitative comparison.
States of Matter.back: Diffusion much faster in gases (molecules farther apart, higher speeds) than in liquids (denser, stronger interactions) and slowest in solids (solid diffusion through defects).

States of Matter.front: Evaporation vs boiling — difference.
States of Matter.back: Evaporation: surface phenomenon at T below boiling point; molecules with sufficient KE escape. Boiling: bulk phenomenon where vapour bubbles form throughout liquid when vapour pressure = external pressure.

States of Matter.front: Triple point — definition & significance.
States of Matter.back: Unique T and P where three phases (solid, liquid, gas) coexist in equilibrium. Used to define temperature standards (e.g., triple point of water).

States of Matter.front: Phase diagram axes & regions — basics.
States of Matter.back: P–T phase diagram maps regions where solid, liquid and gas are stable; lines are phase boundaries; critical point and triple point shown; melting curve slope indicates relative densities (e.g., water's negative slope).

States of Matter.front: Why water has negative slope of solid–liquid line in phase diagram.
States of Matter.back: Ice is less dense than liquid water; increasing pressure lowers melting point (melting favoured), giving a negative slope (Clapeyron relation).

States of Matter.front: Sublimation — definition & example.
States of Matter.back: Direct solid → gas transition without passing through liquid (at pressures/temperatures where liquid is not stable). Example: dry ice (solid CO₂) sublimes at 1 atm.

States of Matter.front: Deposition — definition & example.
States of Matter.back: Direct gas → solid transition (reverse of sublimation). Example: frost formation from water vapour.

States of Matter.front: Solid types — classification (brief).
States of Matter.back: Crystalline solids (long-range order) and amorphous solids (no long-range order; e.g., glass, rubber). Crystalline subdivided: ionic, covalent (network), molecular, metallic solids.

States of Matter.front: Ionic, molecular, covalent network & metallic solids — general properties.
States of Matter.back: Ionic: high mp, brittle, conduct when molten/aqueous. Molecular: low mp, soft, poor conductors. Covalent network (diamond, SiO₂): very high mp, hard, poor conductors (except graphite). Metallic: variable mp, good conductors, malleable due to delocalised electrons.

States of Matter.front: Unit cell — definition and lattice vs basis idea (short).
States of Matter.back: Unit cell: smallest repeating unit of a crystal lattice that builds the entire crystal by translation. Lattice = array of points; basis = atoms associated with each lattice point.

States of Matter.front: Seven crystal systems (list).
States of Matter.back: Cubic, tetragonal, orthorhombic, monoclinic, triclinic, hexagonal, trigonal (rhombohedral).

States of Matter.front: Bravais lattices — how many in 3D?
States of Matter.back: 14 Bravais lattices (distinct lattice types in 3D considering centring types).

States of Matter.front: Simple cubic (SC) — atoms per unit cell, coordination number, packing efficiency.
States of Matter.back: SC: 1 atom per cell (8 corner atoms × 1/8), coordination number 6, packing efficiency ≈ 52.4%.

States of Matter.front: Body-centred cubic (BCC) — atoms per cell, CN, packing efficiency & example metals.
States of Matter.back: BCC: 2 atoms per cell (8 corners ×1/8 + 1 centre), CN = 8, packing efficiency ≈ 68%. Examples: Fe (α-Fe), Cr, W.

States of Matter.front: Face-centred cubic (FCC / CCP) — atoms per cell, CN, packing efficiency & examples.
States of Matter.back: FCC/CCP: 4 atoms per cell (8 corners ×1/8 + 6 faces ×1/2), CN = 12, packing efficiency ≈ 74% (highest for spheres). Examples: Cu, Al, Ag, Au.

States of Matter.front: Hexagonal close packing (HCP) — CN and packing efficiency.
States of Matter.back: HCP: coordination number 12, packing efficiency ≈ 74% (same as FCC). Example metals: Mg, Zn (different c/a ratios).

States of Matter.front: Packing efficiency concept — what it means.
States of Matter.back: Fraction of space occupied by atoms (modelled as spheres) in a unit cell; higher packing efficiency = denser atomic packing.

States of Matter.front: Relationship between edge length a and atomic radius r for FCC and BCC (useful formulas).
States of Matter.back: FCC: face diagonal = 4r → a = 4r / √2 = 2√2 r. BCC: body diagonal = 4r → a = 4r / √3.

States of Matter.front: Density of a crystalline solid (unit cell formula).
States of Matter.back: ρ = (Z · M) / (N_A · a³) for cubic cell where Z = atoms per cell, M = molar mass, a = edge length, N_A = Avogadro number.

States of Matter.front: Miller indices (h k l) — purpose & how to find for a plane.
States of Matter.back: Miller indices denote orientation of crystal planes: take intercepts with axes in unit cell, express as fractions of a, b, c, take reciprocals and clear denominators → (h k l).

States of Matter.front: Interplanar spacing for cubic crystals (formula).
States of Matter.back: d_{hkl} = a / √(h² + k² + l²) where a = cubic cell edge length.

States of Matter.front: Bragg's law for X-ray diffraction.
States of Matter.back: nλ = 2d sinθ where n = order, λ = X-ray wavelength, d = interplanar spacing, θ = diffraction angle. Used to determine crystal structures and lattice constants.

States of Matter.front: What is polymorphism (or allotropy for elements)?
States of Matter.back: Polymorphism: same chemical substance exists in more than one crystal form (different arrangement). Allotropy = polymorphism for elements (e.g., diamond vs graphite for carbon).

States of Matter.front: Defects in solids — types & brief effect.
States of Matter.back: Point defects: vacancies, interstitials, substitutional (affect diffusion, electrical properties). Line defects: dislocations (affect mechanical strength). Surface defects: grain boundaries. Defects alter conductivity, strength and diffusion.

States of Matter.front: Schottky vs Frenkel defects (ionic solids).
States of Matter.back: Schottky: paired cation and anion vacancies preserving stoichiometry (common in high coordination ionic solids). Frenkel: cation vacancy + cation interstitial (common when cations small).

States of Matter.front: Electrical conductivity in metals vs ionic solids vs semiconductors.
States of Matter.back: Metals: conduction by delocalised electrons (good conductors). Ionic solids: conduct when molten or in solution (ions mobile). Semiconductors: conductivity increases with temperature or doping; band theory applies.

States of Matter.front: Band theory — conductor vs semiconductor vs insulator (brief).
States of Matter.back: Conductor: valence band overlaps conduction band (or partially filled). Insulator: large band gap. Semiconductor: small band gap; conductivity increases with T or doping (donor/acceptor levels).

States of Matter.front: Glass — why is it called an amorphous solid?
States of Matter.back: Glass lacks long-range order (no regular crystal lattice), behaves mechanically like a solid but structurally resembles a frozen liquid; shows glass transition (T_g) not a sharp melting point.

States of Matter.front: Glass transition temperature (T_g) — definition.
States of Matter.back: T_g is the temperature where an amorphous polymer/glass transitions from rigid (glassy) to rubbery (viscoelastic) state; below T_g material is brittle, above T_g it softens.

States of Matter.front: Colloids — definition & classification by phase of dispersed/dispersion medium.
States of Matter.back: Colloids: heterogeneous mixtures with particle sizes ~1–1000 nm dispersed in medium. Types: sols (solid in liquid), gels (liquid in solid), aerosols (liquid/solid in gas), emulsions (liquid in liquid).

States of Matter.front: Tyndall effect — what it indicates.
States of Matter.back: Scattering of light by colloidal particles causing visible light path; distinguishes colloids from true solutions (no Tyndall effect).

States of Matter.front: Brownian motion — cause & significance for colloids.
States of Matter.back: Random motion of colloidal particles due to bombardment by solvent molecules; provides kinetic stability preventing sedimentation and evidence of molecular motion.

States of Matter.front: Coagulation & stabilization of colloids — brief.
States of Matter.back: Coagulation (flocculation) = aggregation of colloidal particles (e.g., by adding electrolytes). Stabilization via charge (electrostatic repulsion) or steric hindrance (adsorbed polymers).

States of Matter.front: Osmosis & osmotic pressure — formula for dilute solutions.
States of Matter.back: π = i M R T where π = osmotic pressure, i = van 't Hoff factor, M = molarity, R = gas constant, T = K.

States of Matter.front: Colligative property example — freezing point depression formula.
States of Matter.back: ΔT_f = K_f · m · i where ΔT_f = freezing point lowering, K_f = cryoscopic constant, m = molality, i = van 't Hoff factor.

States of Matter.front: Why salt lowers freezing point of water (practical reason).
States of Matter.back: Addition of solute lowers chemical potential of liquid → lowers freezing point (colligative effect). Used for de-icing roads.

States of Matter.front: Raoult's law — statement for ideal solutions.
States of Matter.back: Partial vapour pressure p_i = x_i · p_i° where x_i = mole fraction of component i in liquid, p_i° = vapour pressure of pure i. Total P = Σ p_i.

States of Matter.front: Deviations from Raoult's law — positive & negative causes.
States of Matter.back: Positive deviation: weaker A–B interactions → higher vapour pressure (e.g., ethanol + hexane). Negative deviation: stronger A–B interactions (e.g., H-bonding) → lower vapour pressure.

States of Matter.front: Azeotrope — what is it and an example.
States of Matter.back: Azeotrope: mixture that boils at constant composition and behaves like a pure substance (no further separation by simple distillation). Example: ethanol–water (azeotrope ~95.6% ethanol by volume at 1 atm).

States of Matter.front: Simple vs fractional distillation — when used.
States of Matter.back: Simple distillation: separate components with large bp differences. Fractional distillation: for closer boiling points using fractionating column to achieve repeated vaporisation–condensation (industrial petroleum refining).

States of Matter.front: Sublimation purification technique — suitable for which substances?
States of Matter.back: Used for solids that vaporise without decomposition (e.g., iodine, naphthalene, camphor) to separate from non-volatile impurities.

States of Matter.front: Critical point — its coordinates on phase diagram.
States of Matter.back: Point (T_c, P_c) where liquid and gas phases become indistinguishable; beyond this temperature no amount of pressure can liquefy the gas.

States of Matter.front: Why real gases behave ideally at low pressure & high temperature.
States of Matter.back: Low pressure → molecules far apart (negligible volume). High T → kinetic energy >> intermolecular attractions (negligible a term). Both conditions make interactions negligible → ideal behaviour.

States of Matter.front: Van der Waals constants a and b — physical meaning.
States of Matter.back: a measures magnitude of attractive forces between molecules (pressure correction). b accounts for finite volume of molecules (excluded volume per mole).

States of Matter.front: Mean molecular speed, most probable speed & average speed — relation.
States of Matter.back: For Maxwell distribution: most probable speed v_mp = √(2RT/M); average speed v_avg = √(8RT/πM); rms speed v_rms = √(3RT/M).

States of Matter.front: Simple exam practice: Using PV=nRT, compute moles of gas in 11.2 L at STP.
Simple exam practice: Using Clausius–Clapeyron, how does vapour pressure change qualitatively with temperature?
States of Matter.back: Vapour pressure increases exponentially with temperature; a plot of ln P vs 1/T is linear (slope = −ΔH_vap / R).

States of Matter.front: Important exam tip: units & temperature for gas laws.
States of Matter.back: Always use absolute temperature (K) in gas law formulas. Ensure pressure units match R constant chosen (e.g., R=0.08206 uses atm & L).

States of Matter.front: Common pitfalls students make on states-of-matter MCQs (three points).
States of Matter.back: 1) Forgetting to convert °C → K. 2) Confusing evaporation with boiling. 3) Using wrong value or units of R in PV=nRT problems.

States of Matter.front: One-line strategy to answer states-of-matter MCQs quickly.
States of Matter.back: Identify the phase/phenomenon, recall the governing law/equation (PV=nRT, Clausius–Clapeyron, Clapeyron/Clausius), convert units consistently, and check physical reasonableness (e.g., T increases → vapour pressure increases).

Atomic Structure.front: What is an atom (simple definition)?
Atomic Structure.back: An atom is the smallest unit of an element that retains its chemical identity, made of a dense nucleus (protons + neutrons) and surrounding electrons.

Atomic Structure.front: Define atomic number (Z) and mass number (A).
Atomic Structure.back: Atomic number Z = number of protons in nucleus (determines element). Mass number A = protons + neutrons (A = Z + N).

Atomic Structure.front: How is an isotope written in nuclear notation?
Atomic Structure.back: A conventional form: ¹⁴₆C where superscript = mass number (A) and subscript = atomic number (Z).

Atomic Structure.front: What are isotopes?
Atomic Structure.back: Isotopes are atoms of the same element (same Z) with different numbers of neutrons (different A) — they have similar chemical behaviour but different masses and some nuclear properties.

Atomic Structure.front: What is an ion? Cation vs anion.
Atomic Structure.back: Ion = charged atom/particle. Cation = positively charged (lost e⁻). Anion = negatively charged (gained e⁻).

Atomic Structure.front: What is atomic mass (relative/average mass)?
Atomic Structure.back: Relative atomic mass is the weighted average mass of an element's isotopes relative to ¹²C. Expressed in unified atomic mass units (u) where 1 u = 1/12 mass of ¹²C.

Atomic Structure.front: Briefly: Rutherford's α-scattering experiment & its conclusion.
Atomic Structure.back: Most α particles passed through gold foil but some scattered strongly → concluded atom is mostly empty space with a tiny, dense, positively charged nucleus.

Atomic Structure.front: Thomson's plum-pudding model — what did it propose and why was it replaced?
Atomic Structure.back: Thomson proposed electrons embedded in a uniform positive 'pudding'. It failed to explain α-scattering results and discrete spectral lines, so replaced by nuclear/quantum models.

Atomic Structure.front: Bohr model — main postulates (brief).
Atomic Structure.back: Electrons move in quantized circular orbits with quantized angular momentum mvr = n·h/2π; radiation emitted/absorbed when electron jumps between orbits; energy levels E_n = −13.6 eV / n² for H-like atoms.

Atomic Structure.front: Limitations of Bohr model.
Atomic Structure.back: Works well for hydrogenic (one-electron) systems but fails for multi-electron atoms and cannot explain fine structure, intensities, or electron distributions (requires quantum mechanics).

Atomic Structure.front: What is the de Broglie relation?
Atomic Structure.back: Matter has wave nature: λ = h / p where λ = wavelength, h = Planck's constant (6.626×10⁻³⁴ J·s), p = momentum (mv).

Atomic Structure.front: Heisenberg uncertainty principle (exam form).
Atomic Structure.back: Δx · Δp ≥ h / (4π). It states position (x) and momentum (p) cannot both be known exactly — intrinsic quantum uncertainty.

Atomic Structure.front: Wavefunction Ψ and probability density.
Atomic Structure.back: Ψ (wavefunction) describes quantum state; |Ψ|² gives probability density of finding an electron at a point. Ψ solutions come from Schrödinger equation.

Atomic Structure.front: What is the Schrödinger equation (conceptual)?
Atomic Structure.back: Time-independent Schrödinger equation HΨ = EΨ finds allowed energy levels E and corresponding wavefunctions Ψ (foundation of quantum description of atoms).

Atomic Structure.front: Quantum numbers — list & meaning.
Atomic Structure.back: Principal n (1,2,3...) energy level; azimuthal ℓ (0..n−1) subshell shape (s=0,p=1,d=2,f=3); magnetic m_ℓ (−ℓ..+ℓ) orbital orientation; spin m_s = ±½ electron spin.

Atomic Structure.front: Allowed values for ℓ and m_ℓ for n=3.
Pauli exclusion principle (one-line).
Atomic Structure.back: No two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers (n, ℓ, m_ℓ, m_s).

Atomic Structure.front: Hund's rule (maximum multiplicity).
Atomic Structure.back: For degenerate orbitals (same energy), place one electron in each orbital with parallel spins before pairing — minimizes electron repulsion and lowers energy.

Atomic Structure.front: Aufbau principle (order of filling).
Atomic Structure.back: Electrons occupy lowest energy orbitals first (commonly memorised by n+ℓ rule; when equal, lower n fills first). Sequence: 1s, 2s, 2p, 3s, 3p, 4s, 3d, 4p...

Atomic Structure.front: Give noble-gas shorthand for chromium and copper ground state configurations.
Atomic Structure.back: Cr: [Ar] 4s¹ 3d⁵ (not 4s²3d⁴). Cu: [Ar] 4s¹ 3d¹⁰ (not 4s²3d⁹) — observed exceptions due to half/full d-subshell stability.

Atomic Structure.front: Why do exceptions (Cr, Cu) occur to Aufbau order?
Atomic Structure.back: Extra stability gained from half-filled (d⁵) or fully filled (d¹⁰) subshells offsets the energy cost, leading to electron promotion from s to d.

Atomic Structure.front: Which electrons are valence electrons (definition)?
Atomic Structure.back: Electrons in the outermost principal shell (highest n) that participate in bonding and determine chemical properties; for transition metals valence includes (n)s and (n−1)d electrons involved.

Atomic Structure.front: What is an orbital? s, p, d, f shapes (qualitative).
Atomic Structure.back: An orbital is a region where an electron is likely found. s: spherical; p: dumbbell-shaped (two lobes); d: cloverleaf or donut+clover shapes; f: more complex shapes.

Atomic Structure.front: Number of orbitals per subshell and electrons per orbital.
Atomic Structure.back: s: 1 orbital → 2 e⁻; p: 3 orbitals → 6 e⁻; d: 5 orbitals → 10 e⁻; f: 7 orbitals → 14 e⁻.

Atomic Structure.front: Nodes in atomic orbitals — total, radial and angular nodes.
Atomic Structure.back: Total nodes = n − 1. Angular nodes = ℓ (number of nodal planes). Radial nodes = n − ℓ − 1.

Atomic Structure.front: Example: nodes for 3p orbital.
Atomic Structure.back: n=3, ℓ=1 ⇒ total nodes = 2; angular nodes = 1; radial nodes = 3 − 1 − 1 = 1.

Atomic Structure.front: What is effective nuclear charge (Z_eff)?
Atomic Structure.back: Z_eff is the net positive charge felt by an electron after accounting for shielding by inner electrons; higher Z_eff pulls electrons closer, lowering energy.

Atomic Structure.front: Shielding & penetration — qualitative definitions.
Atomic Structure.back: Shielding: inner electrons reduce nuclear attraction on outer electrons. Penetration: extent orbital electron density reaches close to nucleus (s penetrates most, so experiences higher Z_eff).

Atomic Structure.front: What is the Rydberg formula for hydrogen spectral lines?
Atomic Structure.back: 1/λ = R_H (1/n₁² − 1/n₂²) with R_H ≈ 1.097×10⁷ m⁻¹; n₂ > n₁ integers. Gives wavelengths of emission/absorption lines.

Atomic Structure.front: Name common hydrogen series & spectral regions (n₁ values).
Atomic Structure.back: Lyman (n₁=1, UV), Balmer (n₁=2, visible), Paschen (n₁=3, IR), Brackett (n₁=4, IR).

Atomic Structure.front: Energy levels of hydrogen (formula & numeric constant).
Atomic Structure.back: E_n = −13.6 eV / n² (E_1 = −13.6 eV). Energy difference ΔE = E_i − E_f corresponds to photon hν.

Atomic Structure.front: Relation between photon energy, frequency and wavelength.
Atomic Structure.back: E = hν = hc/λ where h = Planck's constant, c = speed of light, ν = frequency, λ = wavelength.

Atomic Structure.front: Photoelectric effect — key observation & significance.
Atomic Structure.back: Light above threshold frequency ejects electrons from metal with kinetic energy KE_max = hν − φ (φ = work function). Demonstrated particle nature of light (photons).

Atomic Structure.front: What is ionization energy (IE)?
Atomic Structure.back: Ionization energy = energy required to remove an electron from a gaseous atom/ion (first IE removes one electron to form +1 ion).

Atomic Structure.front: Successive ionization energies — general trend & significance.
Atomic Structure.back: Successive IE values increase; large jump occurs when removing an electron from a lower shell/core — reveals electron configuration and valence electrons.

Atomic Structure.front: Electron affinity (EA) — concept.
Atomic Structure.back: Electron affinity = energy change when an electron is added to a gaseous atom to form an anion. More negative EA means greater tendency to accept an electron.

Atomic Structure.front: Atomic radius — how measured and trend across period/group.
Atomic Structure.back: Atomic radius can be covalent/van der Waals/metallic depending on context. Generally decreases across a period (increasing Z_eff) and increases down a group (higher n).

Atomic Structure.front: Explain isoelectronic species.
Atomic Structure.back: Isoelectronic species have the same number of electrons and similar electronic structures (e.g., N³⁻, O²⁻, F⁻, Ne are isoelectronic).

Atomic Structure.front: What is a ground state vs excited state electron configuration?
Atomic Structure.back: Ground state = lowest energy arrangement of electrons. Excited state = any configuration where one or more electrons occupy higher energy orbitals than in ground state.

Atomic Structure.front: Term symbols (very brief idea) — example ²P½.
Atomic Structure.back: Term symbols (²S+1L_J) summarise total spin multiplicity (2S+1), orbital angular momentum (L), and total angular momentum (J). Used in atomic spectroscopy (advanced topic).

Atomic Structure.front: Stern–Gerlach experiment — one-line outcome.
Atomic Structure.back: A beam of silver atoms splits into two spots in a nonuniform magnetic field → evidence for quantized electron spin (m_s = ±½).

Atomic Structure.front: Electron spin and magnetic moment (qualitative).
Atomic Structure.back: Electron has intrinsic spin (m_s = ±½) giving rise to a magnetic moment; spin contributes to fine structure and magnetic properties.

Atomic Structure.front: What causes fine structure in atomic spectra?
Atomic Structure.back: Fine structure arises from electron spin–orbit coupling (interaction between electron spin and its orbital motion) and relativistic effects.

Atomic Structure.front: What is Zeeman effect (brief)?
Atomic Structure.back: Splitting of spectral lines into multiple components in presence of an external magnetic field (used to probe atomic energy levels).

Atomic Structure.front: What is Moseley's law (practical note)?
Atomic Structure.back: Square root of frequency of X-ray spectral lines varies linearly with atomic number Z — established that Z (not atomic mass) orders elements in periodic table.

Atomic Structure.front: Compare orbit (Bohr) vs orbital (quantum).
Atomic Structure.back: Orbit (Bohr) = fixed circular path with definite position & momentum (classical-like). Orbital = probability distribution (Ψ²) with no definite path; quantum mechanically correct.

Atomic Structure.front: How electronic configuration determines chemical periodic trends (brief).
Atomic Structure.back: Valence electron configuration controls reactivity, ionization energy, preferred oxidation states and position in periodic table (group/period).

Atomic Structure.front: What is Aufbau 'n + ℓ' rule in practice?
Atomic Structure.back: Order orbitals by increasing n + ℓ; if two orbitals have same n + ℓ, the one with lower n fills first (used to predict filling order).

Atomic Structure.front: Why 4s electrons are lost before 3d in many transition metal ions?
Atomic Structure.back: Although 4s is filled before 3d in neutral atoms, in ions 3d orbitals become lower in energy than 4s and 4s electrons are removed first (observed experimentally).

Atomic Structure.front: How to write condensed electron configurations using noble gas core.
Atomic Structure.back: Use the previous noble gas in brackets then write remaining orbitals, e.g., Fe: [Ar] 4s² 3d⁶ or commonly [Ar] 3d⁶ 4s² (shorthand saves space).

Atomic Structure.front: What are valence and core electrons (definition)?
Atomic Structure.back: Valence electrons are in outermost shell (involved in bonding). Core electrons are inner, tightly bound electrons not directly involved in bonding.

Atomic Structure.front: What is Aufbau order up to 4p (listing).
Explain why atomic emission spectra are line spectra, not continuous.
Atomic Structure.back: Lines arise because electrons occupy discrete quantized energy levels; transitions between levels emit/absorb photons of specific energies → discrete wavelengths.

Atomic Structure.front: How to use Rydberg formula to compute wavelength for hydrogen Balmer transition n=3→n=2.
Atomic Structure.back: 1/λ = R_H (1/2² − 1/3²) = R_H (1/4 − 1/9) = R_H × (5/36). Use R_H ≈ 1.097×10⁷ m⁻¹ to find λ in metres.

Atomic Structure.front: What is the Bohr radius a₀ (concept & approx value)?
Atomic Structure.back: Bohr radius a₀ is the radius of the n=1 orbit in Bohr model ≈ 0.529 Å (0.529 × 10⁻¹⁰ m).

Atomic Structure.front: What is Rydberg constant R_∞ (practical approximate value)?
Atomic Structure.back: R_∞ (R_H) ≈ 1.097 × 10⁷ m⁻¹ — used in spectral calculations for hydrogenic species.

Atomic Structure.front: Why multi-electron atoms are more complex than hydrogen?
Atomic Structure.back: Electron–electron repulsion, shielding and configuration interactions split subshell energies; no exact analytical solution like hydrogen — requires approximations (Hartree–Fock, etc.).

Atomic Structure.front: What is Slater's rule (very brief idea)?
Atomic Structure.back: Slater's rules give approximate screening constants to estimate effective nuclear charge Z_eff felt by an electron (used qualitatively in exams).

Atomic Structure.front: What are spectroscopy selection rules for electric dipole transitions (simple)?
Atomic Structure.back: Allowed transitions require Δℓ = ±1 (change in orbital angular momentum) and Δm_ℓ = 0, ±1 (simple electric dipole selection rules).

Atomic Structure.front: Practice: write the ground state electronic configuration of oxygen (Z=8).
Atomic Structure.back: O: 1s² 2s² 2p⁴ (or [He] 2s² 2p⁴). According to Hund’s rule the 2p orbitals have two paired and two unpaired electrons (total spin S = 1).

Atomic Structure.front: Practice: predict the number of unpaired electrons in Fe²⁺ (Z=26).
Atomic Structure.back: Fe neutral: [Ar] 4s² 3d⁶. Fe²⁺: [Ar] 3d⁶ (4s electrons lost). d⁶ high-spin → 4 unpaired electrons (common in first-row divalent ions unless strong field ligand present).

Atomic Structure.front: Common exam pitfall: confusing orbital energy order vs occupancy order.
Atomic Structure.back: Remember that energy ordering can change between atoms and ions (e.g., 4s fills before 3d but is lost first on ionisation); use n+ℓ rule as guide but know exceptions.

Atomic Structure.front: Quick checklist to solve atomic structure MCQs.
Atomic Structure.back: Identify Z; write electron configuration (use noble-gas core); apply Pauli, Hund and Aufbau; check exceptions; relate configuration to properties (IE, valence, unpaired electrons).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the Periodic Law (modern form)?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: The modern Periodic Law: "The properties of the elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers (Z)." (Moseley — atomic number, not atomic mass, determines periodicity.)

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Who proposed the Periodic Table and what was Mendeleev's key idea?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Dmitri Mendeleev (1869) arranged elements by increasing atomic mass and grouped elements with similar properties into columns; left gaps predicting undiscovered elements and their properties.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Name three earlier attempts that led to the Periodic Table (brief).
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Dobereiner's triads (similar properties in groups of three), Newlands' Law of Octaves (repeating every 8 elements), and Meyer/Mendeleev's tables showing periodicity.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: How did Moseley modify the Periodic Law?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Henry Moseley (1913) showed atomic number (Z), determined from X-ray spectra, is the fundamental property ordering elements — resolving anomalies when ordered by atomic mass.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is a 'long-form' periodic table and how many groups does it have?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Long-form (modern) periodic table has 18 groups (numbered 1–18) and 7 periods; it arranges elements by increasing atomic number with s, p, d, f blocks.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Define 'period' and 'group' in the periodic table.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Period: horizontal row (same principal quantum number n for valence shell). Group: vertical column (elements have similar valence electron configuration → similar chemical properties).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are 'blocks' (s, p, d, f) in the periodic table?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Blocks refer to the type of atomic orbital being filled with electrons: s-block (groups 1–2 + He), p-block (groups 13–18), d-block (transition metals, groups 3–12), f-block (lanthanoids & actinoids).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Which elements are in the s-block?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: s-block: Groups 1 (alkali metals) and 2 (alkaline earth metals), plus hydrogen (H) and helium (He — note He is s-block but often placed with noble gases).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Which elements are in the p-block?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: p-block: Groups 13–18 (includes metalloids, nonmetals, halogens, and noble gases).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Which elements are transition metals (d-block)?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: d-block: Groups 3–12 — elements with partially filled d-orbitals; typical transition metals show variable oxidation states, colored compounds, catalytic activity.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are lanthanoids and actinoids (f-block)?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Lanthanoids (La–Lu, 4f) and actinoids (Ac–Lr, 5f) are inner transition elements; often shown separated at bottom; lanthanoid contraction and actinide series properties are important.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is periodicity?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Periodicity: the recurring trends in properties of elements as a function of increasing atomic number (e.g., atomic radius, ionization energy, electronegativity).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Trend: Atomic radius across a period and down a group — explain.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Across a period (left → right): atomic radius decreases due to increasing Z_eff (effective nuclear charge). Down a group: atomic radius increases due to higher principal quantum number (n) and added shells (shielding).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Trend: Ionic radius — general rules for cations and anions.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Cations are smaller than parent atoms (loss of electron(s) → less electron–electron repulsion, higher Z_eff per electron). Anions are larger than parent atoms (gain of electron(s) → more repulsion).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Trend: First ionization energy (I₁) across a period and down a group — explain.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Across a period: I₁ generally increases (higher Z_eff, electrons held more tightly). Down a group: I₁ decreases (valence electrons farther from nucleus, more shielding).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Trend: Electron affinity (EA) and its general behaviour.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: EA generally becomes more negative across a period (atoms more willing to accept electrons) and becomes less negative down a group (added electron is further from nucleus). Exceptions exist due to subshell structure.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Trend: Electronegativity across a period and down a group.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Across a period: electronegativity increases. Down a group: electronegativity decreases. Fluorine is the most electronegative element (Pauling ≈ 3.98 ≈ 4.0).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is effective nuclear charge (Z_eff) and how does it affect periodic trends?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Z_eff ≈ Z − S (Z = atomic number, S = shielding). Higher Z_eff pulls electrons closer → smaller radius, higher I₁, higher electronegativity.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Explain metallic character trend in the periodic table.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Metallic character increases down a group (easier to lose electrons) and decreases across a period (left → right) as atoms gain higher ionization energies and more nonmetallic behavior.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are alkali metals (Group 1) — key properties & typical reactions?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Alkali metals: very reactive, soft metals, one valence electron (ns¹). Form M⁺, strong reducing agents, react vigorously with water → M⁺ + OH⁻ + ½H₂.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are alkaline earth metals (Group 2) — key properties?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Group 2: ns² configuration, less reactive than alkali metals but reactive, form M²⁺, higher melting points than Group 1; common examples: Be, Mg, Ca.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Group 17 — Halogens: general properties and common compounds.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Halogens (F, Cl, Br, I): diatomic nonmetals (X₂), high electronegativity, form X⁻ halide ions, react with metals to form ionic halides and with hydrogen to form HX acids (e.g., HCl).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Group 18 — Noble gases: properties and occurrence.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Noble gases: inert gases with filled valence shells (ns² np⁶ except He: 1s²). Very low chemical reactivity; used in lighting, inert atmospheres. Some compounds (XeF₂, XeO₃) exist for heavier noble gases.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are metalloids? Give examples.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Metalloids (semimetals) have intermediate properties between metals and nonmetals: e.g., B, Si, Ge, As, Sb, Te. Often lie along the 'staircase' between metals and nonmetals.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the 'staircase' in the periodic table?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: A diagonal line (staircase) from B to At separating metals and nonmetals; elements adjacent to staircase are metalloids.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Define oxidation state and typical valencies for Groups 1, 2, 13, 14, 15, 16.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Group 1: +1; Group 2: +2; Group 13: +3 (common); Group 14: +2, +4 (C usually ±4 covalently); Group 15: −3 to +5; Group 16: −2 to +6 (oxygen usually −2).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the diagonal relationship? Give two classical examples.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Elements diagonally adjacent in the periodic table (e.g., Li↔Mg and Be↔Al) show similar properties (e.g., ionic sizes, charge/radius ratio, polarising power).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is lanthanoid contraction and why is it important?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Lanthanoid contraction: gradual decrease in ionic/atomic radii across the lanthanoid series (La→Lu) due to poor shielding by 4f electrons; causes unexpected similarities between 4d and 5d elements and affects chemistry (e.g., separation difficulties).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the inert pair effect?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Inert pair effect: tendency of ns² electrons (in heavier p-block elements) to remain non-ionized or unshared in compounds, leading to lower oxidation states (e.g., Pb⁴⁺ vs Pb²⁺; Tl³⁺ vs Tl⁺).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Why are transition metals often coloured and show variable oxidation states?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Colour arises from d–d electronic transitions (between split d-orbitals) and charge-transfer transitions. Variable oxidation states come from similar energies of (n−1)d and ns electrons.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is electronic configuration pattern for Group 1 & 2 elements (general)?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Group 1 (alkali metals): [core] ns¹; Group 2 (alkaline earth): [core] ns² (where n = period number).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Why is helium placed with noble gases though it is an s-block element?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: He (1s²) chemically behaves like noble gases (inert) and has filled valence shell; so often grouped with Group 18 despite being s-block electronically.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is metallic radius vs covalent radius vs van der Waals radius (short definitions)?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Metallic radius: half internuclear distance in metal lattice. Covalent radius: half distance between bonded identical atoms. Van der Waals radius: half distance between nonbonded adjacent atoms in solid/gas phase.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: How does ionization energy vary within a multi-electron atom for successive ionizations?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Successive ionization energies increase (I₂ > I₁, I₃ > I₂) because removing electrons increases effective nuclear attraction on remaining electrons; big jumps indicate removal from inner shells (identify valence electrons count).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are typical properties of Group 13 elements (Boron group)?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Group 13: general configuration ns² np¹. Boron is a metalloid, others are metals. Show +3 oxidation state commonly; show some covalent character (e.g., BCl₃).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is diagonal relationship example Li and Mg — list similar properties.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Li and Mg: similar ionic sizes, form nitrides (Li₃N, Mg₃N₂), form organometallics with covalent character, form hydroxides with similar solubility patterns.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What are allotropes and name important allotropes of carbon?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Allotropes: different structural forms of the same element. Carbon allotropes: diamond (tetrahedral, insulating), graphite (layers, conductive), fullerenes, graphene.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Explain why fluorine is more reactive than chlorine though both are halogens.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Fluorine has higher electronegativity and small size leading to very high oxidising power; however bond strengths and steric/electronic effects also influence reactivity (F₂ is very reactive).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is metallic character — how to determine for an element quickly?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Metallic character: tendency to lose electrons (form cations). Elements that are left/bottom of the periodic table are more metallic; right/top are less metallic (more nonmetallic).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Why do noble gases show very low chemical reactivity? Name exceptions where compounds exist.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Noble gases have filled valence shells (stable electron configurations). Heavier noble gases (Xe, Kr) can form compounds with very electronegative elements (e.g., XeF₂, XeO₃, KrF₂) under strong oxidising conditions.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the general trend of metallic character down a group and across a period?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Down a group: metallic character increases. Across a period (L→R): metallic character decreases.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Common exam trap: ordering elements by atomic mass vs atomic number — what to remember?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Always order by atomic number (Z) for modern periodic law. Historical anomalies (e.g., Ar vs K when using atomic mass) are resolved by atomic number ordering.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: How does electronegativity correlate with bond type?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Large electronegativity difference → ionic bond. Moderate difference → polar covalent. Small/negligible difference → nonpolar covalent.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the relationship between oxidation state and group number for main group elements?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Main group elements often show oxidation states equal to group number (positive) or (8 − group number) as negative (e.g., Group 16: commonly −2; Group 15: −3).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is Fajan's rule (brief) and when does covalent character increase for ionic compounds?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Fajan's rule: small cation with high charge and large, highly polarizable anion → greater covalent character. High charge density on cation polarizes anion electron cloud.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Give characteristic properties of Group 14 elements (C, Si, Ge, Sn, Pb).
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Group 14: show variable oxidation states (+2, +4). Carbon forms multiple covalent structures (allotropes). Down the group metallic character increases; inert pair effect appears for heavier elements (Pb²⁺).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Why does atomic radius decrease across a period though electrons are being added?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Added electrons occupy same principal shell but increasing nuclear charge (Z) pulls electrons closer (Z_eff increases) overcoming added electron repulsion → smaller radius.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is amphoteric behavior in periodic table context? Give example.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Amphoteric oxides/hydroxides can react with both acids and bases. Example: Al₂O₃, ZnO, PbO (show amphoteric behaviour).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Important examples of diagonal relationship pairs besides Li↔Mg.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Be↔Al, B↔Si (in some properties) — show similarities in hydrolysis, salts, and covalent character.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: How to use periodic trends to predict which element has higher ionization energy: N or O?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Across a period IE increases; but small anomaly: O (paired electron in 2p) has slightly lower I₁ than N (half-filled stability). So N > O (I₁).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: What is the role of electronic configuration in determining group properties?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Elements in same group have similar outer electronic configuration (same number of valence electrons) → similar chemical reactivity and valency (e.g., Group 1: ns¹).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Why are heavier elements (lower in group) more reactive for metals?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Down a group, outer electrons are farther from nucleus and more shielded → easier to remove → higher reactivity for metals (e.g., Cs more reactive than Na).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Practice question: Arrange the following in increasing atomic radius: Na, Mg, Al.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Across a period radius decreases: Al < Mg < Na in terms of increasing radius → Correct increasing order: Al < Mg < Na (largest Na).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Practice question: Which has higher electronegativity: Cl or Br? Why?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Cl (period 3) is more electronegative than Br (period 4) because electronegativity decreases down a group due to larger atomic size and shielding.

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Exam tip: Quick test for isoelectronic species (examples: O²⁻, F⁻, Na⁺) — how to check?
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Count electrons: O²⁻ (8+2=10), F⁻ (9+1=10), Na⁺ (11−1=10) → all have 10 electrons → isoelectronic with Ne (10 e⁻).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Practice question: Explain why Ga shows +1 oxidation state sometimes (in addition to +3).
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Due to inert pair effect and stability of filled d¹⁰ core (in heavier post-transition metals), lower oxidation states (+1) become more stable for heavier Group 13 elements (e.g., Tl⁺, In⁺, sometimes Ga⁺).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: Short checklist to solve periodic classification multiple-choice questions (4 steps).
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: 1) Identify group/period or electronic configuration. 2) Use valence electron pattern to predict valency/oxidation states. 3) Apply periodic trends (radius, IE, EA). 4) Watch for known exceptions (half-filled, filled subshells, inert pair, diagonal relationship).

Periodic Classification of Elements.front: One-line summary: How to quickly decide whether an element is a metal, nonmetal or metalloid from its position.
Periodic Classification of Elements.back: Left & bottom → metal; right & top → nonmetal; along the staircase (B to At) → metalloid/semimetal.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is a chemical bond?
Chemical Bonding.back: A chemical bond is the attractive force that holds atoms together in molecules or solids, arising from electrostatic attraction between nuclei and electrons or between ions.

Chemical Bonding.front: Name the main types of chemical bonds.
Chemical Bonding.back: Ionic (electrostatic between cation & anion), covalent (sharing of electron pairs), coordinate (dative covalent), metallic (delocalised 'sea' of electrons), and intermolecular forces (H-bonding, van der Waals).

Chemical Bonding.front: Define ionic bond and give an example.
Chemical Bonding.back: Ionic bond: electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions formed by electron transfer. Example: Na → Na⁺ and Cl + e⁻ → Cl⁻ → NaCl (ionic lattice).

Chemical Bonding.front: What are characteristics of ionic compounds?
Chemical Bonding.back: High melting/boiling points, crystalline solids, conduct electricity when molten/aqueous, soluble in polar solvents, brittle, formed between metals & nonmetals.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is lattice energy (qualitative)?
Chemical Bonding.back: Lattice energy is the energy released when gaseous ions form an ionic solid. Larger ionic charges and smaller ionic radii → higher lattice energy → stronger ionic bonding.

Chemical Bonding.front: Born–Haber cycle — what is it used for (brief)?
Chemical Bonding.back: A thermochemical cycle used to calculate lattice energy and relate formation enthalpy, ionization energy, electron affinity, sublimation, and bond energies for ionic compounds.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is covalent bonding?
Chemical Bonding.back: Covalent bond: a bond formed by sharing one or more pairs of electrons between atoms (electron pair localized between atoms). Example: H—H, Cl—Cl.

Chemical Bonding.front: Lewis (electron dot) structure — what does it show?
Chemical Bonding.back: Lewis structure represents valence electrons as dots and bonds as pairs of electrons (lines). It helps predict molecular connectivity, lone pairs, formal charges, and resonance.

Chemical Bonding.front: How to calculate formal charge?
Chemical Bonding.back: Formal charge = (valence electrons on free atom) − (nonbonding electrons) − ½(bonding electrons). Sum of formal charges equals molecule/ion charge.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is resonance? Give two examples.
Chemical Bonding.back: Resonance: delocalization of electrons over two or more Lewis structures (resonance contributors); true structure is hybrid. Examples: CO₃²⁻, NO₃⁻, benzene (C₆H₆).

Chemical Bonding.front: Define bond order (simple covalent).
Chemical Bonding.back: Bond order (classical) = number of bonding electron pairs between two atoms. Higher bond order → shorter, stronger bond (e.g., C≡C bond order 3).

Chemical Bonding.front: Bond length vs bond order vs bond enthalpy — how are they related?
Chemical Bonding.back: Higher bond order → shorter bond length and higher bond enthalpy (stronger bond). Single > double > triple length/strength order reversed for strength.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is coordinate (dative) bond? Example notation.
Chemical Bonding.back: Coordinate bond: both electrons in the shared pair come from one atom (donor → acceptor). Notation: :NH₃ → H⁺ → NH₄⁺; arrow → indicates donor → acceptor.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is electronegativity? Name common scales.
Chemical Bonding.back: Electronegativity is the tendency of an atom to attract bonding electron density. Common scales: Pauling, Mulliken. Pauling scale widely used (F ≈ 3.98 ≈ 4.0).

Chemical Bonding.front: How to estimate % ionic character from electronegativity difference (Pauling formula)?
Chemical Bonding.back: % ionic character ≈ (1 − e^{−(Δχ)²/4}) × 100, where Δχ = difference in Pauling electronegativities of bonded atoms.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is polarity of a bond and how is it indicated?
Chemical Bonding.back: Polarity: unequal sharing of electrons due to electronegativity difference → partial charges δ⁺ and δ⁻. Indicated by dipole moment μ (vector) or δ symbols.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is dipole moment (μ) and its unit?
Chemical Bonding.back: Dipole moment μ = q × r (magnitude of charge separation × distance). SI unit: C·m; common unit in chemistry: Debye (1 D ≈ 3.33564×10⁻³⁰ C·m).

Chemical Bonding.front: How to decide if a molecule is polar even if bonds are polar?
Chemical Bonding.back: Molecular polarity depends on vector sum of bond dipoles; symmetric molecular geometry can cancel bond dipoles → nonpolar molecule (e.g., CO₂ is nonpolar despite polar C=O bonds).

Chemical Bonding.front: What is VSEPR theory (basic idea)?
Chemical Bonding.back: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion (VSEPR): electron pairs (bonding & lone pairs) around a central atom arrange to minimize repulsion, determining molecular shape (AX_nE_m notation).

Chemical Bonding.front: Explain AX_nE_m notation in VSEPR.
Chemical Bonding.back: A = central atom, X = surrounding atoms (n of them), E = lone electron pairs on A (m of them). Use pattern to predict geometry (e.g., AX₄ → tetrahedral; AX₃E → trigonal pyramidal).

Chemical Bonding.front: Common VSEPR shapes and bond angles (quick list).
Chemical Bonding.back:
Linear (AX₂): 180°
Trigonal planar (AX₃): 120°
Tetrahedral (AX₄): 109.5°
Trigonal bipyramidal (AX₅): 90° & 120°
Octahedral (AX₆): 90°
Note lone pairs reduce bond angles slightly.

Chemical Bonding.front: Examples: hybridization for CH₄, C₂H₂, C₂H₄, NH₃, H₂O, BF₃, SF₆, PCl₅.
Chemical Bonding.back: CH₄ sp³; C₂H₂ (ethyne) sp; C₂H₄ (ethene) sp²; NH₃ sp³ (one lone pair); H₂O sp³ (two lone pairs); BF₃ sp²; SF₆ sp³d² (octahedral); PCl₅ sp³d (trigonal bipyramidal).

Chemical Bonding.front: What is hybridization (concept)?
Chemical Bonding.back: Hybridization: mixing of atomic orbitals on a central atom to form equivalent hybrid orbitals for bonding (e.g., sp, sp², sp³, sp³d, sp³d²). Used to explain molecular shapes and bond angles.

Chemical Bonding.front: How to determine hybridization from steric number?
Chemical Bonding.back: Steric number = number of atoms bonded to central atom + number of lone pairs. Hybridization: SN 2 → sp; SN 3 → sp²; SN 4 → sp³; SN 5 → sp³d; SN 6 → sp³d².

Chemical Bonding.front: What is percent s and p character in sp, sp², sp³ hybrids?
Chemical Bonding.back: sp: 50% s, 50% p; sp²: 33.3% s, 66.7% p; sp³: 25% s, 75% p. More s character → shorter, stronger bonds and greater electronegativity of that orbital.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is overlap in covalent bonding (σ and π bonds)?
Chemical Bonding.back: σ (sigma) bond: head-on overlap of orbitals (stronger, allows free rotation). π (pi) bond: side-by-side overlap of p orbitals (weaker, restricts rotation). Double bond = σ + π; triple bond = σ + 2π.

Chemical Bonding.front: Why are multiple bonds shorter and stronger than single bonds?
Chemical Bonding.back: Multiple bonds have additional π overlap in addition to σ overlap, increasing bond order and electron density between atoms → shorter bond length and higher bond enthalpy.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is resonance-stabilized bond order? Example CO₃²⁻
Chemical Bonding.back: Resonance gives fractional bond order. In CO₃²⁻ three equivalent structures → bond order = (1 double bond + 2 single bonds)/3 = 4/3 ≈ 1.33 for each C–O bond.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is aromaticity (brief) and Hückel's rule?
Chemical Bonding.back: Aromaticity: special stability of cyclic, planar, conjugated π-systems with (4n + 2) π electrons (Hückel's rule). Example: benzene (6 π electrons, n = 1).

Chemical Bonding.front: What are intermolecular forces (IMFs) and why are they important?
Chemical Bonding.back: IMFs are attractions between molecules (not bonds within). They determine boiling/melting points, solubility, vapor pressure. Types: hydrogen bonding, dipole–dipole, London dispersion (van der Waals).

Chemical Bonding.front: Define hydrogen bond and give examples of donor & acceptor atoms.
Chemical Bonding.back: Hydrogen bond: strong dipole–dipole interaction where H is bonded to highly electronegative atom (F, O, N) and interacts with lone pair on F, O, N of another molecule. Example: H₂O···H₂O, HF···HF, NH₃···H₂O.

Chemical Bonding.front: Types of van der Waals forces: London, Debye, Keesom — brief definitions.
Chemical Bonding.back: London (dispersion): instantaneous induced dipoles in all atoms/molecules (present in all species; increases with polarizability). Debye: permanent dipole induces dipole in neighbor. Keesom: interaction between permanent dipoles.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is polarizability and how does it affect London forces?
Chemical Bonding.back: Polarizability = ease of distortion of electron cloud. Larger atoms/molecules with more electrons are more polarizable → stronger London dispersion → higher boiling points.

Chemical Bonding.front: How does bond polarity affect boiling point and solubility?
Chemical Bonding.back: Polar molecules with strong dipole interactions or H-bonding have higher boiling points and are soluble in polar solvents (like water). Nonpolar molecules dissolve better in nonpolar solvents due to dispersion forces.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is metallic bonding (free electron model)?
Chemical Bonding.back: Metallic bonding: metal atoms contribute valence electrons to a delocalised 'sea' of electrons that move through a lattice of positive metal ions—explains conductivity, malleability, ductility, and metallic luster.

Chemical Bonding.front: What are network covalent solids? Give examples.
Chemical Bonding.back: Covalent network solids: atoms connected by covalent bonds in a continuous 3D network → very high melting points, hard, poor electrical conductors (except graphite). Examples: diamond (C), SiO₂ (quartz), SiC.

Chemical Bonding.front: Why is graphite a conductor but diamond is an insulator?
Chemical Bonding.back: Graphite: each C is sp² hybridized with one delocalised π electron per C that moves along layers → electrical conductivity. Diamond: sp³ network; all electrons localized in σ bonds → insulator.

Chemical Bonding.front: Explain Fajan's rules (qualitative) — when does ionic compound show more covalent character?
Chemical Bonding.back: Small cation with high positive charge + large, highly polarizable anion → increased covalent character. Polarization of anion by cation distorts electron cloud → covalency increases.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is the relationship between ionic radius and coordination number?
Chemical Bonding.back: Ionic radius increases with increasing coordination number because ions can accommodate more neighbors → larger effective size in high coordination lattices.

Chemical Bonding.front: What is coordination number (crystal chemistry) — example in NaCl and CsCl?
