Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.front: Entropy of mixing ideal gases (formula for two gases).
Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.back: ΔS_mix = −nR (x_A ln x_A + x_B ln x_B + ...). Mixing ideal gases increases entropy; depends only on mole fractions, not identity.

Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.front: Why irreversible mixing increases entropy but reversible mixing can be arranged theoretically.
Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.back: Spontaneous mixing is irreversible and increases entropy. Reversible separation requires work and precisely controlled reversible steps (idealised).

Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.front: Practice problem type: converting between molarity and partial pressure for a dissolved gas (Henry's law link).
Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.back: Use Henry's law for gas solubility: C = k_H P_gas. To get molarity from gas partial pressure use appropriate k_H (units depend on form used).

Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.front: Short checklist for energetics MCQs (4 steps).
Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.back:
1) Identify if question needs ΔH, ΔE, ΔG, ΔS or equilibrium.
2) Choose correct formula (Hess, ΔG = −RT ln K, q = mcΔT, etc.).
3) Watch standard state & units.
4) Use sign conventions carefully (exothermic negative ΔH).

Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.front: Common pitfalls in gas & energetics problems (three points).
Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.back: 1) Forgetting to convert M (g·mol⁻¹) to kg·mol⁻¹ for u_rms. 2) Mixing up ΔE vs ΔH for calorimetry (bomb → ΔE). 3) Using wrong value of R or inconsistent units.

Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.front: One-line summary: how to approach any 'Behaviour of Gases & Energetics' MCQ.
Behaviour of Gases & Energetics.back: Identify gas vs thermodynamics topic, choose ideal vs real-gas relation, convert units carefully (T in K, M units), apply correct formula (PV = nRT, u_rms, ΔH/ΔE relations, Hess, Nernst/ΔG when needed).

Electrolysis.front: What is electrolysis?
Electrolysis.back: Electrolysis is a non-spontaneous redox process driven by an external electric current that causes chemical changes (oxidation at the anode and reduction at the cathode) in an electrolytic cell.

Electrolysis.front: Name the two main types of electrochemical cells and key difference.
Electrolysis.back: Galvanic (voltaic) cell: spontaneous redox produces electrical energy. Electrolytic cell: external electrical energy drives a non-spontaneous redox (electrolysis).

Electrolysis.front: Define anode and cathode in electrolysis (polarity & reactions).
Electrolysis.back: Anode: positive electrode in electrolytic cell where oxidation occurs (anions or neutral species lose electrons). Cathode: negative electrode where reduction occurs (cations gain electrons).

Electrolysis.front: How to write electrode reactions (notation) — example convention.
Electrolysis.back: Write half-reactions with electrons explicit: Oxidation: Cu(s) → Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻. Reduction: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu(s). Overall: combine balanced halves.

Electrolysis.front: Faraday's first law of electrolysis (statement & formula).
Electrolysis.back: Mass of substance deposited ∝ total charge passed. m ∝ Q, where Q = total charge (Coulombs).

Electrolysis.front: Faraday's second law of electrolysis (statement).
Electrolysis.back: For the same quantity of electricity passed, the masses of different substances deposited are proportional to their chemical equivalent masses (E = M / n where n = electrons transferred).

Electrolysis.front: Key quantitative formula linking mass, current & time.
Electrolysis.back: m = (Q · M) / (n · F) where Q = I·t (Coulombs), I = current (A), t = time (s), M = molar mass (g·mol⁻¹), n = electrons per formula unit, F = Faraday constant ≈ 96485 C·mol⁻¹.

Electrolysis.front: Value and meaning of Faraday constant (F).
Electrolysis.back: F ≈ 96485 C·mol⁻¹ — the electric charge carried by one mole of electrons (N_A × e).

Electrolysis.front: Define electrochemical equivalent (z) and relation.
Electrolysis.back: Electrochemical equivalent z = mass deposited per unit charge = m / Q. Using Faraday: z = M / (n · F). Units: g·C⁻¹.

Electrolysis.front: Relation between equivalents, molar mass and n (electrons).
Electrolysis.back: Equivalent mass E = M / n, where n is number of electrons exchanged per mole for the species (e.g., for Cu²⁺, n = 2 → E = M/2).

Electrolysis.front: Charge calculation: formula Q = I·t — units & examples.
Electrolysis.back: Q (C) = I (A) × t (s). Example: 2 A for 30 min → t = 1800 s → Q = 3600 C.

Electrolysis.front: Mass deposited example (numeric): 2.0 A passed for 30 min to deposit Cu from Cu²⁺. M(Cu)=63.546 g·mol⁻¹, n=2. Find mass.
Current efficiency (percent yield) — definition & formula.
Electrolysis.back: Current efficiency (%) = (actual mass deposited / theoretical mass from Q) × 100. Practical value < 100% due to side reactions or losses.

Electrolysis.front: Predicting electrode products in aqueous electrolysis — rule of thumb.
Electrolysis.back: At cathode: species with more positive (less negative) reduction potential is reduced (often H₂ from H⁺/H₂O if metal is more electropositive). At anode: species with less positive oxidation potential (e.g., Cl⁻ → Cl₂ vs H₂O → O₂) is oxidized depending on concentration and overpotential.

Electrolysis.front: Overpotential (η) — what is it and why important?
Electrolysis.back: Overpotential is the extra potential (beyond thermodynamic E°) required to drive an electrode reaction at practical rate due to kinetics. It influences which species appears at electrode (e.g., Cl₂ vs O₂).

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of molten sodium chloride (NaCl(l)) — products & half-reactions.
Electrolysis.back:
Cathode (reduction): Na⁺ + e⁻ → Na(l).
Anode (oxidation): 2Cl⁻ → Cl₂(g) + 2e⁻.
Overall: 2NaCl(l) → 2Na(l) + Cl₂(g).

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of aqueous NaCl (brine) — industrial (chlor-alkali) products.
Electrolysis.back: Main products (depending on conditions): Cl₂(g) at anode; H₂(g) at cathode; NaOH remains in solution. Overall (ideal): 2NaCl(aq) + 2H₂O → Cl₂(g) + H₂(g) + 2NaOH(aq).

Electrolysis.front: Chlor-alkali process — brief industrial importance.
Electrolysis.back: Commercial electrolysis of brine producing Cl₂, NaOH and H₂. Cell types include diaphragm, mercury, and membrane cells; membrane cell is now common (lower contamination, higher efficiency).

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of water — half-reactions in acidic & basic media.
Electrolysis.back:
Acidic: Anode: 2H₂O → O₂ + 4H⁺ + 4e⁻; Cathode: 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ → 2H₂.
Basic: Anode: 4OH⁻ → O₂ + 2H₂O + 4e⁻; Cathode: 2H₂O + 2e⁻ → H₂ + 2OH⁻.
Overall: 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of CuSO₄ with inert electrodes — products.
Electrolysis.back: Cathode: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu(s) (deposition). Anode (inert, e.g., Pt): 2H₂O → O₂ + 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ (oxygen evolution) if solution dilute; if copper anode used, Cu → Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ (anode dissolves) maintaining Cu²⁺.

Electrolysis.front: Electrorefining of copper — principle & overall process.
Electrolysis.back: Impure copper anode oxidized to Cu²⁺; Cu²⁺ reduced at pure copper cathode and deposited as pure Cu. Impurities less reactive (noble) fall off as anode slime (precious metals) or remain in solution (more reactive).

Electrolysis.front: Electrowinning vs electrorefining — difference.
Electrolysis.back: Electrowinning: extraction of metal from its solution (ore leachate) by electrodeposition onto cathode. Electrorefining: purification of impure metal by making it anodic and re-depositing pure metal at cathode.

Electrolysis.front: Electroplating — basic idea & steps.
Electrolysis.back: Electroplating deposits a thin metal layer onto an object (cathode) from a metal-ion-containing electrolyte using controlled current. Steps: clean substrate, prepare electrolyte of metal salt, apply current, control time/current density for desired thickness.

Electrolysis.front: Important electroplating parameters: current density, time, bath composition.
Electrolysis.back: Current density (A·dm⁻²) controls deposition rate and quality; too high → rough/porous deposit; too low → slow. Bath composition, temperature, pH and additives affect brightness, adhesion and grain size.

Electrolysis.front: Electrochemical series use in electrolysis — predicting reducibility/oxidizability.
Electrolysis.back: Species with higher (more positive) reduction potentials are easier to reduce; lower potentials more easily oxidized. Useful to predict which ions will discharge first at electrodes (with kinetic/overpotential caveats).

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of molten PbBr₂ — products & half-reactions example.
Electrolysis.back:
Cathode: Pb²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Pb(l).
Anode: 2Br⁻ → Br₂(g) + 2e⁻.
Overall: PbBr₂(l) → Pb(l) + Br₂(g).

Electrolysis.front: Predicting products from aqueous solutions with multiple ions — order of discharge.
Electrolysis.back: At cathode: metal cation is discharged if its reduction potential is more positive than H⁺/H₂ (and practical factors). At anode: species with lower oxidation potential or lower overpotential is oxidized (e.g., Cl⁻ often oxidized to Cl₂ in brine instead of H₂O→O₂ if Cl⁻ conc high and anode favours Cl₂).

Electrolysis.front: Example: Electrolysis of aqueous CuCl₂ with copper electrodes — what happens?
Electrolysis.back: Anode (Cu anode): Cu(s) → Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ (anode dissolves). Cathode: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu(s). Net: copper transferred from anode to cathode; Cl⁻ remains in solution; little Cl₂ formed if Cu anode used.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of molten Al₂O₃ (Hall–Héroult) — principle & reagents.
Electrolysis.back: Al₂O₃ dissolved in molten cryolite; at cathode: Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al(l). At carbon anode: 2O²⁻ → O₂ + 4e⁻ but carbon anodes oxidize to CO/CO₂ → CO₂ emitted. Industrial process to produce Al from Al₂O₃.

Electrolysis.front: Downs cell (Mg production) — brief principle.
Electrolysis.back: Electrolysis of molten MgCl₂ (often mixed with CaCl₂ to lower melting point) producing Mg(l) at cathode and Cl₂ at anode. Used for magnesium production.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis & thermodynamics: when is electrolysis possible by applying voltage?
Electrolysis.back: Electrolysis is possible when applied cell voltage > ΔE° (thermodynamic potential) + overpotentials + IR drop. Required external work supplies ΔG = n·F·E_applied to drive non-spontaneous reaction.

Electrolysis.front: Why some electrode reactions are kinetically slow (require large overpotential)?
Electrolysis.back: Slow electron-transfer kinetics, complex multi-step mechanisms, adsorption/desorption barriers cause high activation energies and hence significant overpotential (e.g., O₂ evolution often has large overpotential).

Electrolysis.front: Polarization curve — what it shows in electrolysis context.
Electrolysis.back: Plot of electrode potential vs current density showing activation polarization (kinetics), ohmic drop (IR), and concentration polarization (mass transport limits). Useful to design electrolysis cells and select operating current.

Electrolysis.front: Mass transport limitations — diffusion & migration effects in electrolysis.
Electrolysis.back: At high current densities, reactant depletion near electrode causes concentration polarization; diffusion/migration limit rate; stirring, flow, or high electrolyte concentration mitigates this.

Electrolysis.front: Sacrificial anode (cathodic protection) — concept & common metals.
Electrolysis.back: Sacrificial anode is a more active (anodic) metal connected to protected structure; it corrodes preferentially (oxidized) and protects the structure (e.g., Zn for steel ships/pipelines).

Electrolysis.front: Electrolyser cell types — diaphragm, mercury, membrane (brief).
Electrolysis.back: Diaphragm cell: porous barrier separates cathode/anode compartments (permits ion flow). Mercury cell: uses Hg cathode forming amalgam (old method, environmental issues). Membrane cell uses ion-exchange membrane (e.g., Nafion) separating compartments — high purity NaOH in chlor-alkali.

Electrolysis.front: Why conductivity of the electrolyte matters in electrolysis.
Electrolysis.back: Higher ionic conductivity reduces ohmic (IR) losses, lowers required voltage for given current, improves energy efficiency. Low conductivity increases cell voltage and energy consumption.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis & energy consumption — relation & efficiency factors.
Electrolysis.back: Electrical energy consumed = E_cell × Q = E_cell × I × t. Efficiency affected by overpotentials, side reactions, heat losses, and internal resistance. Industrial processes aim to minimize these factors.

Electrolysis.front: Role of additives in electroplating baths (brighteners, leveling agents).
Electrolysis.back: Additives modify nucleation and growth of deposited metal, control grain size, improve brightness, smoothness and adhesion, and reduce dendritic growth. Small quantities have strong effects.

Electrolysis.front: Electrochemical equivalent & example: compute z for Cu (M=63.546 g·mol⁻¹, n=2).
Practical deposition thickness estimate — relation with area and density.
Electrolysis.back: Thickness (m) ≈ mass / (area × density). Use m from electrolysis equation and density of metal to compute deposited layer thickness for electroplating design.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolysis of molten vs aqueous salts — differences to remember.
Electrolysis.back: Molten salts: only ions present → products are elements (e.g., Na, Cl₂). Aqueous salts: water can be involved — H₂ or O₂ may be produced depending on potentials and concentrations; competing reactions and solution chemistry matter.

Electrolysis.front: Why inert vs active anodes change electrolysis products (example Cu anode).
Electrolysis.back: Active anode (made of the same metal) dissolves supplying metal ions (electrorefining). Inert anode (Pt, graphite) does not oxidize; oxidation occurs of anions or water instead (e.g., O₂ evolution).

Electrolysis.front: Electrolytic corrosion (galvanic vs electrolytic) — brief note.
Electrolysis.back: Electrolytic corrosion: metal corrodes due to applied external current or stray currents; galvanic corrosion arises from galvanic coupling of dissimilar metals in electrolyte causing anodic dissolution of the less noble metal.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolytic cell notation example and interpretation.
Electrolysis.back: Anode | Anode solution || Cathode solution | Cathode. E.g., Pt | H₂O (anode) || Cu²⁺ (aq) | Cu (cathode). Left is oxidation, right is reduction; '||' is salt bridge or membrane.

Electrolysis.front: Calculating time for given mass deposition — formula & example.
Electrolysis of concentrated vs dilute brine — why different anode products?
Electrolysis.back: In concentrated Cl⁻ solutions, Cl₂ evolution favored at anode. In dilute solutions or with high overpotential, O₂ evolution from water may dominate. Cell type and electrode material influence selectivity.

Electrolysis.front: Concentration polarization & limiting current (brief).
Electrolysis.back: At high current, reactant near electrode depleted and diffusion cannot replenish fast enough — current reaches limiting value; potential increases sharply and undesirable reactions may occur.

Electrolysis.front: Passivation of electrodes — what & why it matters.
Electrolysis.back: Passivation: formation of insulating oxide or film on electrode surface (e.g., Anodic oxide on Al) reduces current, alters reaction, may require polishing/chemical treatment to restore activity.

Electrolysis.front: Electrochemical methods for analysis: coulometry vs voltammetry (brief).
Electrolysis.back: Coulometry quantifies analyte by measuring total charge to complete reaction (very accurate). Voltammetry measures current as function of applied potential to identify/quantify species and kinetics.

Electrolysis.front: Electrolytic refining of silver/gold — importance of anode slime.
Electrolysis.back: Precious metals (Ag, Au) often do not dissolve into solution and fall as anode slime during refining; this slime is collected and refined separately for recovery of valuable metals.

Electrolysis.front: Principle of electroplating to prevent corrosion (example zinc coating).
Electrolysis.back: Zinc electroplated onto iron forms sacrificial protection: even if coating scratched, zinc (more anodic) corrodes preferentially, protecting base metal (galvanisation).

Electrolysis.front: Safety & environmental issues in electrolysis industries (brief).
Electrolysis.back: Industrial electrolysis can produce toxic gases (Cl₂), corrosive products (NaOH), and CO₂ (from carbon anodes). Mercury cells cause mercury pollution — modern processes avoid mercury and minimise emissions.

Electrolysis.front: Role of temperature in electrolysis efficiency & kinetics.
Electrolysis.back: Higher temperature increases ion mobility and kinetics reducing overpotential and energy demands but may increase side reactions and corrosion; many industrial cells operate at elevated temperatures for efficiency.

Electrolysis.front: Practical exam tip: when given a cell with current & time, always calculate Q first.
Electrolysis.back: Compute Q = I·t in Coulombs. Then use m = (Q·M)/(n·F) or z = M/(nF) to find mass. Check units and round reasonably.

Electrolysis.front: Common pitfalls in electrolysis numerical problems (three points).
Electrolysis.back: 1) Forgetting to convert time to seconds. 2) Using wrong value of n (electrons exchanged). 3) Mixing up molar mass units (g·mol⁻¹) vs kg (ensure consistency in final units).

Electrolysis.front: Short checklist to approach electrolysis MCQs (4 steps).
Electrolysis.back: 1) Identify species present and possible electrode reactions. 2) Use electrochemical series & concentrations to predict discharge. 3) Compute Q = I·t and use m = (Q·M)/(n·F) if deposition asked. 4) Consider overpotential/side reactions for realistic predictions.

Electrolysis.front: One-line summary: how to decide products in aqueous electrolysis.
Electrolysis.back: Compare reduction potentials and concentrations; consider water involvement and overpotentials — the species with more favourable net (E° − η) will be discharged.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Why is carbon unique in forming a large number of compounds?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Carbon has electronic configuration 1s²2s²2p² — tetravalency (forms 4 covalent bonds), small atomic size (strong covalent bonds), catenation (ability to form C–C bonds), and multiple bond formation (C=C, C≡C) → huge variety of stable compounds.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is catenation?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Catenation is the ability of an element (especially carbon) to form long chains and rings by bonding with atoms of the same element (C–C, C=C links). Strength and stability of C–C bonds enable catenation.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Allotropes of carbon — list and one key property each.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Diamond: sp³ tetrahedral network, very hard, insulator. Graphite: sp² layered sheets, conducts electricity, lubricious. Fullerenes (C₆₀, C₇₀): closed-cage molecules, molecular solids. Graphene: single sp² layer, exceptional strength & conductivity. Carbon nanotubes: rolled graphene, high tensile strength.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Structure & bonding in diamond vs graphite (brief).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Diamond: each C sp³ bonded to 4 C atoms → 3D covalent network. Graphite: each C sp² bonded to 3 C atoms forming planar hexagonal layers with delocalised π-electrons between layers (weak van der Waals between layers).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Define hybridization and types relevant to carbon compounds.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Hybridization: mixing of atomic orbitals to form equivalent hybrid orbitals. Carbon: sp³ (tetrahedral, single bonds), sp² (trigonal planar, one π bond), sp (linear, two π bonds). Hybridization affects geometry and reactivity.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is homologous series?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: A series of compounds with same functional group and successive members differing by CH₂ unit. Members show similar chemical properties and gradation in physical properties (e.g., alkanes, alcohols).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Define functional group and give common examples in carbon compounds.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Functional group: specific atom/group responsible for characteristic reactions of a compound. Examples: −OH (alcohol), −COOH (carboxylic acid), C=O (aldehyde/ketone), −NH₂ (amine), −OR (ether), −Cl/−Br (haloalkane), −C≡N (nitrile).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Nomenclature: how to name a simple alkane using IUPAC (example: CH₃CH₂CH₃).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Identify longest carbon chain, number chain to give substituents lowest numbers, name substituents alphabetically, use prefixes (di-, tri-) as needed. CH₃CH₂CH₃ → propane.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: General formula and examples for alkanes, alkenes and alkynes.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Alkanes (saturated): C_nH_{2n+2} — e.g., CH₄, C₂H₆. Alkenes (one double bond): C_nH_{2n} — e.g., C₂H₄ (ethene). Alkynes (one triple bond): C_nH_{2n−2} — e.g., C₂H₂ (ethyne).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Isomerism in carbon compounds — main types with brief definitions.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Structural (constitutional): chain, position, functional group isomers. Stereoisomerism: same connectivity but different spatial arrangement — geometric (cis/trans or E/Z) and optical (chiral molecules, enantiomers).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is chirality and optical activity?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Chirality: molecule not superimposable on its mirror image due to an asymmetric (chiral) carbon bearing four different substituents. Optical activity: chiral compounds rotate plane-polarized light; enantiomers rotate equal magnitudes in opposite directions.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: How to identify a chiral (optically active) carbon atom?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: A carbon atom bonded to four different groups (no internal plane of symmetry) is chiral (stereogenic centre). Molecules with at least one chiral centre are often optically active unless racemic mixture.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is racemic mixture?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: A 1:1 mixture of two enantiomers having equal and opposite optical rotations → overall optical rotation = 0 (optically inactive).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Explain Markovnikov's rule (electrophilic addition to alkenes).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: In addition of HX to asymmetrical alkene, hydrogen adds to carbon with more H's (the carbon with fewer alkyl substituents) and X attaches to more substituted carbon → gives the more stable carbocation intermediate (Markovnikov product).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Anti-Markovnikov (peroxide) addition — when does it occur?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Hydrohalogenation of alkenes in presence of peroxides (ROOR) with HBr proceeds via radical mechanism giving anti-Markovnikov product (Br attaches to less substituted carbon). Peroxide effect mainly for HBr, not HCl or HI.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Name & describe free radical halogenation of alkanes (mechanism steps).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Chain reaction with initiation (formation of radicals, e.g., Cl· from Cl₂ under hv), propagation (H abstraction forming alkyl radical then halogenation), termination (radicals combine). Selectivity: tertiary H > secondary > primary.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is resonance and its significance in organic molecules?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Resonance: delocalization of π-electrons across adjacent p-orbitals represented by contributing structures. Resonance stabilizes molecule (e.g., benzene, carboxylate anion), affects acidity and reactivity.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Structure and stability of benzene — aromaticity & Hückel's rule.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Benzene C₆H₆ is planar cyclic with 6 π electrons delocalized over ring, equal C–C bonds (~1.39 Å). Hückel's rule: planar conjugated cyclic molecules with (4n+2) π electrons are aromatic (n = 1 → 6 π e⁻).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Electrophilic aromatic substitution (EAS) — general idea and common reactions.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Aromatic ring undergoes substitution where an electrophile replaces a H. Common EAS: nitration (HNO₃/H₂SO₄ → −NO₂), sulfonation (SO₃/H₂SO₄ → −SO₃H), halogenation (Cl₂/FeCl₃ → −Cl), Friedel–Crafts alkylation/acylation.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Directing effects in benzene — ortho/para vs meta directors (brief).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Electron-donating groups (EDG, e.g., −OH, −OCH₃, −NH₂, alkyl) are ortho/para directors and activate ring. Electron-withdrawing groups (EWG, e.g., −NO₂, −COOH, −CHO, −SO₃H) are meta directors and deactivate ring. Halogens are deactivating but ortho/para directors (due to lone pair resonance).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Friedel–Crafts reactions — two types & limitation.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Friedel–Crafts alkylation (RCl/AlCl₃) introduces alkyl group; acylation (RCOCl/AlCl₃) introduces acyl group. Limitations: deactivated rings (strong EWGs) do not undergo FC; polyalkylation & rearrangements possible; reaction fails with strongly deactivating substituents and with NH₂ present (forms complex with AlCl₃).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is resonance stabilization in carboxylate anion and consequence on acidity?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Carboxylate (RCOO⁻) has two equivalent resonance structures delocalizing negative charge → stabilization of conjugate base → increases acidity of carboxylic acids compared to alcohols.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Common methods to prepare ethanol (C₂H₅OH).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Hydration of ethene (C₂H₄ + H₂O, H₂SO₄/acid catalyst), fermentation of sugars (C₆H₁₂O₆ → 2 C₂H₅OH + 2 CO₂, yeast), reduction of ethanoic acid or acetaldehyde (NaBH₄ or LiAlH₄).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Properties & uses of ethanol and ethanoic acid (acetic acid).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Ethanol: polar protic solvent, flammable, used as fuel, solvent, disinfectant. Ethanoic acid: weak acid (pK_a ≈ 4.76), pungent, used in vinegar (dilute), precursor for esters and acylation reactions.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is esterification (Fischer esterification) and typical reagents?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Condensation of carboxylic acid and alcohol in presence of acid catalyst (H₂SO₄ or HCl) to form ester and water: RCOOH + R'OH ⇌ RCOOR' + H₂O (equilibrium reversible; remove water to shift right).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: How to hydrolyse an ester (acidic & basic hydrolysis)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Acidic hydrolysis (reversible): RCOOR' + H₂O ⇌ RCOOH + R'OH (acid catalyst). Basic hydrolysis (saponification, irreversible): RCOOR' + OH⁻ → RCOO⁻ + R'OH — produces carboxylate salt + alcohol.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is saponification? Give an example.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Base-catalysed hydrolysis of fats (triglycerides) forming glycerol and soap (salts of fatty acids). Example: fat + NaOH → glycerol + sodium stearate (soap).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Define homologous series and give properties for fatty acids & soaps.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Fatty acids are carboxylic acids with long hydrocarbon chains (common series: C₁₂–C₂₂). Soaps (salts) have hydrophobic tail & hydrophilic head enabling micelle formation and emulsification of oils.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Describe the test to distinguish aldehyde vs ketone (Tollens' & Fehling's tests).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Tollens' reagent (Ag(NH₃)₂⁺): aldehydes reduce Ag⁺ → Ag(s) (silver mirror) while most ketones do not. Fehling's solution (Cu²⁺ complex): aldehydes reduce to red Cu₂O precipitate; ketones generally inert (α-hydroxy ketones may react).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is oxidation of primary alcohols? (two-step overview)
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Primary alcohol → (mild oxidation e.g., PCC) → aldehyde → (strong oxidation e.g., KMnO₄, K₂Cr₂O₇) → carboxylic acid. Secondary alcohol → ketone; tertiary alcohol resist oxidation without C–C bond breaking.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Reduction reagents: NaBH₄ vs LiAlH₄ — differences & typical uses.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: NaBH₄: milder, reduces aldehydes & ketones to alcohols, safe in protic solvents. LiAlH₄: strong, reduces aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, amides to alcohols/amines; reacts violently with water — use aprotic solvents (ether).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Explain polymerization: addition vs condensation polymerization (definitions & examples).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Addition polymerization: monomers with double bonds (e.g., ethene) polymerize without by-products → polyethylene. Condensation polymerization: monomers with two functional groups react releasing small molecule (e.g., H₂O) → polyesters (PET), polyamides (nylon).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Give examples & basic description of common polymers from carbon compounds.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Polyethylene (PE): addition polymer from ethene (packaging). Polyvinyl chloride (PVC): from vinyl chloride (pipes). Polystyrene: from styrene (insulation). Teflon (PTFE): from tetrafluoroethene (non-stick). Nylon (polyamide): condensation of diamine + diacid. Bakelite: phenol + formaldehyde (thermoset).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is stereochemistry E/Z nomenclature for alkenes?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Order substituents on each double-bond carbon by Cahn–Ingold–Prelog priority. If higher-priority groups on same side → Z (zusammen), opposite sides → E (entgegen). Useful when cis/trans ambiguous due to substituent complexity.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What are homologues & how do physical properties vary with chain length?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Homologues differ by CH₂ units. As chain length increases, boiling/melting points generally increase (greater van der Waals forces). Solubility in water decreases for longer nonpolar chains.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Name common oxidation reactions of organic compounds (overview).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Alkane oxidation (combustion or radical), alcohol oxidation (1°→aldehyde→acid; 2°→ketone), alkene oxidation (ozonolysis → carbonyls), oxidation of aldehydes → carboxylic acids (KMnO₄).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Combustion of hydrocarbons — general reaction & products.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Complete combustion: C_xH_y + (x + y/4) O₂ → x CO₂ + (y/2) H₂O (products CO₂ and H₂O). Incomplete combustion produces CO, C (soot) and lower efficiency; important in fuels and pollution.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Haloalkanes (alkyl halides) — nucleophilic substitution: SN1 vs SN2 (key differences).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: SN2: bimolecular, one-step backside attack, stereospecific inversion, favoured by primary substrates and strong nucleophiles in aprotic solvents. SN1: unimolecular, carbocation intermediate, racemization, favoured by tertiary substrates and polar protic solvents; rate depends on substrate stability.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What factors influence nucleophilicity & leaving group ability?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Nucleophilicity: charge, basicity, polarizability, solvent effects (protic vs aprotic), sterics. Leaving group ability: stability of leaving anion (better if weak base, e.g., I⁻ > Br⁻ > Cl⁻ > F⁻).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is elimination (E1 vs E2) and relation to substitution?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: E2: bimolecular concerted elimination, strong base abstracts β-H as leaving group leaves → alkene formed (stereospecific anti-periplanar geometry). E1: unimolecular via carbocation then elimination; often competes with SN1; Zaitsev's rule predicts the more substituted alkene as major product.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Explain Zaitsev's rule for elimination reactions.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: In elimination, the more substituted (thermodynamically stable) alkene (more alkyl-substituted double bond) is usually the major product (unless bulky base or anti-Zaitsev conditions favour less substituted).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Alcohol classification and general reactivity differences (1°, 2°, 3°).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Primary (1°): RCH₂OH — oxidizable to aldehyde then acid. Secondary (2°): R₂CHOH — oxidizable to ketone. Tertiary (3°): R₃COH — resistant to oxidation without C–C cleavage; good candidates for dehydration to alkenes under acid.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Tests: Lucas test, and what it distinguishes.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Lucas reagent (ZnCl₂/HCl) distinguishes alcohols: tertiary alcohols react quickly giving turbidity (alkyl chloride), secondary slower, primary very slow or no reaction at room temp due to carbocation formation rates.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is dehydration of alcohols (conditions & products)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Dehydration (acid-catalyzed, e.g., conc. H₂SO₄ or H₃PO₄, heat) removes H₂O to form alkenes. Follows E1 for 2°/3° (carbocation) and E2 for 1° sometimes. Zaitsev product usually predominates.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Carboxylic acids — acidity & factors stabilizing conjugate base.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Carboxylic acids (RCOOH) are more acidic than alcohols due to resonance stabilization of carboxylate anion (RCOO⁻). Electron-withdrawing substituents (−NO₂, −Cl) increase acidity; electron-donating (−CH₃) decrease acidity.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Derivatives of carboxylic acids: acid chlorides, anhydrides, esters, amides — reactivity order & reasons.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Reactivity (toward nucleophilic acyl substitution) typically: acid chloride > acid anhydride > ester > amide (amide least reactive due to resonance donation from N).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: How are amides prepared and what is their general stability?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Prepared by acylation of amines (RCOCl + R'NH₂ → RCONHR') or by condensation of carboxylic acid with amine (difficult). Amides are resonance-stabilized (partial C–N double bond) → relatively stable and less reactive than esters.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is nitration of benzene (conditions & mechanism outline)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Nitration: electrophilic aromatic substitution using nitrating mixture HNO₃/H₂SO₄ generating NO₂⁺ electrophile. NO₂⁺ attacks benzene forming sigma complex, followed by deprotonation to restore aromaticity → nitrobenzene.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Reduction of nitro group — common reagents & products.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Nitro group (−NO₂) can be reduced to amine (−NH₂) using catalytic hydrogenation (H₂/Pd), Sn/HCl, Fe/HCl, or other reducing agents (e.g., LiAlH₄ under certain conditions).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is electrophilic addition to alkenes — general mechanism steps?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Step 1: electrophile (E⁺) attacks π bond forming carbocation intermediate (or bridged ion for halogenation). Step 2: nucleophile (e.g., X⁻, H₂O) attacks carbocation to give addition product. Regioselectivity follows carbocation stability (Markovnikov).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Hydrogenation of alkenes — catalyst & stereochemistry.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Catalytic hydrogenation (H₂ with Pd/C, Pt, or Ni) adds H₂ across C=C syn to give saturated alkane; used to remove unsaturation; stereospecific syn addition gives cis addition on cyclic substrates.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Ozonolysis of alkenes — oxidative cleavage products.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Ozonolysis (O₃ then reductive workup Zn/CH₃COOH or (CH₃)₂S) cleaves C=C to give carbonyl compounds: RCH=CHR' → RCHO + R'CHO (or ketones if substituted). Oxidative workup (H₂O₂) further oxidizes aldehydes to acids.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is phenol: acidity & special properties compared to alcohols?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Phenol (ArOH) is more acidic than aliphatic alcohols due to resonance stabilization of phenoxide anion; however resonance also reduces O−H bond polarity so not as acidic as carboxylic acids. Phenol undergoes electrophilic substitution easily (activated ring).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Tests to identify functional groups: bromine water, KMnO₄, Tollen's, NaHCO₃ — what they indicate?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Bromine water: decolourises with alkenes/activated aromatics (electrophilic addition). KMnO₄ (oxidation): decolourises with alkenes, oxidisable groups. Tollen's: aldehydes → silver mirror. NaHCO₃: carboxylic acids effervesce (CO₂) but phenols do not.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What are aromatic heterocycles? Give examples and properties.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Heterocycles: aromatic rings containing heteroatoms (N, O, S). Examples: pyridine (C₅H₅N) basic (lone pair not in π system), pyrrole (C₄H₅N) non-basic (lone pair in π system), furan, thiophene — aromatic and show substitution patterns analogous to benzene with differing reactivity.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Explain nucleophilic addition to carbonyl compounds (aldehydes & ketones).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Carbonyl C is electrophilic (polar C=O). Nucleophile attacks C forming tetrahedral alkoxide intermediate; after protonation gives addition product (e.g., addition of HCN, alcohols → hemiacetals/acetals, NaBH₄ reduction → alcohols).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Acetal and hemiacetal formation — conditions & significance (protection).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Aldehyde/ketone + alcohol (acid catalyst) → hemiacetal (one alcohol addition) → acetal (two alcohols) on further reaction. Acetals are stable to base and used as protecting groups for carbonyls in synthesis.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is cyanohydrin formation and why useful?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Addition of HCN to aldehyde/ketone gives cyanohydrin (R₂C(OH)CN), introducing a −CN (nitrile) and −OH functional group; nitrile can be hydrolysed to carboxylic acid or reduced to amine, useful in synthetic routes.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What are important uses & preparation of methanol and ethanol industrially?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Methanol prepared from synthesis gas (CO + 2 H₂ → CH₃OH) or destructive distillation. Ethanol prepared by fermentation (biological) or hydration of ethene industrially. Uses: fuels, solvents, precursors in chemical industry.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: How to prepare alkenes from alcohols (dehydration) and from haloalkanes (dehydrohalogenation).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Alcohol dehydration (acid, heat) yields alkenes (E1/E2). Dehydrohalogenation: strong base (KOH/EtOH or NaOEt) removes HX from haloalkane → alkene (E2 mechanism).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is vinyl & allylic position (nomenclature importance)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Vinyl: carbon directly part of C=C (sp²) bearing substituent. Allylic: carbon next to C=C (–CH₂–CH=CH–) — allylic hydrogens are more reactive (e.g., easily radical-stabilized, more acidic).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Explain benzylic position & its reactivity.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Benzylic: carbon directly attached to aromatic ring. Benzylic C–H bonds are weaker; benzylic oxidation (e.g., side chain of toluene → benzoic acid with KMnO₄) occurs readily if benzylic C has at least one H.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is Friedel–Crafts acylation advantage vs alkylation?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Acylation avoids carbocation rearrangements and gives ketone substituent that deactivates ring, preventing polyacylation. Alkylation can lead to rearrangements and over-alkylation.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What are important petroleum fractions and general use (relating to hydrocarbons)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Petroleum fractional distillation yields LPG (C₃–C₄ gases), gasoline (C₅–C₁₂), kerosene, diesel, lubricant fractions; hydrocarbon chain length and branching affect octane/cetane properties for fuels.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Octane number & knocking in engines — brief relation to hydrocarbons.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Octane number measures fuel's resistance to knocking (premature combustion). Branched alkanes and aromatics generally have higher octane numbers than straight-chain alkanes; additives (e.g., MTBE) improve octane.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is cracking (thermal & catalytic) and why used?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Cracking breaks long-chain hydrocarbons into smaller useful fractions (e.g., gasoline). Thermal (high T) and catalytic (zeolites, lower T) methods; also produces olefins used in petrochemicals.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What is reforming in petroleum industry?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Catalytic reforming converts low-octane linear hydrocarbons into higher-octane branched/cyclic/aromatic compounds (improves gasoline quality) often using Pt catalysts.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: What are green chemistry considerations for carbon compounds (brief)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Reduce hazardous reagents, adopt atom economy (fewer by-products), use renewable feedstocks (bioethanol), catalysis, energy-efficient processes, and minimize persistent pollutants (e.g., avoid mercury/lead).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Laboratory safety & hazard notes for working with organic solvents/compounds.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Many organics are flammable, volatile, toxic or irritant. Use fume hood, avoid ignition sources, proper PPE (gloves, goggles), store in compatible containers, dispose wastes per regulations.

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Practice question: Write IUPAC name for CH₃–CH(CH₃)–CH₂–OH.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Longest chain contains 3 carbons → propan-1-ol with methyl substituent at C-2: 2-methylpropan-1-ol (commonly isobutanol).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Practice question: Major product of hydration of propene (H₃O⁺ or H₂O/H⁺)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Markovnikov addition → 2-propanol (isopropanol) as major product (H adds to CH₂ end, OH to more substituted carbon).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Practice question: Product of ozonolysis (reductive workup) of cyclohexene?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Cyclohexene cleaves the C=C to give adipaldehyde equivalent → actually oxidative cleave of cyclic C=C leads to dialdehyde (hexanedial). With oxidative workup would give dicarboxylic acid (adipic acid).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Practice question: Give structure & name of an amide derived from ethanoic acid & ammonia.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Amide: ethanamide (commonly acetamide) CH₃CONH₂ formed by condensation of CH₃COOH and NH₃ (with dehydration/activation).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Practice question: How to convert benzyl chloride (C₆H₅CH₂Cl) to benzyl alcohol (C₆H₅CH₂OH)?
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Nucleophilic substitution: react with aqueous NaOH (SN2 at benzylic position) or use AgNO₃/H₂O (solvolysis) to give benzyl alcohol (careful of competing elimination under harsh conditions).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: Common pitfalls students make in carbon chemistry problems (three points).
Carbon and its Compounds.back: 1) Ignoring resonance & conjugation effects on reactivity. 2) Mixing up SN1/SN2 conditions & substrate effects. 3) Forgetting stereochemical outcomes (inversion vs racemization) and regiochemistry (Markovnikov/anti-Markovnikov).

Carbon and its Compounds.front: One-line strategy for solving carbon-compound MCQs in competitive exams.
Carbon and its Compounds.back: Identify functional groups → apply general reactivity rules (nucleophile/electrophile, oxidation/reduction, resonance effects) → consider mechanism stereotypes (SN1/SN2, E1/E2, electrophilic addition/substitution) → pick answer consistent with stability & regiochemistry.

Fuels.front: What is a fuel (simple definition)?
Fuels.back: A fuel is a material that stores chemical energy which can be released by combustion or other reactions to produce heat, light or work (e.g., coal, petrol, CNG, H₂).

Fuels.front: Classification of fuels (broad categories).
Fuels.back: Fuels are classified as solid (coal, coke, biomass), liquid (petrol, diesel, kerosene, bioethanol, biodiesel), and gaseous (natural gas CH₄, LPG: C₃H₈/C₄H₁₀, hydrogen H₂).

Fuels.front: Primary vs secondary fuels — what's the difference?
Fuels.back: Primary fuels occur naturally and are used directly (coal, petroleum, natural gas). Secondary fuels are derived from primary fuels (coke, gasoline from crude oil, synthesis gas converted to fuels).

Fuels.front: What is combustion (general reaction)?
Fuels.back: Combustion is the rapid oxidation of fuel: Fuel + oxidant (usually O₂) → CO₂ + H₂O + heat (complete combustion). Incomplete combustion yields CO, C (soot) and less heat.

Fuels.front: Stoichiometric combustion — meaning and why important.
Fuels.back: Stoichiometric combustion uses exactly the theoretical amount of air required to completely oxidize the fuel (no excess O₂ or unburnt fuel). Important for calculating air required and combustion efficiency.

Fuels.front: How to calculate theoretical air required for hydrocarbon CₓH_y combustion (outline).
Fuels.back: Balanced: CₓH_y + (x + y/4) O₂ → x CO₂ + (y/2) H₂O. Air contains 21% O₂ by volume → theoretical air (moles) = (x + y/4) / 0.21. Convert to mass/volume as needed.

Fuels.front: Excess air — definition & effect on combustion.
Fuels.back: Excess air = (actual air − theoretical air) / theoretical air × 100%. Excess air ensures complete combustion but lowers flame temperature and efficiency due to heat carried away by unused air.

Fuels.front: Gross calorific value (GCV or Higher Heating Value, HHV) — definition.
Fuels.back: GCV (HHV) = heat released when 1 unit of fuel is completely combusted and combustion products are cooled to original temperature, condensing water vapour (includes latent heat of vaporization of H₂O).

Fuels.front: Net calorific value (NCV or Lower Heating Value, LHV) — definition.
Fuels.back: NCV (LHV) = heat released when products remain as vapour (does NOT include latent heat of vaporization of water). NCV = GCV − latent heat of vaporization of H₂O formed.

Fuels.front: Which fuels are usually quoted as HHV and which as LHV in practice?
Fuels.back: Solid fuels and conventional fuel tables often quote HHV. Gas turbines and engines often use LHV (because water leaves as vapour). Always check which convention is used.

Fuels.front: Units of calorific value commonly used.
Fuels.back: Common units: kJ·kg⁻¹, kcal·kg⁻¹ for solid/liquid fuels; kJ·m⁻³ or MJ·m⁻³ for gaseous fuels; J·g⁻¹ also used. 1 kcal = 4.184 kJ.

Fuels.front: Bomb calorimeter — purpose and what it measures.
Fuels.back: A bomb calorimeter measures the heat of combustion (ΔE) at constant volume. From temperature rise and calorimeter constant one can compute GCV (approx) for a fuel sample.

Fuels.front: Proximate analysis of coal — components measured.
Fuels.back: Proximate analysis gives moisture (M), volatile matter (VM), fixed carbon (FC) and ash content (A) — used to evaluate coal quality and behaviour in combustion.

Fuels.front: Ultimate analysis of coal — components measured.
Fuels.back: Ultimate analysis reports elemental composition by mass: C, H, N, S, O (by difference) and ash. Used to compute theoretical air and calorific values.

Fuels.front: What is fixed carbon (in coal context)?
Fuels.back: Fixed carbon = combustible residue left after volatile matter is driven off; approximates solid carbon content available for slow combustion (char).

Fuels.front: Why volatile matter is important in coal combustion?
Fuels.back: Volatile matter (gases released on heating) influences ignition, flame stability and ease of combustion — higher VM gives easier ignition and flaring flames.

Fuels.front: What is coal rank (peat → anthracite)?
Fuels.back: Coal rank measures coalification: peat → lignite → sub-bituminous → bituminous → anthracite. Higher rank → higher carbon content, higher calorific value, lower volatile matter.

Fuels.front: What is coke (metallurgical coke) and how is it produced?
Fuels.back: Coke is a porous, carbon-rich solid made by destructive distillation (carbonization) of coal in absence of air (coking ovens). Used in metallurgy (blast furnaces) and as a fuel.

Fuels.front: What is gasification (basic idea)?
Fuels.back: Gasification converts carbonaceous feedstock (coal, biomass) into synthesis gas (syngas: mixture of CO + H₂ + CO₂ + small hydrocarbons) by partial oxidation at high T. Syngas used for fuel synthesis or electricity.

Fuels.front: Producer gas vs water gas — basic compositions & production.
Fuels.back: Producer gas: made by partial combustion with air (CO + N₂ + CO₂ + small H₂). Water gas: made by passing steam over hot carbon (CO + H₂) — requires oxygen/air to heat bed (producer gas used to generate heat to form water gas).

Fuels.front: Why syngas calorific value differs from natural gas?
Fuels.back: Syngas (CO + H₂ + diluents) has lower calorific value per m³ than natural gas (mainly CH₄) because of dilution by N₂/CO₂ and lower H/C energy density.

Fuels.front: Natural gas composition & typical impurities (brief).
Fuels.back: Natural gas is mainly methane CH₄ (~70–95%), with C₂–C₅ hydrocarbons, CO₂, N₂, H₂S (toxic) and water vapour. Processing removes impurities and heavier hydrocarbons for distribution.

Fuels.front: LPG — what it is and typical composition.
Fuels.back: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) is a mix of propane C₃H₈ and butane C₄H₁₀ (plus isomers). Stored as liquid under pressure; used for cooking, heating and as automotive fuel (autogas).

Fuels.front: CNG vs LPG — differences relevant to transport fuels.
Fuels.back: CNG (compressed natural gas) is mainly gaseous CH₄ stored at high pressure (~200–250 bar) — low volumetric energy density but clean burning. LPG is liquid under moderate pressure, higher volumetric energy density, easier storage in tanks.

Fuels.front: What is octane number (RON/MON) and why it matters in petrol (gasoline)?
Fuels.back: Octane number measures anti-knock quality of petrol; higher octane resists knocking. RON (research octane number) and MON (motor octane number) differ by test conditions; performance index often (R+M)/2.

Fuels.front: What causes engine knocking and why is it bad?
Fuels.back: Knocking is premature, uncontrolled ignition of the fuel–air mixture causing pressure spikes, reduced efficiency and engine damage. It occurs when mixture auto-ignites before flame front from spark reaches it.

Fuels.front: How is cetane number related to diesel fuels?
Fuels.back: Cetane number measures ignition quality of diesel: higher cetane → shorter ignition delay → smoother combustion. Diesel engines require fuels with good cetane numbers for efficient operation.

Fuels.front: Typical anti-knock additives for petrol and common concerns.
Fuels.back: Historically tetraethyllead (TEL) used to raise octane (toxic, phased out). Alternatives include oxygenates (MTBE, ETBE, ethanol) and aromatic hydrocarbons; environmental/toxicity and air-pollution issues govern choice.

Fuels.front: What is reforming (catalytic reforming) in petroleum refining?
Fuels.back: Reforming converts low-octane straight-run naphthas into high-octane aromatics and isoparaffins (increasing gasoline octane) using catalysts (Pt) and heat; also produces hydrogen as by-product.

Fuels.front: What is cracking (thermal vs catalytic)?
Fuels.back: Cracking breaks heavy hydrocarbons into lighter fractions. Thermal cracking uses high T; catalytic cracking uses zeolite catalysts at lower T for more selective production of gasoline and olefins.

Fuels.front: What is hydrocracking and its advantage?
Fuels.back: Hydrocracking uses hydrogen and catalysts to break heavy fractions producing high-quality diesel and jet fuels with low sulfur; it saturates olefins and removes heteroatoms (HDS).

Fuels.front: Desulfurization in fuels — why necessary and typical process.
Fuels.back: Sulfur in fuels produces SO₂ on combustion ⇒ acid rain and catalyst poisoning. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) converts sulfur compounds to H₂S which is removed; required to meet low-sulfur fuel specs.

Fuels.front: What is cetane improver for diesel (brief)?
Fuels.back: Cetane improvers (e.g., 2-ethylhexyl nitrate) are additives that decrease ignition delay and improve cold-start and combustion quality in diesel engines.

Fuels.front: Flash point, fire point and autoignition temperature — definitions.
Fuels.back: Flash point: lowest T at which vapor forms ignitable mixture producing a momentary flash. Fire point: T where vapour continues burning. Autoignition temperature: T at which fuel self-ignites without external flame.

Fuels.front: Why flash point is important for fuel storage & transport?
Fuels.back: Flash point indicates flammability hazard; fuels with low flash points (e.g., petrol) require stricter handling and storage rules than fuels with high flash points (diesel).

Fuels.front: Cloud point, pour point and viscosity — relevance to fuels (especially diesel).
Fuels.back: Cloud point: T where wax crystals appear (cloudiness). Pour point: lowest T at which fuel flows. Viscosity affects pumpability and atomization in engines; low T properties critical in cold climates.

Fuels.front: What is cetane number typical range for diesel fuels?
Fuels.back: Cetane numbers typically range ~40–55 for diesel; higher cetane desirable. Biodiesel often has good cetane numbers compared to some petrodiesel fractions.

Fuels.front: Biomass & biofuels — main types and production routes.
Fuels.back: Bioethanol (fermentation of sugars/starches), biodiesel (transesterification of vegetable oils/fats to fatty acid methyl esters FAME), biogas (anaerobic digestion producing CH₄/CO₂), bio-syngas (gasification → Fischer–Tropsch fuels).

Fuels.front: Transesterification for biodiesel — basic reaction.
Fuels.back: Triglyceride + 3 MeOH (or EtOH) → 3 fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) + glycerol (catalysts: NaOH, KOH or acid catalysts).

Fuels.front: Advantages & limitations of biodiesel compared to petro-diesel.
Fuels.back: Advantages: renewable, biodegradable, lower particulates and CO emissions, higher lubricity. Limitations: cold-flow issues, lower energy density, possible NOx increase, feedstock competition with food crops.

Fuels.front: What is hydrogen as a fuel — pros & cons?
Fuels.back: H₂ offers high gravimetric energy density and zero CO₂ on combustion (if produced renewably). Challenges: low volumetric density (storage), production cost, infrastructure, safety (leakage & flammability).

Fuels.front: Fuel cells — general principle and fuel-cell vs combustion efficiency.
Fuels.back: Fuel cell converts chemical energy directly to electricity via electrochemical reactions (e.g., H₂ + ½O₂ → H₂O). Fuel cells can achieve higher efficiencies than internal combustion engines and produce low local emissions.

Fuels.front: Common fuel cell types and fuel choices briefly.
Fuels.back: PEMFC (proton exchange membrane fuel cell) uses H₂, low T; SOFC (solid oxide fuel cell) can use H₂, CO or hydrocarbons at high T; MCFC (molten carbonate) also high T. Reforming hydrocarbons can supply H₂ for some cells.

Fuels.front: Octane vs cetane — opposite requirements for spark-ignition vs compression-ignition engines.
Fuels.back: Spark-ignition (petrol) engines require high octane (anti-knock) to avoid autoignition. Compression-ignition (diesel) engines require high cetane (easy ignition) for short ignition delay.

Fuels.front: What is smoke point for aviation kerosene (jet fuel)?
Fuels.back: Smoke point measures tendency to produce soot when burned in a lamp flame; higher smoke point → cleaner combustion. Jet fuels have specified smoke points to control soot and engine deposits.

Fuels.front: Jet fuel properties & common specifications (brief).
Fuels.back: Jet fuels (Jet A, JP-8) are kerosene-range fractions with strict specs: low freezing point, controlled flash point, low sulfur, proper thermal stability and clean combustion to prevent deposits.

Fuels.front: Octane enhancers from bio-sources — ethanol blending (E10, E85) effect on fuel properties.
Fuels.back: Ethanol raises octane number, increases vapour pressure, reduces CO emissions; blends like E10 (10% ethanol) common. High blends (E85) require compatible engines; ethanol is hygroscopic and lowers energy density per litre.

Fuels.front: What is thermal efficiency of engines and how fuel properties affect it?
Fuels.back: Thermal efficiency depends on engine cycle, compression ratio and fuel calorific value. Higher octane allows higher compression ratio in SI engines → higher efficiency; diesel engines benefit from high cetane and high energy density.

Fuels.front: Pollutant formation from fuel combustion — main species.
Fuels.back: Typical pollutants: CO (incomplete combustion), unburnt hydrocarbons (UHC), NOₓ (from high-temperature oxidation of N₂), SOₓ (from fuel sulfur), particulate matter (soot), and CO₂ (greenhouse gas).

Fuels.front: How NOₓ forms in combustion and basic control methods.
Fuels.back: NOₓ forms thermally at high flame temperatures (Zeldovich mechanism) and from fuel-bound nitrogen. Control methods: lower flame temperature (excess air management, EGR), staged combustion, catalytic aftertreatment (SCR).

Fuels.front: How particulate (soot) forms and control measures.
Fuels.back: Soot forms from incomplete combustion of hydrocarbon-rich zones (fuel-rich pockets), especially in diesel. Controls: better atomization, optimized air–fuel mixing, diesel particulate filters (DPF), oxidation catalysts.

Fuels.front: Flue gas desulfurization (FGD) — purpose and typical methods.
Fuels.back: FGD removes SO₂ from combustion exhaust to limit acid rain. Methods: wet scrubbing with lime/limestone (CaCO₃/Ca(OH)₂) producing gypsum (CaSO₄·2H₂O), dry sorbents, and catalytic processes.

Fuels.front: What is knock-limited compression ratio and octane requirement link?
Fuels.back: Higher compression ratio increases thermal efficiency but raises tendency to knock; fuels with higher octane withstand higher compression ratios without knocking, allowing more efficient engine designs.

Fuels.front: Fuel storage safety basics (vapour, ignition, corrosion).
Fuels.back: Store in well-ventilated, cool areas away from ignition. Prevent static discharge, control vapour build-up (explosive atmospheres), use corrosion-resistant tanks, follow flash point regulations and secondary containment for spills.

Fuels.front: What is energy density (gravimetric & volumetric) and examples?
Fuels.back: Gravimetric energy density = energy per mass (MJ·kg⁻¹). Volumetric energy density = energy per volume (MJ·L⁻¹). H₂ high gravimetric but low volumetric; diesel/petrol high volumetric energy density ideal for transport.

Fuels.front: How do additives improve fuel performance (brief types)?
Fuels.back: Additives: detergents (keep injectors clean), antioxidants (prevent gum), corrosion inhibitors, anti-icing agents, octane/cetane improvers, cold-flow improvers for diesel, lubricity improvers for low-sulfur fuels.

Fuels.front: What is fuel stability (storage) and factors causing degradation?
Fuels.back: Stability refers to resistance to oxidation, polymerization and microbial growth. Factors: oxygen, light, heat, metal traces (catalyse oxidation), presence of water (microbial growth) and contaminants.

Fuels.front: Microbial contamination in fuels — why a problem and mitigation.
Fuels.back: Water/organic interface supports microbial growth producing biomass, acids and sludge clogging filters. Control: remove water, biocides, fuel polishing and good tank hygiene.

Fuels.front: Important refinery products (fractions) and approximate boiling ranges.
Fuels.back: LPG (gases), gasoline/petrol (~35–200 °C), kerosene/jet (~150–300 °C), diesel (~250–360 °C), heavy fuel oil (>350 °C), lubricating oils, bitumen/residuum.

Fuels.front: Why aromatics & olefins influence gasoline octane?
Fuels.back: Aromatics and branched isoparaffins have high octane values, boosting anti-knock properties; olefins can raise octane but affect stability and emissions, so controlled amounts are allowed.

Fuels.front: Practice: Calculate theoretical O₂ requirement for complete combustion of octane C₈H₁₈.
Fuels.back: Reaction: C₈H₁₈ + (12.5) O₂ → 8 CO₂ + 9 H₂O. So O₂ required = 12.5 mol per mol C₈H₁₈. For air (21% O₂ by vol) theoretical air ≈ 12.5/0.21 ≈ 59.52 mol air per mol fuel.

Fuels.front: Practice: Convert heating value units — 1 MJ·kg⁻¹ to kJ·g⁻¹.
Fuels.back: 1 MJ·kg⁻¹ = 1000 kJ per 1000 g = 1.0 kJ·g⁻¹. So multiply/divide consistently (1 kJ·g⁻¹ = 1000 kJ·kg⁻¹ = 1 MJ·kg⁻¹).

Fuels.front: Common exam pitfalls when solving fuel problems (three points).
Fuels.back: 1) Mixing mass and mole bases incorrectly (use consistent basis). 2) Forgetting to include N₂ when using air (air ≈ 21% O₂ by volume or 23.3% by mass). 3) Confusing HHV & LHV (latent heat of water).

Fuels.front: One-line approach to answer fuel/calorimetry MCQs quickly.
Fuels.back: Identify fuel formula & basis (1 mol or 1 kg), write balanced combustion, compute O₂/air or moles of products, use HHV/LHV appropriately, convert units carefully and check reasonableness.

Metallurgy.front: What is metallurgy (simple definition)?
Metallurgy.back: Metallurgy is the science and technology of extracting metals from their ores and modifying metals to produce useful products (extraction, refining, alloying, heat treatment).

Metallurgy.front: Define ore, mineral and gangue.
Metallurgy.back: Mineral: naturally occurring inorganic substance with definite composition (e.g., hematite Fe₂O₃). Ore: mineral from which a metal can be profitably extracted. Gangue: worthless impurities associated with ore (silica, clay).

Metallurgy.front: What is concentration (beneficiation) of an ore?
Metallurgy.back: Concentration is removal of gangue from the ore to increase metal content — done by mechanical & physico-chemical methods (gravity, magnetic, froth flotation, leaching).

Metallurgy.front: Gravity concentration — principle & examples.
Metallurgy.back: Separates particles by difference in specific gravity using water or air (e.g., jigs, shaking tables) — used for dense ores like cassiterite (SnO₂) and gold-containing ores.

Metallurgy.front: Magnetic separation — when used & basic idea.
Metallurgy.back: Used when ore or gangue has magnetic properties (e.g., magnetite Fe₃O₄). Magnetic separators attract magnetic particles, separating them from non-magnetic gangue.

Metallurgy.front: Froth flotation — principle & typical reagents.
Metallurgy.back: Hydrophobic particles attach to air bubbles and float; hydrophilic particles sink. Reagents: collectors (xanthates), frothers (pine oil), activators, depressants (NaCN), used for sulfide ores (e.g., CuFeS₂).

Metallurgy.front: What is roasting (definition & purpose)?
Metallurgy.back: Roasting: heating sulfide ores in excess air to convert to oxides or sulfates (e.g., 2ZnS + 3O₂ → 2ZnO + 2SO₂). Purpose: remove volatile impurities (S) and prepare for reduction.

Metallurgy.front: What is calcination (definition & difference from roasting)?
Metallurgy.back: Calcination: heating carbonate or hydrated ores in limited air to remove CO₂/H₂O and produce oxides (e.g., CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂). Roasting typically for sulfides in oxidizing atmosphere; calcination for carbonates/ hydrates.

Metallurgy.front: Define smelting.
Metallurgy.back: Smelting: reduction of ore (oxide/sulfide) at high temperature with a reducing agent (coke or CO) in a furnace to obtain metal (e.g., blast furnace for iron).

Metallurgy.front: What is a flux and why is it used?
Metallurgy.back: Flux is added to combine with gangue and form slag (liquid) which can be removed (e.g., CaO + SiO₂ → CaSiO₃). Fluxes (lime, silica) promote removal of impurities and lower melting point of slag.

Metallurgy.front: Define slag and matte.
Metallurgy.back: Slag: molten non-metallic by-product (flux + gangue). Matte: molten sulfide phase (e.g., Cu₂S + FeS) formed during smelting of sulfide ores, later converted to metal.

Metallurgy.front: What is leaching (hydrometallurgy) — brief idea.
Metallurgy.back: Leaching dissolves the desired metal from ore using aqueous solutions (acids, cyanide, ammonia). Followed by purification (solvent extraction) and recovery (electrowinning or precipitation).

Metallurgy.front: Heap leaching — what and when used?
Metallurgy.back: Low-grade ores placed on impermeable pads and irrigated with leach solution (e.g., cyanide for Au). Economical for low-grade deposits (gold, copper oxides).

Metallurgy.front: What is solvent extraction & electrowinning (SX–EW)?
Metallurgy.back: Solvent extraction: transfers metal ions from aqueous phase to organic extractant selectively. Electrowinning: electrodeposition of pure metal from purified electrolyte (used for Cu, Zn, etc.).

Metallurgy.front: Give the general steps in pyrometallurgy vs hydrometallurgy.
Metallurgy.back: Pyrometallurgy: concentration → roasting/calcination → smelting → converting → refining. Hydrometallurgy: concentration → leaching → solution purification (SX) → metal recovery (precipitation/electrowinning).

Metallurgy.front: What is the reactivity series and why important in metallurgy?
Metallurgy.back: Order of metals by reactivity (K > Na > Ca > Mg > Al > Zn > Fe > ... > Ag > Au). Determines method of extraction: highly reactive metals require electrolysis; less reactive by reduction with CO/coke.

Metallurgy.front: Briefly explain the Ellingham diagram significance.
Metallurgy.back: Ellingham diagram plots ΔG° of oxide formation vs T. It predicts which oxides can be reduced by a given reducing agent (CO, C, Al). Lower line = more stable oxide; intersections indicate feasible reduction reactions.

Metallurgy.front: What is aluminothermy (thermite process)?
Metallurgy.back: Reduction of metal oxides by aluminium powder using its strong reducing power (e.g., Fe₂O₃ + 2Al → 2Fe + Al₂O₃). Used for welding rails and producing metals from refractory oxides.

Metallurgy.front: Describe blast furnace process for iron (raw materials & products).
Metallurgy.back: Charge: iron ore (hematite/magnetite), coke (fuel & reducing agent), limestone (flux). Reactions: C → CO → CO reduces Fe₂O₃ to Fe. Products: molten pig iron (high C), slag (CaSiO₃), top gases (CO, CO₂).

Metallurgy.front: Key reaction: reduction of iron oxide by carbon monoxide.
Metallurgy.back: Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂ (g). CO is primary reducing agent in blast furnace at high T.

Metallurgy.front: What is pig iron, wrought iron and steel (differences)?
Metallurgy.back: Pig iron: product from blast furnace with ~3–4% C and impurities. Wrought iron: nearly pure Fe with very low C (<0.08%) and fibrous slag—malleable. Steel: iron–carbon alloy with controlled C (0.02–2.14%) and alloying elements for desired properties.

Metallurgy.front: Describe basic oxygen steelmaking (LD process) in brief.
Metallurgy.back: Molten pig iron charged into converter; high-purity O₂ blown at supersonic speed oxidizes C, Si, Mn, P → gases and slag; quick process to produce steel with controlled composition.

Metallurgy.front: What is the Bessemer process (historical) — core idea & limitation?
Metallurgy.back: Air blown through molten pig iron oxidizes impurities to produce steel rapidly. Limitation: acidic (SiO₂) process couldn't remove phosphorus/sulfur well; superseded by basic oxygen and electric furnaces.

Metallurgy.front: Electric Arc Furnace (EAF) — application & advantage.
Metallurgy.back: EAF melts scrap steel or direct reduced iron using electrical arcs. Advantage: flexible feedstock (scrap), lower CO₂ per tonne if powered by clean electricity, good for specialty steels.

Metallurgy.front: What is refining by oxygen removal and deoxidizers (e.g., Al, Si)?
Metallurgy.back: After steelmaking, oxygen is removed by adding deoxidizers (aluminium, silicon, manganese) which form oxides that float to slag, preventing gas porosity and improving quality.

Metallurgy.front: Explain basic refining of copper (pyrometallurgy overview).
Metallurgy.back: Concentrate → roasting (to remove S) → smelting → matte formation (Cu₂S/FeS) → converting (oxidize FeS→slag and Cu₂S→Cu) → fire/refining → electrolytic refining for high purity Cu (electrowinning).

Metallurgy.front: What is matte in copper extraction?
Metallurgy.back: Matte is molten sulfide mixture (mainly Cu₂S and FeS) formed during smelting; it is separated from slag and further converted to blister copper and refined.

Metallurgy.front: How is aluminium extracted industrially (two main steps)?
Metallurgy.back: Bayer process: purify bauxite to get Al₂O₃ (alumina). Hall–Héroult process: electrolytic reduction of molten Al₂O₃ (dissolved in molten cryolite) to metallic Al at cathode (Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al).

Metallurgy.front: Bayer process — main idea & impurity removal.
Metallurgy.back: Bauxite digested with NaOH dissolves Al₂O₃ as aluminate; impurities (Fe₂O₃, TiO₂) remain insoluble as red mud. Al(OH)₃ precipitated, calcined → Al₂O₃.

Metallurgy.front: Hall–Héroult electrolytic cell key points & role of cryolite.
Metallurgy.back: Al₂O₃ dissolved in molten cryolite (Na₃AlF₆) lowers melting point and increases conductivity. Electrolysis at ~950°C reduces Al³⁺ to Al metal; carbon anodes oxidize to CO/CO₂.

Metallurgy.front: Why aluminium is extracted via electrolysis not chemical reduction by C?
Metallurgy.back: Al₂O₃ is very stable; carbon reduction would require extreme conditions and would form Al₄C₃ and contaminations. Electrolysis provides controlled reduction despite high energy demand.

Metallurgy.front: Extraction of zinc (general steps).
Metallurgy.back: Sphalerite (ZnS) concentrate → roasting to ZnO → reduction via coke (pyrometallurgy) or leaching & electrowinning (hydrometallurgy): ZnO + H₂SO₄ → ZnSO₄ (aq) → purification → electrolysis → Zn.

Metallurgy.front: Lead extraction from galena (PbS).
Metallurgy.back: Roasting: 2PbS + 3O₂ → 2PbO + 2SO₂. PbO reduced by carbon or CO at high T: PbO + C → Pb + CO. Refining by cupellation for precious-metal separation and other refining steps.

Metallurgy.front: What is cupellation and where is it used?
Metallurgy.back: High-temperature oxidation process to separate noble metals (Ag, Au) from base metal impurities using a porous hearth (lead is oxidized & absorbed in bone ash, leaving noble metal).

Metallurgy.front: Gold extraction — cyanidation (brief).
Metallurgy.back: Au + 2CN⁻ + H₂O + ½O₂ → Au(CN)₂⁻ + 2OH⁻ (in presence of O₂ and alkaline medium). Gold recovered by adsorption on activated carbon or by zinc precipitation (Merrill–Crowe) and refined by smelting/electrorefining.

Metallurgy.front: What is amalgamation (historical) for gold/silver)?
Metallurgy.back: Process where mercury forms amalgams with gold/silver from crushed ore; amalgam heated to evaporate Hg leaving precious metal. Largely phased out due to mercury toxicity.

Metallurgy.front: What is electrolytic refining (principle & example)?
Metallurgy.back: Impure metal anode dissolves into electrolyte; pure metal deposits at cathode. Example: Cu anode dissolves → Cu²⁺ → deposited on cathode as pure Cu; impurities form anode slime.

Metallurgy.front: Anode slime — what & importance?
Metallurgy.back: In electrolytic refining, insoluble impurities (Au, Ag, Se, Te) collect as anode slime and can be processed separately to recover precious metals.

Metallurgy.front: What is leaching of copper (oxide vs sulphide)?
Metallurgy.back: Oxide copper ores are amenable to acid leaching (H₂SO₄) producing Cu²⁺ for SX–EW. Sulfide ores require bioleaching or roasting + smelting; direct leaching of sulfides is difficult.

Metallurgy.front: What is bioleaching (bacterial leaching)?
Metallurgy.back: Use of microorganisms (Thiobacillus) to oxidize sulfide minerals producing soluble metal salts (e.g., Cu²⁺). Used for low-grade ores and heap leaching of copper, gold.

Metallurgy.front: What is solvent extraction selectivity principle (for Cu separation)?
Metallurgy.back: Organic extractants preferentially bind certain metal ions from acidic aqueous solutions; pH and extractant control selectivity (e.g., LIX reagents for Cu over Fe).

Metallurgy.front: What is electrowinning for copper production (SX–EW)?
Metallurgy.back: After solvent extraction concentrates Cu into electrolyte, electrowinning deposits copper plates at cathodes producing high-purity cathode copper without smelting.

Metallurgy.front: How is iron purified to steel quality (desulfurization & dephosphorization)?
Metallurgy.back: Fluxes (lime) and oxidizing slag treatments remove S & P; CaO–SiO₂–MgO slags and basic processes (LD) help remove P (by forming Ca₃(PO₄)₂) and S (by forming CaS in presence of reductants).

Metallurgy.front: What are primary and secondary steelmaking steps?
Metallurgy.back: Primary: convert pig iron to crude steel (Bessemer/LD/EAF). Secondary: refining processes (vacuum degassing, ladle metallurgy, alloy additions) to adjust composition and remove gases/inclusions.

Metallurgy.front: What is vacuum degassing and its role?
Metallurgy.back: Process of reducing dissolved gases (H, O, N) from molten steel by exposing it to low pressure, improving mechanical properties and reducing porosity.

Metallurgy.front: Define alloy and give examples of common alloys with composition & use.
Metallurgy.back: Alloy: mixture of metal(s) with other elements to improve properties. Examples: steel (Fe-C), stainless steel (~Fe–Cr 11–20% ± Ni) corrosion resistant; brass (Cu–Zn) malleable & decorative; bronze (Cu–Sn) durable; duralumin (Al–Cu) lightweight structural.

Metallurgy.front: What is stainless steel (why corrosion resistant)?
Metallurgy.back: Steel alloy containing ≥~11% Cr; Cr forms a thin, adherent, protective Cr₂O₃ passive layer that resists corrosion. Addition of Ni, Mo improves toughness and pitting resistance.

Metallurgy.front: What is cast iron and types (gray, white, malleable)?
Metallurgy.back: Cast iron: Fe–C alloy with high carbon (2–4%). Gray iron: graphite flakes (good damping); white iron: cementite (Fe₃C) hard & brittle; malleable iron: heat-treated white iron producing tempered carbon clusters (improved ductility).

Metallurgy.front: Explain heat treatment terms: annealing, normalizing, quenching, tempering (short).
Metallurgy.back: Annealing: heat & slow cool to soften and relieve stress. Normalizing: heat above A_c3 and air cool to refine grain. Quenching: rapid cooling (water/oil) to form hard martensite. Tempering: reheat quenched steel to reduce brittleness and adjust hardness.

Metallurgy.front: What is martensite and why is it hard?
Metallurgy.back: Martensite: supersaturated, distorted body-centred tetragonal (BCT) structure formed by rapid quenching of austenite; high dislocation density & trapped carbon makes it very hard and brittle.

Metallurgy.front: Define austenite, pearlite and cementite (Fe–C microstructures).
Metallurgy.back: Austenite (γ): FCC Fe solution of C stable at high T. Pearlite: lamellar mixture of ferrite (α-Fe) + cementite (Fe₃C) formed on slow cooling; cementite: iron carbide (Fe₃C) hard and brittle.

Metallurgy.front: What is carburizing (case hardening)?
Metallurgy.back: Introduce carbon to surface by heating steel in contact with carbonaceous material (pack, gas carburizing) to produce a hard, wear-resistant surface (case) while keeping ductile core.

Metallurgy.front: What is nitriding (surface hardening)?
Metallurgy.back: Diffusion of nitrogen into steel surface at moderate T forming hard nitrides (e.g., Fe₄N) providing wear resistance without quenching.

Metallurgy.front: Explain work hardening (strain hardening).
Metallurgy.back: Increase in strength/hardness due to plastic deformation (cold working) that increases dislocation density and impedes further dislocation motion.

Metallurgy.front: What is powder metallurgy (brief use)?
Metallurgy.back: Manufacture of components by compacting metal powders and sintering — enables near-net shapes, high melting/ refractory materials, and tailored porosity or composition.

Metallurgy.front: What is corrosion (definition) and main types?
Metallurgy.back: Corrosion: chemical/electrochemical deterioration of metals by reaction with environment. Types: uniform corrosion, galvanic (dissimilar metal coupling), pitting, crevice, intergranular, stress corrosion cracking.

Metallurgy.front: Galvanic corrosion — principle & prevention.
Metallurgy.back: When two dissimilar metals electrically connected in electrolyte, the more active (anodic) metal corrodes. Prevention: use similar metals, insulating joints, coatings, cathodic protection (sacrificial anode).

Metallurgy.front: Cathodic protection — sacrificial anodes vs impressed current.
Metallurgy.back: Sacrificial anode: attach more active metal (Zn, Mg) that corrodes instead. Impressed current: external DC supplies protective current making structure cathodic.

Metallurgy.front: What is passivation and examples?
Metallurgy.back: Formation of thin protective oxide film that slows corrosion (e.g., Cr₂O₃ on stainless steel, Al₂O₃ on aluminium). Passive films can be damaged by chloride ions causing pitting.

Metallurgy.front: How is metal purification by zone refining done (for high purity metals)?
Metallurgy.back: A molten zone passes along a rod; impurities concentrate in molten zone and are moved to one end; repeated passes produce ultra-pure semiconductor-grade metals (Si, Ge).

Metallurgy.front: What is metal casting (brief process steps)?
Metallurgy.back: Mold preparation → melt metal → pour into mold → solidification → shakeout → cleaning & heat treatment. Casting types: sand, die, investment.

Metallurgy.front: What is galvanization?
Metallurgy.back: Coating iron/steel with a layer of zinc to protect against corrosion; zinc acts as sacrificial anode and barrier; common method: hot-dip galvanizing.

Metallurgy.front: What are refractory materials and why important in metallurgy?
Metallurgy.back: Materials resistant to high T and chemical attack (e.g., MgO, Al₂O₃, SiC) used to line furnaces, crucibles and reactors in metallurgical processes.

Metallurgy.front: What is spinel & its role in slags?
Metallurgy.back: Spinel (MgAl₂O₄-type) and other complex oxides can form in slag affecting viscosity and melting behaviour; slag chemistry tailored to control these phases for good separation.

Metallurgy.front: Environmental issues in metallurgy (brief).
Metallurgy.back: Air pollution (SO₂, particulates, CO₂), water contamination (acid mine drainage, heavy metals), solid waste (tailings, red mud). Control: scrubbers, tailings management, flue gas desulfurization, waste recycling.

Metallurgy.front: What is red mud (in alumina production)?
Metallurgy.back: Waste from Bayer process containing Fe oxides, TiO₂ and other impurities; alkaline and poses disposal challenges; research into red mud utilization ongoing.

Metallurgy.front: What is pickling in metallurgy?
Metallurgy.back: Acid treatment (e.g., HCl, H₂SO₄) to remove oxide scale from metal surfaces prior to further processing (plating, painting).

Metallurgy.front: Why is nitrogen control important in steel?
Metallurgy.back: Excess N can form nitrides causing embrittlement; for some steels controlled N improves strength but must be controlled via melting atmosphere and degassing.

Metallurgy.front: How are superalloys different and typical applications?
Metallurgy.back: High-performance alloys (Ni-, Co- or Fe-based) with excellent high-T strength & corrosion resistance (crucial in gas turbines, jet engines, chemical plants). Alloying elements: Al, Ti, Cr, Mo, Co.
