Metallurgy.front: What is electroplating vs electroless plating?
Metallurgy.back: Electroplating: metal deposition using external current. Electroless plating: autocatalytic chemical reduction (no external current) depositing metal like Ni–P; gives uniform coating even on complex shapes.

Metallurgy.front: What is precious metal recovery from ores & slimes (brief)?
Metallurgy.back: Recovery uses a combination of physical concentration, chemical leaching (cyanidation), adsorption (activated carbon), and refining (electrolytic, chlorination, aqua regia) depending on matrix.

Metallurgy.front: Practice: Balance reaction of hematite reduction by CO (simple).
Metallurgy.back: Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂. (Used conceptually in blast furnace reduction.)

Metallurgy.front: Practice: Why is limestone added to blast furnace charge?
Metallurgy.back: Limestone (CaCO₃) decomposes to CaO which acts as flux combining with silica gangue to form liquid slag (CaSiO₃) that can be removed.

Metallurgy.front: Exam tip: quick way to decide extraction method for a metal.
Metallurgy.back: Check position in reactivity series: very reactive → electrolysis of molten salts; moderately reactive → reduction of oxide by CO/coke (pyrometallurgy) or hydrometallurgy if oxide/oxide soluble; least reactive (noble) → found native or recovered by leaching/complexing.

Metallurgy.front: Common pitfalls students make in metallurgy MCQs (three points).
Metallurgy.back: 1) Confusing roasting vs calcination. 2) Using wrong reducing agent for a given metal (e.g., thinking C reduces Al₂O₃). 3) Ignoring role of flux/slag chemistry and limestone purpose.

Metallurgy.front: One-line summary: how to approach metallurgy MCQs quickly.
Metallurgy.back: Identify the ore type (oxide/sulfide/carbonate), choose concentration method, decide roasting/calcination or leaching, pick reduction method based on reactivity/Ellingham logic, and consider refining/heat-treatment needed.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: What general physical properties characterise metals?
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Metals are typically lustrous, good conductors of heat & electricity, malleable, ductile, and have high density and melting points (with many exceptions). They form cations (Mⁿ⁺) and metallic bonds with delocalised electrons.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: What are chemical properties common to many metals?
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Metals tend to lose electrons (oxidation), react with acids to produce H₂ (except very noble metals), form basic oxides (M O or M O₂), and form alloys among themselves.

Very light alkali metal; soft, reacts vigorously with water → LiOH + ½H₂. Widely used in Li-ion batteries, psychiatric medication (Li salts), and lightweight alloys. Stored under oil due to reactivity.

Soft alkali metal, reacts vigorously with water → NaOH + ½H₂. Important in NaCl (table salt), Na-vapour lamps, organic reductions (e.g., Birch), and production of Na compounds. Produced by electrolysis of molten NaCl in industrial cells.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Potassium — key facts and biological role
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Alkali metal, very reactive with water; essential biological cation (K⁺) for nerve impulses and muscle function. Used in fertilizers (K₂O expressed as % K₂O), and some pyrotechnics.
Light, low-density alkaline-earth metal; burns with bright white flame (MgO). Used in structural alloys (aircraft), flash photography, and as Mg²⁺ is central in chlorophyll and enzyme cofactors.
Alkaline-earth metal; Ca²⁺ essential in biology (bones, signaling). Metallurgical use as deoxidizer and desulfurizer; quicklime (CaO) used as flux in smelting and in steelmaking slag formation.

Lightweight, corrosion-resistant due to protective Al₂O₃ film. Extracted by Hall–Héroult electrolytic reduction of Al₂O₃ in molten cryolite. Extensive use in aerospace, packaging (foil), and alloys (e.g., duralumin).
Aluminium forms a very thin, adherent Al₂O₃ oxide layer that prevents further oxidation (passivation). Mechanical damage can reform the oxide rapidly in air.

Major ores: hematite (Fe₂O₃), magnetite (Fe₃O₄). Extracted in blast furnace using coke/CO as reducing agent → pig iron → refined to steel. Iron is central to construction, machinery and manufacturing.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: What causes rust and how is it prevented?
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Rust = hydrated iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃·nH₂O) formed by electrochemical corrosion in presence of O₂ & moisture. Prevention: coatings (paint, galvanizing), sacrificial anodes, stainless alloys (Cr passivation), cathodic protection.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Steel vs cast iron — difference in carbon content and properties
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Steel: Fe–C alloy with ~0.02–2% C, tunable properties (hardness, ductility) via heat treatment/alloying. Cast iron: higher C (~2–4%), brittle, good castability. Alloying elements (Cr, Ni, Mn) modify properties.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Stainless steel — why corrosion resistant and typical composition
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Contains ≥~11% Cr which forms protective Cr₂O₃ passive film; Ni, Mo improve toughness and pitting resistance. Common grades: 304 (Fe–18Cr–8Ni) and 316 (with Mo for marine resistance).

Excellent electrical & thermal conductor; malleable, ductile. Common ores: chalcopyrite (CuFeS₂), chalcocite (Cu₂S). Used in electrical wiring, plumbing, coins, alloys (brass, bronze). Refined by electrolysis to high purity.

Bronze = Cu–Sn alloy (also with other elements) → durable, corrosion-resistant, used for bearings, statues. Brass = Cu–Zn alloy → malleable, used for fittings, musical instruments; composition controls colour & properties.
Highest electrical & thermal conductivity of all metals. Tarnishes (Ag + H₂S → Ag₂S). Used in electronics, jewellery, mirrors and some catalysts. Forms Ag⁺ compounds and complexes (e.g., AgNO₃).

Very noble (resistant to oxidation & corrosion), excellent conductor, highly dense. Used in jewellery, electronics, dentistry, and as monetary reserve. Forms stable complexes (AuCl₄⁻) and is recovered from ores via cyanidation.

Pt and Pd are platinum-group metals with excellent catalytic activity (automotive catalytic converters, hydrogenation, fuel cells). Chemically inert, corrosion-resistant, used in jewellery & catalytic processes.
Only common metal liquid at room temperature; used historically in thermometers & amalgams. Highly toxic (neurological) and bioaccumulative; many uses phased out due to environmental/health concerns.

Extracted from galena (PbS). Dense, malleable, used historically in pipes, paints, batteries (Pb–acid). Pb²⁺ is toxic affecting nervous system; leaded petrol and paints phased out due to health risks.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Zinc — uses and role in corrosion protection
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Commonly used for galvanizing steel to provide sacrificial corrosion protection. Used in brass (Cu–Zn), batteries (Zn–C, Zn–air), and as a reducing agent in metallurgy (e.g., Zn reduction in extraction).

Used for solder (with Pb historically), tinplate for cans (protective coating over steel), and in alloys (bronze). 'Tin pest' is an allotropic transformation of white tin to brittle grey tin at low T, historically problematic in cold climates.
Corrosion-resistant, ferromagnetic (some alloys), major component in stainless steels and superalloys; used in rechargeable batteries (Ni–Cd, Ni–MH), plating (Ni plating) and catalysts.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Chromium — role in stainless steel & toxicity
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Cr provides corrosion resistance by forming Cr₂O₃ passive film (stainless steel). Hexavalent chromium (Cr⁶⁺) compounds are toxic and carcinogenic; Cr³⁺ is an essential trace element in small amounts.
Mn improves hardenability, strength and removes oxygen (demanganization) and sulfur (forms MnS) during steelmaking. Essential alloying element in many steels and cast irons.

High strength-to-weight ratio, corrosion-resistant due to TiO₂ passive layer, biocompatible (implants), used in aerospace, medical devices and pigments (TiO₂). Titanium alloys (e.g., Ti–6Al–4V) widely used.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Vanadium & molybdenum — alloying for strength at high T
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: V and Mo are used as alloying elements in steels to increase toughness, hardenability and high-temperature strength (used in tools, high-strength low-alloy steels and superalloys).
Tungsten has the highest melting point (~3410 °C) of all pure metals and very high density; used for filaments (historically), cutting tools, and high-temperature alloys.
Used in high-temperature, wear-resistant alloys and permanent magnets (Alnico, rare earth magnets often doped). Cobalt is also present in vitamin B₁₂ (biological trace element).
Used historically in Ni–Cd batteries, pigments and plating. Highly toxic (renal, bone) and carcinogenic; many uses restricted and replaced by safer alternatives.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Bismuth — unusual safety profile among heavy metals
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Heavy metal with low toxicity compared to lead/mercury; used in medical compounds (bismuth subsalicylate), low-melting alloys, and as a lead substitute in some applications.
Pb, Hg, Cd, Cr⁶⁺ and some forms of As are hazardous: bioaccumulate, damage nervous system, kidneys and are carcinogenic. Environmental controls and remediation are crucial.
Electrolytic refining yields high-purity copper: impure Cu anode dissolves, Cu²⁺ plates on cathode; precious impurities form anode slime recoverable for Au/Ag recovery.
Coating steel with zinc provides a sacrificial anode (zinc corrodes first) and physical barrier, greatly extending life of steel structures (e.g., galvanised roofing, pipes).
Noble/precious metals (Au, Pt, Pd, Ag) resist oxidation/corrosion due to low chemical reactivity; valued for rarity, stability and catalytic/electronic properties.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Alloy example: Duralumin — composition & why important
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Duralumin is an Al alloy (Al–Cu–Mg–Mn) offering high strength-to-weight ratio — historically important in aerospace for structural parts (heat-treatable).

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Why aluminium & copper are widely used in electrical transmission
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Copper has highest electrical conductivity and excellent ductility; aluminium is lighter (lower density) with good conductivity per mass and is cost-effective for overhead lines (often used as Al conductor with steel core).

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Electrical & thermal conductivity: which metal is best?
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity, followed by copper and gold. Copper used most widely due to cost/performance balance.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Solder materials — common alloys & changes over time
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Traditional solders were Sn–Pb alloys (low melting, easy wetting). Due to toxicity, Pb-free solders (Sn–Ag–Cu, SAC) are now common in electronics, with higher melting points.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Hydrogen embrittlement — which metals are affected & why it matters
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Hydrogen uptake can make metals (steel, high-strength alloys) brittle causing cracking under stress. Important in manufacturing, high-pressure H₂ systems and corrosion control.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Metal fatigue — basic idea & engineering relevance
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Progressive structural damage under cyclic stress leading to crack initiation and propagation. Material selection, stress concentration control and fatigue testing are critical in engineering design.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Uranium — fuel use & isotopes of importance
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: U is the primary nuclear fuel: U-235 (fissile) and U-238 (fertile). Uranium is mined, milled to 'yellowcake' (U₃O₈), converted/enriched (for reactors or weapons) and fabricated into fuel.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: How corrosion and passivation depend on alloying (brief)
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Alloying elements like Cr, Ni, Mo form stable oxides or modify electrochemistry to improve corrosion resistance (e.g., stainless steels). Some elements (S, P) decrease corrosion resistance.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Why precious metals are used as catalysts
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Pt, Pd, Rh stabilize transition states, provide adsorption sites for reactants, and undergo reversible surface oxidation states — excellent for hydrogenation, oxidation and automotive catalytic converters.

Recycling conserves resources, saves energy (e.g., recycling aluminium saves ~95% of primary energy), reduces mining impact and landfill; metals can often be recycled repeatedly with little quality loss.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Key lab safety notes when handling metals & their salts
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Avoid inhalation of dust/fumes (metal oxides), minimize skin contact (toxic metals), use fume hood for volatile or toxic metal compounds, follow disposal regulations for heavy-metal waste.

Important Facts About Some Metals.front: Common exam tip: how to quickly pick metal facts in MCQs
Important Facts About Some Metals.back: Identify the property asked (reactivity, density, conductivity, biological role, toxicity, major ore or extraction method) then recall signature facts (e.g., Hall-Héroult for Al, blast furnace for Fe, galvanizing = Zn coating).

Non Metal.front: What is a non-metal (general definition & typical properties)?
Non Metal.back: Non-metals are elements that are generally poor conductors of heat and electricity, not lustrous, brittle (if solid), and tend to gain electrons to form anions in reactions. They show varied physical states (gases, liquids, solids) and form acidic oxides.

Non Metal.front: Which common elements are classified as non-metals in the periodic table?
Non Metal.back: Major non-metals: H, C, N, O, P, S, Se, the halogens (F, Cl, Br, I) and the noble gases (He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn). (Some elements like Si, B are metalloids.)

Non Metal.front: Trend: electronegativity & ionization energy for non-metals
Non Metal.back: Non-metals generally have high electronegativity and high ionization energies compared to metals (increase across a period and decrease down a group). This explains tendency to gain electrons (form anions) and form covalent bonds.

Non Metal.front: Why many non-metals form covalent bonds rather than ionic bonds?
Non Metal.back: Non-metals have relatively high ionization energies and similar electronegativities with other non-metals, so sharing electrons (covalent bonding) is energetically favoured over full electron transfer.

Allotropy: existence of an element in two or more different structural forms (allotropes) with different properties (e.g., carbon: diamond, graphite, fullerenes; phosphorus: white, red, black). Important because allotropes have very different chemical/physical behaviour.
H is the lightest element; dihydrogen H₂ is a colourless, odourless gas, slightly soluble in water. Exists as H₂ (non-polar) with weak intermolecular forces (low boiling point −252.9 °C).
Combustion: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O (high energy release). Reacts with many metals to form hydrides (e.g., NaH), with non-metals (e.g., HCl from H₂ + Cl₂ under light).
Steam reforming of methane: CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂ (then CO + H₂O → CO₂ + H₂). Electrolysis of water: 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂ (renewable if electricity green). Also partial oxidation, thermochemical routes.

Non Metal.front: Hydrides — types and examples (ionic, covalent, metallic)
Non Metal.back: Ionic (salt-like) hydrides: M⁺H⁻ (alkali/alkaline earth metals). Covalent hydrides: CH₄, NH₃, H₂O. Metallic (or interstitial): transition metal hydrides (e.g., PdHₓ). Reactivity varies widely.

Strong dipole–dipole interaction when H bonded to F, O or N interacts with lone pairs on F/O/N of a neighbouring molecule. Explains high boiling points and unique properties of H₂O, NH₃, HF, and biological molecules (DNA/proteins).

Major allotropes: dioxygen O₂ (paramagnetic gas) and ozone O₃ (tri-atomic, reactive, pale-blue gas with characteristic odour). O₂ supports combustion; ozone is a powerful oxidant and absorbs UV in stratosphere.

Non Metal.front: Preparation of oxygen in laboratory (common method)
Non Metal.back: Decomposition of hydrogen peroxide: 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂ (catalysed by MnO₂). Also by heating KClO₃ with MnO₂: 2KClO₃ → 2KCl + 3O₂ (lab classic).
Stratospheric ozone formed by O₂ photolysis and recombination: O₂ + hv → 2O·; O· + O₂ → O₃. Absorbs UV-B & UV-C protecting life; tropospheric ozone is pollutant and oxidant harmful to health.
N₂ has a strong triple bond (N≡N) making it kinetically inert at room T. Essential for life but reactive conditions (high T, catalysts) are needed to convert N₂ to reactive compounds (e.g., ammonia).
N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃; carried out at 200–350 atm, 400–500 °C with heterogeneous Fe-based catalysts and promoters. Le Chatelier and kinetics trade-offs govern industrial conditions.
NH₃ used to make NH₄NO₃, urea (NH₂)₂CO, ammonium phosphates — cornerstone of N-fertilizers. Also used as refrigerant and precursor for nitric acid (Ostwald process).

Non Metal.front: Ostwald process — production of nitric acid (outline)
Non Metal.back: NH₃ + 2O₂ → NO + H₂O (catalyst Pt/Rh); NO → NO₂ (oxidation); NO₂ + H₂O → HNO₃ + NO. Overall converts NH₃ → HNO₃ (used for fertilizers, explosives).
HNO₃ is a strong oxidizing acid; oxidises many metals and organic compounds (e.g., producing NO₂). Concentrated HNO₃ nitrates aromatic rings (nitrobenzene formation with H₂SO₄ catalyst).
White (P₄, highly reactive, toxic, spontaneously ignites in air), red (polymeric, less reactive, used in matches), black (graphite-like, thermodynamically stable). Handling depends on allotrope.

Non Metal.front: Uses of phosphorus — fertilizers & match industry
Non Metal.back: Phosphorus compounds (phosphate rocks → H₃PO₄ → phosphate fertilizers) vital in agriculture. White phosphorus previously used in matches (safety matches use red P on striking surface).
S exists in many allotropes (rhombic α-S₈, monoclinic β-S₈) and forms sulfide minerals (e.g., pyrite FeS₂). Sulfur used for sulfuric acid, vulcanization of rubber and sulfur-containing chemicals.

Non Metal.front: Contact process — industrial production of H₂SO₄ (outline)
Non Metal.back: S → SO₂ (burning); 2SO₂ + O₂ ⇌ 2SO₃ (V₂O₅ catalyst, ~450 °C); SO₃ + H₂O (or H₂SO₄) → H₂SO₄. Produces concentrated sulphuric acid (key industrial chemical).

H₂SO₄ is a strong diprotic acid, dehydrating agent, and oxidizer (conc.). Used in fertilizers, mineral processing, chemical synthesis, petroleum refining. 'Perf of industry' often measured by H₂SO₄ consumption.

Non Metal.front: Halogens — general properties (F, Cl, Br, I)
Non Metal.back: Group 17 elements: high electronegativity, occur as diatomic molecules (F₂, Cl₂, Br₂, I₂). Reactivity decreases down group (F most reactive). Form halide anions X⁻ and many covalent compounds.
Produced by electrolysis of brine (2Cl⁻ → Cl₂ + 2e⁻) in chlor-alkali process; products include Cl₂, NaOH, H₂. Uses: water disinfection, PVC (via vinyl chloride), bleaching, chemical intermediates.
A more reactive halogen displaces a less reactive halide from solution: Cl₂ + 2Br⁻ → 2Cl⁻ + Br₂. Useful qualitative test for halogen reactivity order F₂ > Cl₂ > Br₂ > I₂.

Non Metal.front: Bleaching action of chlorine and hypochlorite
Non Metal.back: Cl₂ + H₂O ⇌ HOCl + HCl; HOCl (hypochlorous acid) oxidizes coloured organic compounds → decolourisation. NaClO (bleach) yields OCl⁻ (active bleaching species).

Non Metal.front: Hydrogen halides and halide acids (HCl, HBr, HI) — properties
Non Metal.back: HX gases form strongly acidic aqueous solutions (HCl → HCl(aq) strong acid). HF is a weak acid but very corrosive and forms strong H-bonds; forms complexes with SiO₂ and glass (etching).

Non Metal.front: Laboratory test for halide ions (AgNO₃ test)
Non Metal.back: Add AgNO₃ to acidic solution: Cl⁻ → white AgCl (soluble in NH₃); Br⁻ → pale yellow AgBr (partially soluble in concentrated NH₃); I⁻ → yellow/cream AgI (insoluble).
Binary compounds of two different halogens (e.g., ClF₃, BrF₅, ICl) often strong oxidizers/fluorinating agents; formula generally XY_n where X less electronegative than Y.

Non Metal.front: P-block non-metals commonly form oxoacids — what are oxoacids?
Non Metal.back: Oxoacids = acids containing oxygen, hydrogen and central element (e.g., HClO₄ perchloric acid, HNO₃ nitric acid, H₃PO₄ phosphoric acid, H₂SO₄ sulfuric acid). Acidity often correlates with oxidation state and electronegativity.

Non Metal.front: Oxoacids strength trend for oxyacids with same central atom
Non Metal.back: For acids of formula HClOₙ, increasing oxidation state (or more O) increases acidity (HClO < HClO₂ < HClO₃ < HClO₄). More electronegative central atom or more resonance-stabilised conjugate base → stronger acid.

Non-metal oxides are usually acidic or neutral (e.g., CO₂ acidic, NO₂ acidic; some are amphoteric like SO₂? mostly acidic). Acidic oxides form acids with water: SO₃ + H₂O → H₂SO₄; CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ (weak).

Non Metal.front: Acidic, basic & amphoteric oxides — distinguishing feature
Non Metal.back: Acidic oxides react with bases to give salts (SO₂ + 2NaOH → Na₂SO₃ + H₂O). Basic oxides (mostly metal oxides) react with acids. Amphoteric oxides (e.g., Al₂O₃) react with both acids and bases.

Carbon allotropes: diamond (hard, sp³), graphite (soft, sp², conducts electricity), graphene, fullerenes, carbon nanotubes. Forms covalent compounds and extensive organic chemistry; essential to life.

Non Metal.front: Carbon oxides CO and CO₂ — properties & reactivity
Non Metal.back: CO: toxic, binds to haemoglobin, acts as reducing agent (CO + O₂ → CO₂), forms metal carbonyls. CO₂: acidic oxide, forms carbonates and bicarbonates; greenhouse gas responsible for anthropogenic warming.
Formed by incomplete combustion of carbonaceous fuels. CO is colourless/odourless; detection uses CO detectors or chemical tests (e.g., blood carboxyhaemoglobin measurement).
SO₂ produced by combustion of sulfur-containing fuels causes acid rain (converted to H₂SO₄). Flue gas desulfurization (FGD) uses lime/limestone scrubbing to remove SO₂ from exhaust gases.

Non Metal.front: Nitrogen oxides (NO, NO₂) — formation & environmental impact
Non Metal.back: NO formed at high T from N₂ + O₂ in engines; oxidizes to NO₂ which contributes to photochemical smog and acid rain; NO_x control via EGR, catalytic converters and combustion tuning.
Phosphates (PO₄³⁻) are crucial fertilizers; phosphine PH₃ is a toxic, flammable gas produced by hydrolysis of metal phosphides (e.g., Ca₃P₂ + 6H₂O → 3Ca(OH)₂ + 2PH₃).
Biological N-fixation: nitrogenase enzymes in certain bacteria convert N₂ → NH₃. Industrial: Haber–Bosch produces NH₃ from N₂ and H₂ providing fertilizer feedstock.

Oxygen: cellular respiration; Nitrogen: amino acids & nucleic acids; Phosphorus: ATP, DNA backbone; Sulfur: amino acids (Cys, Met); Halides (Cl⁻): electrolyte balance; Iron (metal) in haemoproteins (not strictly non-metal).

AgNO₃ test for Cl⁻/Br⁻/I⁻ (precipitates); Flame test for Cl⁻ not diagnostic but metal halides show colours; oxidizing reagents (e.g., KMnO₄) can liberate halogens from halides under certain conditions.

Group 18 elements: very low reactivity (filled shell), monoatomic gases, low boiling points. Uses: inert atmospheres (Ar in welding), lighting (Ne signs, Kr/Xe in some lamps), cryogenics (He), ion propulsion & lasers.
Xenon forms compounds (e.g., XeF₂, XeF₄, XeO₃) under strong oxidising/fluorinating conditions — demonstrates that noble gases can be forced to bond under specific conditions.

NO_x and SO_x → air pollution & acid rain. Ozone at ground level is a pollutant. Chlorine gas is toxic. Phosphates cause eutrophication in water bodies. Proper handling, abatement and regulations required.

Non Metal.front: Redox behaviour: non-metals as oxidising agents
Non Metal.back: Many non-metals (O₂, F₂, Cl₂, O₃) are powerful oxidizers (accept electrons). Oxidizing strength generally decreases down a group (F₂ strongest oxidizer).

Non Metal.front: Reducing agents among non-metal compounds — examples
Non Metal.back: Some non-metal hydrides or oxyanions can be reducing (e.g., H₂S reduces oxidants; SO₂ is a reducing agent in some contexts). Organic compounds (carbon-based) often act as fuels (reducing agents) in combustion.
H₂O₂ prepared industrially by anthraquinone process; it's a pale liquid, strong oxidizer, decomposes to H₂O + ½O₂ (catalysed by MnO₂), used as bleach and disinfectant.
Non-metals like BF₃, AlCl₃ (metalloid/metal-like) are Lewis acids (electron-pair acceptors). Non-metal lone-pair donors (NH₃, H₂O) act as Lewis bases forming adducts with such acids.

Non Metal.front: Acid–base behavior of non-metal oxides & hydrides
Non Metal.back: Non-metal oxides usually form acids (CO₂ → H₂CO₃, SO₂ → H₂SO₃), while non-metal hydrides (HF, HCl) give acidic aqueous solutions. Amphoteric behaviour rare for pure non-metals but some oxides show duality.

Non Metal.front: Common laboratory preparations for certain non-metal gases
Non Metal.back: Cl₂: MnO₂ + HCl → MnCl₂ + Cl₂ + H₂O (lab). NO₂: heating nitrates or oxidizing NO. CO₂: CaCO₃ + 2HCl → CaCl₂ + CO₂ + H₂O. NH₃: heating NH₄Cl + Ca(OH)₂ (lab source).

Non Metal.front: Tests to distinguish oxygen, nitrogen & hydrogen gases in lab
Non Metal.back: O₂ supports glowing splint → relights; H₂ ignites with pop with a flame; N₂ is generally inert (no relight or pop).

Non Metal.front: Redox & acid–base examples important for exams (quick recall)
Non Metal.back: Ostwald (NH₃ → HNO₃), Haber (N₂ → NH₃), Contact (SO₂ → SO₃ → H₂SO₄), Chlor-alkali (2Cl⁻ → Cl₂ + 2e⁻, producing NaOH & H₂), Haber & Ostwald used for fertilizers & explosives.

Non Metal.front: Industrial uses of chlorine & chlorinated compounds
Non Metal.back: Water disinfection (Cl₂/ClO₂), PVC production (polymer), organic chlorination for solvents & intermediates, NaOCl (bleach). Environmental concerns: formation of organochlorines/dioxins.

Non Metal.front: Interconversion & storage concerns for non-metal hydrides (e.g., H₂ storage)
Non Metal.back: Hydrogen storage options: compressed gas, cryogenic liquid, metal hydrides (absorption). Safety concerns: flammability, embrittlement of metals, leak detection.

Non Metal.front: Important exam tip: how to approach non-metal MCQs quickly
Non Metal.back: Identify the element/allotrope and property category (physical, chemical, industrial). Recall signature facts (e.g., N₂ triple bond → inert; Cl₂ via brine electrolysis; H₂O unusual boiling due to H-bonding; P₄ white reactive; SO₂→acid rain). Use process names (Haber, Ostwald, Contact).

Common Fact.front: What is a mole (definition)?
Common Fact.back: One mole is the amount of substance containing Avogadro's number of entities: N_A = 6.02214076×10²³ particles (exact by SI definition).

Common Fact.front: Avogadro constant (value & unit).
Common Fact.back: N_A = 6.02214076×10²³ mol⁻¹. Used to convert between moles and number of particles.

Common Fact.front: Universal gas constant R (common values).
Common Fact.back: R = 8.314462618 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ (= 0.083145 L·bar·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹) and R = 0.082057 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ (use with atm & L).

Common Fact.front: Faraday constant (value & meaning).
Common Fact.back: F = 96485 C·mol⁻¹ (≈ 9.6485×10⁴ C per mole of electrons). Charge of one mole of electrons.

Common Fact.front: Elementary charge and electron mass (approx).
Common Fact.back: e = 1.602176634×10⁻¹⁹ C; mass_e ≈ 9.109×10⁻³¹ kg. Proton mass ≈ 1.673×10⁻²⁷ kg.

Common Fact.front: Atomic mass unit (amu/u) definition & value.
Common Fact.back: 1 u = 1 unified atomic mass unit = 1/12 mass of ¹²C = 1.66053906660×10⁻²⁷ kg.

Common Fact.front: Density formula & units.
Common Fact.back: Density ρ = mass/volume. Common units: g·cm⁻³, kg·m⁻³, g·mL⁻¹ (1 g·cm⁻³ = 1000 kg·m⁻³).

Common Fact.front: Convert between °C and K.
Common Fact.back: T(K) = T(°C) + 273.15. Use Kelvin for thermodynamic formulas.

Common Fact.front: Significant figures — quick rule for multiplication/division & addition/subtraction.
Common Fact.back: Multiplication/division: result has same sig figs as factor with least sig figs. Addition/subtraction: result has same decimal places as quantity with least decimal places.

Common Fact.front: Molarity vs Molality — definitions & when to use which.
Common Fact.back: Molarity (M) = moles solute / litres solution (temperature-dependent). Molality (m) = moles solute / kg solvent (temperature-independent). Use molality for colligative properties.

Common Fact.front: Mole fraction xᵢ — definition & use.
Common Fact.back: xᵢ = nᵢ/Σ n_j. Dimensionless; used in Raoult's law and thermodynamic mixing calculations.

Common Fact.front: ppm and ppb — meaning in aqueous dilute solutions.
Common Fact.back: ppm ≈ mg·L⁻¹ for dilute aqueous solutions (1 ppm ≈ 1 mg per kg or L). ppb ≈ µg·L⁻¹.

Common Fact.front: Ideal gas law — formula & units caution.
Common Fact.back: PV = nRT. Use P in Pa or atm consistent with chosen R; V in m³ or L; T in K.

Common Fact.front: Molar volume of ideal gas at STP (273.15 K, 1 atm).
Common Fact.back: V_m = 22.414 L·mol⁻¹ (often approximated as 22.4 L·mol⁻¹).

Common Fact.front: Boyle, Charles and Avogadro laws — short statements.
Common Fact.back: Boyle: P ∝ 1/V (T,n const). Charles: V ∝ T (P,n const). Avogadro: V ∝ n (P,T const).

Common Fact.front: Density–molar mass relation for gases (ideal).
Common Fact.back: ρ = PM / (RT) where M is molar mass (kg·mol⁻¹) and P in Pa (unit consistency required).

Common Fact.front: Root mean square speed (u_rms) formula.
Common Fact.back: u_rms = √(3RT / M) with R = 8.314 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ and M in kg·mol⁻¹.

Common Fact.front: Graham’s law of effusion (rate relation).
Common Fact.back: rate_A / rate_B = √(M_B / M_A). Lighter gas effuses/diffuses faster.

Common Fact.front: Common laboratory gases and a diagnostic test (O₂, H₂, CO₂).
Common Fact.back: O₂: relights a glowing splint. H₂: 'pop' test with a burning splint (ignites). CO₂: extinguishes flame; turns limewater (Ca(OH)₂) milky (CaCO₃).

Common Fact.front: pH definition and relation to [H⁺].
Common Fact.back: pH = −log₁₀[H⁺]. At 25 °C, pH + pOH = 14 because K_w = [H⁺][OH⁻] = 1.0×10⁻¹⁴.

Common Fact.front: K_w value & temperature dependence.
Common Fact.back: At 25 °C, K_w = 1.0×10⁻¹⁴. K_w increases with temperature (neutral pH shifts with T).

Common Fact.front: pKa and acid strength (interpretation).
Common Fact.back: pK_a = −log₁₀K_a. Smaller pK_a → stronger acid. Useful in Henderson–Hasselbalch calculations for buffers.

Common Fact.front: Henderson–Hasselbalch equation (buffer pH).
Common Fact.back: pH = pK_a + log₁₀([A⁻]/[HA]). Good for approximate buffer calculations when concentrations are not extremely low.

Common Fact.front: Common strong acids list.
Common Fact.back: Strong acids: HCl, HBr, HI, HNO₃, HClO₄, and H₂SO₄ (first dissociation very strong).

Common Fact.front: Common strong bases list.
Common Fact.back: Strong bases: Group 1 hydroxides (NaOH, KOH), Ba(OH)₂ (soluble Group 2 hydroxide).

Common Fact.front: Solubility rules — important quick rules (salient points).
Common Fact.back: Nitrates NO₃⁻ and acetates C₂H₃O₂⁻ are soluble. Alkali metal salts and NH₄⁺ salts soluble. Chlorides, bromides, iodides soluble except with Ag⁺, Pb²⁺, Hg₂²⁺. Sulfates mostly soluble (except BaSO₄, PbSO₄, CaSO₄ partly). Carbonates, phosphates generally insoluble except alkali/NH₄⁺ salts.

Common Fact.front: Solubility product K_sp — definition & example for AgCl.
Common Fact.back: K_sp = [cation]^a [anion]^b at saturation. For AgCl(s) ⇌ Ag⁺ + Cl⁻, K_sp = [Ag⁺][Cl⁻]. Use to compute solubility and precipitation conditions.

Common Fact.front: Common lab oxidising agents.
Common Fact.back: KMnO₄ (acidic), K₂Cr₂O₇ (acidic), H₂O₂, NaOCl, concentrated HNO₃, O₃. Strong oxidisers often give oxygen transfer or two-electron oxidations.

Common Fact.front: Common lab reducing agents.
Common Fact.back: NaBH₄ (mild), LiAlH₄ (strong), H₂/Pd (catalytic hydrogenation), Sn/HCl, Fe/HCl (for nitro → amine).

Common Fact.front: Typical colour of KMnO₄ & K₂Cr₂O₇ solutions.
Common Fact.back: KMnO₄: purple/violet. K₂Cr₂O₇: orange (Cr₂O₇²⁻ orange, Cr³⁺ green on reduction).

Common Fact.front: Common laboratory precipitates: AgCl, BaSO₄, PbSO₄ colours.
Common Fact.back: AgCl: white (darkens in light). BaSO₄: white (insoluble). PbSO₄: white (insoluble).

Common Fact.front: Tollen’s & Fehling’s tests — what they detect.
Common Fact.back: Tollen’s reagent (Ag(NH₃)₂⁺): aldehydes → silver mirror. Fehling’s (Cu²⁺ complex): aldehydes reduce Cu²⁺ → red Cu₂O precipitate; ketones usually negative.

Common Fact.front: Flame test colours — quick memorable list.
Common Fact.back: Li⁺ = crimson, Na⁺ = intense yellow, K⁺ = lilac (with Na contamination gives pink), Ca²⁺ = brick-red, Ba²⁺ = green, Cu²⁺ = blue/green.

Common Fact.front: Oxidation number rules — key rules to remember.
Common Fact.back: Elemental form = 0. For monatomic ion = its charge. O usually −2 (except peroxides −1). H usually +1 (−1 in metal hydrides). Sum of oxidation numbers in neutral compound = 0; in polyatomic ion = ion charge.

Common Fact.front: Naming ionic compounds quick rules (IUPAC basics).
Common Fact.back: Cation name (metal) first, then anion. For simple anions: add −ide (e.g., chloride). For oxyanions: −ate (higher O) and −ite (lower O). Indicate transition metal oxidation state in Roman numerals (e.g., FeCl₂ = iron(II) chloride).

Common Fact.front: Common functional groups — recognition & one-liner reactivity.
Common Fact.back: Alcohol −OH (nucleophilic/acidic H), Carbonyl C=O (electrophilic C), Carboxylic acid −COOH (acidic), Amine −NH₂ (basic), Ester −COOR (hydrolyzable), Amide −CONH₂ (less reactive due to resonance).

Common Fact.front: Aromaticity quick test (Hückel rule).
Common Fact.back: Planar, cyclic, conjugated systems with (4n + 2) π electrons (n = 0,1,2...) are aromatic (e.g., benzene with 6 π e⁻).

Common Fact.front: Isomerism overview (brief).
Common Fact.back: Structural isomers have different connectivity. Stereoisomers have same connectivity but different spatial arrangement: geometric (cis/trans or E/Z) and optical (enantiomers).

Common Fact.front: SN1 vs SN2 — quick distinguishing features.
Common Fact.back: SN2: one-step bimolecular, backside attack, inversion of configuration, favoured by primary substrates? No — favoured by primary & methyl (tertiary hindered). SN1: two-step via carbocation, racemisation, favoured by tertiary substrates and polar protic solvents.

Common Fact.front: E1 vs E2 elimination quick points.
Common Fact.back: E2: single-step, strong base, anti-periplanar requirement. E1: two-step via carbocation, weak base enough, often competes with SN1.

Common Fact.front: Markovnikov’s rule (alkene addition).
Common Fact.back: In addition of HX to asymmetrical alkene, H adds to carbon already bearing more H's; X to the more substituted carbon (follows carbocation stability) — unless peroxide effect for HBr.

Common Fact.front: Common catalysts & their general use (short list).
Common Fact.back: Pd/C, Pt, Ni — hydrogenation; Fe, V₂O₅ — oxidation (industrial); AlCl₃ — Friedel–Crafts; H₂SO₄/H₃PO₄ — acid catalysts for dehydration/esterification; enzymes — biocatalysts.

Common Fact.front: Catalyst vs reagent — primary difference.
Common Fact.back: Catalyst increases reaction rate without being consumed (regenerated). Reagent participates stoichiometrically and is consumed.

Common Fact.front: Common organic oxidizing agents and typical oxidations.
Common Fact.back: KMnO₄/K₂Cr₂O₇ oxidize primary alcohols to acids (strong) or to aldehydes with controlled conditions; secondary alcohols → ketones.

Common Fact.front: Common reducing agents and typical reductions.
Common Fact.back: NaBH₄ reduces aldehydes/ketones → alcohols. LiAlH₄ reduces aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, amides. H₂ with Pd reduces C=C and nitro → amine (catalytic hydrogenation).

Common Fact.front: Hess’s law — practical use.
Common Fact.back: Total ΔH for a reaction independent of path; use tabulated ΔH_f° or combine known reactions to compute unknown enthalpies.

Common Fact.front: ΔG°, ΔH°, ΔS° relation and spontaneity rule.
Common Fact.back: ΔG = ΔH − TΔS. At constant T,P: ΔG < 0 spontaneous; ΔG = 0 equilibrium; ΔG > 0 non-spontaneous. ΔG° relates to K by ΔG° = −RT ln K.

Common Fact.front: Equilibrium constant K relation to ΔG° at 298 K (quick numeric form).
Common Fact.back: ΔG° (kJ·mol⁻¹) ≈ −(8.314×10⁻³ kJ·K⁻¹·mol⁻¹)(298.15 K) ln K ≈ −0.002479 KJ·mol⁻¹·ln K (use calculator for exact).

Common Fact.front: Le Châtelier’s principle — one-line statement.
Common Fact.back: If a dynamic equilibrium is disturbed (by change in concentration, pressure, temperature), the system shifts to counteract the disturbance and restore equilibrium.

Common Fact.front: Simple solubility-temperature rule for solids & gases.
Common Fact.back: Solubility of most solids in liquid increases with temperature. Solubility of gases in liquids decreases with increasing temperature (and increases with pressure via Henry's law).

Common Fact.front: Henry’s law — formula & meaning.
Common Fact.back: C_gas = k_H · P_gas (concentration of dissolved gas proportional to its partial pressure). k_H depends on gas, solvent, and temperature.

Common Fact.front: Colligative properties — definition & examples.
Common Fact.back: Properties that depend on number of solute particles, not identity: vapor-pressure lowering, boiling point elevation, freezing point depression, osmotic pressure.

Common Fact.front: Van’t Hoff factor i — what it corrects for.
Common Fact.back: i accounts for particle number from solute (electrolyte dissociation). Ideal: NaCl → i = 2, CaCl₂ → i = 3; real i may be lower due to ion pairing.

Common Fact.front: Common lab glassware volume conversions (mL ↔ L).
Common Fact.back: 1000 mL = 1.000 L. Use mL for small volumes (pipettes, burettes), L for molarity calculations.

Common Fact.front: Titration basics — equivalence vs end point.
Common Fact.back: Equivalence point: stoichiometric completion of reaction. End point: indicator colour change—should be as close to equivalence as possible.

Common Fact.front: Common titration indicators & transition ranges.
Common Fact.back: Phenolphthalein ≈ 8.2–10.0 (acid–base titrations where equivalence basic). Methyl orange ≈ 3.1–4.4 (acidic end). Bromothymol blue ≈ 6.0–7.6.

Common Fact.front: Quick ionic strength concept.
Common Fact.back: Ionic strength I = ½ Σ c_i z_i²; affects activity coefficients and hence 'effective' concentrations in non-dilute solutions.

Common Fact.front: Common lab safety quick reminders.
Common Fact.back: Wear PPE (gloves, goggles, lab coat). Work in fume hood for volatile/toxic reagents. Know location of eyewash, fire extinguisher, spill kits. Dispose heavy-metal/toxic waste per rules.

Common Fact.front: pKa of acetic acid & ammonia typical exam values.
Common Fact.back: Acetic acid pK_a ≈ 4.76. Ammonia pK_b ≈ 4.75 (so pK_a of NH₄⁺ ≈ 9.25). Use approximate values when given or when typical numbers suffice.

Common Fact.front: Common laboratory drying agents (desiccants).
Common Fact.back: Anhydrous CaCl₂ (not for strong acids), P₂O₅ (very strong dehydrant), silica gel (general), molecular sieves (selective).

Common Fact.front: Common qualitative test: effervescence with NaHCO₃ indicates what?
Common Fact.back: Evolving CO₂ gas indicates presence of an acid that reacts with bicarbonate — typically carboxylic acid or inorganic acid like HCl. CO₂ turns limewater milky.

Common Fact.front: Common inorganic precipitate tests — sequence for halides using AgNO₃.
Common Fact.back: Add AgNO₃ to acidified sample: white precipitate → Cl⁻ (AgCl); cream/yellow → Br⁻ (AgBr); yellow/cream strongly → I⁻ (AgI). Solubility in NH₃ distinguishes them.

Common Fact.front: Why we acidify samples before AgNO₃ test.
Common Fact.back: To remove interfering anions (e.g., CO₃²⁻, OH⁻) that would precipitate with Ag⁺; acid converts CO₃²⁻/OH⁻ to CO₂/H₂O so they don’t interfere.

Common Fact.front: Common qualitative test: Na₂CO₃ vs NaHCO₃ behaviour on heating.
Common Fact.back: NaHCO₃ decomposes on heating → Na₂CO₃ + CO₂ + H₂O (effervescence). Na₂CO₃ is stable on gentle heating.

Common Fact.front: Simple mnemonic: oxidising agents often contain high oxidation-state oxyanions.
Common Fact.back: Examples: Permanganate (MnO₄⁻), dichromate (Cr₂O₇²⁻), nitrate (NO₃⁻), chlorate/perchlorate (ClO₃⁻/ClO₄⁻).

Common Fact.front: Common laboratory solvent polarity ranking (some common solvents).
Common Fact.back: Polar protic: H₂O > MeOH > EtOH. Polar aprotic: DMSO > DMF > acetone. Non-polar: hexane, benzene. Solvent choice affects reaction rates/mechanisms (e.g., SN2 faster in polar aprotic).

Common Fact.front: Boiling point elevation & freezing point depression formulas.
Common Fact.back: ΔT_b = K_b · m · i ; ΔT_f = K_f · m · i. K_b and K_f are solvent constants; m = molality; i = van't Hoff factor.

Common Fact.front: Osmotic pressure formula for dilute solutions.
Common Fact.back: π = i·M·R·T (M = molarity, R = gas constant, T = K). Used to determine molar mass of macromolecules.

Common Fact.front: Common empirical rules for predicting acidity in organic acids.
Common Fact.back: Electron-withdrawing groups (−NO₂, −Cl) near acidic proton increase acidity; resonance stabilization of conjugate base increases acidity; hybridization: sp-hybridized C–H (alkyne) more acidic than sp² (alkene) > sp³ (alkane).

Common Fact.front: Common base strength trend for oxides/hydroxides down group.
Common Fact.back: Basicity generally increases down alkali/alkaline-earth groups (e.g., LiOH < NaOH < KOH) for hydroxides (solubility also matters).

Common Fact.front: Electron configuration notation quick tip (aufbau).
Common Fact.back: Fill orbitals in order of increasing energy: 1s → 2s → 2p → 3s → 3p → 4s → 3d → 4p etc. Use noble gas shorthand [Ne]3s²3p⁵ for convenience.

Common Fact.front: Common periodic trends: atomic radius, ionization energy, electronegativity.
Common Fact.back: Atomic radius decreases across a period and increases down a group. First ionization energy increases across a period, decreases down a group. Electronegativity (Pauling) similar trend to ionization energy.

Common Fact.front: Common cations & their typical charges (quick list).
Common Fact.back: Alkali: +1 (Na⁺, K⁺). Alkaline-earth: +2 (Mg²⁺, Ca²⁺). Transition metals: variable (Fe²⁺/Fe³⁺, Cu⁺/Cu²⁺). Ammonium NH₄⁺ is common polyatomic cation.

Common Fact.front: Common anions & typical formulas: nitrate, sulfate, carbonate, phosphate, acetate.
Common Fact.back: Nitrate NO₃⁻, Sulfate SO₄²⁻, Carbonate CO₃²⁻, Phosphate PO₄³⁻, Acetate C₂H₃O₂⁻ (or CH₃COO⁻).

Common Fact.front: Common reaction types to memorise for exams.
Common Fact.back: Acid–base neutralisation, precipitation, redox, substitution (nucleophilic/electrophilic), addition, elimination, condensation (esterification), hydrolysis, polymerisation, combustion.

Common Fact.front: Quick stoichiometry strategy (4 steps).
Common Fact.back: 1) Convert given quantities to moles. 2) Use balanced equation to find mole ratios. 3) Convert to desired units (g, L at STP, etc.). 4) Check limiting reagent and units.

Common Fact.front: How to handle percent yield and theoretical yield quickly.
Common Fact.back: Theoretical yield: calculated from limiting reagent. Percent yield = (actual yield / theoretical yield) × 100%.

Common Fact.front: Electronegativity scale example — most electronegative element.
Common Fact.back: Fluorine is most electronegative (Pauling ≈ 3.98). High electronegativity differences → ionic character; similar electronegativities → covalent.

Common Fact.front: Practical exam tip: units & dimensional analysis.
Common Fact.back: Always check units stepwise. Convert mass ↔ moles using molar mass, volume (L) ↔ moles for gases use PV = nRT, be careful with prefixes (milli, micro, kilo).

Common Fact.front: Common mnemonic for reactivity series top to bottom (K to Au).
Common Fact.back: Potassium (K), Sodium (Na), Calcium (Ca), Magnesium (Mg), Aluminium (Al), (Carbon), Zinc (Zn), Iron (Fe), Tin (Sn), Lead (Pb), (Hydrogen), Copper (Cu), Silver (Ag), Gold (Au). Metals above H reduce acids releasing H₂.

Common Fact.front: Quick conversions: 1 atm in Pa & 1 bar in Pa.
Common Fact.back: 1 atm = 101325 Pa. 1 bar = 100000 Pa. Use consistent pressure units with R.

Common Fact.front: Common exam pitfalls (three quick points).
Common Fact.back: 1) Unit inconsistency (L vs m³, g vs kg). 2) Confusing molarity vs molality. 3) Forgetting to account for stoichiometric coefficients or ionisation/van't Hoff factor in colligative problems.

Common Fact.front: One-line strategy to tackle 'common facts' MCQs.
Common Fact.back: Identify property category (thermo, stoichiometry, acid–base, redox, periodic trend), recall the signature rule or constant, convert units consistently, and check reasonableness of numerical answers.

Man Made Substances.front: What is a polymer (simple definition)?
Man Made Substances.back: A polymer is a large molecule (macromolecule) made by repeating structural units (monomers) joined by covalent bonds (e.g., polyethylene, polystyrene).

Man Made Substances.front: Difference between addition (chain-growth) and condensation (step-growth) polymerisation.
Man Made Substances.back: Addition: monomers with double bonds add together without by-product (e.g., polyethylene). Condensation: monomers with two functional groups react with elimination of small molecule (H₂O, HCl) forming polymer (e.g., nylon, polyester).

Man Made Substances.front: Thermoplastic vs thermosetting polymers — key difference.
Man Made Substances.back: Thermoplastics soften on heating and can be remoulded (e.g., PE, PVC, PET). Thermosets form cross-linked networks and do not soften on heating (e.g., Bakelite, epoxy).

Man Made Substances.front: Define monomer, repeat unit and degree of polymerisation (n).
Man Made Substances.back: Monomer: small molecule that polymerises. Repeat unit: structural unit that repeats in polymer chain. Degree of polymerisation (n) = number of repeat units per polymer molecule.

Man Made Substances.front: Polyethylene (PE) types & uses.
Man Made Substances.back: LDPE (low-density) — branched, flexible, films. HDPE (high-density) — linear, stronger, bottles/pipes. Uses: packaging, containers, pipes, toys.

Man Made Substances.front: Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) properties & uses.
Man Made Substances.back: PVC: versatile polymer, rigid (pipes) or plasticized (flexible vinyl). Resistant to chemicals, used in pipes, window frames, cables, flooring. Beware of additives (plasticizers) and recycling issues.

Man Made Substances.front: Polystyrene (PS) — types & applications.
Man Made Substances.back: Rigid PS: disposable cups, CD cases. Expanded polystyrene (EPS, Styrofoam): insulation, packaging. Brittle as pure polymer; can be foamed for low density.

Man Made Substances.front: Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) — common uses & recycling code.
Man Made Substances.back: PET: polyester used in beverage bottles and textiles (polyester fibre). Recycling code #1. Recyclable to fibres, new bottles, or polyester applications.

Man Made Substances.front: Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE/Teflon) — special properties.
Man Made Substances.back: PTFE is chemically inert, has very low friction and high thermal stability. Uses: non-stick coatings, gaskets, chemical-resistant linings.

Man Made Substances.front: Bakelite — what type of polymer and significance.
Man Made Substances.back: Bakelite (phenol–formaldehyde) is a thermosetting resin — rigid, heat-resistant — one of the first commercial plastics used for electrical insulators and handles.

Man Made Substances.front: Nylon (polyamides) — formation & uses.
Man Made Substances.back: Nylon (e.g., Nylon-6,6) is a condensation polymer made from diamine + dicarboxylic acid (or from caprolactam). Used in fibres, ropes, tyre cords and engineering plastics.

Man Made Substances.front: Polyester (PET/PBT) — formation & common uses.
Man Made Substances.back: Condensation polymer of diacid (terephthalic) and glycol (ethylene glycol) → polyester. Uses: textile fibres, bottles, films and engineering plastics.

Man Made Substances.front: Natural vs synthetic polymers — examples.
Man Made Substances.back: Natural: cellulose, rubber, proteins, DNA. Synthetic: polyethylene, nylon, polystyrene, PVC.

Man Made Substances.front: What is vulcanisation of rubber?
Man Made Substances.back: Vulcanisation: cross-linking natural rubber with sulfur (or peroxides) to form S–S bridges increasing elasticity, strength and heat resistance (Tyres are vulcanised rubber).

Man Made Substances.front: Natural rubber vs synthetic rubber (examples & differences).
Man Made Substances.back: Natural rubber (polyisoprene) is elastic but degrades with O₂/heat; synthetic rubbers (SBR, neoprene, nitrile) tailored for oil resistance, heat, or chemical stability.

Man Made Substances.front: Elastomers — what are they?
Man Made Substances.back: Elastomers are polymers with rubber-like elasticity (large reversible deformation). Examples: natural rubber, silicone rubbers, polyurethane elastomers.

Man Made Substances.front: Textile fibres: natural (cotton, wool, silk) vs synthetic (nylon, polyester, acrylic).
Man Made Substances.back: Cotton (cellulose) — breathable, hydrophilic. Wool (protein) — warm, absorbs moisture. Silk — protein fibre. Synthetic fibres: nylon (strength), polyester (wrinkle resistance), acrylic (wool substitute).

Man Made Substances.front: Rayon (viscose) — what is it and how produced (brief)?
Man Made Substances.back: Rayon is a regenerated cellulose fibre made by dissolving cellulose (wood pulp) and re-precipitating it as fibres (viscose process). It's semi-synthetic with properties between natural & synthetic fibres.

Man Made Substances.front: Carbon fibre & fiberglass — what are composites?
Man Made Substances.back: Composites combine fibres (carbon, glass) embedded in a polymer matrix to produce materials with high strength-to-weight ratio used in aerospace, sports equipment, and automotive parts.

Man Made Substances.front: Definition of composite material & examples.
Man Made Substances.back: Composite = two or more distinct materials combined to obtain superior properties (e.g., concrete = cement + aggregates; CFRP = carbon fiber reinforced polymer).

Man Made Substances.front: Concrete — composition & basic principle.
Man Made Substances.back: Concrete = cement + sand + coarse aggregate + water. Cement hydrates to bind aggregates forming a hard composite; strength depends on water–cement ratio and curing.

Man Made Substances.front: Portland cement — main components & hydration products (simple).
Man Made Substances.back: Clinker contains CaO, SiO₂, Al₂O₃, Fe₂O₃. Hydration forms calcium silicate hydrate (C–S–H, strength-giving) and Ca(OH)₂. Setting & hardening occur by these hydration reactions.

Man Made Substances.front: Difference between cement and concrete.
Man Made Substances.back: Cement is the binder (powder) that reacts with water; concrete is a mixture of cement, aggregates and water forming a structural material after curing.

Man Made Substances.front: Glass — basic composition & types.
Man Made Substances.back: Common soda–lime glass: SiO₂ + Na₂O + CaO. Borosilicate (Pyrex) contains B₂O₃ for thermal shock resistance. Glass is amorphous (non-crystalline) and transparent.

Man Made Substances.front: Tempered glass vs annealed glass — differences.
Man Made Substances.back: Tempered glass is heat-treated to create surface compressive stresses → higher strength and shatters into small blunt pieces. Annealed glass breaks into sharp shards; used where controlled breakage not required.

Man Made Substances.front: Ceramics — defining features & examples.
Man Made Substances.back: Ceramics are inorganic, non-metallic solids (oxides, carbides, nitrides) formed by heating and cooling — e.g., porcelain, bricks, tiles, refractory materials.

Man Made Substances.front: Refractories — role in industry.
Man Made Substances.back: Refractories (e.g., Al₂O₃, MgO, SiC) withstand very high temperatures and chemical attack; used to line furnaces, kilns and reactors in metallurgical processes.

Man Made Substances.front: Glass-ceramics & technical ceramics — advanced uses.
Man Made Substances.back: Advanced ceramics (piezoelectric, superconducting, bioceramics) used in electronics, medical implants, insulators, and high-temperature structural components.

Man Made Substances.front: Alloys — why they are made and common examples.
Man Made Substances.back: Alloys combine metals (and sometimes non-metals) to improve properties (strength, corrosion resistance). Examples: steel (Fe–C), brass (Cu–Zn), bronze (Cu–Sn), duralumin (Al–Cu).

Man Made Substances.front: Steel categories — carbon steel vs alloy steel vs stainless steel.
Man Made Substances.back: Carbon steel: mainly Fe–C with varying C content. Alloy steels: additional elements (Cr, Mo, V) for special properties. Stainless steel: contains Cr (≥≈11%) to form passive Cr₂O₃ layer resisting corrosion.

Man Made Substances.front: Solder — composition & modern trends.
Man Made Substances.back: Traditional solders were Sn–Pb alloys; now Pb-free solders (Sn–Ag–Cu, SAC) are used in electronics due to toxicity restrictions.

Man Made Substances.front: Cemented carbides (e.g., tungsten carbide) — use & properties.
Man Made Substances.back: Hard composites of WC particles bonded with Co (called cemented carbides) used for cutting tools and wear-resistant parts due to extreme hardness and toughness.

Man Made Substances.front: Paints & coatings — main components.
Man Made Substances.back: Pigment (colour/opacity), binder/vehicle (film former, e.g., acrylic, alkyd), solvent (controls viscosity), and additives (antifungal, UV stabiliser).

Man Made Substances.front: Function of pigments vs binders in paints.
Man Made Substances.back: Pigments provide colour and hiding power; binders hold pigment particles together and adhere to surface forming protective film.

Man Made Substances.front: Varnish vs paint — main difference.
Man Made Substances.back: Varnish is a transparent protective coating (no pigment) used to protect and enhance appearance of wood; paint contains pigments providing colour plus protection.

Man Made Substances.front: What are synthetic detergents and how differ from soaps?
Man Made Substances.back: Detergents are synthetic surfactants (e.g., linear alkylbenzene sulfonates) that function in hard water and a wider pH range. Soaps are salts of fatty acids (RCOO⁻Na⁺) that form scum with Ca²⁺/Mg²⁺ (hard water).

Man Made Substances.front: Soaps — saponification reaction (concept only).
Man Made Substances.back: Saponification: triglyceride + NaOH → glycerol + sodium fatty acid salts (soap). It's a base-catalysed hydrolysis of esters.

Man Made Substances.front: Micelle formation — how soap cleans dirt.
Man Made Substances.back: Soap molecules form micelles in water: hydrophobic tails trap oil/dirt in core while hydrophilic heads face water, allowing oily dirt to be emulsified and washed away.

Man Made Substances.front: Difference between biodegradable and non-biodegradable polymers.
Man Made Substances.back: Biodegradable polymers (e.g., polylactic acid PLA, some polyesters) can be broken down by microorganisms; many traditional plastics (PE, PS) are persistent and cause environmental accumulation.

Man Made Substances.front: Bioplastics — examples & context.
Man Made Substances.back: Bioplastics include bio-based (from renewable resources, e.g., bio-PET) and biodegradable plastics (PLA, PHA). They aim to reduce fossil feedstock use or improve end-of-life disposal.

Man Made Substances.front: Recycling codes for common plastics (1–7) — quick mapping.
Man Made Substances.back: 1: PET; 2: HDPE; 3: PVC; 4: LDPE; 5: PP; 6: PS; 7: Other (including polycarbonate, bioplastics). Codes indicate sorting & recycling streams.

Man Made Substances.front: Why PVC disposal is problematic.
Man Made Substances.back: PVC contains chlorine and often plasticizers (phthalates); incineration can form dioxins; recycling complicated by additives and mixed streams.

Man Made Substances.front: Polymers in medicine — examples (brief).
Man Made Substances.back: Polymers used in sutures (polyglycolic acid PGA), implants (PEEK), drug-delivery (PLGA), contact lenses (hydrogels), and disposable medical devices (various plastics).

Man Made Substances.front: Adhesives & glues — basic types.
Man Made Substances.back: Types: physical (hot-melt), chemical (epoxy, cyanacrylate), polymer-based (PVA, polyurethane). Choice depends on substrate, strength and curing conditions.

Man Made Substances.front: Explosives — classification & safe facts (high-level).
Man Made Substances.back: Explosives are high-energy compounds classified as low or high explosives (deflagration vs detonation). Common historically known explosives: gunpowder (black powder), TNT, nitroglycerin. (Note: do not attempt synthesis — safety & legal concerns.)

Man Made Substances.front: Gunpowder (black powder) — components (conceptual).
Man Made Substances.back: Traditional composition: saltpetre (KNO₃) oxidiser, charcoal (fuel), and sulphur; burns rapidly producing hot gases and solids (used historically in firearms & fireworks).

Man Made Substances.front: What are refractory cements & where used?
Man Made Substances.back: Refractory cements (alumina, silica-based) withstand very high temperatures; used to line furnaces, kilns and as repair materials in high-T environments.

Man Made Substances.front: What is rubberized fabric & common applications?
Man Made Substances.back: Fabric coated with rubber (or synthetic elastomer) to provide waterproofing and flexibility — used in raincoats, inflatable structures, and protective gloves.

Man Made Substances.front: What is vulcanised fibre (hardboard) and uses?
Man Made Substances.back: Paper fibre treated and compressed to produce hard, strong sheets used in electrical insulation, laminates and industrial components.

Man Made Substances.front: What are flame retardants and why used in man-made materials?
Man Made Substances.back: Additives (halogenated, phosphorus-based, inorganic hydrates) that reduce flammability or slow ignition/propagation. Used in textiles, electronics housings and construction materials to improve fire safety.

Man Made Substances.front: What is synthetic leather (PU leather) and advantages?
Man Made Substances.back: PU leather is polyurethane-coated fabric mimicking leather appearance at lower cost, improved water resistance and easier manufacture (used in upholstery, footwear).

Man Made Substances.front: What are ionic liquids (brief) and why interesting?
Man Made Substances.back: Ionic liquids are salts liquid near room temperature with low vapour pressure and tunable solvating properties—used as green solvents, electrolytes and catalytic media.

Man Made Substances.front: What are aerogels and key properties?
Man Made Substances.back: Aerogels are ultra-low-density porous solids (e.g., silica aerogel) — excellent thermal insulators, high surface area, used in insulation, catalyst supports and space applications.

Man Made Substances.front: What is photodegradation of polymers?
Man Made Substances.back: UV light breaks polymer chains via photochemical reactions → embrittlement, colour change and loss of mechanical properties; UV stabilisers added to mitigate effect.

Man Made Substances.front: Antifouling & anti-microbial coatings — purpose on man-made surfaces.
Man Made Substances.back: Coatings inhibit growth of biofilms, organisms or microbes on surfaces (ships, medical devices) using biocidal agents or low-adhesion surfaces to improve hygiene and performance.

Man Made Substances.front: What is glass fibre reinforced polymer (GFRP) & uses?
Man Made Substances.back: GFRP = glass fibre embedded in polymer matrix — strong, lightweight composite used in boat hulls, panels, pipes and sports equipment.

Man Made Substances.front: What is phenolic resin used for (e.g., Bakelite)?
Man Made Substances.back: Phenolic resins are thermosetting polymers used in electrical insulators, laminates, moulded parts and as adhesives due to heat resistance and mechanical strength.

Man Made Substances.front: What are photoresists and where used?
Man Made Substances.back: Light-sensitive polymers used in photolithography (semiconductor fabrication) to pattern micro-scale features on wafers.

Man Made Substances.front: What is conductive polymer (brief) and example?
Man Made Substances.back: Polymers with conjugated π-backbones that conduct electricity (e.g., polyaniline, polypyrrole) used in sensors, electrodes and antistatic coatings.

Man Made Substances.front: What is silica gel & common application?
Man Made Substances.back: Porous amorphous SiO₂ used as desiccant (moisture adsorbent) and chromatographic adsorbent (column chromatography).

Man Made Substances.front: What is PTFE coating advantage over other coatings?
Man Made Substances.back: PTFE offers extreme chemical resistance, non-stick performance and low friction; used for cookware coatings, seals and bearings in corrosive environments.

Man Made Substances.front: What are superabsorbent polymers (SAPs) and application?
Man Made Substances.back: Polymers (e.g., crosslinked polyacrylate) that absorb & retain large volumes of water relative to mass — used in diapers, wound dressings and agriculture.

Man Made Substances.front: What is glass transition temperature (T_g) for polymers?
Man Made Substances.back: T_g is the temperature where amorphous polymers change from glassy (rigid) to rubbery (flexible) state; important for service temperature of plastics.

Man Made Substances.front: What is melting temperature (T_m) vs T_g?
Man Made Substances.back: T_m is temperature where crystalline domains of polymer melt. Semi-crystalline polymers have both T_g (amorphous regions) and T_m (crystalline regions).

Man Made Substances.front: What is creep in polymers & composites?
Man Made Substances.back: Creep: slow, time-dependent deformation under constant stress, important in long-term load-bearing applications (pipes, structural plastics).

Man Made Substances.front: What is delamination in composites and why to avoid?
Man Made Substances.back: Delamination: separation of composite layers due to poor adhesion or impact → loss of mechanical integrity; critical failure mode in laminated composites.

Man Made Substances.front: Why additives (stabilisers, plasticizers, antioxidants) are used in plastics?
Man Made Substances.back: Additives modify processing and long-term properties: plasticizers increase flexibility, stabilisers prevent degradation (UV, thermal), antioxidants slow oxidation, flame retardants reduce flammability.

Man Made Substances.front: What are microplastics & environmental concern?
Man Made Substances.back: Microplastics are small plastic fragments (<5 mm) from breakdown or microbeads; they persist in environment, bioaccumulate in food chains and pose ecological/health risks.

Man Made Substances.front: What is incineration of plastics & main drawback?
Man Made Substances.back: Incineration converts waste to heat and ash; drawbacks include emission of toxic gases (if chlorinated plastics form dioxins), CO₂ emissions and need for emission controls.

Man Made Substances.front: What is life-cycle assessment (LCA) for man-made materials?
Man Made Substances.back: LCA evaluates environmental impacts of a product from raw materials, manufacture, use, and disposal — used to inform sustainable materials choices.

Man Made Substances.front: What is solvent casting (brief) for polymer films?
Man Made Substances.back: Polymer dissolved in volatile solvent is cast and solvent evaporated to form film — used in coatings and lab membrane preparation (ensure safe solvent handling).

Man Made Substances.front: What are elastomeric foams and uses?
Man Made Substances.back: Foamed elastomers (e.g., PU foam, neoprene foam) provide cushioning, insulation, and sealing in mattresses, insulation panels and gaskets.

Man Made Substances.front: What is ionomer (e.g., Surlyn) and where used?
Man Made Substances.back: Ionomers are polymers with a small fraction of ionic cross-links (e.g., ethylene acrylic acid neutralised by metal ions) — used in packaging, golf ball covers and impact-resistant items.

Man Made Substances.front: What is polycarbonate (PC) — key traits & uses?
Man Made Substances.back: PC is transparent, tough, and heat-resistant engineering thermoplastic used in eyewear lenses, safety shields, CDs and electronic housings (caution: susceptible to scratching & chemical attack).

Man Made Substances.front: What is UV stabiliser/additive role in outdoor plastics?
Man Made Substances.back: UV stabilisers absorb or quench UV radiation reducing chain scission and photodegradation to extend outdoor lifespan of polymers.

Man Made Substances.front: What is crosslinking (chemical) and its effect on polymers?
Man Made Substances.back: Crosslinking forms covalent bonds between polymer chains increasing rigidity, higher T_g, solvent resistance and turning thermoplastics into thermosets when extensive.

Man Made Substances.front: Practical exam tip: how to quickly identify polymer family from name.
Man Made Substances.back: Many polymer names indicate monomer or functional group: 'polyethylene' (from ethene), 'polyvinyl chloride' (from vinyl chloride), 'polyester' (contains ester linkages), 'polyamide' (amide linkages like nylon).

Man Made Substances.front: Common pitfalls students make on man-made substances MCQs (three points).
Man Made Substances.back: 1) Confusing thermoplastic vs thermoset behaviour. 2) Mixing up condensation vs addition polymerisation (watch for small molecule by-product). 3) Ignoring environmental/disposal impacts (PVC & chlorinated plastics).

Man Made Substances.front: One-line approach to solve man-made substances MCQs quickly.
Man Made Substances.back: Identify polymer/fibre type → recall monomer & polymerisation type → note thermoplastic/thermoset and key properties → consider application & environmental facts.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is Biology?
Introduction to Biology.back: Biology is the scientific study of life and living organisms — their structure, function, growth, origin, evolution and distribution.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are the main goals of biology?
Introduction to Biology.back: To describe life, understand mechanisms (how organisms work), explain diversity and evolution, and apply knowledge (medicine, agriculture, conservation).

Introduction to Biology.front: List major branches of biology (concise).
Introduction to Biology.back: Botany, Zoology, Microbiology, Genetics, Ecology, Physiology, Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, Evolutionary Biology, Cell Biology, Biotechnology, Immunology.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is the scientific method (basic steps)?
Introduction to Biology.back: Observation → Question → Hypothesis → Prediction → Experiment / Data collection → Analysis → Conclusion → Replication/Peer review.

Introduction to Biology.front: Define hypothesis, theory and law (in scientific context).
Introduction to Biology.back: Hypothesis: testable statement. Theory: well-supported explanation of natural phenomena. Law: concise statement describing consistent natural relationships (often mathematical).

Introduction to Biology.front: What are controlled experiments and why are controls important?
Introduction to Biology.back: Controlled experiments compare experimental and control groups where only one variable (independent variable) changes; controls isolate the effect of that variable.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are variables in an experiment?
Introduction to Biology.back: Independent variable: manipulated. Dependent variable: measured response. Controlled variables: kept constant to avoid confounding effects.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is an example of measurement units commonly used in biology?
Introduction to Biology.back: Metric system units: meter (m) for length, gram (g) for mass, liter (L) for volume. Subunits: millimeter (mm), micrometer (µm), nanometer (nm).

Introduction to Biology.front: What is microscopy and its basic types?
Introduction to Biology.back: Microscopy is using microscopes to view small objects. Types: light (compound) microscopy, stereo (dissecting) microscopy, electron microscopy (TEM/SEM), fluorescence microscopy.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is resolution vs magnification?
Introduction to Biology.back: Magnification enlarges an image. Resolution (resolving power) is the ability to distinguish two close points as separate — a more important measure of microscope quality.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is cell theory (three core points)?
Introduction to Biology.back: 1) All living organisms are composed of cells. 2) The cell is the basic unit of structure and function in organisms. 3) All cells arise from pre-existing cells.

Introduction to Biology.front: Compare prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells (key differences).
Introduction to Biology.back: Prokaryotes: no membrane-bound organelles, no nucleus, smaller (bacteria/archaea). Eukaryotes: nucleus, membrane-bound organelles (mitochondria, ER), larger (plants, animals, fungi, protists).

Introduction to Biology.front: Name major organelles and one key function each.
Introduction to Biology.back: Nucleus: stores genetic material; Mitochondria: ATP production; Endoplasmic reticulum: protein/lipid synthesis; Golgi apparatus: modifies & packages proteins; Lysosome: digestion; Chloroplast (plants): photosynthesis.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is the plasma membrane structure and its basic role?
Introduction to Biology.back: Phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins (fluid mosaic model); controls transport of substances, cell signaling, and maintains homeostasis.

Introduction to Biology.front: Define osmosis and diffusion (concise).
Introduction to Biology.back: Diffusion: passive movement of molecules from high to low concentration. Osmosis: diffusion of water across a semipermeable membrane from low solute to high solute concentration.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is active transport and an example?
Introduction to Biology.back: Movement of substances against their concentration gradient requiring energy (ATP). Example: Na⁺/K⁺ pump that maintains membrane potential.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is metabolism (broad definition)?
Introduction to Biology.back: All chemical reactions in organisms, including catabolism (breakdown for energy) and anabolism (biosynthesis of molecules).

Introduction to Biology.front: Define enzymes and their role in metabolism.
Introduction to Biology.back: Enzymes are biological catalysts (usually proteins) that speed up chemical reactions by lowering activation energy; they are substrate-specific and regulated.

Introduction to Biology.front: What factors affect enzyme activity?
Introduction to Biology.back: Temperature, pH, substrate concentration, enzyme concentration, presence of inhibitors or activators, and cofactors/coenzymes.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are macromolecules/biomolecules? Name main types.
Introduction to Biology.back: Large biological molecules essential for life: carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, nucleic acids (DNA/RNA).

Introduction to Biology.front: What are carbohydrates — function and examples?
Introduction to Biology.back: Energy source and structural components; monosaccharides (glucose), disaccharides (sucrose), polysaccharides (starch, glycogen, cellulose).

Introduction to Biology.front: What are lipids and their key roles?
Introduction to Biology.back: Hydrophobic molecules: fats/triglycerides (energy storage), phospholipids (membranes), steroids (hormones), and insulation/ protection.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are proteins — basic building blocks and functions?
Introduction to Biology.back: Polymers of amino acids; functions include enzymes, structural proteins (collagen), transporters (hemoglobin), signaling (hormones), immune proteins (antibodies).

Introduction to Biology.front: What are nucleic acids and their roles?
Introduction to Biology.back: DNA stores genetic information; RNA transfers genetic code for protein synthesis and has catalytic/regulatory roles (mRNA, tRNA, rRNA, miRNA).

Introduction to Biology.front: What is DNA structure (basic)?
Introduction to Biology.back: Double helix of two antiparallel polynucleotide strands with sugar-phosphate backbone and complementary nitrogenous bases (A-T, G-C) held by hydrogen bonds.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is the central dogma of molecular biology?
Introduction to Biology.back: DNA → (transcription) → RNA → (translation) → Protein — describes flow of genetic information.

Introduction to Biology.front: Briefly define transcription and translation.
Introduction to Biology.back: Transcription: synthesis of RNA from DNA template. Translation: synthesis of polypeptide using mRNA codons read by ribosomes and tRNA anticodons.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is a gene and an allele?
Introduction to Biology.back: Gene: unit of heredity — DNA sequence coding for a protein or RNA. Allele: alternative form of a gene at the same locus.

Introduction to Biology.front: Define genotype and phenotype.
Introduction to Biology.back: Genotype: genetic makeup (alleles) of an organism. Phenotype: observable traits resulting from genotype and environment.

Introduction to Biology.front: Mendel's laws — state the two classic laws.
Introduction to Biology.back: Law of Segregation: allele pairs separate during gamete formation. Law of Independent Assortment: alleles of different genes assort independently (when on different chromosomes).

Introduction to Biology.front: What is dominant vs recessive inheritance?
Introduction to Biology.back: Dominant allele expresses phenotype when present in one or two copies; recessive expresses phenotype only when both alleles are recessive (homozygous).

Introduction to Biology.front: What is a Punnett square used for?
Introduction to Biology.back: Diagram to predict genotype and phenotype ratios from a genetic cross between parents.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is mutation (brief) and its significance?
Introduction to Biology.back: Change in DNA sequence; source of genetic variation — can be neutral, deleterious (disease-causing) or occasionally beneficial (adaptive).

Introduction to Biology.front: Define natural selection in one sentence.
Introduction to Biology.back: Process where organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring, leading to evolutionary change.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is speciation (basic concept)?
Introduction to Biology.back: Formation of new species from an ancestral population, often due to reproductive isolation and genetic divergence.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are ecosystems and key components?
Introduction to Biology.back: Communities of organisms interacting with each other and with the physical environment; components include producers, consumers, decomposers, abiotic factors and energy flow.

Introduction to Biology.front: Explain food chain and food web (concise).
Introduction to Biology.back: Food chain: linear transfer of energy through trophic levels (producer → consumer → predator). Food web: interconnected food chains showing complex feeding relationships.

Introduction to Biology.front: Define producers, consumers, and decomposers.
Introduction to Biology.back: Producers (autotrophs) make organic matter (photosynthesis). Consumers (heterotrophs) eat producers/other consumers. Decomposers (bacteria/fungi) break down dead matter recycling nutrients.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is ecological niche vs habitat?
Introduction to Biology.back: Habitat: physical place an organism lives. Niche: organism's role in ecosystem — including its use of resources and interactions with others.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is biodiversity and why is it important?
Introduction to Biology.back: Variety of life at genetic, species and ecosystem levels; important for ecosystem resilience, services (pollination, nutrient cycling) and human well-being.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are major threats to biodiversity?
Introduction to Biology.back: Habitat destruction, invasive species, overexploitation, pollution, climate change and disease.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is conservation biology (short)?
Introduction to Biology.back: Science aimed at protecting biodiversity, restoring ecosystems, and managing species to prevent extinction.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is ecology's carrying capacity?
Introduction to Biology.back: Maximum population size of a species that an environment can sustain indefinitely given resources and environmental constraints.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is population growth — exponential vs logistic (basic).
Introduction to Biology.back: Exponential: rapid growth when resources are unlimited (J-shaped). Logistic: growth slows and levels off at carrying capacity (S-shaped) due to limiting factors.

Introduction to Biology.front: Describe basic human impacts on the environment (one line each).
Introduction to Biology.back: Deforestation reduces habitat & carbon sink; pollution contaminates air/water/soil; overfishing depletes stocks; greenhouse gas emissions drive climate change; urbanization fragments ecosystems.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is biotechnology (concise)?
Introduction to Biology.back: Use of biological systems or organisms to develop products or technologies (e.g., genetic engineering, fermentation, biopharmaceuticals).

Introduction to Biology.front: Give a basic example of genetic engineering application.
Introduction to Biology.back: Production of insulin by recombinant bacteria (E. coli) for diabetes treatment — gene inserted to express human insulin protein.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) in one line?
Introduction to Biology.back: Laboratory technique that amplifies specific DNA sequences exponentially to generate many copies for detection or analysis.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is vaccination (simple definition)?
Introduction to Biology.back: Introduction of antigenic material to stimulate adaptive immunity and memory, preventing future disease upon exposure to the pathogen.

Introduction to Biology.front: What are antibiotics and basic caution regarding them?
Introduction to Biology.back: Drugs that kill or inhibit bacteria; they have no effect on viruses. Overuse/misuse leads to antibiotic resistance.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is aseptic technique and its purpose?
Introduction to Biology.back: Practices that prevent contamination by pathogens in lab/clinical settings (sterile tools, flame sterilization, proper hand hygiene) to ensure accurate results and safety.

Introduction to Biology.front: What is epidemiology (brief recap)?
