Pollution.front: Health effects of prolonged exposure to high noise levels
Pollution.back: Hearing impairment, tinnitus, sleep disturbance, cardiovascular stress, reduced productivity and cognitive impairment in children.

Pollution.front: What is sound level measured in and general rules of exposure?
Pollution.back: Decibel (dB, a logarithmic unit). Higher dB indicates louder sound; prolonged exposure to high dB increases risk of hearing damage (risk increases non-linearly with SPL and duration).

Pollution.front: What is thermal pollution and typical sources?
Pollution.back: Discharge of heated water (power plants, industrial cooling) into water bodies raising temperature and lowering dissolved oxygen, affecting aquatic life.

Pollution.front: What is light pollution and its impacts?
Pollution.back: Excessive or misdirected artificial lighting disrupting ecosystems, human circadian rhythms, astronomical observations and behavior of nocturnal species.

Pollution.front: What are persistent organic pollutants (POPs)?
Pollution.back: Toxic organic chemicals resistant to degradation, bioaccumulative and long-range transportable (e.g., DDT, PCBs, dioxins); subject to international controls (Stockholm Convention).

Pollution.front: What international convention deals with persistent organic pollutants?
Pollution.back: Stockholm Convention — global treaty to eliminate or restrict production/use of POPs.

Pollution.front: What is the concept of 'safe disposal' for radioactive waste?
Pollution.back: Containment, isolation and monitoring of radioactive materials (low, intermediate, high level) using engineered barriers and geologic repositories to protect people and environment over long timescales.

Pollution.front: What is environmental impact assessment (EIA)?
Pollution.back: Systematic process to evaluate potential environmental consequences of proposed projects and propose mitigation measures before approval and implementation.

Pollution.front: Key stages of EIA process
Pollution.back: Screening, scoping, baseline studies, impact prediction, mitigation measures, public consultations, environmental management plan (EMP), monitoring and compliance.

Pollution.front: What is environmental monitoring and why important?
Pollution.back: Regular measurement of environmental parameters (air/water quality, noise, biodiversity) to assess compliance, detect changes and guide management actions.

Pollution.front: What is ambient air monitoring vs stack monitoring?
Pollution.back: Ambient monitoring measures pollutant concentrations in outdoor air where people breathe; stack monitoring measures emissions directly from industrial chimneys or outlets.

Pollution.front: Common water quality parameters tested in labs
Pollution.back: pH, turbidity, electrical conductivity, DO, BOD, COD, total suspended solids (TSS), nutrients (N, P), heavy metals and microbial indicators (E. coli, coliforms).

Pollution.front: What is best management practice (BMP) in pollution control?
Pollution.back: Site-specific or sectoral measures (agricultural, urban, industrial) aimed at reducing pollutants at source and during transport (e.g., buffer strips, retention ponds, good housekeeping).

Pollution.front: What is 'zero liquid discharge' (ZLD) approach in industry?
Pollution.back: Treatment strategy to recover and reuse wastewater so that no liquid waste is discharged to environment, often using evaporation and crystallization stages.

Pollution.front: What is ambient water quality classification (purpose)?
Pollution.back: Grouping water bodies by intended uses (drinking, bathing, fisheries, irrigation) to set management priorities and appropriate quality standards.

Pollution.front: What are environmental standards and who sets them?
Pollution.back: Legal limits or guidelines for pollutant concentrations/ emissions set by national agencies (e.g., CPCB, EPA) or international bodies (WHO) to protect health and environment.

Pollution.front: What is the role of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) in India?
Pollution.back: National statutory organization for prevention and control of pollution, setting standards, monitoring, advising government and coordinating State Pollution Control Boards.

Pollution.front: What are State Pollution Control Boards (SPCBs)?
Pollution.back: State-level statutory bodies implementing pollution control laws, granting permits, monitoring compliance and enforcing regulations within their jurisdictions.

Pollution.front: Important Indian environmental laws (short list)
Pollution.back: Water (Prevention & Control of Pollution) Act, 1974; Air (Prevention & Control of Pollution) Act, 1981; Environment (Protection) Act, 1986; Wildlife Protection Act, 1972; Forest Conservation Act, 1980; Hazardous Waste Rules.

Pollution.front: What is National Green Tribunal (NGT) in India?
Pollution.back: Specialized judicial body established for expeditious environmental protection and conservation of forests and natural resources, and for enforcement of legal rights related to environment.

Pollution.front: What is environmental auditing?
Pollution.back: Systematic evaluation of an organization's environmental performance, compliance with laws and policies, and identification of improvement opportunities.

Pollution.front: What is the concept of sustainable development (Brundtland definition)?
Pollution.back: Development that meets present needs without compromising future generations' ability to meet their needs — integrates environmental protection, social equity and economic growth.

Pollution.front: What is circular economy and how does it relate to pollution reduction?
Pollution.back: Economic model that minimizes resource input and waste by reusing, recycling and recovering materials to reduce pollution and conserve resources.

Pollution.front: What are clean technologies (cleantech)?
Pollution.back: Technologies that reduce environmental impacts (renewable energy, efficient processes, pollution control technologies, green chemistry) supporting sustainable industrial development.

Pollution.front: What is source segregation of waste and why important?
Pollution.back: Separating waste at origin (organic, recyclables, hazardous) to improve recycling, treatment efficiency and reduce contamination and disposal needs.

Pollution.front: What are common household hazardous wastes?
Pollution.back: Batteries, paints, solvents, pesticides, electronics, pharmaceuticals — require special disposal to avoid environmental contamination.

Pollution.front: What is the concept of waste-to-energy (WtE)?
Pollution.back: Converting waste into usable energy (biogas, incineration-based power, landfill gas recovery) to reduce landfill volumes and recover resources.

Pollution.front: What is anaerobic digestion and its outputs?
Pollution.back: Microbial breakdown of organic matter in oxygen-free conditions producing biogas (methane + CO₂) and stabilized digestate used as fertilizer.

Pollution.front: What is urban air pollution control — common policy measures?
Pollution.back: Vehicle emission standards, fuel quality improvements, public transport promotion, industrial emission controls, odd-even schemes, awareness campaigns and urban planning for pollution reduction.

Pollution.front: What is environmental justice concept?
Pollution.back: Fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race or income in environmental laws and policies; addresses disproportionate pollution burdens on vulnerable communities.

Pollution.front: What are spill response best practices for oil spills?
Pollution.back: Containment (booms), recovery (skimmers), chemical dispersants (with caution), in-situ burning and bioremediation; prioritize protecting sensitive habitats and rapid containment to limit spread.

Pollution.front: How does agriculture contribute to pollution and mitigation practices?
Pollution.back: Contributes via nutrient runoff, pesticides, soil erosion and greenhouse gases. Mitigation: precision fertilizer application, integrated pest management, conservation tillage, buffer strips and cover crops.

Pollution.front: What is integrated pest management (IPM) and pollution relevance?
Pollution.back: Combines biological, cultural, mechanical and chemical methods to reduce reliance on pesticides, lowering environmental contamination and human exposure.

Pollution.front: What is river basin management approach?
Pollution.back: Integrated management of water resources across entire river catchment coordinating land use, water supply, pollution control and stakeholder participation for sustainable outcomes.

Pollution.front: What is the role of wetlands in pollution control?
Pollution.back: Natural filters: wetlands trap sediments, uptake nutrients, transform pollutants via microbial processes and support biodiversity; used in constructed wetlands for wastewater treatment.

Pollution.front: How are air pollution episodes (smog events) typically managed?
Pollution.back: Temporary measures: advisory alerts, restricting industrial operations, traffic controls, suspension of construction, promoting public transport and emergency health advisories.

Pollution.front: What is cross-media pollution and why challenging?
Pollution.back: Pollutants moving across media (air → water deposition, land application contaminating groundwater) complicate management as controls in one medium may shift impacts to another.

Pollution.front: What is environmental risk assessment (ERA)?
Pollution.back: Process to estimate probability and consequences of adverse effects from environmental hazards, used to prioritize risks and design management strategies.

Pollution.front: What is occupational exposure limit (OEL) concept (brief)?
Pollution.back: Maximum acceptable concentration of hazardous substance in workplace air for worker protection; set by regulatory or advisory bodies and differ from ambient standards.

Pollution.front: What is the role of environmental education and public awareness in pollution control?
Pollution.back: Informs citizens about causes/consequences of pollution, encourages behavior change (reduce, reuse, recycle), supports compliance and community-based monitoring.

Pollution.front: What is household hazardous wastewater and safe handling guidance?
Pollution.back: Greywater, chemicals, paints and pharmaceuticals should not be disposed into drains; use proper collection, recycling and municipal hazardous-waste facilities.

Pollution.front: What is the precaution for antibiotics and antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in environment?
Pollution.back: Antibiotics in wastewater and agricultural runoff select for resistant microbes; treating effluents, controlling discharge of pharmaceutical wastes and prudent antibiotic use reduce AMR spread.

Pollution.front: What are nature-based solutions for pollution mitigation?
Pollution.back: Approaches using ecosystems (green infrastructure, riparian buffers, urban green spaces, constructed wetlands) to deliver pollution control and co-benefits like cooling and biodiversity.

Pollution.front: What is monitoring for persistent contaminants (long-term approach)?
Pollution.back: Periodic surveillance for legacy pollutants (heavy metals, POPs) in soil, sediments, biota and water to assess accumulation and guide remediation and policy.

Pollution.front: Short exam tip: Name three indicators used to assess water quality
Pollution.back: Dissolved oxygen (DO), biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and fecal coliforms (E. coli) are common and informative indicators.

Pollution.front: Short exam tip: Common control methods for vehicular air pollution
Pollution.back: Improved fuel quality, catalytic converters, periodic vehicle emission testing, promoting public transport and electric vehicles.

Pollution.front: Short exam tip: Name three health effects of water pollution
Pollution.back: Waterborne diarrhea (pathogens), bioaccumulation of toxins (heavy metals) causing long-term effects, and algal-toxin related poisoning.

Pollution.front: Short exam tip: What are the two major contributors to eutrophication?
Pollution.back: Excess nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) inputs from agricultural runoff, sewage and detergents.

Pollution.front: Final quick checklist for pollution MCQs
Pollution.back: Know pollutant types and sources, major effects on health/ecosystems, basic monitoring parameters and units, common control technologies, relevant policies and sustainable mitigation strategies.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is Taxonomy?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Taxonomy is the science of naming, describing and classifying organisms into a hierarchical system (Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is Binomial Nomenclature? Give rules.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Binomial nomenclature gives each species two names: Genus name (capitalized) + specific epithet (lowercase), both italicized or underlined. Example: Homo sapiens. Authority and year may follow.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: List the major taxonomic ranks in descending order.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Domain (sometimes) → Kingdom → Phylum → Class → Order → Family → Genus → Species. (Mnemonic: Dear King Philip Came Over For Good Soup)

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What are the general characteristics of Kingdom Animalia?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Multicellular, eukaryotic, heterotrophic, lack cell walls, usually mobile at some life stage, embryonic development includes blastula formation.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Define level of organization in animals (cellular, tissue, organ, organ-system).
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Cellular (Porifera) — cells perform functions individually; Tissue (Cnidaria) — cell layers form tissues; Organ (Platyhelminthes) — organs present; Organ-system (Annelida onwards) — coordinated systems exist.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is symmetry? Name types found in animals.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Symmetry refers to body plan arrangement. Types: Asymmetry (Sponges), Radial symmetry (Cnidaria, Echinodermata adults often pentaradial), Bilateral symmetry (most animals).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What are germ layers? Name diploblastic and triploblastic phyla.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Germ layers are embryonic layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm. Diploblastic (2 layers): Cnidaria. Triploblastic (3 layers): Platyhelminthes and above.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Define acoelomate, pseudocoelomate and coelomate with examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Acoelomate: no body cavity (Platyhelminthes). Pseudocoelomate: body cavity not fully lined by mesoderm (Nematoda). Coelomate: true coelom lined by mesoderm (Annelida, Mollusca, Arthropoda, Echinodermata, Chordata).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is metamerism (segmentation)? Which phyla show it?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Metamerism = serial repetition of body segments (metameres). Prominent in Annelida and Arthropoda; seen in Chordata (vertebrate segmentation).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Protostome vs Deuterostome — key embryo differences.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Protostome: blastopore develops into mouth; spiral determinate cleavage (e.g., Mollusca, Annelida, Arthropoda). Deuterostome: blastopore → anus; radial indeterminate cleavage (e.g., Echinodermata, Chordata).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is mode of coelom formation (schizocoely vs enterocoely)?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Schizocoely (protostomes): mesoderm splits to form coelom. Enterocoely (deuterostomes): coelom forms from outpocketing of the embryonic gut.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What are homologous and analogous organs? Example of each.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Homologous: same origin, different function (e.g., forelimb of human and wing of bat). Analogous: different origin, similar function (e.g., wings of insect and bird).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is exoskeleton vs endoskeleton? Give examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Exoskeleton: external skeleton (Arthropoda — chitin). Endoskeleton: internal skeleton (Echinodermata — ossicles; Vertebrata — bones/cartilage).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Porifera — key features and examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Sponges. Cellular level of organization, asymmetrical, pores (ostia), choanocytes (collar cells), spicules (CaCO3 or SiO2), body plans: ascon/sycon/leucon. Example: Sycon, Spongilla, Grantia.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Porifera reproduction and special adaptation (gemmule).
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Asexual (budding, gemmules in freshwater sponges) and sexual (mostly hermaphrodite). Gemmules are resistant structures for harsh conditions.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Cnidaria (Coelenterata) — defining traits and classes.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Diploblastic, radial symmetry, gastrovascular cavity, cnidocytes with nematocysts, two body forms (polyp, medusa). Classes: Hydrozoa (Hydra), Scyphozoa (true jellyfish), Anthozoa (corals, sea anemones), Cubozoa (box jellies).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Cnidaria — example question: Hydra is which class? (Exam trap)
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Hydra belongs to Class Hydrozoa (freshwater polyp) — shows polyp form only, reproduces asexually by budding.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Ctenophora — what’s unique?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Comb jellies: eight ciliary comb rows for locomotion; no nematocysts (they may have colloblasts sticky cells).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Platyhelminthes — features and classes.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Flatworms: bilateral, triploblastic, acoelomate, dorsoventrally flattened, organ-level organization. Classes: Turbellaria (free-living; e.g., Planaria), Trematoda (flukes; e.g., Fasciola), Cestoda (tapeworms; e.g., Taenia).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Platyhelminthes — human parasite examples to remember for exams.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Trematoda: Fasciola hepatica (liver fluke), Schistosoma spp. (blood flukes). Cestoda: Taenia solium (pork tapeworm), Taenia saginata (beef).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Nematoda — defining characters and example parasites.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Roundworms: bilaterally symmetrical, triploblastic, pseudocoelomate, complete digestive tract (mouth and anus). Examples: Ascaris lumbricoides, Ancylostoma (hookworm), Wuchereria bancrofti (filarial worm).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is eutely and which phylum shows it?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Eutely = fixed number of cells in adult organism; characteristic of some Nematodes (e.g., Caenorhabditis elegans shows fixed cell count).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Annelida — features and major classes.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Segmented worms (metamerism), true coelom, closed circulatory system, setae present (except leeches). Classes: Polychaeta (marine worms), Oligochaeta (earthworms), Hirudinea (leeches).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Annelida — features of earthworm (Oligochaeta) important for exam.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Hermaphrodite, closed circulation with dorsal & ventral vessels, segmented, nephridia for excretion, typhlosole in intestine increases absorption.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Arthropoda — universal characters.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Bilateral, segmented (tagmatization), jointed appendages, exoskeleton of chitin, growth by ecdysis (molting), open circulatory system, well-developed sensory organs.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Major subphyla of Arthropoda and exam examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Chelicerata (spiders, scorpions — no antennae), Myriapoda (centipedes, millipedes), Crustacea (crabs, lobsters, have 2 pairs antennae), Hexapoda (insects — 3 pairs legs), Trilobita (extinct).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Difference between insects (Hexapoda) and crustaceans (Crustacea).
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Insects: 3 body regions (head, thorax, abdomen), 3 pairs legs, 1 pair antennae. Crustaceans: variable segments, typically more than 3 pairs of legs, 2 pairs antennae, mostly aquatic.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Types of metamorphosis in insects — define holometabolous and hemimetabolous.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Holometabolous (complete metamorphosis): egg → larva → pupa → adult (butterfly). Hemimetabolous (incomplete): egg → nymph → adult (grasshopper).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Mollusca — key body plan and major classes.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Soft-bodied, usually with mantle, muscular foot, visceral mass; many have a radula (except bivalves). Classes: Gastropoda (snails), Bivalvia (clams), Cephalopoda (squid, octopus), Polyplacophora (chitons).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is radula and which phylum has it?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Radula is a rasping tongue-like organ with chitinous teeth used for feeding in Mollusca (present in Gastropods and Cephalopods; absent in Bivalves).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Echinodermata — features and significance.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Marine, pentaradial symmetry in adults (bilateral larvae), endoskeleton of calcareous ossicles, water-vascular system with tube feet, deuterostome (e.g., Starfish, Sea urchin).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Explain the water-vascular system and madreporite (Echinodermata).
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Water-vascular system is a hydraulic system for locomotion/feeding; madreporite is the sieve-like plate that admits seawater into the system; tube feet operate via ampullae.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Hemichordata — key points to remember.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Acorn worms and pterobranchs; have pharyngeal gill slits and a stomochord (not a true notochord); deuterostome affinities; important in evolutionary studies.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Phylum Chordata — four hallmark features.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: 1) Notochord, 2) Dorsal hollow nerve cord, 3) Pharyngeal gill slits, 4) Post-anal tail — present at some stage in all chordates.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Subphyla of Chordata and brief examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Urochordata (Tunicates — e.g., Sea squirts), Cephalochordata (Lancelets — e.g., Amphioxus), Vertebrata/Craniata (fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What are agnathans? Give examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Agnathans are jawless fishes (primitive vertebrates). Examples: Lampreys (Petromyzon), Hagfishes (Myxine).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Classes of vertebrates (basic list) and a key trait each.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Pisces (fishes — gills; aquatic), Amphibia (amphibians — metamorphosis, moist skin), Reptilia (reptiles — scaly skin, amniote egg), Aves (birds — feathers, endothermy), Mammalia (mammals — hair, mammary glands).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Classification of fishes: major groups.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Agnatha (jawless), Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fishes — sharks, rays), Osteichthyes (bony fishes — Ray-finned & Lobe-finned fishes).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Important amphibian features and exam examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Double life (aquatic larva with gills, terrestrial adult with lungs), moist skin for respiration, ectothermic. Examples: Frogs (Rana), Salamanders (Ambystoma).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Reptilia — special features (amniotic egg) and examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Amniotic egg with membranes (amnion, chorion, allantois), scaly skin preventing water loss, usually oviparous. Examples: Crocodiles, Snakes, Lizards, Turtles.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Birds (Aves) — characteristics to remember for exams.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Feathers, forelimbs modified into wings, beak without teeth, hollow bones, endothermy (high metabolic rate), respiratory system with air sacs.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Mammalia — unique characters and subclasses.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Mammary glands, hair, three middle ear bones, muscular diaphragm. Subclasses/orders include Monotremes (egg-laying), Marsupials (pouched), Placental mammals (Eutheria).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is the significance of Amphioxus (Branchiostoma) in classification?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Amphioxus (Cephalochordata) retains all four chordate features in adult; used as a basal model for vertebrate evolution and comparative anatomy.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What are vestigial organs? Give examples in animals.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Vestigial organs are reduced structures with little/no function compared to ancestors. Examples: pelvic bones in whales, reduced hind limbs in some snakes.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What evidence is used in modern classification (beyond morphology)?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Embryology, comparative anatomy, cytology, biochemistry (proteins, enzymes), and molecular phylogeny (DNA/RNA sequences) — modern systematics uses molecular data heavily.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is adaptive radiation? Give an animal example.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Adaptive radiation = rapid diversification of a lineage into many species adapted to different niches. Example: Darwin's finches (birds) — though birds, concept applies to many animal groups.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Which phyla show segmentation? (List and short note)
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Annelida (true segmentation), Arthropoda (tagmatized segments), Chordata (vertebral segmentation) — segmentation aids locomotion and specialization.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Explain trophic levels & feeding types in animals (saprophytic, parasitic, holozoic).
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Holozoic: ingestive nutrition (most animals). Parasitic: live on/in host (many Nematodes, Platyhelminthes). Saprophytic: decomposers (fungi/bacteria; animals rarely).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Important exam fact: Which phylum is largest in number of described species?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Arthropoda is the largest phylum (vast diversity of insects being the major contributor).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is tagmatization in arthropods?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Tagmatization = fusion of adjacent segments into functional units (head, thorax, abdomen) specialized for tasks like feeding, locomotion, reproduction.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Give exam-friendly differences: Coelenterata (Cnidaria) vs Porifera.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Porifera: cellular organization, no true tissues, filter feeders (choanocytes). Cnidaria: tissue level, diploblastic, radial symmetry, cnidocytes (stinging cells).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Key identification traits: How to identify an insect?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Three-part body plan (head-thorax-abdomen), three pairs of legs (6 legs), usually two antennae, compound eyes; many have wings on thorax.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is metamorphosis? Why is it adaptive?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Metamorphosis = developmental transformation (larval to adult). Adaptive because larval and adult occupy different niches, reducing intraspecific competition.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Important exam list: Parasitic helminths and their phyla.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Platyhelminthes: Schistosoma (Trematoda), Taenia (Cestoda). Nematoda: Ascaris, Wuchereria, Ancylostoma. Know life cycles often asked in exams.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: How are animal phyla distinguished in classification? (concise exam points)
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: By body symmetry, germ layers, body cavity type, segmentation, presence/absence of specialized organs, type of coelom formation, embryonic development (protostome/deuterostome), and molecular data.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: How to quickly distinguish Annelida from Arthropoda in an exam diagram?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Annelids: soft-bodied, true segmentation with similar segments, setae present, no jointed appendages, closed circulatory system. Arthropods: jointed appendages, chitinous exoskeleton, open circulation.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is a choanocyte and where is it found?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Choanocyte (collar cell) lines internal chambers of sponges (Porifera) and generates water currents and traps food particles via flagellum and collar.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Exam tip: Difference between closed and open circulatory systems — examples.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Closed: blood confined to vessels (Annelida, Vertebrates). Open: blood (hemolymph) bathes organs in sinuses (Arthropods, Molluscs like many gastropods).

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What is a notochord and its role?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Notochord is a flexible rod-like supportive structure in chordates present at some life stage; in vertebrates it is replaced/partially replaced by vertebral column during development.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Give 5 quick mnemonic points to classify an unknown animal specimen.
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Check: 1) Symmetry (radial/ bilateral/ none); 2) Body cavity (acoelomate/pseudocoelom/ coelom); 3) Germ layers (2 or 3); 4) Segmentation; 5) Presence of notochord/vertebrae or exoskeleton.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: What are larval forms important to know? (Names & phyla)
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Trochophore — Annelida & some Mollusca; Veliger — many Molluscs (bivalves/gastropods); Planula — Cnidaria; Nauplius — Crustacea; Bipinnaria — Echinodermata.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Exam fact: Which phylum shows regeneration ability prominently?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Echinodermata (e.g., starfish regenerate arms), also some annelids and planarians (Platyhelminthes) show remarkable regeneration.

Classification of Animal Kingdom.front: Short answer: Why are molecular methods important in modern classification?
Classification of Animal Kingdom.back: Molecular methods (DNA/RNA/protein sequences) reveal evolutionary relationships not obvious from morphology, help resolve homoplasy and provide objective data for phylogenetics.

Animal Tissue.front: What is a tissue?
Animal Tissue.back: A tissue is a group of similar cells and their intercellular substances performing a common function. Tissues are the intermediate level between cells and organs.

Animal Tissue.front: Name the four basic types of animal tissues.
Animal Tissue.back: Epithelial tissue, Connective tissue, Muscular tissue, Nervous tissue.

Animal Tissue.front: What are the primary functions of epithelial tissue?
Animal Tissue.back: Protection, absorption, secretion, excretion, filtration, sensory reception and surface transport.

Animal Tissue.front: Describe characteristics common to all epithelia.
Animal Tissue.back: Closely packed cells with minimal intercellular substance, polarity (apical & basal surfaces), attached to basement membrane, avascular, high mitotic rate, form continuous sheets.

Animal Tissue.front: How are epithelia classified (two axes)?
Animal Tissue.back: By number of layers: simple, stratified, pseudostratified. By cell shape (apical layer): squamous, cuboidal, columnar. Combine for name (e.g., stratified squamous).

Animal Tissue.front: What is simple squamous epithelium? Where found and function?
Animal Tissue.back: Single layer of flat cells — allows rapid diffusion and filtration. Found in alveoli of lungs, lining of blood vessels (endothelium), Bowman's capsule.

Animal Tissue.front: What is simple cuboidal epithelium? Examples and role.
Animal Tissue.back: Single layer of cube-shaped cells — secretion and absorption. Found in kidney tubules, ducts of small glands, thyroid follicles.

Animal Tissue.front: What is simple columnar epithelium? Where and function.
Animal Tissue.back: Single layer of tall cells — absorption and secretion; may have microvilli or cilia. Found in intestinal lining (microvilli), uterine tube (ciliated).

Animal Tissue.front: What is stratified squamous epithelium? Types and examples.
Animal Tissue.back: Multiple layers with flattened surface cells. Keratinized type (skin epidermis) — protective, water-resistant. Non-keratinized (oral cavity, esophagus, vagina) — moist surfaces.

Animal Tissue.front: What is pseudostratified columnar epithelium? Example.
Animal Tissue.back: Single layer of cells with nuclei at different levels giving a stratified appearance; often ciliated and with goblet cells. Example: respiratory epithelium (trachea).

Animal Tissue.front: What is transitional epithelium? Where is it found?
Animal Tissue.back: Special stratified epithelium that stretches — surface cells are dome-shaped when relaxed. Found lining urinary bladder, ureters, part of urethra.

Animal Tissue.front: What is a basement membrane and its layers?
Animal Tissue.back: Basement membrane anchors epithelium to connective tissue. Composed of basal lamina (lamina lucida + lamina densa) produced by epithelium and reticular lamina (produced by connective tissue).

Animal Tissue.front: Name and define the major cell junctions in epithelia.
Animal Tissue.back: Tight junctions (zonula occludens) — seal adjacent cells, prevent paracellular flow. Adherens (zonula adherens) — connect actin cytoskeleton of adjacent cells. Desmosomes (macula adherens) — spot-welds connecting intermediate filaments. Hemidesmosomes — attach cell to basement membrane. Gap junctions — allow intercellular communication via connexons.

Animal Tissue.front: What are goblet cells and where are they found?
Animal Tissue.back: Unicellular mucous-secreting glands (goblet-shaped). Found in respiratory tract and intestinal epithelium — secrete mucus for lubrication/protection.

Animal Tissue.front: Types of multicellular glands (by shape and duct):
Animal Tissue.back: By duct branching: simple (unbranched duct) vs compound (branched duct). By secretory portion shape: tubular, alveolar (acinar), tubuloalveolar.

Animal Tissue.front: Modes of secretion: merocrine, apocrine, holocrine — define and example.
Animal Tissue.back: Merocrine: exocytosis without loss of cell (e.g., pancreatic acinar cells). Apocrine: apical portion pinched off with secretory product (some sweat glands). Holocrine: entire cell disintegrates to release product (sebaceous glands).

Animal Tissue.front: What is connective tissue? Basic components.
Animal Tissue.back: Connective tissue supports and connects other tissues; composed of cells (fixed & wandering) embedded in extracellular matrix (fibers + ground substance).

Animal Tissue.front: List major connective tissue cell types and a short function for each.
Animal Tissue.back: Fibroblast (synthesize fibers & ground substance), Macrophage (phagocytosis), Mast cell (histamine, allergic responses), Plasma cell (antibody production), Adipocyte (fat storage), Chondroblast/chondrocyte (cartilage cells), Osteoblast/osteocyte (bone formation/maintenance).

Animal Tissue.front: What are the three fiber types in connective tissue?
Animal Tissue.back: Collagen fibers (strength, many types — Type I most abundant), Elastic fibers (stretch & recoil), Reticular fibers (Type III collagen — form supportive networks in soft organs).

Animal Tissue.front: Differences between loose (areolar) and dense connective tissue.
Animal Tissue.back: Loose (areolar): loosely arranged fibers, abundant ground substance — supports & cushions; found under epithelium. Dense connective tissue: abundant collagen; regular (tendons, parallel fibers) vs irregular (dermis, multidirectional fibers).

Animal Tissue.front: What are adipose tissues? Types and key differences.
Animal Tissue.back: Adipose stores fat and provides insulation/ cushioning. White (unilocular) adipose — energy storage, endocrine functions. Brown (multilocular) adipose — thermogenesis in infants and hibernating mammals (many mitochondria).

Animal Tissue.front: What is cartilage? General features and why it heals slowly.
Animal Tissue.back: Cartilage is a firm, flexible connective tissue with chondrocytes in lacunae and extracellular matrix rich in collagen and proteoglycans. It is avascular (no blood vessels) so repair is slow and relies on diffusion.

Animal Tissue.front: Name three types of cartilage with distinguishing features and examples.
Animal Tissue.back: Hyaline cartilage: glassy matrix, most common (tracheal rings, articular surfaces). Elastic cartilage: elastic fibers — flexible (pinna of ear, epiglottis). Fibrocartilage: dense collagen bundles — very tough (intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis).

Animal Tissue.front: What are bone (osseous) tissue types? Key structural features.
Animal Tissue.back: Compact bone: dense, forms outer layer, organized into osteons (Haversian systems). Spongy (cancellous) bone: trabeculae with marrow spaces — lighter and houses red marrow. Bone is vascular and remodels continuously.

Animal Tissue.front: Cells of bone: osteoblast, osteocyte, osteoclast — roles.
Animal Tissue.back: Osteoblast: bone-forming cell (secretes osteoid). Osteocyte: mature bone cell in lacunae, maintains matrix. Osteoclast: large multinucleate cell that resorbs bone (derived from monocyte lineage).

Animal Tissue.front: What is hematopoietic tissue? Give primary site in adults.
Animal Tissue.back: Tissue that produces blood cells. In adults, red bone marrow (in vertebral bodies, ribs, pelvis, proximal femur/humerus) is the primary hematopoietic tissue.

Animal Tissue.front: Blood as a connective tissue — components and functions.
Animal Tissue.back: Blood = plasma (liquid matrix) + formed elements (RBCs, WBCs, platelets). Functions: transport (O2, CO2, nutrients, hormones), defense (immune cells), hemostasis (platelets/clotting), regulation (pH, temperature).

Animal Tissue.front: Red blood cells (RBC) — mammalian special features.
Animal Tissue.back: Biconcave, anucleate in mature mammals, rich in hemoglobin for O2 transport, lifespan ~120 days in humans (exam-level fact: RBCs lack nucleus in mammals).

Animal Tissue.front: White blood cells (WBC) — major types and brief function.
Animal Tissue.back: Granulocytes: Neutrophils (phagocytose bacteria), Eosinophils (parasites/allergies), Basophils (histamine, allergic responses). Agranulocytes: Lymphocytes (adaptive immunity — B & T cells), Monocytes (become macrophages).

Animal Tissue.front: Platelets (thrombocytes) — origin and role.
Animal Tissue.back: Fragments of megakaryocytes (bone marrow) in mammals; play central role in blood clotting and hemostasis.

Animal Tissue.front: What is muscle tissue? Types and general function.
Animal Tissue.back: Muscle tissue is specialized for contraction and force generation. Three types: Skeletal (striated, voluntary), Cardiac (striated, involuntary, heart), Smooth (non-striated, involuntary, walls of viscera & blood vessels).

Animal Tissue.front: Skeletal muscle — key histological & functional features.
Animal Tissue.back: Long, cylindrical multinucleated fibers with peripheral nuclei, striations (sarcomeres), voluntary control, attached to skeleton; motor unit = motor neuron + muscle fibers it innervates.

Animal Tissue.front: Structure of sarcomere — important elements to remember.
Animal Tissue.back: Sarcomere boundaries = Z-discs. A-band = thick filaments (myosin) ± overlap; I-band = thin filaments (actin) only; H-zone = myosin only; M-line in center. Sliding filament model: actin slides over myosin during contraction.

Animal Tissue.front: Cardiac muscle — distinguishing histological features.
Animal Tissue.back: Short branched fibers, single central nucleus (often), striated, interconnected by intercalated discs (contain desmosomes and gap junctions) allowing synchronous contraction; involuntary rhythmically active.

Animal Tissue.front: Smooth muscle — characteristics and where found.
Animal Tissue.back: Spindle-shaped cells, single central nucleus, no striations, involuntary control, found in walls of gut, blood vessels, urinary bladder, uterus; contraction via actin-myosin but arranged differently than skeletal muscle.

Animal Tissue.front: How is muscle contraction initiated at the neuromuscular junction?
Animal Tissue.back: Motor neuron releases acetylcholine (ACh) into synaptic cleft, ACh binds receptors on muscle endplate, triggers depolarization, action potential propagates, Ca2+ release from sarcoplasmic reticulum leads to cross-bridge cycling (actin-myosin).

Animal Tissue.front: What is nervous tissue? Major cell types.
Animal Tissue.back: Nervous tissue consists of neurons (excitable cells that transmit nerve impulses) and neuroglia (supporting cells — e.g., astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, microglia in CNS; Schwann cells, satellite cells in PNS).

Animal Tissue.front: Structure of a typical neuron and function of each part.
Animal Tissue.back: Dendrites (receive signals), Cell body (soma — contains nucleus), Axon (conducts impulses away), Axon terminals (synaptic transmission); myelin sheath speeds conduction.

Animal Tissue.front: Difference between Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes.
Animal Tissue.back: Schwann cells (PNS) myelinate single axon segments and support regeneration. Oligodendrocytes (CNS) myelinate multiple axons but CNS has limited regeneration capacity.

Animal Tissue.front: What is myelin and its functional significance?
Animal Tissue.back: Myelin is a lipid-rich insulating layer around axons produced by Schwann cells (PNS) or oligodendrocytes (CNS); increases conduction velocity via saltatory conduction at nodes of Ranvier.

Animal Tissue.front: Types of synapses and basic mechanism of synaptic transmission.
Animal Tissue.back: Chemical synapse (neurotransmitter release across synaptic cleft; e.g., ACh, norepinephrine) and electrical synapse (gap junctions). Chemical synapses involve vesicle release, receptor binding, postsynaptic response.

Animal Tissue.front: Compare regeneration capacity in tissues — examples.
Animal Tissue.back: High regenerative capacity: epithelial tissues (skin, gut epithelium), liver (partial regeneration). Moderate: bone. Poor/limited: cardiac muscle, neurons (CNS), cartilage (avascular).

Animal Tissue.front: What is fibrosis/repair vs regeneration?
Animal Tissue.back: Regeneration = restoration of original tissue by proliferation of cells. Repair by fibrosis = replacement of damaged tissue with scar (collagen) when original cells cannot regenerate (e.g., myocardial infarct).

Animal Tissue.front: Histological stains: purpose of H&E (Hematoxylin & Eosin).
Animal Tissue.back: Hematoxylin stains nuclei blue/purple (basophilic structures). Eosin stains cytoplasm and extracellular matrix pink (acidophilic structures). H&E is the routine histology stain.

Animal Tissue.front: Name commonly tested special histological features: goblet cell, microvilli, cilia, stereocilia.
Animal Tissue.back: Goblet cells — mucus secretion. Microvilli — increase surface area (brush border of intestine). Cilia — motile (respiratory epithelium). Stereocilia — long microvilli-like structures in inner ear & male reproductive tract.

Animal Tissue.front: What is epithelial polarity? Why is it important?
Animal Tissue.back: Polarity refers to distinct apical (facing lumen) and basal (attached to basement membrane) domains. Important for directional transport (absorption/secretion) and specialized functions.

Animal Tissue.front: Quick exam fact: Which tissues are avascular?
Animal Tissue.back: Epithelia and cartilage are avascular (receive nutrients by diffusion).

Animal Tissue.front: Important exam trap: Do ligaments have more elastin or collagen than tendons?
Animal Tissue.back: Ligaments contain more elastic fibers than tendons (so are slightly more elastic), while tendons are richer in type I collagen for tensile strength.

Animal Tissue.front: What is extrafusal vs intrafusal muscle fiber? (short note)
Animal Tissue.back: Extrafusal fibers are regular skeletal muscle fibers that generate force. Intrafusal fibers are modified fibers inside muscle spindles that function as stretch receptors (proprioception).

Animal Tissue.front: What are mast cells and their role in connective tissue?
Animal Tissue.back: Mast cells are resident immune cells that contain granules of histamine and heparin; play roles in allergic reactions and inflammation by releasing mediators on activation.

Animal Tissue.front: What is the ECM ground substance and its components?
Animal Tissue.back: Ground substance is the amorphous material in ECM composed of water, proteoglycans (glycosaminoglycans like hyaluronic acid), glycoproteins (fibronectin, laminin) — provides hydration and resistance to compression.

Animal Tissue.front: Name a short mnemonic to remember the four tissue types.
Animal Tissue.back: E-C-M-N: Epithelium, Connective, Muscle, Nervous — ("Every Cell Makes Noise").

Animal Tissue.front: Exam-style quick fact: Which cell type produces antibodies in connective tissue?
Animal Tissue.back: Plasma cells (differentiated B-lymphocytes) produce antibodies and are often found in connective tissue during immune responses.

Animal Tissue.front: Why is bone considered a dynamic tissue?
Animal Tissue.back: Bone is constantly remodeled by coordinated action of osteoblasts (formation) and osteoclasts (resorption), allowing repair, calcium homeostasis and adaptation to stress.

Animal Tissue.front: Short summary: How to approach a histology diagram question in exam?
Animal Tissue.back: 1) Note overall architecture (layers, lumen). 2) Identify cell shapes and arrangement (simple/stratified). 3) Look for special features (cilia, goblet cells, keratin). 4) Correlate with organ-specific function (absorption, secretion, protection).

Animal Tissue.front: Important identification tip: How to distinguish skeletal vs cardiac vs smooth under microscope?
Animal Tissue.back: Skeletal: long striated fibers, peripheral multiple nuclei. Cardiac: striated branched fibers, central nuclei, intercalated discs. Smooth: spindle-shaped, no striations, single central nucleus.

Animal Tissue.front: Quick recall: Which tissues commonly show inflammation first after injury?
Animal Tissue.back: Loose connective tissue near epithelium shows early inflammation due to abundant blood supply and immune cell presence; neutrophils arrive first during acute inflammation.

Animal Tissue.front: What is an osteon (Haversian system)?
Animal Tissue.back: Structural unit of compact bone: concentric lamellae of bone around a central Haversian canal (contains blood vessels & nerves), connected by Volkmann's canals.

Human Blood.front: What is blood?
Human Blood.back: Blood is a fluid connective tissue composed of plasma (liquid matrix) and formed elements (red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets) that transports gases, nutrients, wastes, hormones and provides defense and homeostasis.

Human Blood.front: What are the two main components of blood?
Human Blood.back: Plasma (55% by volume) — liquid containing proteins, electrolytes, nutrients, hormones; Formed elements (≈45% — hematocrit) — RBCs, WBCs, platelets.

Human Blood.front: Define hematocrit (PCV).
Human Blood.back: Hematocrit (packed cell volume, PCV) is the percentage of blood volume occupied by red blood cells. Normal adult values: males ~40–52%, females ~36–48% (approx exam-friendly ranges).

Human Blood.front: What is plasma vs serum?
Human Blood.back: Plasma is the liquid portion of anticoagulated blood containing clotting factors. Serum is plasma after clotting — it lacks fibrinogen and clotting proteins consumed in clot formation.

Human Blood.front: Name the major plasma proteins and their functions.
Human Blood.back: Albumin (maintains oncotic pressure, transports substances), Globulins (immune — antibodies; transport), Fibrinogen (clotting), Regulatory proteins (enzymes, hormones).

Human Blood.front: What is the normal pH of blood?
Human Blood.back: Normal arterial blood pH is about 7.35–7.45 (slightly alkaline).

Human Blood.front: What is the primary function of red blood cells (RBCs)?
Human Blood.back: RBCs transport oxygen from lungs to tissues and carbon dioxide (as bicarbonate and dissolved CO₂) from tissues to lungs — mediated by hemoglobin.

Human Blood.front: Describe RBC structure and special features in humans.
Human Blood.back: Biconcave disc, anucleate (mature mammalian RBCs), ~7–8 µm diameter, high surface area for gas exchange, flexible membrane to pass through capillaries, contains hemoglobin, lifespan ~120 days.

Human Blood.front: What is hemoglobin? Basic structure and role.
Human Blood.back: Hemoglobin is an iron-containing protein in RBCs composed of four globin chains (adult HbA = 2 α + 2 β) each with a heme group that binds O₂. It carries O₂ and part of CO₂ and buffers H⁺.

Human Blood.front: What is oxyhemoglobin and deoxyhemoglobin?
Human Blood.back: Oxyhemoglobin = hemoglobin bound to oxygen (in lungs). Deoxyhemoglobin = hemoglobin without oxygen (in tissues). Oxygen affinity is affected by pH, CO₂, temperature, 2,3-BPG (Bohr effect).

Human Blood.front: Explain the Bohr effect in one sentence.
Human Blood.back: Increased CO₂ and H⁺ (lower pH) reduce hemoglobin's affinity for O₂, promoting oxygen release to tissues; conversely, lower CO₂/higher pH increases O₂ affinity.

Human Blood.front: What is 2,3-BPG and its role?
Human Blood.back: 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) is produced in RBCs and binds hemoglobin reducing O₂ affinity, facilitating O₂ release to tissues; levels rise in hypoxia, anemia, high altitude.

Human Blood.front: Normal hemoglobin concentration (approx) for adults.
Human Blood.back: Approximate normal hemoglobin: Males ~13.5–17.5 g/dL, Females ~12.0–15.5 g/dL (exam-friendly ranges; slight variations by source).

Human Blood.front: What is erythropoiesis? Where does it occur and what regulates it?
Human Blood.back: Erythropoiesis is RBC formation from hematopoietic stem cells. In adults it mainly occurs in red bone marrow (vertebrae, pelvis, ribs). Erythropoietin (EPO), produced by kidneys in response to hypoxia, stimulates RBC production.

Human Blood.front: Name stages of RBC maturation briefly.
Human Blood.back: Proerythroblast → basophilic erythroblast → polychromatic erythroblast → orthochromatic erythroblast (normoblast) → reticulocyte → mature erythrocyte. Reticulocytes circulate briefly before maturing.

Human Blood.front: What is reticulocyte count and its clinical significance?
Human Blood.back: Reticulocyte count measures young RBCs in blood; elevated in hemolysis or after blood loss (active marrow response), low in aplastic anemia or iron deficiency (poor marrow response).

Human Blood.front: How are RBCs removed? Where does it happen?
Human Blood.back: Senescent or damaged RBCs are phagocytosed by macrophages mainly in spleen (splenic macrophages), liver (Kupffer cells) and bone marrow; hemoglobin components are recycled.

Human Blood.front: Outline heme breakdown and bilirubin forms.
Human Blood.back: Heme → biliverdin → unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin (lipid-soluble) transported to liver bound to albumin → conjugated (direct) bilirubin (water-soluble) after glucuronidation → excreted in bile; gut bacteria convert to urobilinogen.

Human Blood.front: What is jaundice and basic types?
Human Blood.back: Jaundice = yellow discoloration due to bilirubin accumulation. Types: Pre-hepatic (hemolytic) — unconjugated ↑; Hepatic (hepatic dysfunction) — mixed; Post-hepatic (obstructive) — conjugated ↑.

Human Blood.front: What are white blood cells (WBCs)? General functions.
Human Blood.back: WBCs (leukocytes) are cells of the immune system that defend against infections, remove debris, and participate in inflammation and adaptive immunity. Include granulocytes and agranulocytes.

Human Blood.front: List major types of WBCs and a one-line function for each.
Human Blood.back: Neutrophils — phagocytose bacteria (first responders); Eosinophils — combat parasites & modulate allergies; Basophils — release histamine/heparin in allergy; Monocytes → macrophages — phagocytosis, antigen presentation; Lymphocytes — B cells (antibody production), T cells (cell-mediated immunity), NK cells (cytotoxic innate).

Human Blood.front: What is a differential WBC count?
Human Blood.back: Percentage distribution of different WBC types in blood (neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils); helps diagnose infections, allergic reactions, leukemias.

Human Blood.front: Typical total WBC count (approx normal range).
Human Blood.back: Normal total WBC count ≈ 4–11 × 10^9 cells per liter (or 4,000–11,000 cells/µL).

Human Blood.front: Neutrophil characteristics and band cells significance.
Human Blood.back: Neutrophils are multilobed nucleus granulocytes that phagocytose bacteria; band cells (immature neutrophils) increase in severe infection — 'left shift' indicates active neutrophil response.

Human Blood.front: Eosinophil main roles and appearance.
Human Blood.back: Eosinophils contain red-orange granules, combat parasitic helminths and participate in allergic responses by modulating inflammation (increase in parasitic infections and allergies).

Human Blood.front: Basophil vs mast cell — quick distinction.
Human Blood.back: Both contain histamine/heparin; basophils circulate in blood (rare), mast cells are tissue-resident cells (skin, mucosa). Both play roles in allergy.

Human Blood.front: Lymphocyte types and primary roles.
Human Blood.back: B lymphocytes produce antibodies (humoral immunity). T lymphocytes include helper T (CD4) — coordinate immune response, cytotoxic T (CD8) — kill infected cells, regulatory T — control immune reactions. NK cells are innate cytotoxic cells.

Human Blood.front: Monocyte to macrophage transition and function.
Human Blood.back: Monocytes circulate and enter tissues where they differentiate into macrophages; macrophages perform phagocytosis, antigen presentation and secrete cytokines for inflammation and repair.

Human Blood.front: What are platelets and their origin?
Human Blood.back: Platelets (thrombocytes) are small anucleate cell fragments derived from megakaryocyte cytoplasm in bone marrow; they participate in primary hemostasis (platelet plug) and provide phospholipid surfaces for coagulation.

Human Blood.front: Normal platelet count (approx).
Human Blood.back: Normal platelet count ≈ 150–450 × 10^9/L (150,000–450,000/µL).

Human Blood.front: Three stages of hemostasis (brief).
Human Blood.back: 1) Vascular spasm (vasoconstriction), 2) Primary hemostasis — platelet adhesion, activation & aggregation forming a platelet plug, 3) Secondary hemostasis — coagulation cascade forms fibrin mesh strengthening the plug.

Human Blood.front: What is von Willebrand factor (vWF) role?
Human Blood.back: vWF mediates platelet adhesion to exposed subendothelium and carries/stabilizes factor VIII; deficiency causes von Willebrand disease with mucocutaneous bleeding.

Human Blood.front: Outline the coagulation cascade simply (intrinsic vs extrinsic).
Human Blood.back: Extrinsic pathway: tissue factor (III) + factor VII → activates factor X. Intrinsic pathway: factors XII → XI → IX (+VIII) → activate factor X. Common pathway: factor X (+V) converts prothrombin (II) to thrombin (IIa), which converts fibrinogen (I) to fibrin (Ia) forming clot.

Human Blood.front: Name vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.
Human Blood.back: Vitamin K–dependent factors: II (prothrombin), VII, IX, X and proteins C & S (anticoagulant proteins). Vitamin K deficiency or warfarin interferes with their γ-carboxylation and function.

Human Blood.front: What is fibrinolysis? Key enzyme and regulator.
Human Blood.back: Fibrinolysis is clot breakdown. Plasmin (from plasminogen, activated by tPA or uPA) digests fibrin into fibrin degradation products like D-dimer. Plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAI) regulates it.

Human Blood.front: What is D-dimer and clinical significance?
Human Blood.back: D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product produced when cross-linked fibrin is broken down — elevated in thrombosis (e.g., DVT/PE), DIC, postoperative state; used as a screening test for thromboembolism.

Human Blood.front: Common lab tests for coagulation: PT, INR, APTT — what do they assess?
Human Blood.back: PT (prothrombin time) assesses extrinsic (factor VII) and common pathways; INR standardizes PT for warfarin monitoring. APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) assesses intrinsic and common pathways (factors XII, XI, IX, VIII).

Human Blood.front: What is hemostasis vs thrombosis?
Human Blood.back: Hemostasis is the physiological process to stop bleeding and maintain blood fluidity; thrombosis is pathological clot formation within intact vessels, which can occlude blood flow.

Human Blood.front: Define anemia and common clinical features.
Human Blood.back: Anemia = decreased hemoglobin concentration and/or RBC mass leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity; features include pallor, fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, tachycardia, sometimes jaundice if hemolytic.

Human Blood.front: Types of anemia by mechanism (brief).
Human Blood.back: Blood loss (acute/chronic), decreased production (iron deficiency, megaloblastic, aplastic), increased destruction/hemolytic (intrinsic RBC defects like hemoglobinopathies, membrane defects, or extrinsic like autoimmune).

Human Blood.front: Iron metabolism key players: transferrin, ferritin, hemosiderin.
Human Blood.back: Dietary iron absorbed in intestine (Fe2+), transported in plasma bound to transferrin, stored intracellularly as ferritin (soluble) and hemosiderin (insoluble, long-term), recycled from macrophages after RBC breakdown.

Human Blood.front: What is microcytic vs macrocytic vs normocytic anemia (MCV ranges approx)?
Human Blood.back: Microcytic anemia: low MCV (<80 fL) — e.g., iron deficiency, thalassemia. Normocytic: normal MCV (80–100 fL) — acute blood loss, hemolysis. Macrocytic: high MCV (>100 fL) — e.g., B12/folate deficiency, alcoholism.

Human Blood.front: What is hemolytic anemia and common causes?
Human Blood.back: Hemolytic anemia results from premature RBC destruction (intravascular or extravascular). Causes include hereditary spherocytosis, sickle cell disease, G6PD deficiency, autoimmune hemolysis, infections.

Human Blood.front: Basics of sickle cell disease pathophysiology.
Human Blood.back: Mutation in β-globin (Glu→Val) leads to HbS polymerization on deoxygenation, causing RBC sickling, hemolysis, vaso-occlusive crises and multi-organ complications.

Human Blood.front: What is G6PD deficiency and typical trigger events?
Human Blood.back: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency leads to reduced NADPH in RBCs, making them vulnerable to oxidative stress; triggers include fava beans, certain drugs (primaquine, sulfonamides), infections causing hemolysis and bite cells/Heinz bodies.

Human Blood.front: What is thalassemia (very brief)?
Human Blood.back: Inherited defects in globin chain synthesis (α or β) leading to imbalanced globin production, microcytic anemia and variable severity from trait to major requiring transfusions.

Human Blood.front: Polycythemia (erythrocytosis) — primary vs secondary causes.
Human Blood.back: Primary (polycythemia vera): myeloproliferative disorder with increased RBC mass. Secondary: increased EPO (chronic hypoxia, high altitude, EPO-secreting tumors).

Human Blood.front: What is leukopenia vs leukocytosis? Clinical significance.
Human Blood.back: Leukopenia = low WBC count (risk of infections; seen in bone marrow failure, some viral infections). Leukocytosis = high WBC count (often infection, inflammation, leukemia).

Human Blood.front: Describe leukemia in brief.
Human Blood.back: Leukemia = malignant proliferation of hematopoietic cells (myeloid or lymphoid lineages) leading to high abnormal WBC counts, marrow failure, infections, bleeding and organ infiltration.

Human Blood.front: What is thrombocytopenia and common clinical sign?
Human Blood.back: Thrombocytopenia = low platelet count leading to increased bleeding tendency, petechiae, mucosal bleeding; causes include ITP, marrow suppression, DIC, drugs.

Human Blood.front: What is disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)?
Human Blood.back: DIC is widespread activation of coagulation causing microthrombi and consumption of clotting factors/platelets leading to bleeding; triggered by sepsis, obstetric complications, malignancy, severe trauma.

Human Blood.front: What is hemophilia A and B (brief) and inheritance?
Human Blood.back: Hemophilia A = factor VIII deficiency; Hemophilia B (Christmas disease) = factor IX deficiency. Both are X-linked recessive disorders causing prolonged bleeding, hemarthroses; hemophilia A more common.

Human Blood.front: What is the Coombs (direct and indirect) test used for?
Human Blood.back: Direct Coombs (direct antiglobulin test) detects antibodies/complement bound to patient's RBCs (autoimmune hemolysis, transfusion reactions). Indirect Coombs detects free antibodies in serum against RBC antigens (used in prenatal testing and crossmatch).

Human Blood.front: ABO blood group basics and antigen/antibody pattern.
Human Blood.back: ABO antigens on RBC surface: Type A = A antigen (anti-B antibodies in plasma), Type B = B antigen (anti-A), Type AB = both antigens (no anti-A/B antibodies) — universal recipient, Type O = no antigens (both anti-A and anti-B antibodies) — universal donor for RBCs.

Human Blood.front: What is Rh (D) factor and clinical importance?
Human Blood.back: Rh (D) antigen is a highly immunogenic RBC antigen. Rh-negative individuals can form anti-D antibodies after exposure to Rh-positive blood; maternal anti-D can cause hemolytic disease of the newborn in subsequent pregnancies (preventable with anti-D immunoglobulin).

Human Blood.front: Basics of transfusion compatibility for ABO & Rh.
Human Blood.back: Match donor RBC antigens to recipient plasma antibodies: e.g., type O blood lacks antigens and is safe for RBC transfusion to many recipients (but plasma contains anti-A/B). Rh negative should receive Rh-negative RBCs to avoid sensitization.

Human Blood.front: What is crossmatch and why done?
Human Blood.back: Crossmatch tests compatibility between donor RBCs and recipient serum to detect clinically significant antibodies and prevent transfusion reactions; includes immediate spinning and antiglobulin phases as needed.

Human Blood.front: Common blood tests included in a CBC (complete blood count).
Human Blood.back: Hemoglobin (Hb), Hematocrit (Hct/PCV), RBC count, WBC count with differential, Platelet count, Red cell indices (MCV, MCH, MCHC), Reticulocyte count often reported separately.

Human Blood.front: Define MCV, MCH, MCHC and their clinical use.
Human Blood.back: MCV (mean corpuscular volume) = average RBC volume (fL) — micro/macrocytic. MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) = average Hb per RBC (pg). MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) = Hb concentration in RBCs (g/dL) — hypochromic if low.

Human Blood.front: Common laboratory markers in hemolysis.
Human Blood.back: Elevated unconjugated bilirubin, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), low haptoglobin, increased reticulocyte count, hemoglobinuria/hemosiderin in urine in severe intravascular hemolysis.

Human Blood.front: What is ESR and what does it indicate?
Human Blood.back: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) measures the rate at which RBCs settle in an hour — nonspecific marker of inflammation (elevated in infections, autoimmune disease, malignancy). Normal ranges vary by age/sex (approx males 0–15 mm/hr, females 0–20 mm/hr).

Human Blood.front: What is CRP and why is it used vs ESR?
Human Blood.back: C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute-phase protein that rises quickly in inflammation or infection — more sensitive/rapid than ESR for acute changes and used to monitor response to therapy.

Human Blood.front: What is blood banking basic storage times?
Human Blood.back: RBC units stored refrigerated (typically up to 35–42 days depending on preservative), platelets stored at room temperature with agitation (~5–7 days), plasma frozen (FFP) stored longer; exact times vary by local protocols — check local guidelines for exams requiring specifics.

Human Blood.front: What are blood components commonly transfused?
Human Blood.back: Packed red blood cells (PRBCs), Platelet concentrates, Fresh frozen plasma (FFP), Cryoprecipitate (rich in fibrinogen, factor VIII, vWF), Whole blood (rarely used).

Human Blood.front: What is the basic approach to diagnosing anemia in an exam question?
Human Blood.back: 1) Check Hb/Hct and RBC indices (MCV). 2) Classify as microcytic/normocytic/macrocytic. 3) Use reticulocyte count (high → hemolysis/bleeding; low → underproduction). 4) Use iron studies, peripheral smear, B12/folate, hemolysis markers as next steps.

Human Blood.front: Exam mnemonic: Causes of microcytic anemia (TICS).
Human Blood.back: TICS: Thalassemia, Iron deficiency, Chronic disease (sometimes microcytic), Sideroblastic anemia — helps recall microcytic causes.

Human Blood.front: Quick exam fact: Which WBC increases in acute bacterial infection?
Human Blood.back: Neutrophils (neutrophilic leukocytosis) increase in acute bacterial infections; left shift (increase in bands) indicates severe/active response.

Human Blood.front: Quick exam fact: Which WBC increases in viral infections?
Human Blood.back: Lymphocytes (lymphocytosis) often increase in viral infections (e.g., mononucleosis, viral hepatitis); atypical lymphocytes may be seen in EBV infection.

Human Blood.front: Short summary: How the body responds to acute blood loss (first 24–48 hrs).
Human Blood.back: Immediate hemodynamic compensation (vasoconstriction), redistribution of fluids, increased heart rate; over hours to days, bone marrow increases reticulocyte production (reticulocytosis) to restore RBC mass.

Human Blood.front: What are common exam 'trap' points about blood?
Human Blood.back: 1) Serum vs plasma difference (clotting factors present in plasma). 2) O vs AB donor/recipient roles differ for RBCs vs plasma (O is universal RBC donor, AB is universal plasma donor). 3) Rh sensitization affects subsequent pregnancies (not first usually).

Human Blood.front: What is a peripheral blood smear and what information does it give?
Human Blood.back: Microscopic examination of stained blood film reveals RBC size/shape (anisocytosis, poikilocytosis), presence of RBC inclusions (Heinz bodies), white cell morphology (blasts), platelet appearance — important in diagnosing anemias, infections, leukemias.

Human Blood.front: Final quick revision lines: Key points to remember about human blood (bullet list).
Human Blood.back: Blood = plasma + formed elements; RBCs carry O₂ via hemoglobin; WBCs defend; platelets & clotting factors stop bleeding; coagulation cascade has intrinsic & extrinsic pathways; ABO & Rh systems crucial for transfusions; CBC + indices guide anemia classification.

System of the Human Body.front: What is an organ system?
System of the Human Body.back: An organ system is a group of organs that work together to perform complex functions for the body (e.g., circulatory system transports blood).

System of the Human Body.front: List the major organ systems of the human body (concise).
System of the Human Body.back: Integumentary, Skeletal, Muscular, Nervous, Endocrine, Cardiovascular (Circulatory), Lymphatic & Immune, Respiratory, Digestive, Urinary (Excretory), Reproductive, Sensory (special senses).

System of the Human Body.front: Integumentary system — main components and functions.
System of the Human Body.back: Skin, hair, nails, sweat and sebaceous glands. Functions: protection, thermoregulation, sensation, vitamin D synthesis, barrier to pathogens and water loss.

System of the Human Body.front: Layers of the skin and key features.
System of the Human Body.back: Epidermis (keratinized stratified squamous epithelium; contains melanocytes), Dermis (vascular, nerves, glands; collagen & elastin), Hypodermis/subcutaneous (fatty connective tissue for insulation & energy).

System of the Human Body.front: What is keratinization and where does it occur?
System of the Human Body.back: Keratinization = progressive accumulation of keratin in epidermal cells leading to tough outer layer; occurs in stratified squamous epidermis (stratum corneum).

System of the Human Body.front: Skeletal system — functions (short list).
System of the Human Body.back: Support & shape, protection of organs, movement (with muscles), mineral storage (calcium, phosphate), blood cell production (red bone marrow), metabolic reservoir.

System of the Human Body.front: Types of bones by shape with quick examples.
System of the Human Body.back: Long (femur), Short (carpal bones), Flat (sternum), Irregular (vertebrae), Sesamoid (patella).

System of the Human Body.front: Basic structure of a long bone (key parts).
System of the Human Body.back: Diaphysis (shaft with compact bone), Epiphyses (ends with spongy bone & articular cartilage), Metaphysis (growth plate area in kids), Medullary cavity (marrow), Periosteum (outer connective tissue).

System of the Human Body.front: What is bone remodeling and key cells involved?
System of the Human Body.back: Continuous process of bone resorption and formation. Osteoclasts resorb bone; osteoblasts form new bone; osteocytes maintain bone matrix.

System of the Human Body.front: What are joints and their major functional types?
System of the Human Body.back: Points where bones meet. Functional types: Synarthrosis (immovable), Amphiarthrosis (slightly movable), Diarthrosis (freely movable — synovial joints).

System of the Human Body.front: Synovial joint key features (quick).
System of the Human Body.back: Articular cartilage, synovial cavity filled with fluid, synovial membrane, joint capsule and ligaments; allows wide range of motion.

System of the Human Body.front: Muscular system — main roles.
System of the Human Body.back: Movement, posture maintenance, heat production (shivering thermogenesis), joint stabilization, circulation assistance (venous return).

System of the Human Body.front: Three muscle types and a one-line distinguishing feature.
System of the Human Body.back: Skeletal — voluntary, striated, multinucleated; Cardiac — involuntary, striated, intercalated discs; Smooth — involuntary, non-striated, spindle-shaped.

System of the Human Body.front: Sliding filament model — the basic mechanism of muscle contraction.
System of the Human Body.back: Myosin heads bind actin, pivot (power stroke) using ATP, pulling actin filaments toward the M-line; Ca2+ and troponin–tropomyosin regulate cross-bridge formation.

System of the Human Body.front: Nervous system — major divisions and quick functions.
System of the Human Body.back: Central Nervous System (CNS: brain & spinal cord) processes information. Peripheral Nervous System (PNS: cranial & spinal nerves) transmits signals to/from body. Autonomic nervous system controls involuntary functions.

System of the Human Body.front: Autonomic nervous system — sympathetic vs parasympathetic (one-line).
System of the Human Body.back: Sympathetic: 'fight or flight' — increases heart rate, dilates pupils, bronchodilation. Parasympathetic: 'rest and digest' — decreases heart rate, stimulates digestion, constricts pupils.

System of the Human Body.front: Neuron structure and function of main parts.
System of the Human Body.back: Dendrites receive input, soma integrates signals, axon conducts action potentials, axon terminals release neurotransmitters at synapses.

System of the Human Body.front: What is myelin and its functional importance?
System of the Human Body.back: Lipid-rich insulating sheath around axons (Schwann cells in PNS, oligodendrocytes in CNS) that increases conduction velocity via saltatory conduction at nodes of Ranvier.

System of the Human Body.front: Briefly describe how an action potential is generated (key ions).
System of the Human Body.back: Depolarization: Na⁺ influx via voltage-gated channels; repolarization: K⁺ efflux; refractory periods prevent back-propagation; resting potential maintained by Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase.

System of the Human Body.front: Endocrine system — general role.
System of the Human Body.back: Glands secrete hormones into bloodstream to regulate growth, metabolism, reproduction, stress response and homeostasis (slower but longer-lasting than neural signals).

System of the Human Body.front: Name major endocrine glands and one key hormone each.
System of the Human Body.back: Hypothalamus (releasing hormones), Pituitary (GH, TSH, ACTH), Thyroid (T3/T4), Parathyroid (PTH), Adrenal cortex (cortisol), Adrenal medulla (epinephrine), Pancreas (insulin/glucagon), Gonads (estrogen/testosterone).

System of the Human Body.front: Hypothalamic–pituitary axis (basic idea).
System of the Human Body.back: Hypothalamus secretes releasing/inhibiting hormones that regulate anterior pituitary which releases trophic hormones controlling peripheral endocrine glands (e.g., TRH → TSH → thyroid → T3/T4).

System of the Human Body.front: Cardiovascular system — main components and primary functions.
System of the Human Body.back: Heart (pump), blood vessels (arteries, veins, capillaries), blood (transport medium). Functions: transport O₂/CO₂, nutrients, hormones; thermoregulation; immune cell transport; waste removal.

System of the Human Body.front: Path of blood flow through the heart (concise).
System of the Human Body.back: Body → vena cavae → right atrium → tricuspid valve → right ventricle → pulmonary valve → pulmonary arteries → lungs → pulmonary veins → left atrium → mitral (bicuspid) valve → left ventricle → aortic valve → aorta → body.

System of the Human Body.front: Cardiac cycle phases (basic).
System of the Human Body.back: Systole (ventricular contraction — ejects blood) and Diastole (ventricular relaxation — chambers fill). Heart sounds: S1 (AV valves close), S2 (semilunar valves close).

System of the Human Body.front: Normal resting adult vital ranges: heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure, temperature.
System of the Human Body.back: Heart rate: 60–100 bpm; Respiratory rate: 12–20 breaths/min; Blood pressure (normal): ~120/80 mmHg; Body temperature ≈ 37°C (98.6°F). (Exam-friendly approximate values.)

System of the Human Body.front: What are arteries, veins and capillaries (structural differences)?
System of the Human Body.back: Arteries: thick muscular walls, high pressure, carry blood away from heart. Veins: thinner walls, valves to prevent backflow, carry blood to heart. Capillaries: single endothelial layer for exchange.

System of the Human Body.front: What determines blood pressure and short-term regulators?
System of the Human Body.back: BP determined by cardiac output × systemic vascular resistance. Short-term regulation: baroreceptor reflex (autonomic), chemoreceptors, circulating catecholamines.

System of the Human Body.front: Lymphatic & immune system — key roles.
System of the Human Body.back: Lymphatic vessels return interstitial fluid to bloodstream, transport dietary lipids, and carry immune cells; immune system defends against pathogens via innate and adaptive responses.

System of the Human Body.front: Primary vs secondary lymphoid organs (examples).
System of the Human Body.back: Primary (site of lymphocyte development): bone marrow (B cells), thymus (T cells). Secondary (site of immune activation): lymph nodes, spleen, tonsils, MALT (mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue).

System of the Human Body.front: Respiratory system — main functions and major structures.
System of the Human Body.back: Exchange of O₂ and CO₂, pH regulation and vocalization. Structures: nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli (site of gas exchange).

System of the Human Body.front: Mechanism of breathing (ventilation) — brief.
System of the Human Body.back: Inspiration: diaphragm contracts & external intercostals expand thoracic cavity → intrapulmonary pressure drops → air flows in. Expiration: mostly passive elastic recoil; forced expiration uses abdominal muscles.

System of the Human Body.front: Alveoli structure and importance for gas exchange.
System of the Human Body.back: Alveoli: thin (type I pneumocytes) for gas diffusion, type II pneumocytes secrete surfactant to reduce surface tension and prevent alveolar collapse; large surface area for efficient exchange.

System of the Human Body.front: Quick respiratory fact: what reduces surface tension in alveoli?
System of the Human Body.back: Pulmonary surfactant (produced by type II pneumocytes) reduces surface tension, prevents alveolar collapse and lowers work of breathing.

System of the Human Body.front: Digestive system — main functions and organs (concise).
System of the Human Body.back: Ingestion, digestion (mechanical & chemical), absorption of nutrients, elimination. Organs: mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine (duodenum/jejunum/ileum), large intestine, liver, gallbladder, pancreas.

System of the Human Body.front: Role of accessory digestive organs: liver, pancreas, gallbladder.
System of the Human Body.back: Liver: bile production, metabolism, detoxification, nutrient storage. Pancreas: digestive enzymes & bicarbonate (exocrine), insulin & glucagon (endocrine). Gallbladder: stores & concentrates bile.

System of the Human Body.front: Small intestine — principal site and specialisation for absorption.
System of the Human Body.back: Major site of digestion & nutrient absorption; villi and microvilli (brush border) greatly increase surface area for absorption of amino acids, glucose, fatty acids, vitamins.

System of the Human Body.front: Major digestive enzymes and where they act (brief list).
System of the Human Body.back: Amylase (saliva & pancreas) — starch → maltose; Pepsin (stomach) — protein → peptides; Pancreatic proteases (trypsin, chymotrypsin) — proteins → peptides; Lipase (pancreas) — fats → fatty acids & glycerol; Brush border enzymes (disaccharidases) complete carbohydrate digestion.

System of the Human Body.front: Liver functions important for exams (bullet).
System of the Human Body.back: Metabolism (carbs, lipids, proteins), detoxification, bile production, storage (glycogen, vitamins), synthesis of plasma proteins and clotting factors, conversion of ammonia → urea.

System of the Human Body.front: Urinary system — main functions and components.
System of the Human Body.back: Kidneys (filter blood & produce urine), ureters, urinary bladder, urethra. Functions: waste excretion, fluid & electrolyte balance, acid–base homeostasis, blood pressure regulation (renin), erythropoietin production.

System of the Human Body.front: Functional unit of kidney and its parts.
