System of the Human Body.back: Nephron: Glomerulus (filtration), Bowman’s capsule, proximal tubule (reabsorption), loop of Henle (concentration), distal tubule, collecting duct (aldosterone & ADH act here).

System of the Human Body.front: Brief role of ADH and aldosterone in urine concentration.
System of the Human Body.back: ADH (vasopressin) increases water reabsorption in collecting ducts (via aquaporins) — concentrates urine. Aldosterone increases Na⁺ reabsorption and K⁺ secretion in distal tubule/collecting duct — affects water retention and BP.

System of the Human Body.front: Renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) — short pathway.
System of the Human Body.back: Low renal perfusion → renin released → angiotensinogen → angiotensin I → ACE → angiotensin II → vasoconstriction + aldosterone release → increased Na⁺/water retention → ↑BP.

System of the Human Body.front: Reproductive system — main difference between male and female (overview).
System of the Human Body.back: Male: testes produce sperm & testosterone; male ducts deliver sperm to outside. Female: ovaries produce oocytes & hormones; uterus supports embryo/fetus; monthly cycles (menstrual/ovarian).

System of the Human Body.front: Hormones of female reproductive cycle (key players).
System of the Human Body.back: GnRH (hypothalamus) → FSH & LH (pituitary). Ovarian hormones: estrogen & progesterone regulate follicle development, ovulation and prepare uterine lining; hCG from embryo maintains corpus luteum in early pregnancy.

System of the Human Body.front: Basic fertilization and early embryonic events (quick).
System of the Human Body.back: Fertilization usually in fallopian tube → zygote → cleavage → morula → blastocyst → implantation in uterine lining; placenta forms to support embryo/fetus.

System of the Human Body.front: Special senses — organs and quick functions.
System of the Human Body.back: Vision (eye; retina photoreceptors rods/cones), Hearing & balance (ear; cochlea & vestibular apparatus), Taste (taste buds), Smell (olfactory epithelium), Touch (skin receptors).

System of the Human Body.front: Eye: roles of cornea, lens and retina (one line each).
System of the Human Body.back: Cornea: initial light refraction; Lens: fine focusing via accommodation; Retina: photoreceptors convert light to neural signals for vision.

System of the Human Body.front: Ear: role of cochlea vs vestibular apparatus.
System of the Human Body.back: Cochlea transduces sound into nerve impulses (hearing). Vestibular apparatus (semicircular canals, utricle, saccule) senses balance and linear/rotational acceleration.

System of the Human Body.front: Homeostasis — concise definition and an example.
System of the Human Body.back: Maintenance of stable internal environment (e.g., body temperature, blood glucose). Achieved through feedback mechanisms (negative & positive).

System of the Human Body.front: Negative vs positive feedback (short).
System of the Human Body.back: Negative feedback counteracts change to maintain stability (thermoregulation). Positive feedback amplifies change until an outcome (e.g., oxytocin during childbirth).

System of the Human Body.front: Thermoregulation — how the body loses and conserves heat (brief).
System of the Human Body.back: Heat loss: radiation, conduction, convection, evaporation (sweating). Conservation: vasoconstriction, shivering (skeletal muscle), behavioral changes, brown adipose thermogenesis in infants.

System of the Human Body.front: Fluid compartments: intracellular vs extracellular (approx proportions).
System of the Human Body.back: Total body water ~60% of body weight. Intracellular fluid ~2/3 of body water; Extracellular fluid ~1/3 (plasma ~1/4 of ECF, interstitial fluid ~3/4 of ECF).

System of the Human Body.front: Acid–base balance — basic buffer systems in body.
System of the Human Body.back: Bicarbonate buffer (HCO₃⁻/CO₂) is primary extracellular buffer; proteins and hemoglobin act as buffers; kidneys regulate HCO₃⁻ reabsorption/ secretion; lungs regulate CO₂ elimination.

System of the Human Body.front: Basic immune response steps (innate then adaptive).
System of the Human Body.back: Innate: physical barriers, phagocytes (neutrophils, macrophages), NK cells, complement, inflammation. Adaptive: antigen presentation → activation of T & B cells → specific cellular & humoral immunity; memory cells form.

System of the Human Body.front: Vaccination principle in one line.
System of the Human Body.back: Vaccines expose immune system to antigens (weakened/killed/subunit) to induce adaptive immunity and memory without causing disease, enabling rapid response on future exposure.

System of the Human Body.front: Common physiological reflexes to remember (examples).
System of the Human Body.back: Stretch reflex (knee jerk), Withdrawal reflex (pain), Baroreceptor reflex (blood pressure regulation), Pupillary light reflex (autonomic control).

System of the Human Body.front: Integration between systems: give 3 exam-style examples.
System of the Human Body.back: 1) Respiratory & circulatory: O₂/CO₂ transport. 2) Renal & endocrine: RAAS & BP regulation. 3) Digestive, hepatic & endocrine: nutrient absorption, metabolic conversion & insulin/glucagon control.

System of the Human Body.front: Energy metabolism—role of insulin and glucagon (short).
System of the Human Body.back: Insulin (fed state) promotes glucose uptake & glycogen/fat synthesis. Glucagon (fasting) promotes glycogenolysis & gluconeogenesis to raise blood glucose.

System of the Human Body.front: Basics of stress response (HPA axis) in one line.
System of the Human Body.back: Stress → hypothalamus releases CRH → pituitary releases ACTH → adrenal cortex secretes cortisol (mobilizes energy, suppresses inflammation).

System of the Human Body.front: Aging — major system changes with age (bullet).
System of the Human Body.back: Reduced bone density, muscle mass (sarcopenia), decreased cardiac output, reduced lung elasticity, slower neural conduction, immune senescence (reduced adaptive response), decreased renal function.

System of the Human Body.front: Clinical quick fact: what is shock and main types?
System of the Human Body.back: Shock = inadequate tissue perfusion. Types: hypovolemic (blood loss), cardiogenic (heart failure), distributive (septic, anaphylactic), obstructive (tension pneumothorax, tamponade).

System of the Human Body.front: Homeostatic short answer: how does body respond to hemorrhage acutely?
System of the Human Body.back: Vasoconstriction via sympathetic activation, tachycardia, increased RAAS activation → fluid retention; bone marrow increases erythropoiesis over days (reticulocytosis).

System of the Human Body.front: Quick pharmacology link: which system does atropine affect and how?
System of the Human Body.back: Atropine blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (parasympathetic), causing increased heart rate, decreased secretions, pupil dilation (mydriasis).

System of the Human Body.front: What is the significance of the blood–brain barrier (BBB)?
System of the Human Body.back: Selective barrier formed by tight junctions of brain capillary endothelium that protects CNS from toxins and controls transport; important clinically for drug delivery and infection protection.

System of the Human Body.front: What is maximal oxygen uptake (VO₂ max) significance (one line)?
System of the Human Body.back: VO₂ max measures aerobic fitness — the maximal rate of O₂ consumption during intense exercise; higher values indicate greater cardiorespiratory fitness.

System of the Human Body.front: Quick exam tip: correlate signs to system — cyanosis, jaundice, edema (which systems?).
System of the Human Body.back: Cyanosis → respiratory/circulatory insufficient O₂. Jaundice → hepatic/biliary/hemolytic system. Edema → cardiovascular (heart failure), renal (nephrotic), lymphatic obstruction, or hypoalbuminemia (liver).

System of the Human Body.front: What is physiology vs anatomy (short definitions)?
System of the Human Body.back: Anatomy = structure of body parts; Physiology = function of those parts and how they work together.

System of the Human Body.front: Exam mnemonic: Major functions by system (single-line mnemonic idea).
System of the Human Body.back: SAMPLE: Support (skeletal), Apply movement (muscular), Maintain fluids/gases (cardio/resp), Process food (digestive), Eliminate wastes (urinary) — helps recall core roles.

System of the Human Body.front: How to approach an exam question on integrated physiology (strategy).
System of the Human Body.back: Identify which systems are involved, recall basic mechanisms for each system, trace inputs → processing → outputs, and mention compensatory responses or clinical correlations briefly.

System of the Human Body.front: Final concise recap: What is the best one-line summary for 'System of the Human Body'?
System of the Human Body.back: The human body is an assembly of interdependent organ systems that maintain internal stability and perform specialized functions enabling survival, reproduction and adaptation.

Nutrients.front: What is a nutrient?
Nutrients.back: A substance obtained from food that provides energy, building blocks, or regulatory molecules necessary for growth, repair and maintenance of the body.

Nutrients.front: Differentiate macronutrients and micronutrients (one line).
Nutrients.back: Macronutrients (carbohydrates, proteins, fats, water) are required in large amounts and provide energy or structure; micronutrients (vitamins, minerals) are required in small amounts for regulation and enzymatic functions.

Nutrients.front: What are the three energy-yielding macronutrients and their caloric values per gram?
Nutrients.back:
Carbohydrates = 4 kcal/g
Proteins = 4 kcal/g
Fats = 9 kcal/g
(Alcohol = 7 kcal/g but not a nutrient).

Nutrients.front: Why is water classified as a nutrient?
Nutrients.back: Water is essential for life — solvent for biochemical reactions, medium for transport, temperature regulation, lubrication and as a reactant/product in metabolism.

Nutrients.front: What is a balanced diet (short definition)?
Nutrients.back: A diet that provides appropriate proportions of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, fiber and water to meet energy and nutrient needs for health and activity.

Nutrients.front: Carbohydrates — main functions in the body.
Nutrients.back: Primary energy source for cells (especially brain and RBCs), spare protein from being used for energy, component of nucleic acids & glycoproteins, provide dietary fiber.

Nutrients.front: Types of dietary carbohydrates (major categories).
Nutrients.back: Monosaccharides (glucose, fructose), Disaccharides (sucrose, lactose), Oligosaccharides, Polysaccharides (starch, glycogen), Non-digestible carbohydrates (dietary fiber).

Nutrients.front: What is dietary fiber? Types and benefits.
Nutrients.back: Non-digestible plant carbohydrates: soluble fiber (forms gel, helps lower cholesterol, slows glucose absorption) and insoluble fiber (adds bulk, promotes bowel movements). Benefits: improved gut health, reduced constipation, lower CVD risk.

Nutrients.front: What is glycemic index (GI) in brief?
Nutrients.back: GI ranks carbohydrate-containing foods by how quickly they raise blood glucose compared to a reference (glucose or white bread). Low GI foods produce slower, lower rises in blood glucose.

Nutrients.front: Proteins — major functions in the body.
Nutrients.back: Structural components (muscle, collagen), enzymes, hormones, immune molecules (antibodies), transporters, acid–base balance and can serve as energy source in starvation.

Nutrients.front: What are essential and non-essential amino acids?
Nutrients.back: Essential amino acids cannot be synthesized by the body and must be obtained from diet; non-essential can be synthesized endogenously.

Nutrients.front: What is protein quality? Examples of high-quality proteins.
Nutrients.back: Protein quality refers to amino acid composition and digestibility. High-quality (complete) proteins contain all essential amino acids (e.g., eggs, milk, fish, meat, soy).

Nutrients.front: Define limiting amino acid (short).
Nutrients.back: The essential amino acid present in the lowest proportion relative to requirement in a food protein that limits the body's ability to use other amino acids for protein synthesis.

Nutrients.front: How to complement plant proteins (concept of complementary proteins).
Nutrients.back: Combine plant foods with different limiting amino acids (e.g., rice + dal) so that together they provide all essential amino acids in required proportions.

Nutrients.front: Fats (lipids) — primary functions in the body.
Nutrients.back: Concentrated energy store, structural component of cell membranes, carrier for fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), insulation & protection, precursors for signaling molecules (eicosanoids).

Nutrients.front: Types of dietary fats (brief).
Nutrients.back: Saturated fatty acids, monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA), polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), trans fatty acids. Essential PUFAs include linoleic acid (omega-6) and alpha-linolenic acid (omega-3).

Nutrients.front: What are essential fatty acids and why important?
Nutrients.back: Linoleic acid (omega-6) and alpha-linolenic acid (omega-3) cannot be synthesized by humans; they are necessary for membrane structure, eicosanoid synthesis and neural development.

Nutrients.front: Role of omega-3 fatty acids (one line).
Nutrients.back: Omega-3 PUFAs (e.g., EPA, DHA) support cardiovascular health, reduce inflammation, and are important for brain development (found in fish oils, flaxseed).

Nutrients.front: Trans fats — exam-relevant points.
Nutrients.back: Artificial trans fats (partially hydrogenated oils) increase LDL and lower HDL cholesterol and are associated with higher CVD risk; many countries/regulators restrict their use.

Nutrients.front: What are vitamins (short definition)?
Nutrients.back: Organic micronutrients required in small amounts for enzymatic reactions and physiological regulation; classified as fat-soluble (A, D, E, K) and water-soluble (B-complex, C).

Nutrients.front: Vitamin A — functions and deficiency sign.
Nutrients.back: Functions: vision (component of rhodopsin), epithelial integrity, growth & immune function. Deficiency: night blindness, xerophthalmia, increased infection susceptibility.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin D — key roles and how obtained.
Nutrients.back: Promotes calcium & phosphorus absorption for bone mineralization; synthesized in skin from 7-dehydrocholesterol via UV light and obtained from dietary sources (fish, fortified foods). Deficiency → rickets/osteomalacia.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin E — role and deficiency (short).
Nutrients.back: Antioxidant protecting cell membranes from oxidative damage; deficiency rare but may cause hemolytic anemia and neurologic problems in severe cases.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin K — main function and clinical relevance.
Nutrients.back: Essential for γ-carboxylation of clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and proteins C/S; deficiency can cause bleeding; gut flora produce some vitamin K; newborns may need prophylactic K.

Nutrients.front: Water-soluble vitamins — general features.
Nutrients.back: Include B-complex and vitamin C: generally not stored (except B12), excess excreted in urine, act as coenzymes in metabolism; deficiencies develop relatively quickly with poor intake.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) — function & deficiency disease.
Nutrients.back: Coenzyme in carbohydrate metabolism (TPP). Deficiency causes beriberi (dry — neuropathy; wet — cardiac failure/edema) and Wernicke–Korsakoff in alcoholics.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) — key points.
Nutrients.back: Component of FAD/FMN (redox reactions). Deficiency leads to cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis and seborrheic dermatitis.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin B3 (Niacin) — function and deficiency (pellagra).
Nutrients.back: Precursor of NAD/NADP for redox reactions. Deficiency results in pellagra: dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia (and if untreated, death).

Nutrients.front: Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) — role & deficiency sign.
Nutrients.back: Cofactor in amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. Deficiency may cause microcytic anemia, neuropathy, and dermatitis.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) — sources and deficiency consequences.
Nutrients.back: Found in animal products; essential for DNA synthesis and myelin maintenance. Deficiency → megaloblastic anemia, neurological symptoms; requires intrinsic factor for absorption.

Nutrients.front: Folate (Vitamin B9) — importance in pregnancy.
Nutrients.back: Required for nucleotide synthesis and methylation reactions. Maternal deficiency is associated with neural tube defects; folate supplementation recommended periconceptionally.

Nutrients.front: Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) — functions and deficiency.
Nutrients.back: Antioxidant, required for collagen synthesis and iron absorption. Deficiency causes scurvy: bleeding gums, poor wound healing, petechiae.

Nutrients.front: What are minerals? Briefly define.
Nutrients.back: Inorganic elements required for structural roles (e.g., calcium in bone), cofactors for enzymes, fluid balance and nerve/muscle function. Classified as macro (major) or trace (micro) minerals.

Nutrients.front: Calcium — major functions and deficiency consequences.
Nutrients.back: Bone & tooth mineralization, muscle contraction, nerve transmission, blood clotting. Chronic deficiency contributes to osteopenia/osteoporosis; hypocalcemia causes tetany.

Nutrients.front: Phosphorus — role and dietary sources.
Nutrients.back: Second most abundant mineral; forms bone mineral with Ca²⁺, component of ATP, nucleic acids and cell membranes (phospholipids). Found in dairy, meat, legumes.

Nutrients.front: Iron — function and forms in body.
Nutrients.back: Essential for oxygen transport (hemoglobin), storage (ferritin), and electron transport (cytochromes). Exists as Fe²⁺ (ferrous) and Fe³⁺ (ferric); absorbed better as Fe²⁺.

Nutrients.front: Iron deficiency — signs and groups at risk.
Nutrients.back: Microcytic, hypochromic anemia causing fatigue, pallor, koilonychia; high-risk groups: infants, young children, pregnant women, heavy menstrual bleeding.

Nutrients.front: Iodine — role and deficiency effect.
Nutrients.back: Required for thyroid hormone synthesis (T3/T4). Deficiency causes goiter and hypothyroidism; in pregnancy can cause cretinism and developmental delay in offspring. Iodized salt prevents deficiency.

Nutrients.front: Zinc — functions and deficiency manifestations.
Nutrients.back: Cofactor for many enzymes, important for growth, wound healing, immune function and taste. Deficiency → growth retardation, delayed wound healing, impaired immunity, loss of appetite.

Nutrients.front: Sodium & potassium — roles in fluid balance and nerve function.
Nutrients.back: Na⁺ major extracellular cation important for fluid balance and membrane potential. K⁺ major intracellular cation critical for resting membrane potential and muscle/nerve function.

Nutrients.front: Fluoride — role and source (short).
Nutrients.back: Important for dental enamel strength and caries prevention; commonly added to water or dental products.

Nutrients.front: Antioxidant nutrients — examples and purpose.
Nutrients.back: Vitamins A (beta-carotene), C and E, selenium and some phytochemicals act to neutralize free radicals and protect cells from oxidative damage.

Nutrients.front: What is malnutrition (simple definition)?
Nutrients.back: Abnormal physiological condition resulting from deficiency, excess or imbalance of nutrients; includes undernutrition (wasting, stunting, micronutrient deficiencies) and overnutrition (overweight/obesity).

Nutrients.front: Define PEM; differentiate marasmus and kwashiorkor.
Nutrients.back: Protein–energy malnutrition (PEM) is due to inadequate energy and/or protein. Marasmus: energy deficiency → severe wasting. Kwashiorkor: protein deficiency with edema, fatty liver, skin changes.

Nutrients.front: How is nutritional status commonly assessed (four domains)?
Nutrients.back: Anthropometry (height, weight, BMI, MUAC), Biochemical tests (hemoglobin, serum proteins, micronutrients), Clinical signs (hair, nails, mucosa), Dietary assessment (recall, food frequency).

Nutrients.front: What is BMI? Formula and classification (general).
Nutrients.back:
Body Mass Index = weight (kg) / height (m)^2.
Categories (general): <18.5 underweight; 18.5–24.9 normal; 25–29.9 overweight; ≥30 obese.

Nutrients.front: Basal metabolic rate (BMR) — what is it and factors affecting it?
Nutrients.back: BMR is the energy expended at rest to maintain basic physiological functions. Influenced by age, sex, body composition (muscle increases BMR), thyroid hormones, climate and genetics.

Nutrients.front: Energy balance concept (short).
Nutrients.back: Energy intake (food) vs energy expenditure (BMR + physical activity + thermic effect) — positive balance → weight gain; negative balance → weight loss.

Nutrients.front: Why are micronutrients important despite small quantities?
Nutrients.back: They act as cofactors, coenzymes and structural components essential for metabolic reactions, growth, immune function and prevention of deficiency diseases.

Nutrients.front: Fortification vs enrichment — quick difference.
Nutrients.back: Fortification: adding nutrients not originally present (e.g., iodized salt). Enrichment: restoring nutrients lost during processing (e.g., adding B vitamins back to flour).

Nutrients.front: Why are pregnant women given iron and folic acid supplementation?
Nutrients.back: To prevent maternal anemia and reduce risk of neural tube defects (folic acid) and support increased maternal and fetal blood volume & growth (iron).

Nutrients.front: What is 'hidden hunger' in nutrition terms?
Nutrients.back: Micronutrient deficiencies (vitamins/minerals) that occur even when calorie intake may be adequate, leading to health and developmental problems.

Nutrients.front: Common deficiency diseases: name the vitamin/mineral and classic disease (short list).
Nutrients.back: Vitamin C → scurvy; Vitamin D → rickets/osteomalacia; Vitamin A → night blindness/xerophthalmia; Thiamine → beriberi; Niacin → pellagra; Iodine → goiter; Iron → microcytic anemia; B12 → megaloblastic anemia & neurologic signs.

Nutrients.front: What is dietary diversification and why is it recommended?
Nutrients.back: Eating a variety of foods across food groups to ensure intake of required macro- and micronutrients and reduce risk of deficiencies.

Nutrients.front: Role of diet in prevention of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) — key points.
Nutrients.back: Balanced diet, limited saturated/trans fats, adequate fiber, reduced salt and sugar intake, adequate fruits & vegetables reduce risk of CVD, diabetes, hypertension and some cancers.

Nutrients.front: What is the purpose of nutrition labeling on packaged foods?
Nutrients.back: To inform consumers about energy, macronutrient composition and key micronutrients so they can make informed dietary choices and manage intake of calories, fats, sugars and salt.

Nutrients.front: How does alcohol affect nutrient status?
Nutrients.back: Alcohol provides calories but little nutrition, can interfere with absorption and metabolism of nutrients (e.g., thiamine), and in excess contributes to liver disease and malnutrition.

Nutrients.front: What are probiotics and prebiotics (short definitions)?
Nutrients.back: Probiotics: live beneficial microbes that confer health benefits (e.g., Lactobacillus). Prebiotics: nondigestible food components (e.g., inulin) that stimulate growth/activity of beneficial gut bacteria.

Nutrients.front: What is nutritional epidemiology — one-line purpose?
Nutrients.back: Study of relationships between diet, health and disease patterns in populations to inform public health nutrition policies and interventions.

Nutrients.front: Briefly: Healthy eating plate principles (core ideas).
Nutrients.back: Emphasize vegetables & fruits, whole grains, healthy protein sources (legumes, fish), healthy fats in moderation, limit processed foods, and hydrate with water.

Nutrients.front: What are complementary feeding recommendations (general idea for infants)?
Nutrients.back: Introduce safe, nutritious complementary foods around 6 months while continuing breastfeeding; ensure nutrient-dense foods to meet increasing iron and energy needs.

Nutrients.front: Why is exclusive breastfeeding recommended for the first 6 months?
Nutrients.back: Breast milk provides complete nutrition, immune protection and reduces risk of infections; supports optimal growth and development in first 6 months.

Nutrients.front: Short note: Role of nutrition in immunity.
Nutrients.back: Adequate macro- & micronutrients (protein, vitamins A/C/D/E, zinc, iron) are essential for immune cell production & function; malnutrition impairs host defenses and increases infection risk.

Nutrients.front: What is refeeding syndrome (brief)?
Nutrients.back: Metabolic disturbances (hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) that can occur when severely malnourished patients receive rapid nutritional rehabilitation; requires careful monitoring.

Nutrients.front: Nutritional intervention levels (population to individual) — examples.
Nutrients.back: Population-level: food fortification, public health campaigns. Community-level: supplementation programs (vitamin A, iron). Individual-level: dietary counseling, therapeutic feeding for malnourished patients.

Nutrients.front: Exam tip: Distinguish between deficiency signs of vitamin A, D and C quickly.
Nutrients.back: Vitamin A → night blindness/xerophthalmia; Vitamin D → rickets/osteomalacia (bone deformities); Vitamin C → scurvy (bleeding gums, poor wound healing).

Nutrients.front: What is the role of dietary calcium and vitamin D together?
Nutrients.back: Calcium provides mineral for bone, vitamin D enhances intestinal calcium absorption — both are essential to maintain bone health and prevent rickets/osteoporosis.

Nutrients.front: How is iron absorption enhanced or inhibited?
Nutrients.back: Enhanced by vitamin C (reduces ferric → ferrous), heme iron (meat sources) is better absorbed. Inhibited by phytates (legumes), polyphenols (tea/coffee), calcium and some medications.

Nutrients.front: Short summary: Key steps to manage iron deficiency anemia (practical).
Nutrients.back: Confirm diagnosis (CBC, indices), identify cause, iron supplementation (oral ferrous salts), improve dietary iron & vitamin C intake, treat underlying bleeding sources, monitor response (reticulocytes increase then Hb).

Nutrients.front: Final quick revision lines: Nutriton essentials (3–4 bullets).
Nutrients.back: 1) Eat a variety of foods for macro- & micronutrients. 2) Maintain energy balance to manage weight. 3) Ensure sufficient protein and key micronutrients in vulnerable groups (children, pregnant women). 4) Fortification and supplementation target common deficiencies.

Human Diseases.front: What is a disease?
Human Diseases.back: A disease is a deviation from normal structure or function of body organs/systems that produces specific signs and symptoms and impairs normal functioning.

Human Diseases.front: Differentiate acute, chronic and subacute disease (short).
Human Diseases.back: Acute: sudden onset, short duration. Chronic: long-developing and persistent (months–years). Subacute: between acute and chronic in onset/duration.

Human Diseases.front: What are signs vs symptoms?
Human Diseases.back: Signs are objective findings observed by others (fever, rash). Symptoms are subjective complaints reported by the patient (pain, fatigue).

Human Diseases.front: What is etiology and pathogenesis?
Human Diseases.back: Etiology = cause(s) of disease (infectious agents, genetics, environment). Pathogenesis = mechanism of disease development and progression.

Human Diseases.front: Define epidemiology (one line).
Human Diseases.back: Epidemiology is the study of disease frequency, distribution and determinants in populations and the application of this knowledge to control health problems.

Human Diseases.front: What are endemic, epidemic and pandemic?
Human Diseases.back: Endemic: disease constantly present in a population. Epidemic: sudden increase in cases above expected level. Pandemic: epidemic spread across multiple countries/continents.

Human Diseases.front: Modes of transmission of infectious diseases (list).
Human Diseases.back: Direct contact, droplet, airborne, fecal–oral, vector-borne, bloodborne, sexual, vertical (mother-to-child), fomites (contaminated objects).

Human Diseases.front: What is an incubation period?
Human Diseases.back: Time interval between exposure to an infectious agent and appearance of first symptoms.

Human Diseases.front: What is a carrier in infectious disease context?
Human Diseases.back: A person (or animal) who harbors a pathogen without symptoms and can transmit it to others (e.g., Typhoid Mary for Salmonella Typhi).

Human Diseases.front: Basic chain of infection — key components.
Human Diseases.back: Infectious agent → reservoir → portal of exit → mode of transmission → portal of entry → susceptible host. Breaking any link prevents spread.

Human Diseases.front: Standard precautions for infection control (core idea).
Human Diseases.back: Treat all blood/body fluids as potentially infectious — hand hygiene, PPE, safe injection practices, respiratory hygiene, environmental cleaning.

Human Diseases.front: Difference between sterilization and disinfection.
Human Diseases.back: Sterilization: complete elimination of all microorganisms including spores (e.g., autoclave). Disinfection: kills many pathogens but may not eliminate spores (e.g., chemical disinfectants).

Human Diseases.front: What is antimicrobial resistance (AMR)?
Human Diseases.back: AMR is when microbes evolve to survive exposure to drugs that previously killed them; leads to treatment failure and requires stewardship to limit misuse of antibiotics.

Human Diseases.front: Principles of antimicrobial stewardship (short).
Human Diseases.back: Use antibiotics only when needed, choose narrow-spectrum agents when possible, dose and duration appropriately, de-escalate based on culture results, prevent infections (vaccination, hygiene).

Human Diseases.front: What is sepsis? Key clinical concept.
Human Diseases.back: Sepsis = life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection; early recognition and prompt antibiotics + source control are critical.

Human Diseases.front: SIRS vs sepsis (concise).
Human Diseases.back: SIRS = systemic inflammatory response syndrome (non-specific criteria). Sepsis = SIRS-like response specifically due to infection with organ dysfunction.

Human Diseases.front: Basic signs of inflammation (cardinal signs).
Human Diseases.back: Redness (rubor), heat (calor), swelling (tumor), pain (dolor) and loss of function (functio laesa).

Human Diseases.front: Fever — why it occurs and basic management idea.
Human Diseases.back: Fever is an elevation of set-point in hypothalamus due to pyrogens (e.g., cytokines, bacterial products). Manage by treating cause, antipyretics and hydration when needed.

Human Diseases.front: What are zoonoses?
Human Diseases.back: Diseases that transmit from animals to humans (e.g., rabies, leptospirosis, plague, some influenza strains).

Human Diseases.front: Common bacterial infections to remember for exams.
Human Diseases.back: Tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), Typhoid (Salmonella Typhi), Cholera (Vibrio cholerae), Diphtheria (Corynebacterium diphtheriae), Leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae), Tetanus (Clostridium tetani).

Human Diseases.front: Tuberculosis — key exam points.
Human Diseases.back: Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Primary lung infection may be latent. Symptoms: chronic cough, weight loss, fever, night sweats. Diagnosed by chest X-ray, sputum AFB microscopy/GeneXpert; treated with multi-drug therapy (DOTS).

Human Diseases.front: What is DOTS (short exam fact)?
Human Diseases.back: Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course — TB control strategy to ensure adherence to anti-TB therapy and prevent resistance.

Human Diseases.front: Typhoid fever — transmission and prevention.
Human Diseases.back: Fecal–oral transmission via contaminated food/water (Salmonella Typhi). Prevent by safe water, sanitation, food hygiene and vaccination where indicated.

Human Diseases.front: Cholera — presentation and immediate management.
Human Diseases.back: Profuse watery diarrhea ('rice-water'), vomiting, rapid dehydration. Immediate management: prompt rehydration (oral rehydration salts or IV fluids), zinc in children, antibiotics in severe cases.

Human Diseases.front: Common vector-borne diseases (key examples).
Human Diseases.back: Malaria (Anopheles mosquitoes), Dengue (Aedes mosquitoes), Chikungunya (Aedes), Kala-azar/Leishmaniasis (sandflies), Japanese encephalitis (Culex), Filariasis (Culex/Anopheles).

Human Diseases.front: Malaria — causative agents and basic prevention.
Human Diseases.back: Plasmodium spp. (P. falciparum, P. vivax etc.) transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. Prevention: vector control (nets, IRS), prompt diagnosis & treatment, chemoprophylaxis in travellers.

Human Diseases.front: Dengue — warning signs and severe disease feature.
Human Diseases.back: Warning: severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, mucosal bleeding, lethargy. Severe dengue includes plasma leakage, hemorrhage and organ impairment leading to shock.

Human Diseases.front: HIV/AIDS — transmission and basic prevention.
Human Diseases.back: Transmitted via sexual contact, blood transfusion, sharing needles, vertical transmission. Prevention: safe sex (condoms), blood screening, needle safety, ART for positives, PMTCT for pregnant women.

Human Diseases.front: Hepatitis — major types and transmission routes (A–E brief).
Human Diseases.back: Hep A & E: fecal–oral (contaminated food/water). Hep B, C, D: bloodborne/sexually transmitted (B & C chronic risk; B preventable by vaccine).

Human Diseases.front: Influenza — why annual vaccination recommended (short).
Human Diseases.back: Because circulating influenza virus strains change (antigenic drift/shift); vaccines are updated yearly to match predicted strains and reduce morbidity/mortality.

Human Diseases.front: COVID-19 — basic transmission and prevention measures.
Human Diseases.back: Respiratory droplet and airborne transmission; prevention: vaccination, masks, hand hygiene, ventilation, testing/isolation of cases and contact tracing in outbreaks.

Human Diseases.front: Common viral exanthems (one-line associations).
Human Diseases.back: Measles (rubeola) — Koplik spots, confluent rash; Rubella — milder rash, congenital rubella risk; Varicella — vesicular 'dew drop on rose' lesions; Scarlet fever (bacterial toxin-mediated) — sandpaper rash.

Human Diseases.front: Measles — classic triad and complication risk.
Human Diseases.back: Fever, cough, coryza + Koplik spots and maculopapular rash. Complications: pneumonia, encephalitis; prevented by MMR vaccination.

Human Diseases.front: What is herd immunity (concise)?
Human Diseases.back: When a sufficient proportion of a population is immune (vaccination or prior infection), spread of contagious disease is reduced protecting susceptible individuals.

Human Diseases.front: Common fungal infections relevant to exams.
Human Diseases.back: Candidiasis (Candida spp.), Dermatophytosis (tinea/ringworm), Aspergillosis (Aspergillus), Cryptococcosis (Cryptococcus in immunocompromised).

Human Diseases.front: What are opportunistic infections? Examples.
Human Diseases.back: Infections by normally non-pathogenic organisms that cause disease when host immunity is compromised (e.g., Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in HIV).

Human Diseases.front: Parasitic infections — frequently tested examples.
Human Diseases.back: Giardiasis (Giardia lamblia), Amoebiasis (Entamoeba histolytica), Ascariasis (Ascaris lumbricoides), Hookworm, Trichuriasis, Schistosomiasis, Malaria, Toxoplasmosis.

Human Diseases.front: Foodborne diseases — common pathogens to remember.
Human Diseases.back: Salmonella, E. coli (enterotoxigenic/EHEC), Staphylococcus aureus (preformed toxin), Clostridium perfringens, Vibrio parahaemolyticus, Norovirus.

Human Diseases.front: Rabies — presentation and post-exposure management.
Human Diseases.back: Fatal encephalitis if untreated: hydrophobia, agitation, paralysis. Post-exposure: wound cleaning, passive immunization (rabies immunoglobulin) + active vaccine series.

Human Diseases.front: Tetanus — cause and prevention (short).
Human Diseases.back: Clostridium tetani produces neurotoxin causing muscular spasms/lockjaw. Prevention by active immunization (toxoid) and wound care; give tetanus immunoglobulin for severe contaminated wounds in non-immune individuals.

Human Diseases.front: Leprosy (Hansen disease) — causative agent and basic types.
Human Diseases.back: Mycobacterium leprae; clinical spectrum from paucibacillary (tuberculoid) with nerve involvement to multibacillary (lepromatous) with widespread lesions. Early diagnosis prevents disability.

Human Diseases.front: What is antimicrobial prophylaxis (short)?
Human Diseases.back: Use of antibiotics or antivirals to prevent infection in high-risk situations (e.g., surgical prophylaxis or post-exposure prophylaxis for certain exposures).

Human Diseases.front: Hospital-acquired infections (HAI) — common examples.
Human Diseases.back: Catheter-associated urinary tract infection, ventilator-associated pneumonia, central-line associated bloodstream infection, surgical site infection, Clostridioides difficile colitis.

Human Diseases.front: What is vaccination schedule importance for public health exams?
Human Diseases.back: Routine immunization schedules (e.g., childhood vaccines) protect individuals and communities; knowledge of key vaccines (BCG, DPT, OPV/IPV, MMR, Hep B, Hib, measles) is frequently tested.

Human Diseases.front: Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) — main categories.
Human Diseases.back: Cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, chronic respiratory diseases, cancers, mental health disorders, chronic kidney disease — major contributors to morbidity and mortality worldwide.

Human Diseases.front: Cardiovascular disease — common modifiable risk factors.
Human Diseases.back: Hypertension, smoking, diabetes, high LDL cholesterol, obesity, physical inactivity, unhealthy diet, excessive alcohol use.

Human Diseases.front: Hypertension — definition (general exam-friendly).
Human Diseases.back: Persistent elevation of arterial blood pressure (commonly defined as ≥140/90 mmHg in some guidelines; check local exam specifics).

Human Diseases.front: Diabetes mellitus — main types and a key difference.
Human Diseases.back: Type 1: autoimmune β-cell destruction → insulin deficiency (often juvenile onset). Type 2: insulin resistance ± relative insulin deficiency (associated with obesity, lifestyle).

Human Diseases.front: Diabetes — classic symptoms to recognize.
Human Diseases.back: Polyuria (excessive urination), polydipsia (excessive thirst), polyphagia (increased hunger), unexplained weight loss, fatigue, blurred vision.

Human Diseases.front: Basic diabetes complications (short list).
Human Diseases.back: Microvascular: retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy. Macrovascular: coronary artery disease, stroke, peripheral vascular disease. Also increased infection risk and poor wound healing.

Human Diseases.front: Cancer — basic hallmarks (simple list).
Human Diseases.back: Uncontrolled proliferation, invasion of surrounding tissue, potential to metastasize, evasion of apoptosis, angiogenesis, genetic mutations driving changes.

Human Diseases.front: Common cancer screening tests (examples).
Human Diseases.back: Pap smear (cervical cancer), mammography (breast cancer), FOBT/colonoscopy (colorectal cancer), PSA (prostate — debated), visual inspection/VIA (cervix in low-resource settings).

Human Diseases.front: What is screening vs diagnostic test (short difference)?
Human Diseases.back: Screening: tests asymptomatic populations to detect disease early. Diagnostic: tests used to confirm disease in symptomatic individuals or after positive screen.

Human Diseases.front: Stroke (CVA) — two main types and immediate management principle.
Human Diseases.back: Ischemic (arterial occlusion) and hemorrhagic (bleeding). Immediate management: rapid recognition (e.g., FAST), urgent medical evaluation; ischemic stroke may be eligible for thrombolysis if early.

Human Diseases.front: COPD vs asthma — key distinguishing features.
Human Diseases.back: Asthma: reversible airway obstruction, often allergic, variable symptoms. COPD: progressive, largely irreversible airflow limitation (chronic bronchitis/emphysema), associated with smoking history.

Human Diseases.front: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) — basic markers and complications.
Human Diseases.back: Reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR) or kidney damage >3 months. Complications: anemia, hypertension, electrolyte imbalances, bone mineral disorders, uremia.

Human Diseases.front: Common psychiatric disorders often tested (very brief).
Human Diseases.back: Depression, anxiety disorders, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, substance use disorders; recognition and referral/management basics are important.

Human Diseases.front: What is antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) and why important?
Human Diseases.back: Laboratory testing to determine which antibiotics effectively inhibit a pathogen; guides targeted therapy and slows resistance development.

Human Diseases.front: Basic lab tests used in infection diagnosis (short list).
Human Diseases.back: Complete blood count (WBC trends), blood cultures, urine culture, Gram stain, rapid antigen tests, serology (antibodies), PCR-based molecular tests.

Human Diseases.front: What is a rapid diagnostic test (RDT) and an example?
Human Diseases.back: Point-of-care tests giving quick results, often antigen-based (e.g., malaria RDT, rapid antigen tests for influenza/COVID-19). Useful for prompt decisions.

Human Diseases.front: What is contact tracing and its role in outbreaks?
Human Diseases.back: Identifying and following people who had contact with an infected person to prevent further transmission by testing, isolation or prophylaxis.

Human Diseases.front: What are social determinants of health (brief)?
Human Diseases.back: Conditions where people are born, grow, live, work and age (education, income, housing, environment) that influence health outcomes and disease risk.

Human Diseases.front: Occupational diseases — examples and prevention principle.
Human Diseases.back: Examples: asbestosis (asbestos), silicosis (silica), occupational asthma, noise-induced hearing loss. Prevention: exposure control, PPE, monitoring and health surveillance.

Human Diseases.front: What is primary, secondary and tertiary prevention (public health)?
Human Diseases.back: Primary: prevent disease occurrence (vaccination, sanitation). Secondary: early detection & treatment (screening). Tertiary: reduce disability & complications (rehabilitation).

Human Diseases.front: What is prophylaxis vs treatment (concise)?
Human Diseases.back: Prophylaxis = preventive intervention (vaccines, chemoprophylaxis). Treatment = interventions to cure or manage established disease.

Human Diseases.front: Basic approach to a febrile patient in exam-style question.
Human Diseases.back: Assess severity (vitals, red flags), exposure/travel history, localizing signs/symptoms, initial labs (CBC, cultures), start empiric therapy if severe; target therapy when cause identified.

Human Diseases.front: Emergency first aid basics for bleeding, burns and fractures (short).
Human Diseases.back: Bleeding: apply direct pressure, elevate, seek help. Burns: cool with water, cover sterile dressing, avoid ice. Fracture: immobilize, splint, avoid moving unless necessary, seek urgent care.

Human Diseases.front: What is antimicrobial prophylaxis in surgery (simple principle)?
Human Diseases.back: Single-dose antibiotic before incision (timed to ensure adequate tissue levels during surgery) to prevent surgical site infections in selected procedures.

Human Diseases.front: Food safety key messages to prevent disease (simple list).
Human Diseases.back: Cook food thoroughly, store at safe temperatures, use safe water, avoid cross-contamination, practice hand hygiene during food prep.

Human Diseases.front: What is vaccine cold chain and why important?
Human Diseases.back: Temperature-controlled supply chain to keep vaccines potent from manufacturer to administration; breaks in cold chain can reduce vaccine effectiveness.

Human Diseases.front: What is antimicrobial prophylaxis for HIV exposure (PEP) and timing relevance?
Human Diseases.back: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is short-term antiretroviral therapy after potential HIV exposure; must be started promptly (within hours ideally) to be effective.

Human Diseases.front: What are eradication vs elimination goals (public health terms)?
Human Diseases.back: Elimination: reduction to zero incidence in a defined area (requires ongoing measures). Eradication: permanent worldwide reduction to zero (no further control measures needed), e.g., smallpox.

Human Diseases.front: What is herd immunity threshold concept (simple)?
Human Diseases.back: Proportion of immune individuals required in a population to interrupt disease transmission; threshold varies by disease contagiousness (R0).

Human Diseases.front: What is post-infectious sequelae (example)?
Human Diseases.back: Complications occurring after apparent recovery from infection (e.g., rheumatic fever after streptococcal pharyngitis, Guillain–Barré after some infections).

Human Diseases.front: What is occupational exposure to bloodborne pathogens and basic protection?
Human Diseases.back: Risk of HIV/HBV/HCV via needle-stick or blood contact; protection: standard precautions, PPE, safe sharps disposal, HBV vaccination for healthcare workers.

Human Diseases.front: What is latent infection vs active infection (short)?
Human Diseases.back: Latent infection: pathogen present but inactive/without clinical disease (can reactivate). Active infection: pathogen replicating and causing clinical disease.

Human Diseases.front: What are common childhood vaccine-preventable diseases to remember?
Human Diseases.back: Measles, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Polio, Hepatitis B, Hib-related meningitis, Rotavirus, Pneumococcal and Meningococcal disease (vaccine lists vary by program).

Human Diseases.front: What is immunization schedule relevance in exams?
Human Diseases.back: Know key vaccine timing (birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 9–12 months etc.) and vaccines given in national programs; specifics may vary by country so follow local syllabus.

Human Diseases.front: What is antimicrobial prophylaxis for rheumatic fever?
Human Diseases.back: Long-term benzathine penicillin prophylaxis in people with prior rheumatic fever to prevent recurrence and rheumatic heart disease (per guidelines).

Human Diseases.front: What is congenital infection? Examples to recall.
Human Diseases.back: Infections transmitted from mother to fetus causing congenital disease: TORCH infections — Toxoplasma, Others (syphilis), Rubella, CMV, Herpes simplex; Zika is also notable.

Human Diseases.front: What is surveillance in public health?
Human Diseases.back: Ongoing systematic collection, analysis and interpretation of health data for planning, implementation and evaluation of public health practice.

Human Diseases.front: What is disability-adjusted life year (DALY) — one-line idea.
Human Diseases.back: DALY measures overall disease burden as years of healthy life lost due to premature mortality and years lived with disability; used to compare impact of diseases.

Human Diseases.front: What are common causes of mortality globally (major categories)?
Human Diseases.back: Non-communicable diseases (CVDs, cancers), communicable diseases (lower respiratory infections), injuries, maternal & perinatal conditions — patterns vary by region.

Human Diseases.front: What is rational use of drugs (short)?
Human Diseases.back: Patients receive medications appropriate to their clinical needs, in doses that meet individual requirements, for an adequate period, and at the lowest cost to them and the community.

Human Diseases.front: What is the role of public health education in disease control?
Human Diseases.back: Informs communities about prevention, symptoms and seeking care, promotes healthy behaviors (handwashing, vaccination, sanitation) and reduces stigma to improve uptake of services.

Human Diseases.front: Key quick revision points to remember for 'Human Diseases' (bullet list).
Human Diseases.back: Understand infectious vs non-infectious causes, modes of transmission, prevention (vaccination, sanitation), common diseases (TB, malaria, diarrheal diseases, HIV), NCD risk factors, basics of diagnosis & treatment, and public health measures (surveillance, outbreak control).

Miscellaneous.front: What is Homeostasis?
Miscellaneous.back: Ability of the body to maintain stable internal environment despite external changes, e.g., body temperature regulation.

Miscellaneous.front: What is Metabolism?
Miscellaneous.back: Sum of all biochemical reactions in the body. Includes catabolism (breakdown) & anabolism (build-up).

Miscellaneous.front: What is Enzyme?
Miscellaneous.back: Biological catalyst made of proteins that speeds up biochemical reactions without being consumed; highly specific.

Miscellaneous.front: What is the pH of human blood?
Name universal blood donor & universal recipient.
Miscellaneous.back: Universal donor: O negative. Universal recipient: AB positive.

Miscellaneous.front: What is the largest organ of the human body?
Miscellaneous.back: Skin (largest external organ); Liver (largest internal organ).

Miscellaneous.front: Which vitamin is synthesized in the skin by sunlight?
What is the normal human body temperature?
What is the smallest cell and largest cell in the human body?
Miscellaneous.back: Smallest: Sperm cell. Largest: Ovum (egg cell).

Miscellaneous.back: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome; caused by HIV.

What is dialysis?
Miscellaneous.back: Artificial removal of waste from blood when kidneys fail.

Which vitamin helps in blood clotting?
Which organ produces bile?
What is gene?
Miscellaneous.back: A unit of heredity controlling traits, made of DNA.

Miscellaneous.front: What is mutation?
Miscellaneous.back: Sudden change in DNA sequence that may cause variation or disease.

Miscellaneous.front: What is biotechnology?
Miscellaneous.back: Use of living organisms for industrial, medical, agricultural applications (e.g., GM crops, insulin production).
